Victoria, B.C. July 18th 1901.

A.W. Vowell, Esq.
Genl. Ind. Agt.
Victoria.

Sir:

I recently paid an official visit to the Schools and Missions of the Presbyterian Church in Canada on the West Coast of Vancouver Island, and was surprised to learn that the Roman Catholic Church contemplates to send a Priest to Ahousaht. While I admire the patience, & perseverance of the pioneer missionaries of that church here and elsewhere, I certainly think that the sending of a Priest to Ahousaht is a work of supererogation. The Presbyterian Church in Canada opened a School and established a mission there years ago, when the place was destitute of any agency for the Improvement of the Indians. An excellent School house and a dwelling house were erected at considerable cost. For years a Teacher was paid by our church, without any assistance from the Government. We pay now the full salary (minus the Government grant of $300.00) of two Teachers a Principal and an assistant. The School, as you know, is a Government School, conducted under Government regulations. It is one of the largest, best disciplined, and most proficient on the west coast, beside there are now peace and harmony among the Indians, who have confidence in our Church and workers there.

In view of these facts, I hereby on behalf of the Synod of the Presbyterian Church in Canada enter my protest against any Priest or any Agent of the Roman Catholic Church going to Ahousaht, and respectfully petition that you will not grant permission to the sending of a Priest or any Agent of that Church there, or sanction anything that may endanger harmony among the Indians, or in any way interfere with our school and work.

Hoping you will give this matter the consideration it deserves.

I remain,

Yours Truly.

(sgd) J. Campbell.

Convr. F.M.Com.
I have the honor to forward herewith for the information of the Department a copy of a letter of yesterday's date today received from the Reverend Dr. Campbell, of the Presbyterian Church, of this city, in which he states that on the occasion of his making an official visit to the missions of the Presbyterian church on the West Coast of Vancouver Island, West Coast Agency, he learned that the Roman Catholic Church authorities contemplate placing a priest at Ahousaht. The doctor does not give the source of his information and I have accordingly sent a copy of his letter to the Right Reverend Bishop Orth of this city for information relative thereto as well as to Mr. Agent Guillo for a report from him into all the particulars of the case. It is curious to note that the Reverend Dr. Campbell protests against the alleged contemplated action of the Roman Catholic Church authorities in this case, in view of what has transpired in connection with

NOTES ON INDIAN WORK? B.C.

1. GEOGRAPHY.

Ucluelet is fifty miles from Alberni.
Dodger's Cove is about twelve miles south of Ucluelet.
Johannit is thirty-eight miles north from Ucluelet.
Nesqually is twenty-seven miles north of Nooksack.
Nootka is sixty-five miles north of Nesqually.
Nuchalatl is twenty-five north of Nootka.
Nuchalatl fishing station is seven miles north east of Nuchalatl across Esperanza Inlet.
Nuchalatl village is seven miles east of the fishing station.
Back to Nootka on the east side of Nootka island from Nuchalatl Village is twenty-five miles.
Nuchalatl Village is seven miles east of Nootka.
Nuchalatl Fishing station is twenty-five miles east of Nootka.

2. MISSIONARY ACTIVITIES.

Bishop Segher and Father Brabant left Victoria on the 15th May 1874, having in that year visited the Indian Bands on the west coast of Vancouver Island and baptised several hundred children. The details of this trip are given by Bishop Segher, and the following are a few extracts from his diary:

May 13th 1874; arrived at 9 A.M. at Ucluelet. Our boat was heard thundering voice, but we were told he did not translate words with much correctness. Perhaps he thought that he had the desired effect. I baptized seventy-five children this afternoon.

April 16th, entered Dodger's Cove at 1 P.M. On this day I wrote: "In this and in every tribe on the coast instructed by stating who we were, what was our object. Then came the story of the creation, the fall of man, the deluge, the languages, the redemption of mankind; after which, the Native baptism was administered to their little ones. If time was left, a few hymns and songs were taught. I also used the teaching of the Sign of the Cross and the making of the sign by the Indians was the great thing and caused real joy. In this camp eighty baptisms of children."

This extract indicates the general mode of procedure employed by the missionary. He returned to Victoria on the 15th May, having completed the visit and baptising between seven and eight hundred children.

It is upon such work the Roman Catholic Church claims to have pre-empted this whole region, and apparently are credited with baptising Indians in Government reports.

MATS TO SCHOOLS.

On page 96 of the same book Father Brabant says: "I discussed with Bishop Segher the idea of a Boarding School for our children. I wrote to the Indian agent who promised that he would see that the support of the teachers and children from the mission funds. Next I was sent for and this same agent urged me to go at once, and said that as soon as the school opened the per capita grant would be available. I was very disappointed by the Agent, and so I returned to Victoria, where I thought that the efforts of the rotester would be more available.

The school was abandoned at that time, but four years later it was revived. He wrote: "I am obliged to write to you for information from Bishop Christie with this regard. I want to consult you about the education of the Indian Children of the Mission, and have obtained..."
it will be given to one of the sects; your children will be perverted and you will lose the fruit of your labors.

On page 38 are the words; 'October—our school is now built' i.e. at Clayoquot.

PER CONTRA:

The Presbyterian Church opened a day School in Ahousaht seven miles from Clayoquot in December 1896. No mission work of any kind had been done there since 1890, until Mr Russell our missionary opened the school. Year after year we made application for a Board Grant until 1900 when it was finally granted.

It was built in 1896 - Boarding School at Ahousaht to forty children. The Government granted £500 towards the building, but not until 1900 was the usual boarding grant given although application was made from year to year.

In the meantime the Roman Catholic Bishop goes to Ottawa with a per capita boarding school grant for fifty children at Clayoquot where they had formerly had no school.

For several years the tribes in Nootka Sound had been begging for a teacher and school. They had sent delegations to Ahousaht, and stating that although a pilot was stationed at Nootka sixty-seven miles south of Nootka, he only visited them once or twice a year and did nothing for them. We sent a delegation under solicitation and sent Mr. Russell of Victoria to visit them in June last. The Indians there urged him to remain and start a school. He returned to Nootka and signed by the second chief and other leading men of the Band. The first Chief and his son, chief alone, refused to sign. They were very displeased.

Mr. Russell accordingly decided to remain, rented a house and opened a school. Probably the Roman Catholics who had formerly been opposed to the Indians opening an opposition day school, opened an opposition day school, probably in Victoria. Mr. Fowl in response to a letter to Mr. Oswald ordering him to close the school, wrote Mr. Oswald thinking it better to keep the school open. Mr. Gillod when asked the reason for the school, said that the Indian Act does not prevent it.

We have interpreted the interpretation of the act in the manner which we thought best after repeated invitations to Mr. Fowl to attend every step on the approval of the act. We have taken in the meantime, but it seems to us that these measures shall prevent us from seeking to do good to these people. There can be no other purpose of any ecclesiastical advantage.

To the Hon. Clifford Sifton,
Supt. General of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir;-

I am instructed by the Foreign Mission Committee of the Presbyterian Church in Canada to make application to the Department of Indian Affairs for the following Grants:

1. DAY SCHOOL GRANT FOR DODGER'S COVE.

In this Band located in Barclay Sound there are two hundred Indians. Our Missionary has labored amongst them for six years, and a Day School was opened in March 1899. There are thirty-two children enrolled and an average attendance of thirteen. The application is for a Day School Grant.

2. BOARDING SCHOOL GRANT FOR AHOUAHT.

There are nearly three hundred Indians in this Band, and there are one hundred and one children under sixteen years of age. A Day School was opened in December 1895. For five years previous no Mission work of any kind had been done in that village. During the last year sixty-eight children received instruction in the School, but fifty-six was the highest number on the roll at one time.

The Day School Grant was given to this school in 1900.

It was thought when the Alberni School was built in 1896 capable of accommodating from forty to fifty children, it would afford sufficient accommodation for the tribes on the Coast. But it is already full and very few of these are from the Coast Tribes. It was found indeed that Alberni is beyond the sphere of the Coast Indians and that they will not send their children so far.
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, 29th November, 1901

The Secretary:

With respect to the application made by Rev. Dr Mackay, Secretary of the Foreign Missionary Committee of the Presbyterian Church in Canada on the 7th instant for grants to certain schools now carried on by them and for the establishment of other schools, I beg to say, regarding the request for a boarding school grant for 50 pupils at Ahousaht in the West coast Agency of Vancouver Island, B.C., that it is for the Department to decide, first, whether another boarding school is necessary in this agency; second, if considered necessary, where it should be located and third, under whose control it should be placed.

There are two boarding schools now in operation in this Agency, one at Alberni conducted by the Presbyterians and the other at Clayoquot carried on by the Roman Catholics, with provision at each school for 50 pupils, which can be increased if occasion arises.

The last census of this agency gives a total of 2479 souls including 723 children under 16 which would make the school population of about 400.

In addition to these two boarding schools there are six day schools situated at the following points:

Ahousaht...Presbyterian
Ucluelet...Roman Catholic
Spitset...Roman Catholic
Actess...known to Dept. as Kyasquet
Nitinah...Methodist
Ohiat...Presbyterian, which receives no grant, and is presumably the Dodger's Cove school for which provision will be made next year.
The day school at Ahousaht where the Presbyterians wish to establish a boarding school is the largest and best attended of any in the Agency, nearly all the children of school age (about 60) are enrolled at this school and are fairly regular in their attendance, the average for last year being 40. The Indians of this reserve do not take their wives and families with them when they go salmon fishing, sealing or hop picking as almost all the other Indians on the West Coast do, which accounts for their progress and regularity. While a boarding school would ensure constant attendance and quicker progress it is a question whether what they can acquire at the day school will not be sufficient for their future needs. It is well "not to forget wisdom in teaching knowledge".

This reserve is small and the children as they grow up will have to live as their parents do now by sealing, fishing and native industries, and it seems to me that they will be better fitted to follow these pursuits, which are taught them by their parents while they are young, than after several years residence in a boarding school. Of course there will always be orphan, neglected and infirm children requiring the care and attention afforded by a boarding school, but their number will be small and they can be provided for at existing institutions.

The West Coast Indians are said to be industrious and fond of earning money and were it not for the competition of Chinamen and Japs in the canneries, they would be well off; as it is they are independent and provide for their own wants and the feeling of dependence and unreliance that life in a boarding school engenders, would be a set-back to the
civilization they are working out for themselves through necessity.

2. Although the Presbyterians are in a small majority at Ahousaht the census returns show that all the Indians on the surrounding reserves and to the north are either Roman Catholics or pagans. The Roman Catholic boarding school at Clayoquot draws its pupils chiefly from the section of country in which the Presbyterians wish to locate their boarding school, while the Methodists claim nearly all the Indians about Nitinaht (south-east of Barclay Sound) and would certainly object to any recruiting being done in their mission field. The last census credits the Presbyterians with only 375 adherents out of a total population of 2480 in this Agency, while the Roman Catholics have 961 and the Methodists 178 and the remaining 966 are given as pagans, who offer a field for missionary work for any religious body desiring to enter it, but they should do so at their own expense as the Department should not be expected to pay for making converts to any particular creed.

I do not see, therefore, that the Presbyterians have any strong claim to Government support for another boarding school at Ahousaht or elsewhere in the West Coast Agency at present.

3. In my memorandum of the 26th instant I referred to the trouble the Department has to contend with on account of disputes between opposite religious denominations in their endeavors to obtain Government support for their schools. When preparing the memorandum referred to I had not the "Notes re Indian Work B.C." submitted by Dr Mackay before me, but after reading these notes I am more than ever
convinced that whatever concessions are made to the one will be demanded by the other.

I may remind you that the School Vote for the current year is over $400,000.00 and the increases asked for that have so far come under my notice, will, if granted, require a vote of nearly half a million for next year, which is a pretty heavy outlay for the results obtained and I am inclined to think that if the greater part of this money, which is paid over to missionary societies for education, had been expended by the Department under an improved system, Indian civilization would have advanced more rapidly.

Martin Browne

To the Hon. Clifford Sifton,
Supt. General of Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir;-

I am instructed by the Foreign Mission Committee of the Presbyterian church in Canada to make application to the Department of Indian Affairs for the following grants:

1. DAY SCHOOL GRANT FOR DOUGLAS COWE.

In this Band located in Barclay Sound there are two hundred Indians. Our missionary has labored amongst them for six years, and Day School was opened in March 1899. There are thirty-two children enrolled and an average attendance of thirteen. The application is for a Day School Grant.

2. BOARDING SCHOOL GRANT FOR NICHOLSON.

There are nearly three hundred Indians in this Band, and there are one hundred and one children under sixteen years of age. A Day School was opened in December 1895. For five years previous no mission work of any kind had been done in the village. During the last year sixty-eight children received instruction in the school, but fifty-six was the highest number on the roll at one time.

The Day School Grant was given to this School in 1900. It was thought when the Iberni School was built in 1896 capable of accommodating from forty to fifty children, it would afford sufficient accommodation for the Tribes on the Coast. But it is already full, and very few of these are from the Coast tribes. It was found indeed that Iberni is beyond the sphere of the Coast Indians, and that they will not send their children so far.

It is accordingly deemed necessary in order to keep these children in regular attendance and give them the best possible advantages, that a Boarding School be erected at Ahousat. With that object in view application is now made for a Boarding School Grant for fifty children.

3. SHOAL LAKE BOARDING SCHOOL.

This is a new school, and the main building is about completed, and has cost us so far $300.00. There will be added next summer an addition for kitchen etc., the whole being planned to accommodate forty children.

There are about four hundred and fifty Indians on the South and West of this Lake for which no provision is made.

This application has been presented to the Hon. Commissioner Laird, and he has notified us that he has placed in the estimates $2160.00 for this school, being the usual boarding school grant for thirty pupils at $72.00 per pupil, and one hundred and fifty-five for purchase of water.

4. CROSSROAD WATER SUPPLY.

This matter was already before the Department this year. Water has hitherto been drawn from the Assiniboine River from a point about one-half a mile away, and up a steep grade. Not only is the labor great, but the quality is at certain seasons not good. There is besides no proper protection against fire.

According to request Mr. Gilmour sent measurements to the Hon. Commissioner Laird. The lateral distance from the river he reports to be eight-hundred yards, and the elevation one hundred and thirty feet.

The Commissioner thinking that very strong power would be required to raise water such a height, and also that eighty hundred...
yards of piping would be expensive; deems it better to try and get water by boring. He accordingly informs us that he has placed in the estimates $750.00 for that purpose.

Trusting these applications will receive favorable consideration,

I am

Yours faithfully,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, 11th November, 1901

Memo. re applications for grants to Presbyterian schools in British Columbia and the North-West made by Rev. Dr Mackay, contained in his letter of the 7th instant.

The undersigned begs to say first with respect to the application for a day school at Dodger's Cove that this matter was previously brought to the attention of the Department by Rev. Dr Moore on behalf of Dr Mackay in May last, who was then informed that the Department did not know the locality called Dodger's Cove or whether the Presbyterians had a school there or not. In dealing with applications for the establishment of schools by religious bodies the Department is obliged to have recourse to its own census returns to show how many Indians belong to the particular body making application. The last return shows that the Presbyterians have adherents in the West Coast Agency of Vancouver Island, the Methodists 216, Roman Catholics 269, the remaining 319 being pagans. The largest Presbyterian population is at Ahousaht where there are 80, as against 75 Roman Catholics and 11 pagans.

The Roman Catholics protested against the Presbyterians carrying on missionary work at Nootka which is in this neighborhood and the Rev. Mr Oswald, the Presbyterian missionary who contemplated establishing a mission in that locality is reported to have discontinued his work and returned to Victoria. A very lengthy protest has been received from Rev.
Mr Swartout, Presbyterian missionary at Ucluelet, against the Roman Catholic bishop and Mr Supt Vowell in, as he says, forcing Mr Oswald to retire. This letter was only received today, and was sent direct to the Department.

The Presbyterians have a boarding school at Alberni and the Roman Catholics have a similar one at Clayoquot. This about evens matters in this locality. If a further grant is made to a Presbyterian boarding school at Ahousaht, the Roman Catholics will no doubt consider themselves ill-used.

With regard to the Shoal Lake boarding school I may say that this matter has already been before the Supt. General and is being dealt with by him.

Referring to the water supply for the Crowstand boarding school, I beg to say that the Indian Commissioner who was communicated with in this matter, reported on the 15th May last that the management of most of our boarding and industrial schools has been at fault in this matter. Buildings having been located with very little consideration as to how they are to obtain a sufficient water supply. He considers that tests should have been made at Pelly to ascertain whether an artesian well would have been a success or not before the school buildings were erected and while agreeing that the school should be assisted to improve its water supply, both from a sanitary and protective point of view, he does not think that money should be expended for this purpose until an engineer or other qualified person examines and reports on the best method of ob-
taining such supply, whether from a well or from the Assiniboine River.

Ottawa, April 17th, 1902.

My dear Dr. Moore,

Referring to your letter of the 15th instant, enclosing one from Dr. Mackay, of the 9th, I beg to say in reply to the inquiries made, first, that provision will be made for a day school at Dodger's Cove, B.C.

Secondly, it was not felt that a grant could be asked for in connection with the proposed Boarding School at Ahousat, at all events, during the present year.

Thirdly, it is the intention to make provision for 30 pupils at the Cecil Jeffrey school but we have not definitely included any amount for desks. It may be possible that something may be done with regard to this matter from our general vote but I am not in a position at present to make any definite promise.

I may further add that the estimates for next year contain an item of $750. for a water supply at Crowstand boarding school.

Enclo. I return Dr. Mackay's letter herewith.

The Rev. Wm. Moore, D.D.,
278 O'Connor Street,
Ottawa.

The Secretary:-

In reply to the inquiries made by Rev. Dr Mackay I beg to say:

1. That provision is made in the Supplementary Estimates for a day school at Dodger's Cove, B.C.

2. That no grant is asked for in connection with the proposed boarding school at Ahousaht by the Department in next year's estimates;

3. Provision is being made for 30 pupils at the Cecil Jeffrey school but nothing is included for desks. If, however, such a promise were made by the Commissioner the General School Vote could stand the expenditure of $150.00 for this purpose, so the Accountant informs me:

4. The main estimates for next year contain an item of $750.00 for the water supply at Crow-stand boarding school.

Dear Mr. Brent,

I send you with this a letter which I received from the Rev. Dr. McKay our Secretary of Foreign Missions, urging some matters truly our work among the Indians.

I am sorry I cannot call on you in person, though I am sure that the interest of the missions will not suffer in the least from my absence. I miss the pleasure of an interview but otherwise the business will be as effectually advanced by Dr. McKay's letter.

He suggests that I should see Mr. Hilton. This I think unnecessary unless you advise it. He is a busy man and I do not care to take up his time unless in case of necessity.

In the police court on Monday authorities were busily engaged in unravelling the story of a crime, the tale of which are of an exceptionally violent nature. The charge is one that is frequently recorded on the court minute book, supplying intoxicants to Indians, but there are circumstances in connection with this case which, if proven, make one of the offenders liable to further prosecution and punishment of a more severe nature than that provided by the Indian Act.

Two men named Oleson and Carlson are charged with having been present at a West Coast Indian Maggie and her ten-year-old daughter, Mary Ann. According to the klootchman's story, as told by the child, the mother and daughter on being liberated from the police station last Friday evening went to the Clarks' cabin in the Harbor cottages. Both Oleson and Carlson were there, and at once proceeded to give them liquor. Carlson giving the girl two glasses half full, and mother ten grams to him seventy-five cents to get another bottle of whisky, which he did. Both also drank. The girl were drunk when they went to sleep.

Next morning Oleson gave the child some more whisky. The mother and Carlson got a couple more bottles of liquor, and he did so, but didn't return any of the money. She and the two men drank the whisky.

The child's evidence substantially corroborated the story told by the mother regarding being supplied with liquor by the two men. Both prisoners asked a number of questions of the witnesses.

The case was adjourned until this afternoon. The accused unable to speak either English or Chinese, and an Indian woman acted as interpreter while her evidence was given. Later the defense went down to the Harbor cottages on Saturday morning and found both mother and child ill, the mother in particular in most deplorable condition. Both Carlson and Oleson pleaded not guilty.

An assault case in which a man named Glenn is the accused and John James the complainant was called, but remained uncharged. Erskine was charged with vagrancy and was remanded until Thursday. He pleaded not guilty.

An Indian and a white man were both fined $5 for drunkenness. Phillip Chalk was also an offender in this particular. He was in a very peculiar state of mind when questioned and pleaded guilty in a mournful tone, while a sombre shadow flitted over his face, testimony as he "hoped" of the trouble into which his insatiate thirst was constantly bringing him. Dear Sir:

The Foreign Mission Committee of the Presbyterian Church in Canada has instructed me to make application for a grant towards Boarding School Building at Ahousaht, and for the maintenance of fifty children. The reasons for application are the following:

1. Mr Russell, the Missionary there, reports that there are nearly three hundred Indians in this Band, and that there are one hundred and one children under sixteen years of age. The improved condition of their homes under the Missionary's influence has decreased the death rate amongst the children, so that the Tribe is likely to increase in numbers.

2. A Day School was opened in 1895, and the Day School Government Grant was allowed in 1900. For five years previous to 1895 no Mission work of any kind had been done in that village. According to Mr Russell's last annual report (1901-1902) sixty-four received instruction during the year. The largest number on the role was fifty-five. The average attendance for the year was 12.9 as compared with 21.1 during the previous year.

3. This unsatisfactory average Mr Russell states is not owing to any difficulty in getting the children to attend school, but to the wandering of the parents for fishing and hunting purposes. As the sealing industry decreases they go in larger numbers to the Fraser River Salmon fisheries and to the hop fields in Washington and can take more of their children with them.
This means not only enforced absence but loss of time and position in the school after their return. This can only be avoided by the erection of a Boarding School.

4. During the last summer in order as far as possible to overcome this difficulty, Mr Russell received into his own home from fourteen to twenty children, utilizing every available corner, and of course at great inconvenience, in order if possible to keep them under instruction. Many more children were pressed upon him by parents but his accommodation was not sufficient to enable him to receive them.

In a letter dated 17th November, Mr Russell states that some of the parents wish to place their children in the Boarding School in order that they may not be witnesses of so much evil occurring in their homes. This is pathetic.

5. In the same letter Mr Russell states that one little girl who was under his care last summer, was taken from him by her mother after her return from the Behring Sea. She took the child away to Victoria with the saddest result. Both mother and child were debauched by sailors, and all her earnings were of course lost. This case was reported in a Victoria paper, a clipping from which was sent by Mr Russell, which I inclose. It is only a Boarding School backed by Government authority that can protect the children from such treatment.

6. It may be added that a letter was received from the Agent Mr Guilled, 16th August, endorsing this application, and expressing
his willingness to write to the Department in support of it.

He states that whilst he cannot take the initiative in the matter, yet, he writes; "I would recommend the Government to give you a Boarding School grant because I consider the results small from Day School teaching and the difficulties great. The children are only under supervision during school hours. The English learnt is of little use, because as soon as they are out of school they talk their own language. Mr Russell is a faithful teacher, and has done faithful work at Ahousaht, but on taking the census last year I was surprised to find that although Mr Russell's is the best day school on the Coast out of 55 children at Ahousaht of age from 6 to 15, 25 attended school two months or more in the year, and the average attendance of the 35 pupils was 4 5/8 months per year. This was taken from the school register."

For these reasons the Foreign Mission Committee feels justified in making this application. Not only is the need urgent, but with favorable conditions the prospects seem to be good.

I am

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

MacKay, secretary of the Foreign Mission Committee of the Presbyterian Church in Canada advising me that his Committee is making an application to the Government at Ottawa for a boarding school grant for Ahousaht and also a building grant and asking me to recommend the same to the favorable consideration of the Department. number of the pupils will hardly gain sufficient knowledge by attendance at the day school to be of practical use to them. Their knowledge of the English language is only gained in school hours. The rest of the day they are speaking their own language and conforming to the Indian irregular and improvident mode of life. The poor attendance is from no fault of the teacher but principally from the moving of the families to their different fishing stations, also their journeys to the Fraser river fisheries and the American hop fields in search of work; besides, Indian children are allowed by their parents to do pretty much as they like and when they are at home the attendance depends chiefly on the personal influence of the teacher with the children. Taking into consideration the good work being done by the two boarding schools already established in this agency, where the pupils being constantly under the supervision of the teachers are taught to speak English intelligently and are being trained to habits of obedience, regularity and industry, I would strongly recommend that the application for a grant to establish a boarding school adjacent to the Markless Ahousahlt Reserve be acceded to.

My Dear Sir:

Allow me again to refer to Boarding School Grant for Ahousaht, B.C. I received a telegram from you when in Vancouver at the General Assembly, stating that the matter was under consideration, but that you favored making Alberni the Boarding School centre for the coast and having Day Schools at Ahousaht, Ucluelet &c. The following considerations must I think modify that view, which was also held by our Committee, when the Alberni School was built some years ago.

1. The Alberni school is now full, up to the number for which the plans provided when accepted by the Govt.

2. The Principal reports that there are 16 other children in Alberni, 11 of whom should be in the school now, but are not. That does not take at all into account the probable 150 or 200 children in the Barclay Sound and Ahousaht combined. (Ahousaht is 35 miles north of Barclay Sound).

3. If the Govt. were prepared to enlarge the Alberni school to accommodate all these, it would in my judgement be unwise. Smaller schools of 50 or 60 children are much more effective and economical as to staff, and administration.

4. Even if the building were provided at Alberni the children
Toronto,

from the coast could not be got to attend. Indian parents are very fond of their children and are not willing to allow them to go so far away—children having a similar fondness for their parents.

5. When at the coast I discussed the matter with Mr. Vowell and Mr. Fell, and both felt strongly that a grant should be allowed for Ahousaht. I called on Mr. Gilloch when at Alberni but did not see him. I have from him, however, a letter expressing the same conviction. In fact all I spoke to were of one mind. The need is there, and experience has proved that without a Boarding School the work cannot be done.

6. I am sorry to have to report that we are to lose the services of Mr. W. J. Russell, who is perhaps the best teacher on the coast. He and Mrs. Russell felt the necessity of doing something for these children to be so urgent that they had twenty-six of them in their own little home. Of course, the result was inevitable. Her health has broken down and they must withdraw. When asked why they took in so many, the natural answer was, How could we refuse when they were knocking at the door? It was, of course, unwise and yet it is hard to blame such unwisdom. There we stand. The increasingly wandering habits of the Indians—fishing, canneries, hop-picking and sealing—make it impossible to maintain attendance at the Day School. Unless they can be kept, they will go with their parents.

7. The ladies of the Board of the W.F.M.S. feel the urgency
to be such that they say, we shall provide the building if the Govt. will give the grant. You will remember that when the case was submitted before we asked a grant for building and a per capita for 50 pupils. Is it not possible to give the per capita this session? The work grows upon our hands. Our Committees are straining continually to carry what is already undertaken. The work necessarily expands. Is it unreasonable to ask the Government to enlarge its grants proportionately in a co-operative work such as the Indian work is? Kindly reopen the question if it has been closed.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Mr. Neill,

It is with deep regret we report the death of our very promising young pupil Will Maguina No. 86 of the Ahousaht Band, on Sunday evening Nov 11th/06. He was at home for a few hours on Saturday the 10th Nov. He did not complain on his return about 5 P.M., but about 4 a.m. I heard some noise, and went to his room and he complained of a pain. He got up to the water pot and returned to bed and said he felt better. I did not give him anything. I went in again in early morning and he said he felt better but he looked pale. He came down to breakfast with the others but we put him to bed and gave him Castor Oil. His temperature was low during the day and the actions of the heart weak. We used hot water bottle and heated blankets to raise his temperature and put mild mustard plaster over the heart.

He gave a little brandy for stimulant but he did not respond to treatment. He did not seem to suffer pain. We kept him in bed in warm room. Towards evening we applied onion poultice to his feet. About 8 p.m. he began to show serious symptoms and died about 11 P.M. The high wind storm made it impossible to send out for the doctor but he had the utmost care from Miss Millar who is a trained nurse. The doctor did not reach here till the second day after death. The Indians who went for him on Monday did not bring him till Tuesday. The boy said he had eaten ten pears and some dried fish eggs at his home.

Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge your letter of March 23rd., No. 607-C-5, directing me to report on a letter dated the 2nd. of January last, addressed to the Department and signed by Chief Billy and twenty-nine other Indians of Ahousaht asking that the present staff of teachers at the Ahousaht Boarding School be removed and replaced by an entirely new lot of Teachers and the Indians threat that unless this was done they would in future refuse to allow their children to attend the school.

I have the honor to refuse—report as follows—that proceeding & to Ahousaht I met the Indians in Council in the Village on April 6. There were twenty Indians present, all that were home, nine of whom were fathers who had children in the School. Chief Billy was absent from the Village at the time of my visit and I saw him later. I questioned the men very closely. They said they signed the letter because their chief, Billy had asked them to do so. In answer to questions they said they did not have anything against the School themselves, but as Chief Billy was away they were careful to say they could not speak for him. The only point they raised was that sometimes a boy's shoes wore out and so leaked, they said—"Good for you to tell Mr. Miller, the Principal, to give new shoes to the boys when shoes are bad".

On Thursday April the 11th., Billy came with three other Indians to see me at Clayoquot. I spent three hours with him, heard a very long speech, and then I asked him questions and found that all the trouble was because of the death of his son in the School in November last.
At first his remarks implied that he blamed the Staff of the School as having caused the boy's death. But when I explained to him the facts and then asked him for a direct answer to the question "Do you believe and say that the School killed your boy?"

He did not answer for some time but finally said, "No, but I want the Staff changed for they should not let my boy die in the School."

He said he had had four children all of whom were dead. Only the youngest who died in November had been in the School, the other three dying at home. When pressed for the reason of his wish for the Staff to be removed he said, "My children are all dead. Will died in the School and when I see the teachers at the School I shall feel ashamed, but if new teachers come I can shake hands with them and not feel ashamed."

The death of the boy is the one thing in his mind. He is superstitious, very ignorant in some ways but very shrewd in other things, and evidently has great influence with his people. From the School Staff and from the Indians I gathered the following facts regarding the death of the boy, Will Maquinna, No 36, son of Chief Billy.

He was admitted to the School on Feb. 1st., 1905, and was eight years of age at the time of his death. He was a very bright clever lad, and a great favorite with the Staff. On Saturday, November 10th., he went to the Village of Ahousaht to visit his grandparents, in compliance with the request of Chief Billy to the Staff before he started for Victoria.

The boy was in good health on Saturday morning. In the afternoon the grandfather gave the boy nine hard green pears which the boy ate, and then they gave him decayed fish eggs of which he ate a large quantity. He returned to the School in the evening and said he did not want any supper. In the night he was taken sick and complained of pains in his stomach. The Principal arose and waited on him. Miss Miller, one of the Staff, is a qualified trained nurse of long experience, and took charge of him giving Physic, Stimulants etc., but he gradually sunk and died at 10 P.M., Sunday November 11th., about twenty hours from the time he first complained of feeling sick.
A violent gale raging at the time made it impossible to go for
the Doctor, the nearest of which was twelve miles away. The Principal
sent for him when the weather modified after the death, and from
examination and inquiry reported it a case of Ptomaine poisoning.

Miss Miller stated that all the symptoms during the sickness were
those of poisoning. Doctor Rolls gave me the following letter:

The Deputy Superintendent General,

I beg to report that I made an inspection of the Ahousht Boarding School on Tuesday the 24th day of September. The school is a new three story balloon frame building of good appearance and convenient arrangement. The boys quarters are in one end of the building, the girls in the other having separate stairway giving access to each as well as a separate bathing and washing rooms, fitted up with modern fixtures. The diningrooms and class rooms are common to the boys and girls.

The buildings are on an elevation overlooking an arm of the sea and afford a very picturesque view of the surrounding mountains, etc...

A small lake has been drained which will provide ample ground for gardening when brought under cultivation. Very little effort has been made to clear other land other than that of reclaiming the lake.

During low tide there is abundance of opportunities for exercise and the playground on the beach, in front of the school, also affords splendid swimming facilities.

The school is badly situated for harborage as no pier can be built for landing either freight or passengers owing to the exposed position of the site. All freight and passengers having to be lowered in-to open boats from steamers which is rather dangerous in rough weather.

In
In my opinion safe dockage should not been have overlooked in the choosing of the site.

The school is dependent on the rainfall for water supply, the water from the roof of building being stored in tanks for domestic use. This supply would be of very little use in case of fire; a bountiful supply of water good water should be a primary consideration in the selection of a school site (as the health of the pupils will depend to a great extent on the purity of the water supply) and that can be obtained by gravitation at little expense in almost every locality on the coast.

I was very favourably impressed with the internal condition of this building, everything being clean and neat and the children are bright and neatly clothed, and, to all appearances, contented.

The Principal, Rev. Mr. Miller impressed me as being a very capable and energetic manager and is intensely interested in the welfare of the school and with his efficient staff will no doubt show good results from their combined efforts.

Sir—

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of January 26, last, forwarding a petition from certain Indians at Ahousaht, asking for the dismissal of the present staff of the Ahousaht Boarding School and the appointment of an entirely new set of teachers; and in reply I beg to say that, while it is not the practice of the Department to deal with petitions of this class where no specific charges are made, it has, however, in this case instituted enquiries with a view to discovering whether there are any just causes of complaint against the school and its staff, and as a result of such enquiries I have to inform you that the Department is satisfied that this school is well conducted and that the staff are able and efficient and wholly devoted to their work and that the petitioners have no grounds for asking for their dismissal.

From the reports received on the investigation held into this matter it would appear that you have taken umbrage against this school on account of the death of your boy in the institution in November, last.

Billy,

Indian,

Ahousaht, B.C.
The Department learns that your boy's death was occasioned by eating some poisonous fish or fish eggs and green fruit, which he obtained while on a visit to his grandparents, in compliance with your wishes.

He was in good health when he left the school on November 10, but he was taken ill on his return from the causes above mentioned and gradually sank and died on the evening of the following day, about twenty-four hours after he first complained of being sick. He received most skilful nursing during his short illness and the treatment was the best that could have been accorded him under the circumstances, and the school is in no way to blame for your son's death, which was caused from poisoning.

The Department is led to make this full explanation in the hope that you will be convinced that the school authorities are in no way responsible for your son's death, which was due to the unwholesome food eaten while on the visit to his grandparents.

If you or any of the Ahousaht Indians at any time have any specific charges to make against the school or the staff, they will be thoroughly investigated by the Indian Agent, who is the proper person to whom such complaints should be made; but the Department wishes to warn you and the Indians to be careful not to make false statements at any time, as they would only cause subsequent trouble.

I may also add for your information that this school was not established for the benefit of the De-
partment or of the staff but for the purpose of educat-
ing the Indians of the Ahousaht band, and if they fail
to take advantage of it, it is their loss and not the
Department's, and you will do well to be careful how you
set about to impair its usefulness by circulating such
petitions as the one sent in by you and using your in-
fluence to undermine the good work the school is engaged

Our School

Our School is situated on the Eastern side of Flores Island, B.C., and several Indians of our village built it in the year 1904.

I helped quite a bit with the building.

In the front of our School is the Clayoquot Sound which separates Flores Island from the main land of Vancouver Island.

In the north-west of our mission is a little village where most of us live; it is a quarter of a mile from the mission.

Every Saturday we go home to visit our parents and relations, and when it's a good day on Sunday we have our service at the village. Most of the people like to go to church especially the young men.

The size of our School house is sixty-eight by forty-eight feet, the height is between fifty and sixty feet.

The number of the boys and girls in the School is forty and we have four Teachers.

We go in School two times a day, once in morning once in afternoon. Our Evening School
School hours are ten o'clock till twelve o'clock and our afternoon school hours are from two o'clock to four o'clock in the evening.

We have one large school room and one small one. The small one was used for the junior classes, but we don't use it now and we use it as a drawing room. The large school room is used for the senior classes. There are twenty-four seats in the large school room and quite a few in the small school room.

There are eleven children in the fourth reader now because two are not here, five in the third, four in the second and quite a number in the part II class and five in the first reader.

Behind our school is a little farm or a little lake trained by Mr. Miller which is between fourteen or fifteen acres of land. In the summer we like to play in our playground because the ground gets hard enough. We have a football and baseball grounds.

Every year we plant potatoes and some other vegetables.

Under the lake house is a large
tank which contains two thousand seven hundred gallons of water. When our upstairs tanks are empty we have to pump up some more water from the large tank.

In the month of July 1908 Mr Ross built a launch for our mission. The power of the engine in the launch is three and a half H.P. and she goes more than eight miles an hour. Her length is about twenty-two feet.

In the same year we build a barn twenty-six by eighteen feet.

We have a new work shop which was built last year whose size is twenty-four by eighteen feet.

Every day after four o'clock we cut wood for our furnace, sometimes for our range in the kitchen. When it is raining we scrub or work in the work shop.

The stumps around the schoolhouse are very many in number, some are large, some are small, some are decaying and some are intact.

The forests around the schoolhouse are also heavily timbered and it's very hard to walk through the woods.
In spring we always have very many different kinds of wild flowers in the woods and rose bushes in the front of the school house.

Last year the boys and Mr. Ross painted the school house and it looks more nicer now.

Not very long ago we made a sidewalk from the front steps to the girls side and we are making one from the edge of the farm to the school room door.

We have one cow her name is Lucy. We take care of her very much we give her plenty of hay and water every day.

We have more than thirty four hens here also which gives us quite a number of eggs every day and we feed them every morning and evening.

The boys over here are fond of foot racing, football and baseball. We are allowed to run a quarter of a mile or an eighth of a mile.

Mr. Ross said he will also make a platform in front of our school house for drilling.

We always have our summer holidays in the month of May and in Autumn.
During our holidays in Fall we fish for the Dog Salmon and some different kinds of fish and besides we always have our Christmas holidays. Before we have our summer holidays we clean every room of the School house.

In the girls side we are going to build a pavilion. We are cutting the trees and bushes from the best place which we thought would do. This pavilion is going to have eight side of an octagon shape.

The teachers don't allow us to go home without permission for if we do they will punish us. We are not also to speak in our Indian language for if we do we are to stay in School on Saturdays.

The teachers also tells us to speak the truth and not steal things that don't belong to us. They are very strict to us in the School especially when we are studying our lessons. They tell us from time to time not to idle.

Very often we have some visitors over here some times from Blayquah.
and from some other places.

In the warm days of spring and summer we very often have a picnic to outside places, sometimes in side places. The boys and girls love to have a picnic in summer. The outside places are good summer resorts and the Indians like to live in these places as well as the school boys and girls.

The boys and girls go to school when they are eight or nine years of age, some sooner. They discharge when they are eighteen years of age.

The boys work at the carpenter work and shoemaker and they work at it with all their best.
O. H. M. S.

Dear Mr. Scott:

We recommend for appointment as principal of Ahousaht Boarding School, Mr. John Ross. We have failed in getting what we have been looking for—a principal who would be teacher as well. Mr. Ross has had much experience and we think it would be better to make him principal rather than appoint an inexperienced man to the control of agents who have been on the staff for a good many years. We shall then look for a lady teacher, and have only one man in the school as we had in the past. When Mr. Miller left he recommended that there should be two men because of the amount of work to be done and the discipline sometimes necessary, and so far away from any white community. Mr. Ross, however, is a powerful man and has had much experience with the Indians, and will, I think, as principal keep the school well in hand. If we succeed in getting as satisfactory a lady teacher as Miss MacKay was I think things will be all right.

Dear Mr. Vowell,

Permit me to ask your kind consideration of a request on behalf of our school. For six years the Presbyterian Church has endeavored to maintain an efficient boarding school for the education of Indian children. The new school was erected and furnished at a cost of $1000. The average annual outlay for running expenses is about $4000 per annum. The enrolment of pupils for last year was forty-five.

Since the beginning of the school the amount of government grant for running expenditure has been $150 dollars per capita for twenty-five pupils.

In addition to the heavy share of running expenses which the church has borne we have been obliged to make frequent requests for liberal grants for necessary improvements.

Being very much isolated we have made it our aim to become industrially independent. In this direction we have recovered a field of about eighteen acres from draining a small lake at a cost of $350. The field is said to be one of the finest on the West Coast and would be very
productive with some further outlay for improvement. We have also made a start in shoemaking, blacksmithing, carpentry and machine shop work. We have just completed a two-and-a-half-foot barn with cabin and equipped with kerosene engine at an outlay of $450. A new barn 26 x 18 has also just been completed. We have been trying to help ourselves and the Church has been generous to us, to enable us to meet even our most urgent necessities.

We feel that while the Indian Department has given much assistance yet considering the work we are doing and more which we wish to do but cannot without the assistance of the Department that we can approach them with confidence of assistance.

We ask the Indian Department to raise the maximum number of scholars for whom our school can draw the grant of $60 per capita per annum from twenty-five to thirty-five. This assistance would enable us to do very much in realizing the necessary developments for our school. Trusting that this request may meet with your esteemed approval.

In reply to your letter No. 134,628/1 of Feb. 19, I have the honour to submit the following report, re water supply and fire protection at Ahousaht School.

The water supply is obtained from rain fall, which is stored in tanks. The total capacity of which is 4070 gals. A tank of 500 gal. capacity is kept sealed in the basement for drinking purposes. Charcoal is often put in to clarify it. About 55 feet at the rear of the School, is a well 9 ft. deep. This water is used for washing purposes only. When the drinking water tank gives out, drinking water has to be brought from a distance, or over a mile, but this seldom happens. It is impossible to obtain good well water anywhere near the School.

As it is practically, an impossibility, to lay a pipe system, owing to land conditions, distance etc., the Principal, Rev. J. T. Dear Sir,

I regret to report an accident which caused the death of a little girl in the school named Carrie George, age 8, eight years old. She was coming out of another little girl's tent to play near the school about one hundred yards away from the school at 5:45 p.m. She was away about twenty minutes when the little girl came running towards the school, her face half covered with the smoke of her clothes when she fell. A big boy named Donald was about two hundred feet away when he heard the call for help and rushed forward and quickly took off his clothing. He was able to save her life by removing her from the fire and giving part of her body. She was carried into the school and everything was done for her that was needed with the best treatment and fastest of burning. She lived about twenty hours.

We regret very much this sad affair as she was the youngest girl in school and a favorite with all. She had the matches from her own tent on her person and no harm can be attached to the school in any way. The carrying of matches by pupils is a bad habit. The school has always been strictly forbidden. No matches were allowed to be used except by the teacher. Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of January 8, 1915, in which you inform me that complaints have been made against Mr. Ross, the principal of the Ahousaht Boarding School, by the Ahousaht Indians through Chief Benson Keatler and Billy August, and your request that I should visit Ahousaht to investigate these charges and report.

In reply I beg to state that I visited Ahousaht on the 3rd instant and met the Indians on the 4th, and while making my investigations my suspicions were confirmed that these complaints against Mr. Ross were framed up by the Indians as a result of his active assistance to the Indian Agent in stopping the potlatch.

Chief Benson Keatler informed me that although he had placed his signature to a letter to the Department complaining against Mr. Ross, there was no truth whatever in the statements made. At the time these letters were written the Indians were somewhat angry about the potlatch and he and Alexander Sutherland were induced to write to the Department. Sutherland was not to be found, he having left for Sidney Inlet immediately after my arrival at Ahousaht.

On November 26th the wife of Billy August and three Indians were taken to Clayoquot and tried before Magistrate Grice for potlatching. They were let off under suspended sentence.

sentence after paying the costs of the Court. About this time Billy August wrote to me complaining about the matter, bewailing the fact that his wife had got into trouble. As I had a full knowledge of the case I replied to him that I considered the magistrate had dealt very leniently with the Indians, for he might very well have imposed the full penalty for potlatching provided under Section 149 of the Act.

That part of the letter of Billy August (of which I have received a copy) wherein he states that the Catholic missionary is better than the Presbyterian is the outcome of a visit made to Ahousaht by the Clayoquot priest, Rev. Father Schindler, which unfortunately took place at the time that Mr. Ross had gone to Clayoquot to attend the trial above referred to. At this time the Indians met the Catholic missionary and endeavored to enlist his sympathies in an effort to have the potlatch custom continued, or at least to allow potlatching to take place between the Ahousaht and Kelsomaht Indians. In an interview I had with Rev. Father Schindler I am convinced that this took place. The Reverend Father, however, claims that he gave them no promise that would lead them to believe he could do anything for them in the matter, except to say that he thought they should be allowed to potlatch locally amongst themselves.

As regards the complaint that Mr. Ross drove the Indians away from the Mission, the explanation of this is that on a certain Sunday Mr. Ross found the Indians playing baseball on the reserve, and he informed them that if they were going to desecrate the Sabbath by playing baseball he would not allow them the use of the school grounds upon which to play matches, and I consider that he was perfectly justified in taking this attitude.
In conclusion I may say that Mr. Ross has always taken a very keen interest in the spiritual and physical welfare of the Ahousaht Indians. At his school the children receive a splendid education and he himself devotes a great deal of time in giving the male pupils first-class instructions in carpentry and joining work and other useful employment. I am convinced that the Ahousaht Indians would be a long while before having another man as missionary to them who would look after their interests so well. I have no doubt that now the Department has started on an active campaign against the potlatch custom complaints, similar to those made against Mr. Ross, will be registered not only against missionaries but also officials of the Department, for the Indians will resent any action put forth by their best friends for the curtailment of some of their old tribal customs.

I consider Rev. J. T. Ross, Principal of the Ahousaht Boarding School, one of the most conscientious missionaries, in this Agency. This school is conducted in a first class manner, as my reports on same always show.

Over seven years ago, his first wife died of consumption, contracted through visiting and attending to Indians suffering from this loathsome disease. Mr. Ross' life among the Indians has been one of self denial and self sacrifice. Dear Dr. Grant,

I received your letter of December 11th with enclosure of a letter you received from the Indian Department, Ottawa. On Dec. 22nd, I had an interview with the young man, Alex Sutherland, who wrote the letter for the Indians of Ahousaht. Before Mrs. Ross, Miss McIvor and myself he confessed that the charges laid against me in the letter are false.

Although there is still some ill-feeling against me on the part of graduates of the Roman Catholic school and possibly a half a dozen of our own following, still almost all the Ahousahts are on friendly terms with us. Of course there has been trouble between myself and the Ahousaht Indians, but to be fair the Indians are not to be blamed so much when you know the whole truth.

For some time I have taken an active part in the suppression of intertribal potlatching. I was the first on the West Coast to lay information before the authorities of a breach of the Indian Act in regard to the custom. In spite of warning from the Indian Agent Cox and myself the Ahousaht Tribe gave a potlatch to the Kelsomaht Tribe Nov. 20th. As it was the first offense four Indians paid the cost, $7.25 each and were let out with a warning that if they were found guilty on a second offense they would be sent to jail. I may say here that I do not think our Indians will break the law again. One lesson will prove sufficient. The potlatch custom when confined to each individual tribe is a harmless custom and simply amounts to inexpensive feasting and dancing. An Indian will invite the whole tribe to feast in an chief's house. He may spend from
$10.00 to $15.00 on sea biscuits or rice to feed the entire tribe, which after all is no more than the average cost of Christmas in the majority of white homes in Canada. But the intertribal potlatching custom is bad. So long as it continues there is no possibility of Indian advancement in British Columbia. Of course, naturally, the Indian feels pretty sore about the new law and they were angry because I was the first to take up a case of the kind on the West Coast.

Now I wish to put the blame just where it belongs. The very day I was called away to give evidence on this particular case held in Clayoquot court, a Jesuit Priest landed here from Clayoquot. The Indians gathered together and the priest spoke to them in a body sympathizing with them and promised to help them. He told them that there was a law against intertribal potlatching but that he would use his influence to help them so that they could potlatch the Kelsomahts. Further I have Indian witnesses to prove that the letter written by Alex Sutherland to the Department was written in the presence of Father Joseph Schindler. Father Joseph did not write it with his own hand but he heard it discussed and was there while a rough draft of the letter was made. Only twice during 1913 was mass said in the Roman Catholic Chapel at Ahousaht, but every time a jesuit priest pays a visit to Ahousaht trouble is made for us. The following Sunday after Father Joseph had his meeting, he landed to say mass for graduates of the Catholic school. After mass he had the audacity to send one of our graduates over to the school to invite our boys over to a meeting which he wished to hold with all the young men on the reserve. The young man delivered his
message but did not return. At this meeting Father Joseph promised to open a night school to teach the young men Latin. Last Sunday Father Joseph landed again but only a few of our following went to his service while we had the largest attendance since last winter. Let me say in closing that the real source of trouble here does not originate so much from any measure of discipline I may exercise in the school or on the reserve but from the mean underhand advantage taken by the Jesuit Priests to sow discord and enmity by showing pretended sympathy to those Indians who wilfully break the laws of the country. I have often said that an Indian's loyalty is worth about the price of a blanket but after all they have shown more loyalty recently than I expected considering what I felt it my duty to do in bringing some of them to task. "As the end justifies the means" with a Jesuit priest, they may eventually win out by their unjust, underhand policy but I shall always have the consolation of knowing that I tried to help the Indians along by an honest policy and my justice has always been tempered with mercy.

I am yours sincerely

Sgd. John Ross.

Dear Mr. McLean:

I have yours of May 26th to hand re the proposed Indian Boarding School at Ahousaht.

The plans and specifications have not reached me yet, but no doubt will come soon.

There is one clause that I do not quite understand. You state, "On examination these are found to be satisfactory and meet the requirements for a Class C school with an enrolment of 25 pupils and staff." We do not understand just what you mean by "Class C school". We have never had any of that grade. It is possible that Mr. Scott did not explain, before leaving, the agreement we reached, when Mr. Turnbull and I conferred with him a few weeks ago. The understanding reached was to the effect, that our Church would get per capita grant usually given to Class B school. At the present time that would mean $110. per pupil.

You understand that the Church is putting up this building to help the Government out at a time of stress. A year ago, it was suggested that the Government put up one big Boarding School at the Coast. Mr. Scott found he could not go ahead with the building at the present time.

Mr. Currie has been doing the work at Alberni in temporary quarters, provided by the Church.

We thought we could solve the problem at Ahousaht, by a day-school. After a year's experiment, all parties are convinced that a day-school is not practicable at Ahousaht, as the parents of the children are not at home more than five months of the year.

We expect that the Government will put up a building at Alberni in the year 1919, but to tide over the present crisis, the W.M.S. consented to put up a small building at Ahousaht to accommodate 25 pupils. Our understanding with Mr. Scott was, that this building would be
small and not too expensive. There will be no difficulty in putting an isolation sick room in the upper story. We will see that provision is made for this.

Kindly let us know by return mail, if the Department is prepared to allow us per capita grant given to schools in Grade B.

We could not undertake to maintain this school on a smaller grant. The school at this point was always expensive. There is no good farm land and the children will be young and unable to undertake manual labor of any kind. The price of everything to be purchased is very expensive and freight rates are high.

We are anxious to commence work at once. As soon as I get a reply, I will wire men at the Coast. Mr. Ross who is to put up the building is already on the ground and has some of the materials purchased.

Hoping to hear by return mail, I am

Yours sincerely,

Past and Present at Ahousaht, B.C.

REV. ARTHUR BARNER

The following extract, which is taken from the diary of a pioneer missionary and dated 1884, will reveal some of the conditions which existed in those days. He had evidently erected a rude building in which to conduct Christian work—feeling that any place of his own construction, and with a different atmosphere, would be superior to the native conditions with which he was surrounded.

"I considered this place very necessary if I want to instruct the Indians of this tribe. Thus far I had done it in the house of the chief, but it was a terrible place.

"The house of the chief was over one hundred feet in length, by sixty in width. The corner posts were immense pieces of cedar twenty feet high; they were met on top by long sticks three feet through. One monster beam was laid across the centre and served as crosspiece to support the roof planks. With a fall, for rain and water of only about two feet, the roof lay almost flat. This is now the form of all the Indians' houses on this coast—immense places with almost flat roofs. The sides are cedar planks fastened by ropes of cedar bark below and above. The cedar roof planks are chiseled out so as to leave a groove for the rain. In fine weather one of these planks is raised and shoved above its neighbor to let in air and give a place of exit for the smoke.

"In this chief's house twelve different..."
families had their home—twelve different open fireplaces supplied the room with smoke and heat. There were no windows in the house, although the crevices between the wall planks permitted some light to enter. How could I instruct these people in such a horrible place of filth and smoke—not mentioning the noise made by the quarrelling of the women, the crying of children, the growling and fighting of dogs? . . .
And then the immodest bearing of the numerous inmates! Yes! I required a place to try and do something for the Ahousaht Indians, and now I rejoice that when I go there next season I will have a place of my own, no matter how poor and how undesirable it may look or be.

"During my stay at Ahousaht I was greatly amused to see a couple of young Indians taking their walk around the place with each a shoe on one foot only! The man wore a shirt with a blanket over his shoulder and the wife had also a blanket over her dress; both had their faces painted with red vermilion. I was told that the reason for this odd action was that they had recently become the parents of twins. By this time they had gone through a very hard experience, and they were still looked upon by all the people as outcasts and as to be shunned. No one will use the vessels they have used to drink or to eat. Those left to be starved dry fish, nothing fresh is to pass their lips. Now, and for a long time to come, they are not allowed to go on the sea in canoes either to fish or for pleasure. The man has to retire daily in the forest, and by shouting and bathing reconcile the 'spirits.' Their life is not a pleasant one, as every one avoids them, and being forbidden to go after food, they have before them the prospect of famine and endless miseries. The birth of twins is a source of great excitement with all the Indians on the coast. They have special songs for the occasion in which all the principal men of the tribe, "in" before the house where the twins are born.

"Another time unusual excitement was caused by one of our chiefs becoming crazy. The Indians soon bethought themselves of an old remedy. They took the crazy man up to the river in the boat. Half a dozen men had charge of him and carried in hands branches of brushwood. . . . given signal they began to flog him; then they took the man by the hair and forced his head under water. The bubbles indicated when to allow him up for breath. Then flogging recommenced . . . and the head under water again. . . . and the process continued till very little life was left in him. Their idea was to flog out the bad spirit who was supposed to be in the poor insane chief!"

To visit Ahousaht today would certainly convince the most sceptical person of the uplifting and regenerating influences brought to bear on the Indians by the prosecution of Christian work in their midst. The village is a very different place; the domestic life is much improved. The number of gasoline launches owned by the Indians speaks of their progress in industry. The neat church building on the hill, filled each Sunday with a well-dressed congregation, and the Community House in the village where social service work is carried on, demonstrate the great advances which are taking place in a moral and spiritual way.

One of the greatest influences in bringing these changes can be traced to the work which is carried on at the Residential School nearby, under the auspices of the Department of Indian Affairs and The Woman's Missionary Society. Fifty bright and progressive girls and boys soon convince the visitor that there is a bright future for the Indian people, that old things are passing away and all things are becoming new, in the lives of the natives of Canada.
POTLATCH GOES INTO DISCARD

West Coast Indians Stage Modern Carnival of Sports on Holiday.

STEER COOKED WHOLE

Old-time Indian potlatch has been tossed into the discard and tribes of the West Coast of Vancouver Island have adopted the white man's method of sporting events. This West Coast Indians inaugurated at Matilda Creek, near Port Alberni, a water and field carnival which promises to become an established provincial attraction.

These tribes celebrated Victoria Day last Thursday with great banquets and they made a great success of it. The enthusiasm and arrangements and success is due to work of the Aboush tribe.

Four hundred Indians, representing tribes from Kyuquot Sound to head of Albemarle attended. In addition there were many white people, and the total attendance was 600. Three hundred dollars was distributed in prizes for various events, and cooked whole. All visitors were guests of the Aboush tribe.

ENJOYMENT

Joseph Titian threw open his big house Saturday night for an Indian dance and white people preferring more than 100 were entertained by dance on SS. Princess Norah by Captain John Keithiah and Harold Little of Matilda Creek. The Indians also had a basketball game.

The Indians decided to observe Sunday as a day of rest, and did little else but barbecue and eat the steer. Monday was filled day with running races for a party of seventy-five Japans and Indians, and races between John Keithiah and Harold Little of Matilda Creek. There was also second money in running races, though the Indians won. The Indians also took the distance event and pole vault.

Gibson's Mill team defeated the Aboush school football team, 2 to 1. The tug-of-war, for a trophy presented by Mr. Gibson, was won by the Dehelet Indians and the Aboush tribe captured the relay race and basketball game.

J. Cohen, forest ranger, informed the writer that Captains Arthur Higginbotham of Vancouver handled the affair. The committee responsible for the affair comprised Captains John Keithiah of the Aboush tribe, and Charles Dixon and Gordon Gibson of Matilda Creek. Pauline Gibson, wife of Gordon Gibson, was present, accompanied by her son, who attended the old school.

In the latter evening Joseph Thomas of Christie's school gave a clever exhibition of canoe work and Herbert Peter and David McCallum romped away with the upset canoe race.
