Landing the New Music at Ahousat

WILLIAM R. WOOD

AHOUSAT? Just where in the world is that? Of old time the central rendezvous of the Ahousat Indians was on the western shore of Vargas Island which occupies the southern area of Clayoquot Sound. Being Canadians you are of course familiar with the general topography of the West Coast. But some three generations ago bitter enmity arose between the Ahousats and a group of Indians who occupied the little peninsula which juts out from the south-eastern corner of Flores Island. The Ahousats, who were a warlike and energetic group, annihilated the northern village, massacred its inhabitants almost to a man, and recognizing the advantages of a site with an interior harbor on one side and ready access to the outer waters on the other, settled down and gave their name to the new location. The name is now applied to the village, to the post office on the western shore of the creek, and to the Indian School which adjoins the reserve.

The new music? Yes, of course, there has been earlier music. From primeval times groups of men and women, seated on the grass on summer afternoons or on the floor of some big house on winter evenings, played the wild chimes of la-hal, the gaming device, which appears to have been universal among the Coast tribes, and accompanied it with the incessant tat-tat-tat of clashing sticks. But for a generation or more Christian hymns have been heard here and there by the music of a little portable organ and, in the little church and the Indian School, small house organs have helped in the service of praise. But time and the dampness of the British Columbia climate had long ago played havoc with their melody and there was dire need of something better.

Two of the workers at the school, recognizing not only the religious value of music but its general cultural importance and being convinced of the possibility of effecting a revival of the musical talents of some of the Ahousat youth, decided that the need was urgent and immediate. The facilities simply must be secured. Being above all things practical, and of the devoted spirit which has been so common a characteristic of our work among the Indians and never suspecting that even such semi-publicity as this would be given to their generous action, they took steps to have them purchased in Vancouver and shipped by the C.P.R. steamer up the coast.

And now the day of their arrival, a piano for the school and an organ for the Village Community House, has come. All the children are on the tip-toe of expectancy and the grown-ups are wondering about the coming of such precious and ponderous pieces of furniture. As the day advances we hear by telephone of the steamer at Ucluelet, a name with many old-time associations in the Indian work of the Presbyterian Church, then at Tofino and finally at Clarks Point, and by this time it is dark and we are compelled to realize that the landing cannot be to-night. No piano could be landed by canoe and got up the rocks in the dark. So reluctantly we are compelled to decide that the music must be allowed to go to Macdonald Creek, where it may be placed on the wharf till the return of daylight. Going out in the big dug-out as the steamer passes we are able to assure ourselves that the music has really come, seeing the two big cases on the lower deck and the landing out of drums and other supplies, we pass the night with what patience we can.

In the morning our faithful man of all work meets us at the reserve float with the launch and landing scow and a group of us step on board. En route to Clarks Point we get the most news for our once-in-ten-days mail, and by that time it has begun to rain with every appearance of giving us a day of it. But after
a half-hour's downpour—the genuine British Columbia article—it slackens, and by the time we reach the Gibson wharf the sun is out again.

With the help of willing hands, strong ropes, heavy plank and convenient little rollers, the piano is soon placed on the scow and we set off for the school, leaving the organ for a second trip as its destination is the Community House in the village. Opposite the school we anchor the launch and with long pike poles work the scow toward the land. In a few minutes it is close ashore and planks and rollers are soon brought into requisition to place the piano on the beach. It is only a few feet and the slope is downward so there is no difficulty and we push the scow off again before the falling tide can leave it stranded. Anchoring it with the launch we face the task of negotiating the rocky slope, above which the school stands.

All the boys are on hand, and four or five brawny young Indians from the village. Planks are laid forward up the rocks and the heavy tow rope is brought on which twenty or more can pull. With a couple of cedar rollers under the piano it begins slowly to move up the rocks. With many an "All together" and "Everybody on the tow" it advances foot by foot. For much of the way it is heavy pulling and the relaying of the plank track is no child's play. But this is a school function, the sun is shining, the boys are in working humor and there is no delay. Soon the steepest and roughest part is passed. The pullers move their burden ten or twelve feet at each effort. Then comes the final stage, up the steep outer stairway to the front hall of the school. Then the planks are laid. The rope team stretches up the steps across the hall and into the dining-room. Here their efforts are rewarded by the ladies of the school and almost with a bound the heavy case is landed in the hall. Paul Sam, the biggest of our Indian helpers, is the first to voice our satisfaction in the triumphant exclamation, "Home at last."

Then it is not long ere the beautiful instrument, relieved of its heavy casing, is carried into the sitting-room and the school gather round, full of curiosity and wonder to see and hear it. Quite undesignedly and yet appropriately enough it happens that the first air picked out by Winona, one of our senior girls, was "God Save the King," and as the shining keys under her touch gave out the sound so familiar and yet strangely sweet from this new instrument, the group sang the first and second stanza of the anthem.

And what of the organ, you ask? Oh, we didn't forget it. As the scow and the launch were taken back to their haven in the inner creek, the mill workers lent a hand and it was placed on the scow, the
plan being to cover it with a tarpaulin for the night and unload it at the village in the morning. The sky was clear and there was every indication of fine weather and a chance to finish our task in the morning sunshine. So we slept quite late but at nine o'clock in the morning—what? Rain? Impossible! But we should have learned ere this that nothing, excepting perhaps forty below, is impossible in British Columbia in the way of weather. A heavy drizzle had begun, and soon it was a "regular" rain, and word came across that the organ was not to be damaged it must be got under cover very soon. There was no alternative.

With five boys rigged in every available rain coat, oilskin and rubber boot we set off over the plank walk to the village where the scow was to meet us at nine-thirty. Rain, rain, rain! We go on raining, raining, raining, on the muddy bank waiting, and we tramp off the long float as the scow arrives. Slats are nailed across the front and back ends of the crate, and under them, along its sides, poles are placed for carrying. Strong of arm and sure of our ability to carry it anywhere we lift the case and move along the float. But when we have gone fifty feet, it is convenient to pause for a minute, and by the time we reach the landward end of the float we realize that we have not the man-power needed to take it up the village slope and over to its destination in the Community House. But it is raining and there is nobody about. At last some one suggests Noah. He lives just at hand and we rouse him out of his "ark" to give us a lift. By the time he reaches us, Daniel, who in spite of the rain had ventured out of his "den," came past and took thought for our need. With the assistance of these two Old Testament worthies we reach rather laboriously still, the steps of the Community House. Rain, rain, rain, as we fumble for the key and discover that the doorway is an inch narrower than the organ-case. Rain, rain, rain, while we hurriedly pry off the tarpaulin, holding the tarpaulin across to prevent its getting wet, slide the organ at last into the building. Then, wet as we are, we sit down to take breath and to congratulate ourselves that in spite of all obstacles we have got both instruments landed safely, and without the slightest injury, in the places for which they were designed.

And now as the boys pass the village people and their friends from Kilsonat and Opitsat come in twos and threes to look at and admire the instruments. To most of them the piano is new, so large, so finely polished, so sweet-toned, so much better than the old organs. And we look forward into the years, see the children getting better musical training with one here and another there being taught to play the instruments themselves and gradually the procuring of instruments for their homes. We see better music in the services and a richer culture all around for the second succeeding generations as a result of the splendid devotion of two workers through which, as we have seen, the new music came to Ahousat.
Mr. Russell T. Ferrier,
Superintendent of Indian Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

To Mr. Clark, Dr. Young, and
the H. M. and W. M. S. Offices.

My term as principal of the Ahousat Indian School has come to an end, and I write to sum up the situation as it appears to me at this time.

May I say in the first place that the most gratifying feature is the fact that in the new principal you have secured a man with a record of long experience and successful service in Indian work. Mr. Jones needed no introduction to the work, and I feel that in his hands there is reason to expect the very fullest success of which the school is capable. Beside his knowledge of Indian character and conditions, his training as a carpenter and his practical experience in handling boats and canoes, will prove of the very highest value for the work here. I judge that he will fit admirably into the situation and that in his hands the future of the school will be well taken care of.

My success in getting the premises into good shape has been only partial. The structural changes contemplated are within sight of completion and I am sure will lessen the difficulties of the staff and make the care of the children much easier. Commodious playrooms for both boys and girls with new stairways at the ends instead of the middle of the building will help greatly. The heating plant (a hot water furnace with coal as the fuel) was got into operation a few days ago and heats the whole building comfortably and effectively. The new water and toilet systems, after the utmost driving I have been able to do is yet two weeks from completion. The men are now working on it and it should be in operation before the close of November. The delay has been due solely to the fact that the contractor did not get his men here till a few weeks ago. Their delay has also held up our getting the new kitchen range into operation, but that will be got going shortly when the water system is connected up. The department has declined for the present to supply a laundry washer which is urgently necessary. I am making one more effort before I leave to have them undertake it, but with little hope of securing immediate action. But with all slips and delays it can still be said that the school is a hundred per cent better adapted for its work than it was in January last. The Department in view of the increased dining room, dormitory and classroom accommodation increased the pupilage from October 1st to 45 and provided for a further increase to 50 in the spring.

Two or three things should be noted very particularly regarding the premises. First, certain further expenditures, not of very large amount, are rendered necessary by the work done during this season, and will be required in the near future. I have in mind first of all the lighting. The plant requires increased storage, and may need a new generator to carry the additional lights which must be put in. Some sixteen to twenty additional bulbs will be needed to light the new power building, the new playrooms, the class room and the dormitories. And this should be put in at the earliest possible moment. Considerable glass and wire screening for protection of the windows should be procured. The new playrooms ought to be given at least one coat of paint. We received
a donation of rails for the freight track, but it will be necessary to secure some cement and some timber, - not a large quantity - for rebuilding the track itself.

In accordance with directions from the office a winch has been got at a cost of $75, and a cable is being ordered which will cost approximately $25.

After fairly full consideration and discussion with other workers I am taking the liberty of urging as my convinced opinion that the Church would be wise from every point of view to approach the Indian Department and offer to turn over to it the ownership of this whole school property, land and buildings. To do this would mean that the Department would come to feel a much more direct and immediate responsibility for maintaining the equipment and the church and Society would be relieved of certain financial obligations which sometimes are fairly heavy. At the same time the opportunities for real service to the Indians which the Church enjoys would not be in any degree circumscribed. I think that the present time, when the Department has just expended over $8000 on the property is 'the psychological moment' to make this approach. Experienced workers among the Indians here are of the same opinion, and I am glad to find the new principal holds the same view.

I have to report, also, that Mrs. Payne, our kitchen matron here, who is over seventy-three years of age and has given some years of wonderfully effective service, has decided that she must give up her position. She will be glad to be relieved at an early date. I have communicated with Mrs. Wicken of Vancouver and she is endeavoring to secure someone to take the position. Mrs. Payne I know, is retiring with very limited means, and if the Committee in its wisdom could see its way to giving her an honorarium of, say, a month's salary, it would be a very Christian way of expressing appreciation of the unique service she has rendered, and the scores of nights when she has sacrificed her sleep to get refreshments for the Indian boys engaged in winter night landings and the other scores of nights when she has got up at 3:30 or 4:00 a.m. to set bread for next day's baking.

Now as to the future of the work here, I am compelled to repeat what I have several times said, that until provision is made for the principal - or someone else - having time to give to the Christianizing of conditions in the Indian village, the school will be working under a fatal handicap. Moral and social conditions there, I am convinced are very definitely worse than they were fifteen or twenty years ago. Unless the principal is relieved of certain duties at the school so as to be able to give some time - a day and a half, or two days wash week, as a minimum - to intercourse and influence and teaching the people in their homes, the school will continue to send its pupils back to something no better than heathenism. I am not hopeless with regard to these people. I believe something can be done for them and that there would be response. BUT - with the exception of Miss Reid's work during recent months - NOTHING HAS BEEN DONE FOR THEM FOR MANY YEARS.
In closing, let me thank Dr. Young, Mrs. Clark and Miss Bennett for their patience and kindness to Mrs. Wood and myself. We have been very conscious of some of our mistakes and blunders and our very manifest lack of efficiency, but are glad to hope that in the hands of experienced and tested workers, the future of the School may be much brighter than its past.

Very truly yours,

(Signed) Wm. R. Wood.

Dear Dr. Scott,

I trust you will pardon the liberty I take in writing you in a somewhat intimately personal way.

After nine months here in charge of the Indian School I am compelled to seek service back in some part of Canada where the climate is not damp as we have it here on the west coast. Neither my wife nor myself seem able to accommodate ourselves to the climatic conditions here.

We have had an opportunity of becoming fairly well initiated into Indian work here and have been attracted by its problems and its opportunities. With the generous assistance of the Department we have been able to put this institution in very much better shape than it was, and have some satisfaction in believing that it will now be capable of very much better work than at any time in the past.

I am wondering whether there may not be an opportunity of serving the Department of Indian Affairs in some capacity elsewhere. I have been impressed with the need for something that might help the Indian youth toward a quickened civic and public consciousness, something that would create in them some sense of unity both with others of their race and with the common life of Canada. The teaching in these schools is religious, an ideal which I have the fullest sympathy, but I fear that it often lacks the social and civic consciousness which is increasingly essential to real citizenship. That I would like to see done, and what I would like to have a hand in doing would be the sending into the hands of every pupil of the senior grades in these schools of a Canadian Life Bulletin issued twice a month and designed to bring these pupils into fresh and vital touch with the Canada of today, its interests, its events, its currents of thought and aspiration, the best things in its life for the quickening of the im-
individual's community and civic responsibility. I am convinced that such a service would be of the greatest value to the teachers and staffs of the schools as well broadening their outlook, giving them the much needed sense of unity with other educational workers, and affording them practical working material which many now lack.

I am not carried away by the theory that the civic consciousness can be created in a day. My experience in Ontario and in Manitoba with rural organization work among our white people has taught me that it is a matter of very slow education, but my contact with our Indian youth here leaves no doubt in my mind that the process can be begun with the Indian pupils and that with the right effort there comes real response. With the type of Bulletin which I suggest I believe that response might be, at least, somewhat accelerated. If handled with reasonable ability, but above all with insight and sympathy, I think it could be made one of the major factors in the development of the minds of our Indian charges.

I wonder if you will be good enough to tell me how the idea strikes you. Is it practicable? Is there any possibility that it might be worked into the policy of the Department? I should greatly appreciate an opportunity to try to work it out.

Very truly yours,

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th ultimo, with general reference to the regulations governing the education of Indians in Canada. The compulsory clauses of the Indian Act call for the attendance of Indian children from 7 to 15 years inclusive. The Department urges all principals, Indian agents and parents to keep the children that are enrolled in residential schools until they reach the age of 18, if it is considered in the best interests of the individual child to do so. The principal of a residential school and the Indian agent may recommend the discharge of a child at any age, if there are adequate reasons for such action. If Indian parents insist on the discharge of their children before they are 18, the principal of the school should refer them to the Indian agent and the Indian agent, if necessary, to the Department. When it is considered in the best interests of a pupil to stay until he or she is 18, every effort is made to have them remain in the school.

With reference to the second question in your letter, if a school principal believes that a home is not suitable for a child, he should so report to the Indian agent before granting holidays or discharge. Where there are children under school age in such a home, the Indian agent's attention should be drawn to the circumstances. The Department then considers ways and means of having the children reared in proper surroundings.

Concerning your third question, there was directed to you, under cover of January 8th, last, several circulars which indicate the Department's wishes. The principal of an Indian residential school is not considered the legal guardian of the pupils. The Department, however, is the legal guardian of all its Indian wards. I note that your copy of the Indian Act is not complete with amendments, and there is being forwarded to you, under separate cover, the latest copy.

Indian Youths Arrive in City

Husky Athletes From Ahousat Please With Their Manner

Descendants of the mighty Ahousat Indians, of the West Coast of Vancouver Island, ten boys from the Ahousat Indian residential school came here yesterday as a follock for a three-day holiday. Ranging from fifteen to eighteen years of age, the boys are of husky build with an average weight of 150 pounds.

Although this is their first visit to a city, and the party is large, the boys are saying little and observing much, their leader, Mr. Jones, says. The boy is extremely keen, and Mr. Jones is hopeful that they may learn a great deal from this visit.

In a forty-foot motor launch, the boat which brought them here, the native youths left Ahousat on Monday. It was planned to take the boat across to Victoria but rough weather, caused by a southeast gale off Cape Mudge, forced the change of plans. The boat was moored at Port Alberni and the party finished the journey by train. During their stay they will be billeted at the YMCA, and will be the guests of various friendly societies in the city. A number of basketball games have been arranged for their pleasure.

The Party

Names of the boys are: Allan George, Eugene Atleo, Ian Seymours, Francis Patrick, Joseph Billy, Thomas Paul, Simon Martin, Roy Alexander, and Norman Gordon. Accompanying Mr. Jones is Stanley Bailey, who is also with the party.

Mr. Jones is very pleased with his wards, whose manner and bearing has already drawn much attention in Victoria. The great achievement of Mr. Jones in influencing and educating these young men cannot be better appreciated when it is known that Ahousat and district are very primitive and isolated by the softening touch of civilization.

As Mr. Jones points out, many years ago massacres took place in the district. He also tells us that the Indians formerly lived at one time at the base of Gorge Mountain (now called Mount Albert). During the camping ground for the present war of Ahousat, the Indians attacked the camp of the settlers and killed all but one man. They adopted the women of the tribe and henceforth lived at Ahousat.

Clifford Tate states that he opened the lid of the extractor while the machine was still running, with the belt released and the brake applied, and he put his hand in. He does not know what happened afterwards nor does he know why he did this. The vocational instructor, who is frequently in the laundry while the machinery is running, generally engaged in repair work, states that two weeks ago he expressly warned the boy Clifford Tate against opening the lid of the extractor before the machine had entirely ceased to revolve.

The injury consisted of a complete break above the right elbow, the muscles and tendons of the upper arm being almost completely severed and the bones of the elbow crushed. It is almost impossible to conceive how such a serious injury could have been sustained when the belt was off the machine. There can be no doubt that the belt was off, as, as I have said, the lid of the machine cannot be opened until the belt has been levered back on the idle pulley. There is no possibility of getting an arm between the revolving basin and the rim of the machine, neither is there any centre post in the revolving part around which an arm could have been wrapped. It can only be presumed that the boy must have caught his hand in some of the clothing and that the arm was carried around the machine.

The accident can only be put down to the carelessness and disobedience of the boy himself.

The boy's arm was treated and placed in a splint by the school nurse after a tourniquet had been applied. He was immediately taken in charge of the nurse to Dr. Robertson at Tofino. The doctor, after examination, telephoned me that amputation was necessary immediately. I had anticipated this from the nature of the injury and I gave my consent. Dr. Robertson will no doubt have reported on the operation. My information is that the boy is progressing satisfactorily.

I telegraphed the boy's father and the grandfather at Sitinat as soon as possible after the operation. The grandfather, at my invitation, came to Tofino and is now with the boy.

I shall be glad to give you any further information you require. I have covered the facts exactly as known, with an explanation of the working of the machinery and the routine followed.

Re: Clifford Tate, accident.

Dear Sir,

Further to my telegram to you of last Saturday, Feb. 19th, re the accident to Clifford Tate, age 14, of the Nitinat Reserve, a pupil at this school, the following is a complete report:

The accident occurred in the school laundry on Saturday morning. Washing is necessary on three days each week. The routine consists of having one matron in charge of the laundry, with a senior boy, experienced in the running of the machinery, in charge of the machinery. One or two senior boys or girls assist. During the current term, owing to the shortage of senior girls, the senior boys have been generally used in the laundry.

While it is admitted that the laundry machinery generally is in poor condition, particularly the engine and the two washing machines, and the arrangement unsafe, as reported to the Department as long ago as August 17th 1935, since which time no appropriation has been made for renewal or repair, it cannot be said that the accident in question was due to the condition of the machinery.

The accident occurred with the extracting machine. This machine is run by a belt from the overhead shaft, running on a slack pulley when the machine is not in use. A lever pulls the belt over to the machine pulley to operate the machine. About a year ago I had this machine so fixed that when it is in operation the lid of the machine cannot be opened, and this arrangement is still good. A brake is operated by the foot at the base of the machine to stop the machine revolving after the belt has been released. This brake at present stops the machine entirely in exactly two minutes after the belt has been released. Instructions were positive that the lid must not be opened after the belt has been released and the brake applied until the machine has entirely stopped. Perforations in the lid makes it possible to see when the machine has stopped before the lid is opened.

At the time of the accident, the matron, Miss Hodgkinson, a boy, Edgar Benson, in charge of the machinery, and Clifford Tate as assistant, were in the laundry. The extractor had just been in operation and Benson had released the belt and applied the brake to stop the machine. He had then gone outside the laundry to get a tub to put the clothes in out of the extractor. The matron was sorting clothes in the laundry. She heard Clifford Tate shout that his arm was broken. She turned round and found him holding his right arm with his left hand. She did not notice at that time whether the extractor was stopped. She took the boy immediately to the nurse in the school. Edgar Benson states that he came into the laundry one or two minutes after the accident and found the machine entirely stopped and proceeded to remove the clothes.

In a remittance just to hand from the W.M.S., Toronto, for the balance of the Per Capita grant for the quarter ending March of this year, I note that the Department appears to have limited the average attendance for which grant is paid to this school at 65 pupils. OTTAWA, 1st February, 1904

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Rev. Dr Mackay of the Presbyterian Missionary Society forwards sketch plans for the new boarding school at Ahousaht. No specifications or estimates accompanied them but the cost of the building is placed at about $7000.00. Of this amount the Department is to contribute $1500.00 which is included in the Supplementary Estimates for this year. Dr Mackay states that it is the intention of the Missionary Society to send a builder from Ontario to superintend the erection of the new structure, and he asks that the plans be approved of with permission to make such changes as further experience may find necessary or desirable.

If detailed plans and specifications have to be submitted it would cause considerable delay in beginning the work. The plans sent in provide for a building which should be suitable to the locality and will have accommodation for fully 80 pupils. The Department at present only provides for 25.

In that climate there will be no difficulty about heating and ventilation, and a suitable site where good drainage can be had should be easily selected. I think the Department would be quite safe in giving the necessary permission to proceed with the work in the manner indicated in the plans.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, 2nd February, 1904.

The Deputy Supt. General,-

The three plans submitted by the Rev. Mr. Mackey of the proposed boarding school at Ahousat, B.C., are sketches of a commodious building 68 ft. X 46 ft., three stories high with a basement. The building appears to be one that should properly fill the requirements of a boarding school, and as far as the sketches show no reasonable exception can be taken thereto. The cost thereof cannot be less than the sum roughly estimated, namely $7,000.

As the Department only contributes $1,500 towards the cost of erection, it would appear that Mr. Mackey's request to have the plans generally approved and to allow latitude for such changes as further experience will be found necessary or desirable should receive favourable consideration.

For the further assurance of the Department, if it is considered desirable or necessary, the sum of $500 might be retained until the building is finally completed, and a report has been received thereon from the Indian Agent.

Chief Surveyor.

Memo.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, 21st June, 1904.

The Deputy Supt. General,-

Referring to Mr. Vowell's letter of the 31st ultimo, and enclosures, I beg to state that I think no exception should be taken to the amended plans submitted for the proposed new boarding school building at Ahousaht, B.C. The re-arrangement appears to be convenient in all particulars. It is to be especially noted that the new building is very much more elaborate, and consequently more expensive, than the one first proposed.

As noted in Mr. Green's memorandum, there is no new plan submitted for the third floor. Mr. Vowell draws attention to the fact that the boys' and girls' dormitories, which are situated on this floor, are close together. It is presumed that no radical change will be made on this floor. It is shown on the first plan submitted that there is a solid partition between the dormitories, and no connection between them on that floor. It is necessary to go down to the next floor, in order to pass from one dormitory to the other. This should be satisfactory.

I may note it is desirable, if possible, to arrange for a small bed-room in each dormitory in which a grown person may sleep who can at the same time be in immediate attendance to preserve order.

Blueprint copies of the plans have been made, and have been placed in the folder on file herewith.

Chief Surveyor.

Notes made by Mr. A.H. Green, Victoria, re altered plan of Ahousaht Boarding School building.

In the new plan the following alterations have been made.

**BASEMENT.**

Both the Boys and Girls playrooms have been reduced in size by 6 feet in width.

Two additional rooms 9.8 x 34.6 and 9.6 x 31 called Boys' Hall and Girls' Hall have been made.

Bairry and Root and Wood room have been dispensed with and converted into Laundry and Drying room.

The flue for heater is placed inside the building instead of outside.

**1st FLOOR.**

The verandah has been moved from front of the building to the back of it.

The kitchen, pantry, and store room though occupying the same space have been re-arranged.

The small class room has been enlarged by 4 ft. and the office reduced by that much.

The Private Dining room, Bed-room, and wash room and store room have been converted into a sitting and dining room.

A flight of steps has been made to the front door.

**2nd FLOOR.**

In both boys' and girls' bathrooms there are but two baths instead of four.

Sitting room has been converted into Private bath room and girls cloak room.

Bed room has been converted partly into Boys cloak room and part thrown into Teacher's room.

Private bathroom and store room has been dispensed with and the re-arranged with the Matron's and Principal's room so as to make another bedroom.

No 3rd floor plan on new drawings.

The whole of the elevations have been changed so much that no comparison can be made. There appears, however, to be more light in the basement and less in the 3rd floor.
Note made by Indian Superintendent.

Mr. Green thinks improvement has been effected. Not quite so much light in 3rd floor, and dormitory boys and girls together, etc.

The water supply is obtained from a well situated about 150 yards from the School in a low-lying part of the ground, in close proximity to the cow barn; and the latter drains in the direction of the well. The whole water supply is surface water, and is naturally liable to contamination from barn seepage, and the well is not suitably lined to exclude surface water. The pipe from the well to the School is above ground and is liable to freeze in cold weather and cut off the supply entirely for hours at a time, when no water for domestic use or fire protection can be secured. Opinions have been expressed to the principal that the water supply under these conditions is a menace to the health of the children.

Suggested Remedy.

That a well of sufficient capacity be dug on higher ground in a position clear of all possible School or barn seepage, and that the same be lined with concrete to a suitable depth to prevent cave-in and to exclude surface water.

The present tank capacity is insufficient. The tank is situated on the second floor and does not provide a water supply to the upper floor either for domestic use or fire protection. Suggested that two tanks of same capacity be installed on upper floor. The second tank should be of galvanized iron.

The water system through the School is not satisfactory, as it consists of half inch pipe with no provision for detecting obstructions, necessitating the disconnection of practically the whole system to remedy any obstruction, the water being at times shut off for hours while obstructions are being located and remedied. The half pipe inch pipe is not large enough as a main system.

II. Toilet Systems.

The toilet system of the School is intended to be a flush system, for staff and girls' toilets, located outside the building. This system was devised and installed by an
amateur and has never given satisfactory service, and is now entirely useless, and should be reconstructed and properly installed.

The septic tank to which the present flush system leads is constructed of lumber and does not function as a septic tank, and has to be frequently cleared by hand. A new cement tank properly constructed is necessary.

The boys' toilets are earth closets, near the shore, and are unsanitary in warm weather and should be provided for in the flush system.

III. Heating Problems.

The heating apparatus of the school is hot air. The furnace is in the basement and is situated near the N. E. Corner, which necessitates long stretches of pipe from the furnace itself to where they enter the building, which wastes much of the heat before it is of use for heating the building. The heating plant itself is too small and in my opinion needs replacing by one of a suitable size placed in a suitable position to get the best results, and the distribution of the heat should be arranged by a qualified mechanic capable of getting the best results from any plant that may be installed in place of the present one, which is worn out and was never satisfactory.

The children's dormitories are never heated by the heating system as there is never enough heat generated to reach them. The same applies to the staff sleeping quarters.

IV. Recreation Rooms.

The recreation rooms in the building are one for boys and one for girls, each of which is about 12 by 12 feet with no means of heating. Both rooms are too small for twenty children to play in.

V. Drying Room.

The question of a drying room needs attention. Some old worn out stoves are being used in one corner of the building, but this method is not satisfactory.

VI. Cooking apparatus

The present range is past repair and needs replacing. Its cooking surface 2 x 4 feet is not large enough.
VII. Engine.

The engine at present in use is past being able to provide sufficient power for the extractor, and is constantly breaking down under that load, and has actually come to the condition where it cannot run the lighting plant. It is of obsolete pattern and would not be worth repairing.

Solution.

The following appears to be a reasonable solution of some of the troubles.

1. Water supply as recommended.

2. Power. That when a suitable well has been located and constructed, that a power and pump house be built at the well but so arranged as to be free from any possible likelihood of contaminating the water. The power house to house the engine, pump, electric storage batteries, washing extractor, under one roof, clear of the School building and leaving the basement space available for recreation rooms for both girls and boys, and reducing the fire hazard of the School by it being free from the engine and gasoline.

3. Sanitary system as suggested.

4. The heating proposition to be looked into by a qualified mechanic and suggestions with estimates prepared by him.

Dear Mr. Neill,

I appreciate very cordially indeed your courtesy and your kind interest in our work here.

We had a visit from Mr. Frost last week and he made a very thorough examination of the premises here, following which he will, I judge report conditions to the department. While in some respects good work was done here by Mr. Miller, he had allowed the equipment to run down to the very last degree during the last year or two, so that today there is scarcely a machine or utensil about the place that is not worn out and in need of replacement.

The same statement applies to the water system, the toilet system and the heating system. Each of these is in a state that requires constant tinkering, and even with that there are times when both staff and children have to endure a great deal of discomfort. This necessarily means a heavy handicap on efficiency. The results which are aimed at both by the Government and by the Church will never be fully attained while ordinary comfort cannot be obtained in the school.

I am most concerned, however, with the fact that there is good reason to judge that these conditions are having a very serious effect on the health of the children. There have been during the last two years or so, an unusual number of deaths of pupils and ex-pupils of the school, an unusual number of discharges from the school on account of physical ailments, and at the present time I am assured by the Field Nurse that the proportion of really healthy children, especially among the girls, was abnormally low. When one recognizes that they sleep in dormitories from which the chill of the B.C. winter is never removed by artificial heat, that the water they drink is never ordinarily drinkable, and that the toilet system exhibits none of the features of ordinary decency, much less comfort, one cannot but have misgivings as to the cause of some of their troubles.
After giving the situation a good deal of careful consideration, and trying to get it out for some five weeks, I have reached the conclusion that unless the health basis can be established on some such lines as they are in other schools, (that is with a heating system that will take some of the damp of the winter out of the rooms, that will give the children pure water to drink, and that will provide comfortable closets) I simply could not think of attempting to do the work. I am not thinking of luxuries but only of ordinary comfort.

So while we recognize that the cost will be very considerable, we are hoping that the Department can be led to see that we are seeking only a minimum, and that the need is absolutely vital, if the interests of the children are not to be sacrificed. I am putting it up to our own church people that they must undertake a part of the needed equipment, and I think they will. My hope is that they will put in the well, the engine and pump house and the kitchen range, which may run to $700.00 or $750.00. If they do, then we trust that the Department will see to the heating and the water and toilet systems.

I judge that Mr. Frost who saw when he was here the other day the heating system utterly failing, the water system obstructed and frozen, and the toilets requiring to be cleared by the principal, will urge the instalment of the needed equipment, and if with your experience and acquaintance with the Indian work, you find it possible to add your influence, I feel sure that we may hope that our plea will be successful. With such equipment I am more than hopeful of what may be done for the young Indians of Ahousat.

I am afraid I am getting out of touch with the world of politics since I came up here, but I shall be watching with interest the course of the Session. I know most of the Manitoba Members fairly well, and count some of them among my best friends.

Hoping for a chance to meet and get better acquainted with you sometime, and counting on your good offices in my present undertaking,

I am, very truly yours,

(Sgd.) Wm. R. Wood.

Dear Sir,

Taking charge recently of the Indian School here, I find conditions that in my judgment demand attention by the Department. The Indian Agent, Mr. R. E. Frost of Alberni spent two days with us last week, and, I presume, will report on conditions as he found them.

I may mention without going into unnecessary detail that, in my judgment, as in that of Mr. Frost, the School cannot do its work unless provision is made for heating the children's quarters, for giving them pure water and for decent toilet facilities. We have none of these at the present time. And in my judgment the work of the School has suffered inexcusably in recent years because of it.

My plea in seeking these provisions is simply that without them we have not the conditions which may be expected to produce healthy existence. Looking back over the record of the School during the past two or three years I find that there have been an unusual number of deaths among pupils and ex-pupils, and unusual number of discharges from the School on account of ill-health, and that at the present time the number of pupils, especially of girls, who are normally healthy is startlingly low. I am convinced that they suffer constantly from the lack of the elementary conditions of human comfort, and that the three things mentioned are the very minimum of requirement to give them an adequate health basis.

The cost will be very considerable, but without such improvement in conditions the School can never do the work expected of it. I may say that I am pressing upon the Women's Missionary Society of the United Church the necessity of their bearing the cost of some of the needed equipment. I think there is good reason to hope that they may undertake to provide the well, the engine and pump house and perhaps a new kitchen range. I am confident they will do all that they can to assist in putting the School in a position to function efficiently.

I shall be glad to furnish any details of information needed and to assist in any way possible, and trust that we may hope to have work begun on the new utilities early in spring.

Sir,

I have the honour to submit herewith a copy of a letter from the Rev Principal of the Ahousaht Indian Residential School, setting out certain conditions as they now exist at that school, and some suggestions for their improvement or remedy, for the information of the Department.

In bringing these matters to the Department's attention, I beg to state that I landed at Ahousaht School on Saturday January 26th at about 11.30 p.m., and found the electric lighting system out of order (no lights) due to a break down of the engine which supplies the power for the system; a mechanic, Mr. W. Bond, was then at work repairing the engine and some time in the early morning temporary repairs were effected and lights were available, but Mr. Bond stated that the repairs were only temporary and might give out at any time, further, that the engine is not now repairing and if repaired is too low powered to carry the load, which is the cause of the short life of the machine and the cause of the frequent trouble. On Sunday night the 27th the engine was again temporarily out of order for a time and no lights were available.

On the night of my arrival at Ahousaht School the weather was unusually cold for the West Coast area and during the night all water connections outside the school and some inside became frozen. The rest of Sunday 27th was spent by the Rev Principal, some of the staff and myself in thawing out the water system to obtain water which we succeeded in doing some time in the afternoon. On Sunday night 27th the weather became more severe with a considerable fall of snow and all water leads both fresh and waste inside and outside the school were frozen solid and thawing them out was impossible, all water for use in the school had to be carried by hand by the pupils and staff from the well which is some 200 yards from the school.

The heating system of the school, when new and in good order was quite inadequate for the school under such conditions of weather as have existed from the 26th ultimo to date and as the plant is badly worn and defectively installed, the result can be readily understood, the school building was uncomfortably cold, frost forming on the bedclothes of some of the staff during the night and was quite noticeable the next morning.

Owing to the failure of the water system, the toilet system was also disorganized causing septic tank and other trouble, which were examined by me with a view to effecting their present remedy and future prevention.

The water supply for the school is obtained from a well, not lined, which is located about 200 yards from the school building and about a third of that distance from the cow barn with a natural slope from the barn to the well, the top of the well is flush with the ground surface, the greater portion of the water in the well is surface water and as is unlined, contamination from the barn is most probable, on my visit on 26th and 27th of January I found considerable ice round the well and on breaking it I found signs of barn seepage in it. The water is pumped from the well to the school by a small engine and the pipes leading to...
Sir,—
the school are supported on posts and raised from 6 to 8 feet above ground and have no protection from frost, which makes water trouble a certainty during such weather as the present.

The attached list of defects in water supply, heating, sanitary arrangements, drying and recreation rooms with the suggested improvements was made on the ground and at the time of my visit to the school at the end of January and is a fair statement of the conditions at the school as they then were, and as the cold weather still continues I fear they have not improved to date.

I respectfully recommend that this matter be examined by a fully qualified person and suggestions and estimates be prepared as to cost of their correction.

I beg to point out that most of these defects are brought out by the present lengthy period of severe weather the like of which has not occurred on the West Coast during the past 20 years.

Dear Mr. Frost,

Following your recent visit to and inspection of the Ahousaht Indian School premises, I am enclosing a copy of the statement then drawn up, setting out conditions and needs as they appear at this time, and proposing certain solutions.

May I say that I have conferred with the School Staff, all of whom have longer acquaintance than I with these conditions, and they are agreed that the statement is a fair and accurate representation of conditions as obtained, and that such reforms as are proposed are vitally and urgently necessary, if results are to be expected in the training of children here.

In facing the solution of these problems I recognize the factor of dual control; a church organization on the one hand and the Indian Department on the other. I may tell you that I am putting before the Women's Missionary Society and the Home Mission Board with which they are associated, the necessity of their undertaking a substantial share of the cost. To be specific, I am urging them to become responsible for the cost of the well, the engine and engine house—the most immediately urgent of our needs—and if possible also the kitchen range, which roughly might perhaps be estimated at $750.00.

If they can—and I am somewhat hopeful they may—undertake this, then I think it reasonable to hope that the Indian Department will undertake the installation of the water system, including toilets, and a heating plant for the building.

Recognizing, as I am sure you do, that the school cannot do effective work until these basic conditions, not of luxury, but of elementary decency and comfort are met, I hope you will press upon the Department the urgency of the need. It is not only the measure of discomfort results to both Staff and children which is conducive to efficiency, the matter is far more serious than that. The nature of the present weather makes the so-called toilet system a positive menace to health. To house forty children in a damp building where they are often chilled and shivering is to make them fertile ground for disease. And it is not to be wondered at that there has been in recent years a very unusual number of deaths and discharges from school due to physical ailments, nor that at the present time the proportion of thoroughly healthy children in the school is alarmingly low. I am convinced that if we can give them pure water, clean toilets and housing in which the chill and dampness are removed we can change the health situation for the better in a single season.

I am communicating also with the Commissioner and the Department, and earnestly hope that some action may be secured in the near future. With very cordial appreciation of your interest in the well being of the school.

I am yours truly,

(signed) Wm. R. Wood,
Principal.

Dear Mr. Frost:

Since your visit I have been endeavouring to inform myself with regard to some of the possibilities of solving our school problems, and one line of my investigation I think is of sufficient importance to put before you.

It is in reference to fuel. As you know the fuel has been wood, burned in a furnace not designed for wood. Fir, which is the wood used, is increasingly difficult to get. The men who have been getting it in the past can do better by taking their logs to saw mills. There will be increasing demand for this material for lumber and at prices that will make it practically impossible to use it for fuel. One business man quotes $15.00 per cord as the price one might expect to pay for it in the very near future, if not now.

From two entirely different quarters I have met men who assure me that oil as fuel is now practicable and once the plant is installed would reduce the cost by more than fifty percent. Simple, safe and easily controlled burners are now obtainable, and so many plants are now using oil on the Coast that there is no problem of getting supplies. I am convinced that a steam or hot water system with oil as fuel would in a period of five years prove more economical by one half than any hot air system that could be put into this institution.

I hope the possibilities of this course will be investigated, before a decision is made as to the future heating of the building.

Very truly yours,

(signed) Wm. R. Wood, Principal.

Notes on above.

1. Heating costs undoubtedly much less with oil fuel.
2. Believed fire hazards would be increased.
3. With steam heating apparatus, an attendant with Engineers certificate would compulsory.

Dear Sir,

May I bring to your attention one more phase of the situation affecting the School here.

Since writing you a few days ago, I have been making such investigations as were possible as to the best course to follow. It has been strongly impressed upon me that fir which has been the usual fuel here and which now costs anywhere from ten to fifteen dollars a cord is going to be increasingly hard to get and increasingly costly. Those who have been getting the logs for fuel are finding it more remunerative to sell them to the saw-mills, and there will be increasing opportunity for this as the West Coast develops. In fact the burning of the kind of timber we have been using must come to an end very soon.

What is the alternative? There is no hardwood, and hemlock and the other woods available are poor fuel. A considerable number of mills, reduction plants, etc., along the coast are now using oil as their regular fuel and finding it more economical than anything else they can procure. Men from two different places in discussing the school problem have assured me that: (1) Oil is available; tankers make regular trips up the coast. (2) The cost of oil would be, in their opinion, very much less than half the cost of wood. (3) With a steam or hot water system installed, the cost of heating the School in this climate could be brought under a dollar a day.

I have not yet been able to investigate the aspect of installment of the oil-burning plant, but would suggest that even if it should cost three or four hundred dollars more than the hot air system, the cost would be much more than offset by the first two or three years reduction of the cost of fuel. In view of this I would urge that consideration be given to the advisability of installing an oil-burning steam or hot-water system for heating the Ahousat School.

Dear Sir,

With further reference to the Ahousat School, may I say that I have definite word from the Church authorities in which they are committed to the expenditure of $750 toward putting the School in good condition, having particularly in mind the providing of a well, an engine and pump house, and a kitchen range. I am in a position to say also that some minor adjustments and repairs in the building will also be taken care of through Church funds.

My attention has been drawn to the fact that there was a difference of opinion some ten years ago or so when the present building was erected between the Missionary Society of the Presbyterian Church and the Department as to the wisdom of building in this location. The Society favored building here and the Department opposed it, regarding the location as unsuitable. The Society went ahead and erected the building. It may be doubted whether their action was the best, for there are some things which may be argued in favor of other locations and against this one.

In my judgment the fact that there stands to the credit of the work generally a building which has done duty for ten years, and which can be put into fairly workable shape, is an unanswerable argument against locating elsewhere at this stage. I think that with a heating system and a water and toilet system of modern type installed the building can be made to do good service, and that to remove the children to any other place or to attempt to find room for them in any other school would in the long run entail very much heavier expenditures.

I welcome very cordially the proposal of your letter of February 14th to secure a report from a competent heating and plumbing contractor on the building and its requirements, and trust that it may be possible to have such a report in the near future. It would, I judge, be very specially advantageous if the actual work of such replacements as may be decided upon could be done during the early summer. Our vacation period is from May 1st, and it would be well to have the work complete when the children return in June.

Dear Sir;-

I have made a survey of the Ahousaht Mission School,I find the heating system is hot air and is entirely too small to heat the building beside being a very poor heating system for that kind of building where constant heat and an even temperature is required,I am recommending that a hot water system of heating be installed with an oil burner,The supply of fir wood is limited,in fact it is almost impossible to get it anywhere near that school.Cool and fuel oil will have to be used,fuel oil is the easier to handle.The approximate cost of a heating system with oil burner is three thousand nine hundred fifty dollars $3950.00.

A pump house large enough to accommodate the electric light plant the pump and the laundry machines should be built.A gas engine large enough to do the pumping,run the laundry and electric light plants,should be installed.The present engine is badly worn and is too small to do the work.

Dear Mr Frost,

Since examining Mr Nelson's estimates for the structural and other carpentry work in connection with the School I am impelled to write my opinion that several items in the list could be done for figures much lower than his.

I have in mind items 2, 3, 4, & 5 in his list. These are pieces of straight carpentry work involving no very intricate problems and requiring only ordinary ability. His estimate for the four items totals $1825.00. After some figuring and consultation I am convinced that these four items can be done for $1250.00. It may be that my figuring involves the use of some of the material still present in use in the building while Mr Nelson may be counting on using all new material, and it may be that I have in mind a rate of wages lower than is paid in some places, but I am very confident that the material can be gotten and the work done within the sum I have mentioned, and that nothing will be sacrificed that is desirable for the building. The other items in Mr Nelson's list involve mechanical and technical problems and probably require the figures he associates with them, but these four I am sure can be done at the lower figure.

So confident am I of this possibility that I am willing to undertake it with local help, if given assurance that the Department will go forward with the other improvements somewhat along the lines indicated in the estimates which have been prepared. Dear Sir,

May I take the liberty of placing before you some considerations regarding the School at this place.

When I took charge at the opening of the year I found conditions that in my opinion militated fatally against efficiency. In particular there was no heating system for the building as a whole, and staff and children existed in conditions of constant discomfort especially in winter. The water system was pitifully inadequate and the water not wholesome. There were no inside toilets, and there were certain structural defects which made segregation of the sexes difficult.

After taking time to size up the situation, I decided for myself two things, first, that I would on no account think of attempting permanent service here unless there could be devised some way of remedying these outstanding defects; second, that all things considered, the Building was worth improving, and could be made fairly adequate for its purpose. So I made up my mind to see immediately, this season, what could be done.

Early in the year I secured a pledge from the Home Mission Committee of the United Church that they would make a special grant of $750 with a view to providing a new well, an engine and pump and pump-house and if possible a kitchen range. At the same time I communicated with your Department and had a favorable reply promising cooperation. Later in pursuance of this promise Mr. Frost, the Agent, was authorized to secure the services of a competent heating and plumbing contractor to report on the needs of the School and the cost of meeting them. He came in due time, and I presume, made his report.
That appears to be as far as we have got. I had expected that his report would recommend quite definitely certain work, and that these recommendations would be considered by the Department, and if accepted contracts would be let and the work proceeded with. We were particularly anxious that the structural changes and the installation of heating and water systems be made during the vacation which runs from May 1st. If not done then we should almost be compelled to ask for an extension of the vacation period. So far no action has been taken and more than half the vacation period has passed.

I may say that we are prepared to accept whatever recommendations Mr. Hanna (whom Mr. Frost engaged) may have made, and to cooperate to the utmost in expediting the work. We believe he is fully acquainted with the conditions and capable of judging what is most likely to serve the purpose. But we are getting very anxious indeed to have the work got under way.

May I say that from the Church side we are putting through improvements which represent much more than the $750 mentioned. If we can carry out the plans on which we are now working we will have of new equipment since last year the following:- A new well, cement cased and galvanized iron top, a six horse power engine, a laundry washer, a power pump capable of supplying a full house system, a building fifty feet by sixteen feet for housing the light plant the laundry, the pump, engine etc., and a fine new play lawn gradually being extended and ultimately to enclose 1000 square yards. In addition the changes we propose for the School Building and the class room, will provide ample room, in dormitory and elsewhere for at least ten additional children.

Our objective, which we are pursuing as strenuously as we are able, is, first, a building so comfortable as to provide an adequate basis for health, and second, a chance to give the young Indians a thorough real preparation for life. It will help us greatly if action re the heating and water systems can be speeded up so as to be completed fairly early in the summer.

Very truly yours,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

I have just had from Mr. E. E. Frost, Indian Agent of Port Alberni, B. C., a copy of your letter of May 15th to him in reference to the heating system to be installed in our school.

In response I have wired you today in the following terms,

Ahousat, B. C. May 25th, 1929.
J. D. McLean, Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa. Re. Ahousat School. Willing to use any fuel Mr. Frost's expert recommends, but wood cannot be got. Urge early action re heating and water systems. School health and efficiency require them. Vacation already half over. May require vacation extended if work is not completed. Letter following.

W. R. Wood, Principal.

Now, to get this matter clear let me say that I have no plans or prejudices in this matter of heating. It is true I wrote the Department on February 21st advising consideration of oil as the fuel. This was done because, first, I had become aware of the increasing difficulty and cost of wood; second, because landing coal is something of a problem on this coast; and, third because two men with some experience had assured me that coal could be used very much more economically than either wood or coal. In response to my letter I had a communication signed by A. F. McKenzie intimating that Mr. Frost had been authorized to have a competent heating and plumbing contractor look into the situation and that he would probably report and recommend in the matter. To me this was entirely satisfactory and in due time Mr. Frost brought Mr. Hanna of Port Alberni to investigate and report.
I discussed the matter with Mr. Hanna, and while I put no pressure on in the direction of having him recommend oil as the fuel, my recollection is that he agreed with the view that oil would heat the building more economically than any other fuel.

Being called in as an expert in the matter I think he is the man who should recommend, and I am quite ready to cooperate in working out whatever plan he recommends, if it is feasible at all. My one concern is to get a system installed which will enable us to make the school ordinarily comfortable both for the pupils and for the staff.

Similarly in the matter of the water and toilet system I had expected that Mr. Hanna would very definitely recommend a system which in his judgment would be the best for our building.

In passing may I remark that I find myself quite unable to get the point of your statement that "it is not economical or satisfactory to operate an oil burner where the school is generating their own electric power." I do not understand why the lighting of a building by electricity should be any barrier to heating it with oil. If Mr. Hanna thinks coal is the fuel we should use, I am prepared to try it, but we would have to devise some better landing system than we yet have. I believe, however, that can be done.

May I add that through a special grant from the Home Mission Committee of the United Church we are going ahead with certain external improvements. Placing the light engine and batteries away from the main building we are securing room for two large playrooms in the basement. Replacing the old washers with an up-to-date laundry washer, we are providing room for all such machinery in a 50' by 16' building which will also house the pump. We have a new well ready with cement casing and galvanized iron top, and are in process of levelling a play lawn at the south side of the School which will by and by be extended to at least 1000 square yards. We are determined to put the School in shape to do creditable work, to provide adequate accommodation for at least ten more pupils, and to give to both staff and pupils what they have never had - ordinary comfortable and healthy quarters.

But everything depends on the Department putting in the water and heating systems. We earnestly hope it may be speeded up as much as possible. And we pledge our fullest cooperation to that end.

Very truly yours,

[Signature]

Principal

R. Wood in payment for work at the school, and in reply I have to refer you to your letter of the 24th September with which you submitted paylists as follows:

August, week 12th to 17th ............ $69.00

" " 26th to 31st ............ $69.00
Sept., " 2nd to 4th ............ $34.50

The total of these paylists is $238.00, not $234.00 as mentioned in your letter quoted.

I have to point out also that under cover of a letter dated the 24th September you submitted a paylist for the week ended 21st September, the amount of which was $76.00, and with your letter of the 26th September you submitted a paylist for the week ended the 14th September, the amount of which was $84.00. The total of all the paylists submitted (namely, $238.00, $76.00, and $84.00) is $398.00, the amount of the cheque, No. 3696, issued in Mr. Wood's favour, which cheque you returned.

If an error occurred in making payment, it would seem to be the result of your having sent in paylists without sufficient explanation. The Department will hold the cheque until hearing from you again. You should state whether it should be re-inclosed to be handed to Mr. Wood.

Yours truly,

Nov. 1st, 1929

Secretary Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

I have your letter with further reference to a laundry washer for the School.

I note that you suggest consulting the authorities of the United Church on the matter. Perhaps I owe you an explanation in regard to my letter. When your telegram reached me it read 'such' instead of 'church' by an error in transmission and of course I failed to get your meaning. I took it to mean that the Department would supply the machine.

Now as regards the church here in the situation. Early in the year I put up to the Church committee its obligation to do something fairly substantial for the School if they were to expect the Department to take the heavier burden of the heating and water systems. In response they at once assumed the amount of $750 to cover the cost of a well, an engine and pump, a pump house and if possible a kitchen range. Now I can report that this obligation has been carried out. Instead of building a small pump house we built a structure 50' x 16' adapted to house the engine, the light plant, the laundry machinery and including a room for ironing and other laundry operations. Then going beyond their original undertaking money was provided from church funds for enlarging the classroom and fitting up a boys' playroom and finally for providing a winch and cable to help in meeting our landing difficulties. The simple fact is that the Church has expended during the season not merely $750 but considerably over a thousand dollars for helping make the premises here fit for effective work. But you will recognize that this makes it impossible to ask for a further extension just now.

And yet the washer is immediately and urgently necessary. I will recall that the investigator appointed by the Department (Mr. Hanna) so reported in his first examination of the premises. The missionary committee has built the laundry house. I still hope the Department will put the washer in it. I am sure if you could see the physical toll required to operate the outworn hand washers here, there would be no hesitation.

Compelled by health to give up the principalship I am leaving by the boat which carries this letter. A capable and experienced man, Rev. Joseph Jones, is taking my place. I trust it will be found possible to crown your very generous help by providing him yet before the end of the year with this very necessary piece of equipment.

With cordial appreciation of your goodness to me in my period of service here, I am,

Very truly yours,

I have the honour to refer to the Department's letter of June 7th, 1929, Para 3, authorizing the expenditure of not more than $1000.00 dollars for the erection of fire escape and water tank trestle and water tank at Ahousaht Indian Residential School.

These items have been completed at an approximate cost of $750.00.

When the estimates for this work were prepared, no provision was made for roofing the water tank, and as the health of the school is endangered from the pollution of the water supply by the large numbers of sea gulls and crows that frequent the school at certain seasons, the necessity for roofing the tank is apparent.

I respectfully recommend, for the favourable consideration of the Department, that the tank be roofed with light galvanized iron, with man hole to permit of the cleaning of the tank when necessary, at an approximate cost of $62.00.

I have the honour to submit to the Department, for consideration, a number of requests for improvements at the Ahousaht Indian Residential School, as asked for by the Rev. Principal of that school, with the estimated approximate cost of the same.

1. One 12 horse power Marine gas engine for school launch.
   Remarks: The Rev. Principal has re-planked and repaired the school launch hull and the same is now in good condition; the engine previously in boat declared by Machine Shop mechanic to be valueless and beyond repair. I recommend the supply of a 12 horse power Vivien engine at approximate cost of $550.00, factory at Vancouver; this price is subject to revision most probably downward. A launch is very necessary at this school for freight work.

2. Two machine drive washing machines, shafting, and belting, at an approximate cost of $175.00.
   Remarks: These machines are needed as all the hand washers except one are worn out and will have to be replaced as soon as possible; two machine drive washers will be able to care for all the laundry work of the school; they could be operated by the engine now installed in the laundry building. I respectfully recommend the favourable consideration of this request.

3. Grant of $100.00 for digging test pits for improved water supply. This matter has been referred to the Department under letter No. 269/30, dated Port Alberni, 12.8.30.

4. 5500 feet of 2"x12" Cedar planking, and 2000 feet of 4"x4" Cedar for posts and stringers, to improve girls play ground, approximate cost $150.00.
   Remarks: I respectfully suggest that this be held in abeyance until an Inspector of schools has been appointed and his opinion obtained on the matter.

5. $50.00 to clear cart road and put in culverts to enable fire wood to be hauled from bush.
   Remarks: I respectfully recommend the favourable consideration of this item as wood is the fuel used for cooking and laundry purposes.

6. $200.00 to clear present ditch system and improve and extend same.
   Remarks: The present ditching system has been choked by erosion and need clearing out and improving as the failure of the system caused the flooding of the ground used for cultivation, and the entire loss of $90.00 worth of seeds sown this spring; but I consider the necessary work can be done at a cost not to exceed $150.00 which I respectfully recommend.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,

I have the honour to bring the attention of the Department to the condition of the water supply at Ahousaht Indian Residential School.

On visiting that school on 5th and 6th instants I found the water supply, as provided by the recently constructed well, very low and quite inadequate for the domestic needs of the school; it had been necessary to shut off a portion of the sanitary arrangements of the school owing to the shortage of water. The old well had been brought into use for washing, bathing and other purposes of that kind.

The new well was pumped dry at about 10 a.m. on 5th instant and at 2 p.m. had regained 16 inches of water and at 5 p.m. the depth of water was 23 inches at which level the water became stationary; this amount of water is not quite sufficient to half fill the storage or pressure tank and with the compulsory constant use of water from it, the tank is suffering to some extent from drought; under these conditions there would be little or no water available for fire protection, even under the curtailed use of water the tank can not be brought to a satisfactory level.

In consequence of these conditions the Rev Principal has applied for an appropriation of $100.00, to sink test pits in search of water to augment the present supply.

I am of the opinion that an increase in the supply can be obtained by going deeper (I take the flow of water in the present well to indicate this) but further depth cannot be got in the present well as the present bottom is on rock for a large part but I am of opinion that the rock can be avoided and greater depth attained in its immediate vicinity, and by constructing and addition to the present well of a greater depth would provide a more ample supply and a larger reservoir, but this can only be verified by sinking test pits, hence the Rev Principal's application for an appropriation for that purpose.

I may add that the water shortage is general in West Coast settlements, as no moisture has fallen for the past five weeks.

I am enclosing that portion of the Rev. Principal's letter dealing with the question of water supply, for the Department's information.

Enc.

Your obedient servant,

My dear Mr. Ferrier:

There has just come to this office a letter from Rev. Joseph Jones, the Principal of the Shousaht Indian Residential School, B.C., and there are two paragraphs in the letter which I think should be sent on to you at once as they refer to pressing matters which Mr. Jones thinks should be attended to without delay. These are the paragraphs to which I refer:

"The road to the Matilda Creek is very necessary and now is a very opportune time to do the work. The Provincial Government has a gang of men working on a road from the Government dock where the steamer lands to the end of the Creek. If we could join on to this road we could take a truck from the school to the dock. Another proposition is to build a road directly to the creek. The present method of landing our supplies on the open beach is too destructive to goods, boats, and clothing to say nothing of our patience. The first trip of the month we were swamped, not through neglect or incompetence, but because men cannot successfully outmatch the sea in power. The road to the Creek or the road to the dock would avoid all this loss and worry.

"The lighting plant is only half the power we need and has been patched up and tinkered with to keep it going. I know it would not pass a Fire Insurance Inspector. Mr. Ferrier told me some time ago to wire him if it broke down, but I cannot allow it to collapse, we need the light so I watch it very carefully. We only have half the lights we need."

Mr. Beaton is absent from the office just now and I am sending this extract on to you at once to ask if there is any possibility of the Government helping with the building of the road to connect with the piece of road which the Provincial Government is building. It would seem from his letter almost essential that this road should be built so that there will be a direct connection from the school to the nearest doctor.

Evidently according to the letter Mr. Jones has been in touch with you about the lighting system. Could not the Department help put this in shape as soon as possible?

Thanking you for your kindness and attention to both Mr. Beaton and myself during our recent visit to Ottawa, and also for the paper with the reference to the opening of the school at Brandon which I find I neglected to acknowledge before,
