May I outline the needs of Ahousaht and the method by which these needs can be met.

First then is the question of clearing land for gardens. When the school was built the land between the lake and the seashore was cleared of standing timber but the stumps were left, the only area cleared was the building site. It is my purpose to clear the land of stumps and put in garden truck. This land between the old lake bottom and the sea is ideal in quality, is higher than the lake bottom (which is sometimes flooded to a depth of one foot or more) and is not subject to flooding. The sal-lal bush is growing in the spaces between the stumps and has to be cut down every two years. To take out these very large stumps is a heavy and laborious task. I would like to get this work done this spring so that a garden may be planted.

The other improvement contemplated will entail considerable expenditure. My suggestion is that the W.M.S. approach the Indian Dept. and offer to transfer this property to them on condition that they assume responsibility for the following improvements:

1. The installation of an adequate lighting system. The present system is dangerous, poorly installed and always on the verge of collapse; we have only half the lights we ought to have. Our batteries will not allow additional lights.

2. The construction of a cedar plank road from Matilda Creek to the School (approx. 1 mile). The difficulty of landing supplies here is very great, the only place is the open beach which is subject to the tide and swell of the open sea. The surf is so strong sometimes that it is impossible to land. I am told that when Mr. Miller was in charge they suffered loss and damage to goods on many occasions, one case in particular when two of the big heavy dug-out canoes were smashed and the contents spilled into the ocean, among them 35 sacks of flour, sugar and groceries, etc.; you can imagine the loss. Mr. Wood has expressed himself very clearly on this landing problem. Before coming here I have had considerable experience in canoes and would enjoy the sensation of riding the surf in an empty canoe and clad in a bathing suit, but I do not relish seeing our supplies damaged and destroyed. On two occasions we have had the canoe swamped and on the last occasion we were capsized. These are not accidents; they are inevitable when the ocean is in certain playful moods, and they may happen when our next shipment comes. The construction of this proposed road will avoid all this expense and worry.

At present the steamer goes into Matilda Creek and unloads at Gibson's Dock. This is only 1-1/2 miles from the school. The Proposed road will end on Matilda Creek; here the water is always calm and we can land our supplies in comfort and safety. From there to the school (a little less than a mile) I propose to carry the supplies by Ford truck over the proposed plank road. The reason it will have to be built of cedar plank is because there are no other materials available. There are limitless cedar trees and we can have them sawn at Gibson's mill. (Cedar will last 20 years or more). It is proposed to make the road eight feet wide but we shall clear a strip twenty feet wide in the bush. The total cost of clearing, constructing road, building floating dock and supplying second hand truck, will be about three thousand dollars. ($3,000.00)

3. The erection of an additional class room. The task of teaching all grades up to grade 8 is too great for one teacher. We have now sufficient accommodation for sixty pupils in the main building, but we cannot put this number in class room. Approximate cost of class room, $2,000.00

4. The erection of a carpenter shop and boat building shop combined. I am teaching the boys carpenter work and also boat building as far as possible.
At present we are using one end of the laundry for our Carpenter work; it is inadequate for this purpose and is certainly impossible for boat building. These West Coast Indians make their living from the sea. If we can teach these boys to build boats (and we can with proper equipment) we shall send them out fully prepared to earn their living in competition with White man or Jap. The building should be 24 ft. x 60 ft. and would cost $2,500.00.

5. Improvements and addition to the Main Building. At present we do not have a separate room for sick children. We require a sick room and nurse's room adjoining. This can be done within the compass of the present building. We shall also require some additions to the plumbing system. My estimate for these improvements is $2,200.00.

6. The Department should also be asked to grant $1000.00 each year for five years to clean out and keep clean the drainage ditches around the farm, clear additional land, build bridges and culverts on ditches, and erect fences.

The total amount asked for (about 17,000.00) is considerably less than the value of this property. I have found the Department willing to provide equipment for the education of the Indian children. We cannot expect them to spend large sums on property they do not own. This property is not an asset to the W.M.S., it is rather a liability. So long as the Title of the Property remains in our name it will be difficult to obtain grants from the Government. By handing it over to them on the above terms, the burden will be taken off our shoulders and placed where it rightly belongs."

Dear Mr. Jones;-

At your suggestion I am pleased to report upon your electric lighting system or installation.

I might say that as it stands it is altogether inadequate to your present needs, there having been considerable additions to the building of late, and I noticed that these additions are not connected to the present wiring system and are therefore without light.

It would be unwise to increase the capacity of the present plant as the batteries have been in use now for over 4 years and are in a very weak condition. The installation of a new plant, preferably of the automatic type and of 110 instead of 32 volts is advisable. These automatic systems eliminate to a great extent the storage battery nuisance and from personal observation I must say that they are giving wonderful satisfaction and service.

In the matter of School wiring your present system was perhaps satisfactory several years ago. However according to the present wiring code it is now sub-standard, the building should be wired in conduit (piping) throughout. This is the only manner in which a building such as yours should be wired to ensure perfect safety, particularly where a direct current installation has to be used.

The foregoing is a true and disinterested report and I shall be glad if your Department should decide to have a qualified electrician call upon you to report. I have no hesitation in stating that he would agree with me as to the inadequacy of your present lighting system, and equipment.

I remain

Yours very truly,

(signed) W.C. Hamilton.

Principal, Ahousat,

A.F.Mackenzie, Esq.,
Secretary Department of Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir,

I have the honour to submit Estimates of the proposed improvements at Ahousaht.

First. Twelve h.p. Marine engine for launch $875.00

Second. Automatic D.C. Lighting system 110 volts installed in the conduit system throughout the main building and to all outbuildings $2,100.00

Third. The Construction of a plank road to connect the School with Matilda Creek and to the road to the dock where the steamers unload. Since my first communication with the Mission Board on this subject, the Provincial Government have begun work on a road from Gibsons Dock to Duncans at the head of Matilda Creek. (See the map of the district shewing proposed road and the different points mentioned.) Upon completion of our road we shall have a direct connection with Matilda Creek where we can always get our freight without danger or loss, and we shall also be connected with the provincial road which when completed will enable us to load a truck at the steamer and unload directly into our store house. I want to impress upon you the difficulties of the present way of landing our freight on the open beach which is exposed to the rolling surf of the Pacific. The Provincial Police attempted to land here in an empty yawl the seas turned them over and our boys had to go to their help. On the 13th of Dec., it was too rough to have the steamer stop here so our freight was taken around to Gibsons' dock, on the 17th the seas having gone down considerably Mr Gibson offered to bring around my freight in their big boat the Anchorite (We have no engine for our boat so I have to hire boats for all the work.) The boat was driven aground on our beach, I hired three other boats to attempt salvage but it was impossible to pull her off, the waves pounded her to pieces before the next high tide. This boat was valued at $5,000.00 they had insurance on her up until three months ago so it is a total loss to our Neighbour except the parts we salvaged from the wreck the next day, since then they have made three attempts to load the engine on a barge but the surf is too strong. Every Government and Church Official who has visited here agree that a road to the calm waters of the Creek is necessary.
Indian Residential School
Ahousaht, B.C.

The proposed road will do this and in addition will eventually land us at the dock.

There is one other advantage in this road. We have here about 11 acres of level land (the bed of a lake drained by ditches). Samples of this soil have been sent to the Agricultural College and they tell us we need to put fertilizer into the soil and say that kelp is the best. Every year tons of kelp is deposited on Powel Beach. This beach is less than 200 yards from the proposed road at one point; here we propose to build a branch road out to the beach, where we can haul the kelp to the farm. At present the land is too impoverished to grow anything, but with ample fertilizer we can grow enough feed to keep cows as well as provide vegetables for the school. At present all these have to be purchased in Victoria or Vancouver.

This road will also provide an excellent walk for the children, at present we have only a narrow plank walk from school to village.

It is proposed to build the road where it is close to ground of cedar, where it is above ground of fir and spruce. The enclosed sketch shows method of construction. You will see that the car or truck will be running on four inch plank, the centre is filled in with two inch plank, the logs at the side are safety buffers. Part of the road is through heavy timber, this will supply us with fuel for some years to come. The school land adjoins Mr. Duncan's Land, he will be pleased to grant "Right of way" over his property.

The length of road will be a little less than 2000 yards including the branch to Powel Beach. The cost I have carefully calculated to be no more than $6500.00

I hope you will give this item your best consideration.

Erection of Carpenter Shop and Boat building Shop combined 24 x 60 feet, we are using a corner of the laundry for carpenter shop, it is inadequate and very unsatisfactory. It is situated on the girls side of main building, the steam is destructive of tools.

We shall require a building for the new lighting system, my proposal is to partition off part of the new Carpenter Shop for this purpose. If the Department will provide the material for this building I and the boys will build and finish same to your satisfaction. Cost of Material $1100

Additional Classroom. The present room 23 ft. 6 in X 34 ft. 3 in x 8 ft. 6 in and a small room 10 ft. 6 in X 18 ft. 3 in, the latter was only intended for cloak room but we have to use it to accommodate the 49 pupils, we have as many as 46 pupils in the classrooms at one time. With an additional classroom we shall relieve the teacher of some of her heavy duty of teaching all the grades. Cost of material will be $850.00 I will build it with the aid of pupils.

There are two other items which can be left over for the following year.

I hope you will see the urgency of these improvements, especially the Road and the Lighting. If the money for the road could be supplied this winter it would relieve a situation of hardship among the Indians and White people here. Fishing was unprofitable to most of the people last Summer. Now the fishing has been opened nearer to Vancouver to relieve the distress there it has closed the market to the West Coast fisherman, there are no fish buyers here this winter.

Dear Sir:

I am sorry I was unable, for business reasons, to proceed to Alouette by the boat of January 23rd, as arranged, but instead I went by the boat of February 3rd.

Attached are plans and particulars of what is required to list the Alouette school building and other buildings, adequately. I have gone thoroughly into the matter of these requirements with Mr. Jones, the principal, and the plans and particulars as submitted have his approval.

We discussed the matter of the location of the listing plant, and it is his wish to have it located, if possible, in a portion of the proposed new boat-house and workshop. This I consider a very good suggestion provided it is kept separate from the other part of the workshop by a partition, and that portion provided with a lock.

It is desirable from a safety standpoint to carry out the work throughout in rigid and flexible conduit. There are portions of the school building and class room where the work can be concealed and this is recommended wherever possible.

It is most practical to have the fuse panel located in the basement; conductors being run to the different floors to junction boxes by means of rigid conduit, thence to the different circuits by means of rigid or flexible conduit. Ten circuits are required to provide for the school building.
The sizes of wire needed are as follows:

Plant to school building No. 6 weather proof.
Trench to fuse panel in basement No. 6 strand R.C.
Building to class room (P.P. entrance switch fused) No. IO R.C.
Building to laundry (entrance switch fused) No. IO R.C.
Building to barn No. 3 solid weather proof.
Fused entrance switch to be located in barn as in laundry
and class room.
Fuse panel to junction box on each floor No. IO R.C.
Light and switch circuits No. I4 R.C.
Convenience outlets No. I2 R.C.

It is recommended that ceiling dome lights be used in the
following locations:

Pupils dining room -------------- 4.
Kitchen ------------------------ 6.
Staff sitting room -------------- I.
Staff dining room -------------- I.
Staff bath-room --------------- I.
Office -------------------------- I.
Girls sewing room -------------- 5.
Class room --------------------- 4.

All dome lights to have pull-chain switches as a part of
the fixture.
All other lights in the building to be of the ordinary
drop type with tin shades. There are two lights in the class room
as shown on sketch which require to be ceiling fixtures with angle
reflector shades to throw light on the black-board.

There are three lights to be placed on outside of school
building. These can be of the ordinary bracket shaded type.
Four poles will have to be provided and installed to carry
the light wires to the barn etc.

In the course of installation it might be necessary to make
minor additions and alterations; this should be taken into account.
The plant I would recommend is of the automatic type, 110 volt. There are several of these on the market and two in particular that I have in mind are the Lister and Kohler.

I have had considerable experience in the servicing of both makes, and apart from the fact that the Lister is a British product and very good and reliable; I feel inclined to recommend the Kohler because of its simplicity, fool proof features and good service, which to my knowledge I know they are rendering.

They are also at a price that does not make such an installation prohibitive. The reason for this being that storage batteries are almost eliminated, only a small 24 volt battery being used for starting purposes. This is a very desirable feature though perhaps it too has its shortcomings, but which are not to be compared with the full storage battery type, where expenditures and upkeep has to be taken into consideration.

The approximate full load - on average of 60 watt per light - is 4½ K.W.

It is thought that a 3 K.W. machine would, with due care, be sufficient as only from one third to one half the maximum load would be carried at any period.

If a greater margin of safety would be desired a 3 or 5 K.W. unit would be advisable when taking into consideration also the possible additions to buildings in the near future.

An appropriation of $1100.00 will be required to cover the complete installation. This will adequately cover all material and work exclusive of plant.

Price of Kohler plants are as follows:

- 2 K.W. automatic 110 volt ----- $950.00
- 5 K.W. automatic 110 volt ----- $2000.00

With an additional $150.00 to cover unforeseen and incidental expenditures will bring the appropriation up to $1200.00 for a 2 K.W. and $2150.00 for a 5 K.W. plant.
February 10th, 1931.

I am also in possession of particulars with reference to the Lister lighting plants.

They manufacture a 3½ K.W. automatic, full battery, 52 cell type which would, I believe be quite adequate for the Ahouset installation. I have no hesitation in recommending this type of plant but as already stated they present a storage battery problem, which is undesirable in isolated locations.

This plant is not a one piece unit such as the Kohler, therefore presents an extra cost in installation.

There is one great advantage attached to the Lister plants in that they are slow speed, having a very long period of life when compared with the high speed type. This does to a great extent offset the storage battery problem, when cost of maintenance is considered.

Price of 3½ K.W. Lister complete with switch board and cooling tanks ------------ $1150.00

80 amp., 52 cell storage battery, glass cell type--$471.00

Cost of installation over Kohler $75.00.

This represents a net saving of $300.00 if a Lister 3½ K.W. is desired in preference to a 5 K.W. Kohler.

I consider that this covers all the information that will be required by your department as it furnishes the required data for plans and specifications, leaving your department to decide on the size and make of the plant to be installed.

Yours faithfully,

W.C. Hamilton

Dear Sir,

I am pleased to hear that the contract for our lighting plant has been let. I hope to get it completed during the holidays. It is our plan to place the generating plant in the proposed Carpenter & Boat-building shop. You will remember I asked for a grant to purchase material for this building, and I and the boys would build it. I have not yet heard anything about the engine for our boat or the other proposed improvements, which are urgently needed. The building of the road this summer would provide employment for our Indians. Only a very small proportion of the fish plants are operating this year and as a result our Indians do not know how they can make a living. They are coming to me constantly asking for work and I have given all that I can.

Will you please give these items your best consideration and oblige yours sincerely

Joseph Jones

Dear Sir,

Mr Hamilton and his electrician arrived here early in June to install the new plant. We were compelled to provide some suitable place for the generator. Mr Frost, Indian Agent was here and he gave authority to purchase lumber to build a house for the plant, this I have done and completed the same at a cost of about $100.00. Our plant is installed and working satisfactorily.

We are still without the carpenter & boatbuilding shop. If we are to do our duty to the boys we need this equipment. Training in these crafts will be more useful to them than all other branches. I have had the training and experience and I want to pass it on to them. Is it possible to apportion part of the money granted to British Columbia Indians for Technical Education? I understand that ten thousand dollars was available for the purpose last year.

I do not think the Missionary society can afford to spend much more this year. They contribute between four and five thousand every year to this school, besides special grants for emergencies.

Our launch is on the ways yet, and I am having to hire a launch to do our work. I understood the Department were purchasing an engine for this launch this year.

I shall be very grateful if you will take into further consideration our needs at Ahousaht.

Yours obediently,

Joseph Jones

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to the Department's letter dated Ottawa May 22nd, 1931 authorizing W.G. Hamilton of Port Alberni, B.C., to rewire the Ahousaht Indian Residential School for electric light according to estimates and plans submitted, and at a cost not to exceed $2200.00.

I beg to advise the Department that the equipment has been installed according to approved plans, and has been in operation for about two weeks.

On the 9th instant in company with the School Principal I inspected the work and machine, and tested its operation under various loads from all parts of the buildings and found the wiring and attachments of good material and workmanship, the automatic plant responded instantly under any load from any part of the building and the lights were powerful and steady under full load.

The installation is according to plans approved by the Department, except that the Kohler Plant was to have been housed in the proposed Carpenter Shop, the erection of which was not, and to date has not, been authorized.

On June 16th, 1931 on visiting Ahousaht School I was asked to decide where the plant should be located, in the absence of the new Carpenter Shop and submitted the suggestion that a small house be erected as a permanent powerhouse, clear of all other buildings, this was agreeable to Mr. Hamilton and approved by the Reverend Principal.

I authorized the purchase of building material for the powerhouse at an estimated approximate cost of $90.00, the Principal and the carpenter pupils of the school to supply the labour, this has been done and I found the engine house well constructed and finished.

I respectfully ask the Department's endorsement of the action taken.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 6th of August, No. 159-2-5 re-improvements at Ahousaht.

We have 52 pupils in residence and 7 more applications signed. To provide for these additional pupils we shall require more classroom and dormitory accommodation.

I beg to submit the following proposals to supplement what I have already suggested to you.

At the present, lumber is remarkably cheap in B.C. I have before me prices of material required for our needs.

First, classroom. For $412.00 I can build a classroom 20 feet x 24 feet, build brick chimney, and paint the building inside and out two coats, also wire the building and connect to our new plant. All we need to complete will be 25 desks and 176 sq.ft. of blackboard.

Second, Carpentershop and boat-building-shop
To provide the extra dormitory space to allow for the admission of the new pupils, I suggest the plan of putting up a building 22 ft. x 46 ft., the lower part for carpenters and boatbuilding, the upper a dormitory for boys, with one room for Assistant Principal. This arrangement will give us ample space and proper equipment for 60 pupils. The cost of material for this, including brick chimney and paint will not be more than $780.00.

If the Department provide for these very necessary additions, I shall take great pleasure in doing the work with the aid of our pupils.

Inspector Barry will be here the first week in September, he will have the opportunity of investigating our needs.

Trusting you will give these items your best consideration I remain yours sincerely

Joseph Jones
Principal

Protection:- There are five fire extinguishers and three extinguishers of the hose type. Inside the building there are two hydrants with hose. The water supply is through a tank at one end of the building. This tank is about on a level with the roof of the main building. I tested one of the hose pipes by having the water turned through it, and found the pressure sufficient for an attempt to fight a small fire in the building. The pressure was not sufficient to send the water over the roof, as the above mentioned tank is not raised enough for this.

The source of the water is a well near the school, from which the water is pumped into the tank. This new well is 12 feet deep and gives an excellent supply of water. The water was found to be in a sandy strata just above the bed rock. This water is slightly coloured. It has been analysed and found to be of good quality. There is a 6 H.P. Fairbanks gas engine, which drives a pump as well as the laundry machinery mentioned below.

There are two wooden fire escapes. Access to the escapes is by means of the dormitory windows. These have wire screens, which are taken off for fire drills, which are held each month. There is an axe in each dormitory. The children could use the axes to knock off the screens from the windows in case of a real fire. During the fire drill which I held the children were clear of the building in less than two minutes.

I wish to recommend that four fire gongs and the necessary electric equipment to operate them be supplied to the school. This will probably cost in the neighbourhood of $100.00 which sum is being placed in the estimates for this school by the Indian Agent.

Laundry:- There are two new washing machines. These were supplied by the Department to the school last year. The power to operate these machines is supplied by the above mentioned gas engine, through shafting. There are two laundry tubs. There is one extractor run off shafting. This is in good condition. The laundry stove, at present in use, is a discarded kitchen range. This range is in a hopeless condition. It is quite worn out. I wish to recommend the supply of a new laundry stove of modern design.

Upper Landing:- About five hundred square feet of V. Joint sheeting and a dormer type skylight are required on the upper landing. This will complete the walls and ceiling of the staircase, and will provide for extra ventilation when necessary. The work in connection with this would be done by the boys.

Kitchen:- The kitchen is badly lighted. Part of the floor is badly worn and will need renewal in the near future. The bake oven is in good condition, but the oven in the kitchen range is wearing thin, and will soon need repair. The kitchen is kept perfectly clean.

Electric Light:- In June a Kohler, direct current, automatic, 2 K.W. electric light machine was installed. This machine works on 110 volts. It cost installed $200.00 with $90.00 for the house in which it has been placed. The sum of $200.00 is still available from the sum allowed for this work.

VICTORIA, B.C. May 11, 1932.

Dear Sir:

I very recently had a call on me from Reverend Mr. Jones, Principal of the Ahousaht Indian Residential School, West Coast Agency, and he took up with me the question of the Department supplying lumber, desks and blackboards for a new classroom, at an approximate cost of $750.00. Captain Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools, reported on the necessity of this additional classroom in a recent report of his inspection at the Ahousaht School. Mr. Jones informed me that he had received a letter from you stating the amount would be included in the 1932-33 estimates but probably there would be a further cut. Mr. Jones also wishes to have a launch built by his pupils under the supervision of a competent builder, the size being 9'6" x 36', the estimated cost of the material to be $500.00 with an engine costing $300.00. Mr. Jones points out that the building of this boat by the pupils would be an excellent chance for them to acquire a knowledge of this profession as launches are the practical means of transportation on the West Coast.

I would be obliged if you would kindly inform me as to whether or not money will be available this year for the purpose above mentioned.

Your obedient servant,

W. E. Ditchburn,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

The Main Estimates provide funds for the lumber for a classroom and for a launch at the Ahousaht Indian Residential School. The estimated costs are $575 and $500 respectively, or a total of $1075. The school management, with the assistance of the manual training class, will be entirely responsible for the construction and the labour, without cost to the Department.

The Department proposes, with the Minister's concurrence, to ask for prices on the lumber from the Gibson Lumber and Shingle Mills, of Ahousaht, and from Lemon-Gommason, of Victoria. The first named firm is mentioned in your memorandum of September 11, 1931, when lumber was required at this school, and the Victoria firm is on the list and has supplied lumber to this institution in the past.

The school is at Ahousaht, on the west coast of Vancouver Island, in the federal district of Comox-Alberni.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Ottawa, October 27, 1932.

Sir:

I have your No. 15/15/26639 of the 15th instant, enclosing a voucher in favour of McLennan, McFeely & Prior Limited, Vancouver, covering the cost of hardware and fittings for boat being built at the Ahousaht Indian Residential School to the amount of $478.74.

In this connection I would refer to letter of May 11, 1932, from the former Commissioner, Mr. Ditchburn, in which he stated that he was informed by the Principal that he wished to build a launch boat by his pupils, under the supervision of a competent builder, and estimated the cost of materials to be $500, with an engine costing $900. The total of the accounts received for the materials and fittings for this boat amounts to $903.74.

I have also your No. 15/15/26640 of the 15th instant, regarding the account covering the cost of desks supplied for the new classroom. In letter referred to above from the former Commissioner, he states he took up with the Principal the question of the extra classroom and was informed that the cost, including lumber, desks and blackboards, would amount to a total of approximately $750. Accounts for the material and furnishings, including desks, have been received, and amount to a total of $844.43.

I may say that the total sum provided in our Estimates for the current fiscal year for the boat and extra classroom was $1500, while the total expenditure for both purposes, as per accounts received, amounts to $1748.17. Accounts to this amount are being paid, but you will observe that no funds are left for the supplying of an engine for the boat. We are not aware when the boat will be completed and the engine required, but the purchase of the engine may have to remain over until after the beginning of the next fiscal year. In the meantime, however, you may, when the building of the boat is sufficiently advanced, forward an estimate of the cost of the engine, when consideration will be given as to whether funds for the purpose can be provided from our Estimates this year or not. If not possible to provide the funds this year, a note will be made to include the amount required in our Estimates for the next fiscal year.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

The Assistant Indian Commissioner, Victoria, B.C., forwards the report of Mr. Inspector Pragnell on his inspection during the past summer of the Ahousaht Indian Residential School. WEST COAST AGENCY INSPECTION REPORT.

AHOUAHT RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL:

I visited same in company with Mr. Agent Frost, and met the Reverend principal, Mr. Jones. This gentleman seems to be doing very good work under great difficulties. This is, to some extent, owing to the poor place originally chosen for the school site. In fact, as regards this, the best that can be said is that the view is good. Landing freight at this school is attended with considerable difficulty and I do not see how this can be rectified. The Principal suggests a road from the school to the reserve float, which would cost about $4000.00.

The Septic tank is broken and out of order. There is no lavatory accommodation in the boys' wing except outside. The fire extinguishers have been kept properly filled. The fire escapes should have treads put on the stairs to prevent slipping. Wood strips of hardwood would do. Water pails are empty.

A playground is being drained by a deep cut. This was done in the form of relief work for the neighbouring village, and was welcome assistance. The floors in the whole building are going, and will soon need renewing. The manual training class room was in splendid order, this part of the children's work being particularly well done, and compares more than favorably with the larger schools. An outside class room was being enlarged.

Geo. S. Pragnell.
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to the Department's letter of September 10th, 1932, calling for a report on the notes made by Inspector Pragnell on his inspection of Ahousaht Indian Residential School.

The septic tank at Ahousaht school is still faulty, and in my opinion will never function properly, as the tank is located on too high a level to allow necessary fall for sewage solids these collect in the drains and cause stoppage. These drains have recently been taken up cleaned and relaid which will allow the present tank to function for a time, but a new tank will eventually have to be built on a lower level to allow proper fall for sewage. This could be done by relief labor under the Principal's supervision, necessitating only the cost of the material for tank construction and drains.

The bill of material needed for new septic tank is as follows:

- Lumber for concrete forms. 1600 bd. feet. $32.00
- Nails. 25 lb. $2.50
- 32 sacks cement. (Landed at Ahousaht) $22.70
- 100 feet 4" Vitirified tile. $8.00
- 1 4" Y $0.50
- 1 3 ft. 4" iron soil pipe. $12.00
- 2 4 ft. 4" right angle elbows. $12.00

Total cost of materials. $147.70

The Rev. Principal calls for two Iron Manholes (frames and covers), but in my opinion cement Manhole covers will be satisfactory and will cost only a fraction of what iron covers would cost.

The stop strips for fire-escape treads have been put on.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo, regarding the condition of the septic tank at the Ahousaht Indian Residential School. It is noted that, although the drains in connection with the present tank have recently been taken up, cleaned and relayed—which will permit the tank to function for a time—you consider it will be necessary to have a new tank built on a lower level, to allow a proper fall for sewage. The quantity of lumber, cement, etc., required in the construction of a new tank, together with the cost of same, has been noted.

If you can arrange for the purchase of the materials, as stated in your letter, in time to have the accounts covering the cost reach the Department before the end of the present fiscal year, March 31, next, approval is granted for you to make the purchase at the present time. The purchase should be made from a firm on the list to receive consideration and you should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost. These you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. It is noted that you estimate the cost of the materials required to be $147.70.

The labour in installing the new septic tank is to be carried out by the school authorities, without cost to the Department. It is considered that cement manhole covers will be satisfactory.

It is to be understood that, if the purchase of the materials cannot be made in time to have the accounts reach the Department for payment from our Appropriation for the present fiscal year, you are to refer the matter to the Department again. I may add that, as our Appropriation will likely be reduced for the coming fiscal year, it is doubtful if we would have funds to provide for the cost of the material. You should therefore give early attention to the purchase of the material referred to in your letter.

GENERAL DESCRIPTION

Type:
Electrical ignition, 4 cycle with overhead valves. Simple in construction, and easy of operation all parts easy of access.

Lower Crank Case:
Rigid box type construction extended to carry reverse gear covers, which are removable. Entirely oil proof.

Upper Crank Case:
Box type construction, entirely closed with hand plates and gear covers, which are removable. Entirely oil proof.

Main Bearings:
Bearings throughout are made of highest grade of nickel babbit. All bearings are of extreme long and large for the greatest possible bearing surface and minimum bearing pressure.

Thrust Bearings:
The thrust bearing is distributed between steel ball thrust collars on either side of the thrust bearing, which is bolted to the engine base. The entire thrust of the propeller on both ahead and astern motion is thus taken up by the engine casting.

Crank Shafts:
Made of best hammered steel, forged in one piece from special billets. Proportioned to Lloyd's rules for marine shafting.

Cylinders:
Hard, close grained cast iron, with ample metal provided for re-boring. The cylinder heads are cast separately, which gives complete accessibility whenever required. The cylinders and connecting rods can be easily lifted out of the engine. Ample water jackets, and large expansion spaces for accessibility. Interchangeable on engines of the same bore and stroke.

Exhaust Manifolds:
Cast iron. Water jacketed, and made in sections bolted together.

Intake Pipe:
Cast iron.

Connecting Rods:
Forged from Lloyd's test steel. Upper and lower bearings adjustable.

Pistons:
Cast iron, having four to six rings, according to the size of the engine, with lap joint. Rings are concentric shaped, and returned after cutting.

Fly Wheel:
Cast iron and spoked. Is of such weight and support so as to absorb all shocks of changing engine speeds.

Valves:
Made of cast iron with high grade steel stems, and operate as noiselessly as possible, without over-heating. They are arranged so that they can be easily removed when necessary. The valve spring is of large diameter, so that it will maintain its strength indefinitely, and give a uniform opening.

Cam Shaft:
Cam shaft is driven from the crank shaft by spur gears through an intermediate gear, which revolves on an idle shaft rigidly fastened to the base. The intermediate gear is adjusted to allow for difference in the centre distances, caused by adjusting the crank shaft bearings.

Cams:
All cams are made of highest grade steel, case hardened. After hardened, the cams are tested and ground where needed for accuracy.

Compression Release:
The compression is released by sliding the entire cam shaft by means of lever situated at aft end of engine.

Lubrication:
The oil system is by "Manzill" force feed oiler, feeding to all cylinders, and to the necessary main bearings, together with splash system in the base. The feed of oil is accomplished automatically, so that only the filling of the oil reservoir is necessary before a long trip.

I should like to recommend that the Department provide a thick rope, at one end of which a large iron ring should be permanently fitted, so that in the event of fire the boys from the new dormitory would have a means of climbing out of one of the windows of their dormitory and reaching the rocks below in safety. The iron ring could be placed under one leg or a bed near one of the windows. At present the only means of escape from this new dormitory is by means of a light stairway on the outside of the building; and this staircase is nearest to the greatest fire hazard, the old brick down woodshed. Should the small boys have to jump from one of the windows they would be very seriously injured as the rocks are below the windows on the sea side of the building.

Dear Sir:

In reporting on his inspection of the Ahousaht Indian Residential School, Inspector Barry writes in part as follows:

"The exit from the dormitories to the escapes is by way of windows, which are covered with light wire screens. These can be knocked out by means of the axes kept near the windows. I think these wire screens might well be removed, and the windows just fastened with string and wax seal.

"I would recommend that the fire escape on the boys' side of the school be continued by steps to the ground, a very simple thing for the manual training class to do if they had the material. On the girls' side the last flight of steps at least should be renewed and placed in a better position to give a more gradual slope and thus permit much wider steps. This escape should also be continued to the ground. The windows on the girls' side should also have the wire screens taken off and string and wax seal used.

"A wooden escape might well be constructed to a window in the new dormitory building. Iron escapes are not in my opinion necessary here. They are just as dangerous as wooden escapes though they look safer. If there is any fire near an escape, iron or wood, children will not come down it."

Please discuss the Inspector's suggestion with the Principal, and you might then supply an estimate of the cost of the material that would be needed. You will note from the above the Inspector considers that the manual training class can do the necessary work, without cost to the Department.

I enclose, for your information, copy of departmental circular with reference to fire prevention and fire drill. Extra copies are being sent, which you should supply to the Principals of the Residential Schools in your agency. Upon the occasion of future visits to this school, you should see that our instructions are being carried out.

Yours truly,

A. F. Mackenzie,
Secretary.

P. B. Ashbridge, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Alberni, B. C.
I went into the question of fire escapes and fire drills with great care. I noticed that my recommendation for a rope with an iron ring to fit under the leg of a bed had not been acted on in the new dormitory building. It is true that a second stairway has been constructed in that building, and the old wood shed removed.

To put it very bluntly, I AM NOT SATISFIED THAT PROPER FIRE DRILLS HAVE BEEN HELD AT THIS SCHOOL SINCE MY LAST INSPECTION. Fire drills have been held down the stairs, but I do not believe that the old wooden fire escapes have been used for a long time. There are two of these wooden fire escapes, one at each end of the main school building. Neither reaches to the ground. The steps on the girls' fire escape are so narrow that it is most dangerous for a child to come down. To make my inspection complete I managed to climb up this escape, but had difficulty in coming down and had in fact to face the escape and use it as a ladder. As the escapes do not reach within some eight feet of the ground I could not get down till a boy got a step ladder and helped me. Such a condition, I think, should be done away with for the sake of the children, even if the Department does not own the building. The exit from the dormitories to the escapes is by way of windows, which are covered with light wire screens. These can be knocked out by means of the axes kept near the windows. I think these wire screens might well be removed, and the windows just fastened with string and wax seal.

I would recommend that the fire escape on the boys' side of the school be continued by steps to the ground, a very simple thing for the manual training class to do if they had the material. On the girls' side the last flight of steps at least should be renewed and placed in a better position to give a more gradual slope and thus permit much wider steps. This escape should also be continued to the ground. The windows on the girls' side should also have the wire screens taken off and string and wax seal used.

I would ask the Department to provide the Principal with a copy of the regulations for fire drills, which the last Principal does not appear to have handed to Mr. Caldwell. I would also urge that when the fire escapes have been lengthened as suggested above and the one on the girls' side changed, regular drills be organized down the new escapes.

A wooden escape might well be constructed to a window in the new dormitory building. Iron escapes are not in my opinion necessary here. They are just as dangerous as wooden escapes though they look safer. If there is any fire near an escape, iron or wood, children will not come down it.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER OF MR. INSPECTOR BARRY, DATED MARCH 29th, 1936, ACCOMPANYING HIS REPORT.

I held the usual fire drill and found that the children could only use the ordinary stairways from the dormitories, as they had not been trained to come down the wooden fire escapes. I made a thorough inspection of these fire escapes and my remarks are contained in the attached report. The expense of the usual iron escapes would be high and I feel that the wooden escapes here might easily be made safe and convenient to use. I believe that the Indian Agent might well be asked to make a report on this subject.

Report of Inspection of Ahousaht Indian Residential School, Feb. 17, 1936

Sir:

I have the honour to submit the following observations on the Ahousaht School.

Fire Escapes and Protection:
Fire escapes are made of wood and attached to wooden building also a large water tank is suspended over the top of fire escape at rear of main building. This presents a very real danger to life and limb in addition to being of little or no value in case of fire.

Laundry:
Situated in a shaky outside building and consists of two antiquated washers and a worn out engine. These are constantly breaking down and are a source of annoyance and expense.

Main Building:
The interior of the building needs complete renovation. Alterations are necessary in the kitchen and dining rooms, also the reception room and dormitories. The outside presents a pleasing appearance and is in good repair and is well painted.

Sanitation:
Sanitary arrangements leave much to be desired. There is only one bath tub, toilet and wash basin for the whole of the staff. No provision is made for the boys toilets upstairs which makes it necessary to provide pails for night use.

Grounds:
In the vicinity of the school grounds are very well kept and clean. There is a large clearance which could, with the aid of a plough or small tractor be cultivated and would be sufficient to supply the school with vegetables, fruits and berries. There is also a very good and well constructed barn and stable where cows could be kept. The cultivation of this tract of land would be excellent training for the boys in addition to its value to the school.
Report of Inspection of Ahousaht Residential School, Feb. 17, 1936.

(Continued)

Principal's Residence:
Owing to school accommodation for use of the Principal being inadequate, he and his family have had to take up residence in temporary quarters above the workshops. It is understood that the Home Missions Board have the matter of a new residence before the Department and it is respectfully suggested that a residence be provided if possible.

General:
In submitting the foregoing report it is seen that the Principal, Mr. A. E. Caldwell is faced with a very real handicap. He is making heroic efforts to repair the buildings and has accomplished much in this direction. It must however be pointed out that any further expenditure on repair work would be a waste of money and it would, in the writer's opinion be advisable to have a very thorough inspection by a competent architect before making further expensive changes.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, April 23rd, 1936.

Dear Sir,

Provision has been made in our appropriation for the current fiscal year for the erection of a residence for the Principal of the Ahousaht Indian Residential School. The amount provided is $3,000 and this is the total that can be allowed for the purpose mentioned.

Please visit the Ahousaht School at an early date and discuss the matter with the Principal and report to the Department what action both of you consider should be taken in the erection of this building.

You should supply an estimate of the material required and, also, an estimate of the labour. In connection with the latter, do you consider that it would be possible to erect the residence by engaging a competent man as foreman and employ Indians? It is possible that this method would be cheaper than to build the residence by contract. Would it be necessary for the Department to forward a plan or would the Principal be in a position to assist in the supervision of the building? The Principal and yourself should consider this matter very carefully and you should report fully to the Department, keeping in mind, of course, that the amount mentioned in the first part of this letter must not be exceeded.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie.
Secretary.

P. B. Ashbridge, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Alberni, B. C.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,-

Funds, to the amount of $3,000.00, have been provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, to erect a residence for the Principal of the Indian Residential School, Ahousaht, B.C., (Electoral District of Comox-Alberni).

The local Indian Agent, after discussing the matter with the Principal of the School, states that the best plan to carry out the work would be to purchase the lumber and other building materials locally, thus effecting a saving on freight, and to engage a competent carpenter-foreman and employ Indian labour, under the supervision of the Principal. Plans and specifications have been prepared. The Agent estimates the cost of the building material and labour to be, approximately, $2,500; freight and hauling, $200; and miscellaneous items, $300.

I should be pleased to receive your authority to incur the expenditure - the work to be carried out by day labour, in charge of a competent foreman. I would request, also, that you supply the name of the foreman-carpenter to be employed and the names of the firms at Port Alberni, the nearest source of supply, from whom the lumber and building materials should be purchased.

Deputy Superintendent General.
April 23, 1936.

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to your letter of April 23, 1936, re the erection of a residence for the Principal of the Ahousaht Indian Residential School.

In obedience to your instructions I visited the school and went carefully into the matter with Mr. Caldwell.

It was decided that the best plan would be to engage a competent builder and employ Indian labor under the supervision of the Principal. Plans have been drawn up and specifications are herewith attached with estimated costs of material and labor. Lumber can be purchased locally which will be a saving on freight. Total estimated cost less freight charges would be $2501.50, leaving a balance of $488.50 for freight and haulage estimated at $200.00 and miscellaneous items $298.50.

Hoping this meets with the requirements of the Department and awaiting your further instruction.

Your obedient servant,

P.B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, Canada.

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to your letter of April 8, 1936, re expenditure of appropriation for Ahousant Residential School.

This matter has been thoroughly discussed with the Principal and it is respectfully recommended that this money would be best spent as follows:

For New laundry building & recreation room $1000.00
For interior painting 200.00
For relining reception room 150.00

The present laundry building is considered unsafe and also too close to the well which supplied the drinking water and it is recommended that this building be torn down and a new one built on a better site. Building to be a two story frame structure 22 x 36, the upper part to serve as a recreation room.

Lumber for this building can be purchased locally to save freight and the labor will be provided by the school under the supervision of the Principal and myself.

For interior painting $200.00.

Owing to several structural changes being made, this item is essential as the whole interior is badly in need of paint. Painting will be done by the boys and the amount stated is to cover cost of paint only.

Item $150.00 relining reception room and hallway. The woodwork as at present is very shabby and the room is very cold in winter. A very great improvement both as to comfort and appearance would be made at an estimated cost of $150.00.

It will be noted that the school authorities will undertake to supply labor in all cases and as the Principal, Mr. Caldwell, is a very practical man, it is respectfully recommended that this offer be accepted. Inspection or work performed will of course be carried out from time to time by myself and every assistance rendered.

Your obedient servant,

P. B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, regarding the erection of a residence for the Principal of the Ahousaht Indian Residential School and giving an estimate of the cost of the material, labour, freight and haulage.

In reply I have to say the Department will approve of the erection of the residence, under the supervision of the Principal and yourself - Indian labour to be employed and the work to be carried out under a competent foreman. You should arrange for the purchase of the lumber and building material required, from the Gibson Sawmill Company, Limited, Ahousaht. Should sufficient supplies not be obtainable from that company, any additional lumber is to be purchased from Bloedel, Stewart and Welsh Company, Limited, of Port Alberni. Hardware is to be purchased from C. A. Elkington, Tofino, and cement and bricks required, from Alfred Kneen, Port Alberni. For any plumbing work required, the services of A. S. It is noted that plans have been drawn up and specifications prepared. The Department will leave in your hands the matter of having the work in erecting the building satisfactorily completed.

You should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of all materials, and proper time sheets, in triplicate, should be kept for the labour employed. The number of days or hours employed and the rate paid in each case should be definitely shown. These accounts, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

MEMORANDUM

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

I have Mr. Jackson's memoranda of the 9th and 11th instant, regarding the erection of a residence for the Principal of the Indian Residential School at Ahousaht, B.C. The local Indian Agent is being informed that he is to arrange for purchase of materials and for the services of a plumber, as directed in memo. of the 11th instant, and that Mr. Neill, M.P., will furnish him with the name of a carpenter-foreman.

Besides the above work, funds have also been provided for the erection of a new laundry building and for repairs and painting to the interior of the main building, at a total cost of $1,350. It is intended to tear down the present old laundry building, which is unsafe and too close to the well which supplies the drinking water for the school, and to erect a new two-story frame building, 22' x 36', the upper part to serve as a recreation room. It is intended, also, to carry out certain painting in the interior of the main building and reline the reception room and hall. The school authorities will undertake to supply all labour and the work will be carried out under the supervision of the Principal, who is a practical man. The local Agent will inspect the work from time to time and render every assistance.

I would request your approval to incur the expenditure and assume that it will be in order for the Agent to purchase the materials from the firms mentioned in memo of the 11th instant.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, regarding the repairs and improvements required by the Principal of the Ahousaht Indian Residential School, to be carried out for the funds provided in the appropriation for the current fiscal year. It is noted that the present laundry building is unsafe and the Principal and yourself recommend that this building be torn down and a new one built, on a better site, to consist of a two-story frame structure, 22 ft. x 36 ft. - the upper part to serve as a recreation room - also that painting of interior of the main building be carried out.

The Department will approve of an expenditure of $1,000.00 in the purchase of lumber and material for the erection of the laundry building; $200.00 to purchase paint for interior painting; and $150.00 for material to reline reception room and hallway. You may arrange for the purchase of the materials, from the firms as mentioned in official letter of the 15th instant.

It is understood that all labour in connection with the above work will be carried out by the school authorities, under the supervision of the Principal and yourself, without cost to the Department. After you have purchased the materials, you should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost. These accounts, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

Sir:

I have the honour to submit herewith regular monthly letter covering conditions within the Agency, for month ending June 30, 1936.

SCHOOLS.

All the schools were inspected during the month and with the exception of the Alberni Residential School, the health of the children was very good. Christie school has re-opened and the remainder have closed for the Summer holidays. All the children who have not had measles at Alberni School are quarantined. New Fire Escapes at the Ahousaht and Christie Schools are being planned. Fire drill was not carried out at these two schools due to poor condition of the escapes. Sanitary conditions were good. Food was good and properly prepared at all schools.

Your obedient servant,

P. B. Ashbridge

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to your letter of September 17, 1936, relating to purchases for the Principal's residence at the Ahousaht Indian Residential School.

The firms mentioned in the official letter of June 15, 1936, were asked to supply goods but were not in a position to do so. I then consulted with Mr. A. W. Neill, M. P., and a list of dealers was drawn up which was agreeable to and recommended by him.

At the same time the matter of labor was taken up as instructed and the foreman was chosen by Mr. Neill.

In conversation with Mr. Neill today he informed me that he had inspected the work and was satisfied that it had been well carried out and that purchases had been made in the public interest.

In view of the excessive freight rates on the Coast it was found necessary to deal with the wholesale firms in order to keep the total cost within the appropriation.

The laundry building has not yet been commenced and I would respectfully request that authority be granted to purchase lumber from Knott Lumber Co. and sash and door from Lawrenson and Skipsey, these names having been approved by Mr. A. W. Neill.

All accounts to date in connection with the Principal's residence are being forwarded under separate cover. These almost complete the total which will not exceed $3000.00 inclusive of fire escapes.

It is regretted if any inconvenience has been caused unwittingly to the Department and I understand that Mr. Neill is writing to Ottawa in explanation of the change of dealers.

Your obedient servant,

Report on condition of Fire Escapes and Fire Fighting Appliances at Ahousaht Residential School.
October 20, 1936.

Fire Escapes.
The fire escapes at this school are of wood construction, and placed at either end of the building. Suspended over the top of one of these escapes is a large storage tank, supported by a wooden trestle. The steps of escape, being of wood, are slimy and dangerous. Orders have been given by myself to keep these sanded. Windows leading to these escapes, at a recent inspection, were found very difficult to open, especially in the small girls dormitory, which is located on the upper floor. These escapes, in the opinion of the writer, are not only worthless, but actually dangerous. Escapes have been recently overhauled and repaired, but are still unsatisfactory.

Pyrenes.
These are 4 large, and several small extinguishers, distributed about the main building. These are all in working order.

Fire Alarm.
Alarm is sounded on a cook's triangle, which is also unsatisfactory, as the staff have not been properly trained in their respective duties.

Hose and Water Supply.
Both inadequate. In case of fire at this school, all efforts would have to be concentrated on the saving of life, as it is not considered that the building could be saved.

Recommendations.
It is a very difficult matter for the writer to make recommendations involving any great expense. The school, which is not owned by the Department, does not warrant any outlay. The building is old and badly constructed. Stairways are narrow, and the rooms poorly laid out. In short, it is, in my opinion, nothing short of a fire trap. It is, of course, essential that the children be given every protection possible, and I would respectfully submit the following recommendations.

1. That a wooden fire escape be placed leading from centre of building on the second floor approximately 5 feet to ground. Labor to be provided by school staff. Estimated Cost $100.00.

2. That fire pails and axes be kept on each landing.

3. That a gong be placed in lower hallway, with switch connection on each floor. Estimated Cost $50.00

As an additional protection to the children, it is further respectfully suggested that definite instructions be issued by the Department to myself, making me responsible for the training, and outlining of the duties of the watchmen at all schools.

Respectfully submitted,

Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

I desire to acknowledge receipt of Mr. Pratt's memorandum of February first and also letter received from Mr. A. W. Neill, M.P., attached thereto.

May I emphasize that the school at Ahousaht is the property, not of the Government, but of the United Church of Canada. We feel that, with the limited appropriations at our disposal, the government-owned institutions should have first claim for consideration. We feel that the criticism sent forward to Mr. Neill by the Principal of the Ahousaht School should have been directed to the church authorities. You may be interested to learn that when Dr. Dorsey and Dr. Cochrane, representing the United Church, visited the Department a few days ago, they expressed the view that, while a new building was needed at Ahousaht, they nevertheless were of the opinion that a new school building at Round Lake, Sask., was more urgently needed. Both these gentlemen were emphatic that, if a building programme was undertaken this year, the construction of a school at Round Lake should receive first consideration.

We feel that the information at our disposal in the Department is sufficient to convince us that a new school should be erected at Ahousaht, just as soon as funds are available for this purpose. Despite this fact, however, we can see no objection to the suggestion made by

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6430, file 876-5, part 3)
made by Mr. Neill, that an inspection of the school building, and particularly the fire escapes, be undertaken by a capable man, at an early date. As this is not a government-owned school, such inspection should be undertaken by the Church authorities. In the event of conditions being found serious enough to warrant the closing of the school, consideration would have to be given to the matter and the whole situation, in so far as educational facilities are concerned, carefully reviewed. The possibility of establishing a couple of day schools in the district could be carefully canvassed, or an attempt made to accommodate the pupils in other schools where space may be available. However, there are no funds for rebuilding available at the present time nor are any being provided.

Director.
Minister's Office

Principal, Indian Residential School,
Ahousaht, B.C.

Dear Sir:

In view of the instructions of the Department with respect to fire protection at Indian Residential Schools, and of a recent complaint regarding condition of fire escapes, the Department instructed me to make a survey and report resulting in authorization of new escapes, equipment, etc.

I feel that I must direct your attention to the unsatisfactory condition of protection at your school, and request that new fire escape be installed immediately. Also that fire pails filled with water, also axes, be placed at vantage points. Gong should also be installed in the separate building, which is used as a dormitory. Furnace room must be kept clean, and free of boxes and litter. This latter should be the duty of the night watchman, who should also report to you any other fire hazard he may notice. Steps of old escapes must be kept free of ice, and sanded, and fire drills carried out at irregular hours without previous warning. I know that the weather has been unsuitable for the building of new escape, but must request that this work be proceeded with, to enable me to assure the Department that all possible protection is afforded to life, and property, at your school.

Yours very truly,

P. B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I have the honour to submit the regular monthly letter covering conditions within this agency, for the month ending April 30, 1937.

Inspection of Schools.

All schools were inspected during the month in company with Mr. Inspector G. L. Barry, and survey of the Alberni school area was carried out also at this time. At both residential schools, the health of the pupils was good. Fire appliances were found to be in good order, and fire drills were carried out. Since date of the Inspector's visit, a new fire escape has been built at the Ahousaht School and new fire hose placed at Christie school.

P. B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.
Sir:

I have the honour to submit the regular monthly letter covering conditions within this agency for month ending June 30, 1937.

The Residential school at Ahousaht was thoroughly inspected, and it was agreed that the building is in bad condition and not worthy of further expenditure of Departmental funds. A special report on the school situation is being prepared, and it is understood that Mr. Inspector Pragnell will also report on this subject.

P. B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.
We visited and inspected this school. The new plank walk from the village (landing place) to the school, built by Indian labour is a big improvement. The dormitories and school in general were nice and clean and tidy. The fire escapes and fire fighting apparatus was in good order, though the former has no wooden stairs. It is greatly improved in this matter, but nothing that can be done prevents this old building from being a fire trap. Further, the water pressure is very poor and the well is getting very low. Again, here, there is no agricultural land available, that is to hand. To my mind it is not worth spending further money on this building, nor for that matter, rebuilding there at all. A day school would do here instead, buildings already ready. The old material could be given to Indians to improve their village.

If a new residential school is erected to replace the Alberni one, I think it should be built large enough to accommodate all the children of the United Church denomination. Of course, if a suitable site could be found, which I doubt, on the west coast itself, it might be preferential from the health point of view. However, no such good agricultural land all ready for use can be found as the old Alberni site, with water and electric light already available. Further the expense of building, for many reasons, would be much greater. The newly erected residence for the principal, Mr. Coldwell, is quite nice.

Geo. S. Pragnell,
Inspector of Indian agencies.

Dear Sir:

I enclose copy of a letter from Principal of the Ahousaht Residential School, Mr. A.E. Caldwell. This is, of course, in the West Coast Agency. This is, as you will see a request for additional grant towards the maintenance of that school. I enclose copy of an itemized estimate of what is required, and I wish to point out that I have reduced the original estimate by $700.00, having cut out $200.00 for paint and $500.00 for a stationary engine and barrel washer for the laundry. The estimate therefore, covers expenditure in plumbing, laundry, kitchen and chimney work.

Indian Agent Asbridge points out that should the Department contemplate keeping this school open, extensive repairs must be carried out, and sanitary arrangements extensively altered, and states that under present conditions, the school is a menace to health and unfit to house children. You will note that the Principal of the school points out that it is a bad fire trap, although asking for this expenditure. It would appear to me if the Principal considers this condition so dangerous he should really ask that the school be closed, or at least ask his Church Superiors to inform the Department to this effect.

Personally I am of the opinion that the actual closing of this school should be very seriously considered by the Department. I have in view the fact, that should a bad fire occur there and if fatality take place, the Department and Government will undoubtedly have to bear the blame, anyhow in the eyes of the public, and that despite the fact that it might be presumed by us that the Principal of the School and
and his Church authorities be thought to bear some responsibility in definite advice in the matter.

Mr. Ashbridge, the Indian Agent, too, in his communication to me states that it is in his opinion that the school should be entirely rebuilt or abandoned. I am inclined to concur in this myself. However, I have talked the matter over with School Inspector Barry to try to find out if there is any alternative should the Department incline to feel that they should not bear the responsibility of keeping this school open. The Inspector informs me that the children of Ahousaht Village could attend a day school at Ahousaht Residential school. By this I mean there is accommodation there that could be used as a day school. Further as the Principal has a good house it is probable that a day school teacher could reside there. This would take care of a considerable number of local children anyway. Some of the others from round about the canal belonging to the United Church now attending the Residential School at Ahousaht could be transferred to the United Church Residential School at Sardis. In this way I think there would be very few, if any children belonging to the United Church in this district who would not be accommodated in either the suggested day school at Ahousaht, the day school at Ucluelet, the day school at Alberni or the Residential school at Coqualeetza.

Yours faithfully,

My dear Mr. Phelan:

In the absence of Dr. Dorey on vacation, there has come to my desk your letter of August 6th, enclosing copy of communication to you from the Indian Commissioner in Vancouver in reference to the Ahousaht Indian Residential School.

In reply, I think we must admit that the condition of the building at Ahousaht is far from what it ought to be, and the Principal has told us, also, that it is a bad fire-trap. Under these circumstances, I can quite understand that the Government hesitates to spend very much money on repairs. We are inclined to agree with the opinion of Mr. Ashbridge that the School should either be entirely rebuilt or abandoned.

On the other hand, the information we have about the situation on the West Coast makes it impossible for us to agree that the Ahousaht Residential School should be abandoned without the building of another residential school for the United Church on the West Coast at some other point. We do not think that all our children could be looked after by the residential schools now in existence, nor that it is reasonable to expect that children from the West Coast could all be accommodated at Coqualeetza. We hope that before the Government thinks of abandoning the present school at Ahousaht, it will decide that a new school should be built for the United Church at some suitable point on the West Coast.

Dr. Dorey and I will be glad to discuss this matter further the first time we are in Ottawa.

Believe me,

Very sincerely yours,

R.B.C.M.T.

AGENT'S REPORT ON WEST COAST AGENCY FOR SEPTEMBER 1938.

At Ahousaht Residential school much has been done to remedy the unfavorable conditions reported from time to time. In the main building the walls have been covered and decorated making the building warmer and more sanitary.

The laundry has been moved to another building, away from the well and drained to a ditch leading to the sea instead of to the septic tank, as formerly. New toilets are to be installed, also another bath for the boys and more lavatory basins are being provided.

Grounds are being cleaned up and made more attractive. In brief, a complete transformation is being effected.

Fire drill was carried out at this inspection, and was satisfactory in so far as evacuation of building was concerned.

Water pressure is too low to be of any value, but all appliances, escapes, etc. are in good order. Children are all healthy and well fed, and making good progress under the new teachers.

Ahousaht Residential School.

This school has been much improved by lining the inner walls and the addition of much needed plumbing, but at best it cannot be considered a safe or sanitary building. Pupilage is at its safe limit and, while all precautions are taken to prevent fire, I cannot feel assured of the safety of the children, as the buildings in which they are housed are old, dry and decayed, with narrow dark stairways. Escapes are in good repair and all equipment is in good order. I am nevertheless convinced that, should fire occur in the night, very few would escape. A very conscientious and careful watchman is employed and on duty at all times, and fire drills are carried out.

During the month there were 32 children confined to bed with Influenza and Tonsilitis, which appeared to be general throughout the school.

Kitchen, dormitories, classrooms and grounds were clean and tidy. Meals are ample, well cooked and varied.

Class registers were not posted, and teachers were instructed to keep these up to date.

Many pupils had the appearance of slovenliness in habits and dress, and two cases of scabies were noted. It is felt that a weekly lecture on personal hygiene would be helpful to Indian children, who are by nature untidy, and in many instances dirty in their habits.

P.B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

AGENT'S REPORT ON FIRE
AHOUAHT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Notification of Agent.
At 6:30 p.m. on January 26th, 1940, I was notified by long distance telephone, relayed by the telegraph operator at Matilda Creek, that the Ahousaht Indian Residential School was on fire.

At my request, he phoned me again at 9 p.m., that the school was completely destroyed, but that no one was hurt.

At noon, January 27th, I received a wire (attached) from Mr. Caldwell, stating that some of the children were being sent down on the C.P.R. boat.

Notification of Department.
At 9 a.m., January 27th, I phoned Major D.M. MacKay all available particulars of the fire, also wired the Department at Ottawa.

Disposal of Evacuated children.
On arrival of C.P.R. boat at Port Alberni I met the children, in charge of Mrs. Preese, Kitchen Matron, and made arrangements for their care. Those going further south were put in charge of a responsible Indian, and proceeded to Port Renfrew, as the seas were too rough to permit of their landing at Clow-0858.

Action taken by Agent.
At 11 p.m. January 29th, 1940, I left for Ahousaht on M.V. "Duncan Scott", arriving at noon, being met on arrival by the Principal, Mr. A.E. Caldwell.

Inspection of damage.
Inspection of the site showed complete destruction of the main building, nothing remaining but cement posts and one brick chimney, and nothing to indicate possible cause of origin of fire.

Construction of Main Building.
The destroyed building was of wood frame construction with shingle roof. Building was very old and dry, being partially built of cedar, and was considered to be a fire hazard. Heating was by furnace situated in the basement, and by stoves in the sitting room and kitchen.

Electric light was supplied by school plant. Wiring was all protected to conform to requirements.

Probable cause of fire.
The theory advanced by Mr. Caldwell as to cause of fire was that of spontaneous combustion caused by accumulation of cedar dust between walls. This, however, is doubtful, as the fire commenced in the upper dormitory on the girls' side of the building, where it would not be exposed to heat from the chimney, or to dampness.
Agent's Report on fire at Ahousaht Residential School. (cont.)

Probable cause of fire.

(cont.)

I would rather think that it was caused by exposed wiring, or a defect in wiring. My reason for this lies in the history of the fire, as given by Mr. Caldwell and other members of the staff.

Mr. Caldwell relates that, about 5:45 p.m. on date of the fire, he noticed that the lights were "jumpy" and subsided to a dull glow. Thinking that the wires may have become crossed, he immediately stopped the engine.

Meantime, Mrs. Preece, the Kitchen Matron, noticed smoke issuing from the upper dormitory and turned in the alarm, and also notified the watchman.

Mr. Caldwell attempted to control the fire with an extinguisher without success.

Villagers gave every assistance, but the supply of water was inadequate to cope with the situation, and the building was completely destroyed within the hour.

It will be noted that the fire did not start in proximity to the chimneys, and that no inflammable material was stored in or near the building.

Evacuation of Children.

Fortunately there was only one child in the dormitories at the time, and she was taken out by Mrs. Sainsbury. The remaining seventy pupils were in the dining rooms on the ground floor, and filed out to a safe place.

Ownership of Building.

The building was the property of the United Church Missions.

Insurance.

Insurance was carried on the building, amount unknown, as the policy was not in the possession of the school authorities.

At the time of the fire there were in residence seventy children. Of these, thirty were sent to their homes at various points on the Coast, and the remainder to their homes at Ahousaht. School Staff.

Of the school staff, the Kitchen Matron, one teacher and the watchman have left, the remainder having taken up residence in the Principal's house, pending instruction from the Women's Missionary Society Headquarters.

School Accounts, Books and Records.

Recommendations.

As this school was the property of, and conducted by, the Church, care was taken to avoid too close inquiry except in so far as loss of Government property and care of pupils was concerned.

Dear Major MacKay:
