CLASSROOM

Condition of Classrooms (Ventilation, light, etc.)

A second classroom has been added to the original classroom building since my last report. This new classroom was entirely constructed by the boys under the supervision of the Principal and Mr. Bailey. It is a very fine little classroom indeed and reflects very great credit on all concerned.

The inside has been nicely finished in some sort of three ply material, and well made lockers constructed for materials and books. The new single desks are well arranged.

The classrooms are well ventilated, and electric light is available when required. Heating is by means of wood burning stoves.

Classroom Register (Is a careful tally made morning and afternoon?)

The classroom Registers are kept with care.

Report on School Work.

Junior Room: Teacher Miss K. Hocking. 40 Desks.

All Day Class. Grade 5; Grade 4A; Grade 4B; Grade 3; Grade 2; Grade 1A; Grade 1B. Total: 28.

Reading: Grade 1B know about 50 words and are now at work on "Two Little Indians." This is a very good little group and they certainly have been well taught from the Blackboard. Grade 1A are near the end of the Canadian Reader Book I. They had previously read "Two Little Indians." Another good group who can read well. Grade 2 are doing very good work in the Second Canadian Reader, as are Grade 4A and Grade 5 in the Fourth and Fifth Canadian Readers.

(Under this heading the Inspector should report upon the classroom activity generally and offer any suggestions for improvement.)

Arithmetic: Grade 1B can read and write numbers and can add. Grade 1A are "Good" at the Combinations and Separations up to 20. Grade 2 can add and subtract. These children have not followed the best method in learning this work; but the work is known. Grade 4B are at work on Multiplication by two and three figures, and should be able to complete Long Division by the end of the School Year. Grade 4A is reviewing Long Division, and Grade 5 is at Fractions. In the All Canada Test, Grade 4B made a Mid Score of 20, the Norm for the Grade being 18. Grade 4A made a Mid Score of 22, the Norm for the Grade being 21. Grade 5 made a Mid Score of 26, the Norm for that Grade being 27.

Achievement: In the B.C. Achievement Test which covers all the school subjects Grade 5 made a Mid Score of 33, the Norm being 39.1. This is only a little below average.

Art: Work is on display. The work seems to be very well done.

General: The Blackboards were full of suitable seat work. The teacher had a Time Table and knew just what she hoped to cover in the lessons taught. The Sand Table was in use.

The teacher's control of the class was "Good". I taught several short lessons to demonstrate points in method. It will be understood that Miss Hocking has received her training at the University of British Columbia and not at a Normal School. This makes it rather more difficult for her to appreciate the peculiar methods used in Primary Work.
Senior Room: Teacher, Mr. S. Bailey. 26 Desks.

Half Day System. Morning Class:- Grade 8, 5; Grade 7, 8.
Afternoon Class:- Grade 6 9.

Reading: Grades 7 and 8 are working on the prescribed course.
They are reading the Lady of the Lake, Voice of Canada, Etc.
Grade 6 has nearly finished the Fifth Canadian Reader. All this work is "Good".

Language: All the above Grades use the Work Books in English Usage and Composition.

Geography: Grades 7 and 8 are using the Senior Geography by Cornish.
This is a book which is not suitable for the Indian Schools and in fact will be changed in the Provincial Schools in the very near future. Grade 6 is working from the B.C.Edition of the Junior Geography, a book which will cover the needs of our Senior Grades till such time as the senior volume of this work is off the press. I gave a test to these children in Geography, making use of the Stevenson South Africa Part I scale.
Grade 8 made a Mid Score of 37, the June Norm being 35.
Grade 6 made a Mid Score of 14, the June Norm being 22.

Arithmetic: Grade 8 are working on elementary Algebra as laid down in the prescribed course. Grade 7 are working on Percentage, and Grade 6 are starting Percentage. In the All Canada Test in the Fundamentals, the following scores were made:
Grade 8 made a Mid Score of 40, the Norm being 39.
Grade 7 made a Mid Score of 36, the Norm being 35,
Grade 6 made a Mid Score of 34, the Norm being 31. These results are "Very Good" and reflect great credit on the teacher.

Singing: No Singing is taught in this room.

History: This is being taught in a systematic manner.

Grammar: Very Good work is being done. The prescribed text is in use. I taught a short lesson in this subject.

Art: The drawing from Nature is "Good".

Spelling: Tested with the Buckingham Ayre's Scale,
Grade 8 made a Mid Score of 100% the June Norm being 98%
Grade 7 made a Mid Score of 96% the June Norm being 94%

Achievement Test: The B.C.Achievement Test was given to these pupils with the following result:
Grade 8 made a Mid Score of 87, the Norm for the Grade being 82.2
Grade 7 made a Mid Score of 71, the Norm being 65.6
Grade 6 made a Mid Score of 46, the Norm being 52.7 The Grade 7 and 8 scores are very good indeed, and well in advance of the averages made in the Provincial Day Schools.

General: The classroom is 24 feet by 24 feet. The Blackboards are 70 feet by 4 feet. The room is finished in three ply lamatco above the Blackboards. There are eight large windows. The heating is by a woodburning heater. Everything is well looked after. The teacher's control of the class is "Very Good".
This is probably one of the best classrooms in the B.C.Indian Residential Schools at the present time. As mentioned above the five children registered in Grade 8 all wrote the Provincial test for High School and all passed with high marks.
Location: The school is located on Flores Island off the West Coast of Vancouver Island. It is reached by C.P.R. Coast Service from Port Alberni three times a month.

Buildings: The buildings are the property of the Women's Missionary Society of the United Church of Canada. Since my last report the Manual Training Class under supervision has erected a second classroom described on previous pages of this report, and a building consisting of a large Manual Training room on the ground floor and a Boys' Dormitory with accommodation for a supervisor's room on the first floor. This dormitory is 24 feet by 48 feet with an 12 feet by 16 feet supervisor's room. The old woodshed which is falling down is only 12 feet from the wall of this new building. I consider this old woodshed more or less of a fire hazard, and should like to recommend its removal. A new woodshed could be erected by the Manual Training Class if they were provided with lumber for this purpose. This woodshed should be about 24 feet by 48 feet and should be erected at a little distance from the other buildings and not far from the sea. There is a perfectly suitable site available. The total cost of the lumber should be under $200.00, and I should only care to recommend this in the event of the Manual Training Class carrying out the work.

There is a fine wooden playground made with cedar planks. This has been added to since my last visit. It is now about 90 feet by 50 feet. The girls play basket ball here.

A new floor is rather urgently required in the Dining Room and adjoining Kitchen. The present floor is very much worn. New treads on the steps of the stairs to playrooms are required. Extensive painting of the outside of the buildings is now necessary.

The above remarks cover the main features noticed with regard to the actual buildings. I am not prepared to state just who should pay for the recommendations should these be sanctioned. No doubt the United Church who own the building would be approached in this matter.

Vocational Training: In addition to the usual house work, the girls learn to mend, darn, patch, make clothes, etc. They make the boys' shirts. They knit, crochet, embroider, and do bead work. There are three sewing machines here, one being used by the staff. I believe that one new Singer Sewing machine TAILOR MODEL and one ordinary Singer machine should be added to the equipment, and charged against appropriations for Vocational Training in B.C.

Manual Training: The Principal teaches this subject, and I am glad to be able to report that the work done at this school during the past year has been very good. Much of it has been in the nature of construction work. The new addition to the classroom block, the new M.T. work shop with dormitory over it, and the addition to the wooden playground have all been erected in first class style. A detailed statement from the Principal is attached to this report.

Fire Protection: There are three soda type extinguishers. These ought to be refilled, and the Indian Agent has been communicated with in this matter by the Principal. There are also five small Pyrene extinguishers. Inside the building there are two hydrants with hose. The water supply is from a tank at one end of the building. This tank is on about the level of the roof of the main building, and is about twelve feet in diameter and ten feet deep. There is not of course sufficient pressure to send water over the main roof of the school.

The water supply is from a surface well which is 18 feet deep to rock. This water is always slightly coloured, and gets rather bitter in summer. It has been analysed and found to be of good quality. The colour is probably due to the fact that there is a cedar swamp quite near the well. The supply of water available in the above mentioned well is satisfactory for domestic purposes. The well is ten feet by twelve feet and eight feet deep, when the water is most abundant. The tank can be kept full from this well during the summer by pumping twice a day. The pumping is done by a 6 H.P. Fairbanks gas engine attached to a pump. This engine also supplies the power to run the laundry machinery mentioned below.

Regular fire drills are held and that carried out during my visit was quite satisfactory.

I should like to recommend that the Department provide a thick rope, at one end of which a large iron ring should be permanently fitted, so that in the event of fire the boys from the new dormitory could have a means of climbing out of one of the windows of their dormitory and reaching the rocks below in safety. The iron ring could be placed under one leg of a bed near one of the windows. At present the only means of escape from this new dormitory is by means of a light stairway on the outside of the building, and this staircase is nearest to the greatest fire hazard, the old broken down woodshed. Should the small boys have to jump from one of the windows they would be very seriously injured as the rocks are below the windows on the sea side of the building.

Dormitories: These are all kept in perfectly clean and neat condition. Six beds and matresses are required to complete the equipment of the new dormitory. At present the boys here use some very old ship's cots bought second hand by the Principal.

Upper Landing: About five hundred square feet of V.joint sheeting and a dormer type skylight are required to shut in this upper landing. The cost would be about $50.00 for material and the boys of the Manual Training Class could easily do the work. This dormer window would greatly improve the ventilation of the main building.

The erection of Carpenter and Boatbuilding shop 34 feet X 48 feet with dormitory and one staff bedroom above, in the attic storage for lumber.
Construction of work benches, mitre boxes, mallets, brooms, inferior saws, and power house.
In addition to the above, all repair work on buildings and engines has been done by the boys; painting and glazing making of furniture, tables, bookcases, chiffoniers, washstands, benches, 62 paddles painted in legendary Indian designs, 52 totem poles, 9 cedar chests of red cedar trimmed with yellow cedar, totem poles at each corner, carved canoes for handles, the lid and front in Indian designs.
The construction of the boat "Dawn" 40 feet length, 10 feet beam drawing 4½ feet. Designed by the Principal and constructed by the boys; the material being supplied by the Department. This launch is a great asset to the school and a fine testimonial to the craftsmanship of the boys.
There are two small washing machines. These were supplied to the school a few years ago as previously reported. There are two laundry tubs, and an extractor.

The power to operate these machines is supplied from the 6 H.P. pumping engine mentioned above. The tank on the heater used for boiling water will need to be replaced. This old tank is galvanized and is feet by 1 feet by 3 feet. The engine mentioned above drives an old 1-125 K.W. General Electric generator.

There is a set of four year old batteries supplying 38 Volts in this system, which is the old lighting system of the school. The Principal asks for new batteries; but I pointed out to him that he has a new electric light system and does not need the old system. I could not recommend the supply of new batteries.

Lighting: The new Electric Light plant consists of a Kohler 110 Volt automatic 1500 Watt system, and the engine uses gas. This system is perfectly satisfactory. All new wires have been placed in pipes as a precaution against fire.

Dining Rooms: As I was staying at the school for several days I had a very good opportunity of seeing the food supplied to the children. I saw it cooked and served. A Diet Sheet is attached for the information of the Department. The quantity, quality, and variety of the food is very good.

The feeding of the Indian children is so nearly connected with the state of their health that it is not a surprise to find that the children have been very well during the past year. A statement with regard to their health is attached.

Kitchen: Part of the floor in the kitchen needs to be renewed. The kitchen range will need to be replaced in the near future, probably next year.

Freight Boat: The boys of the Manual Training Class have constructed a very fine freight boat. This boat was placed at my disposal to visit Christie Indian Residential School, and later to take me part of the way to Ucluelet. The engine supplied by the Department for this boat appears to be working very well indeed.

Sanitary Conditions: All wash places, toilets, and other parts of the school, including the playrooms are kept in a perfectly sanitary condition.

Farming: A statement from the Principal is attached. Farming is not being undertaken at this school. It is not even possible to keep a cow with profit. There are about eleven acres cleared but this is a swamp.

Basement: The heating at this school is by means of an Ideal coal burning hot water system. The plant is by Crane Ltd. and is numbered W-25-7. Fifty tons of coal are used yearly. I do not consider that there is very great need for this hot water heating plant to be inspected by an engineer, and the particulars given here are the result of a thorough inspection of the exterior of the furnace and boiler, in the hope that this might save the Department any expense. There is an exposed smoke pipe leading from the fire box of the furnace to the brick chimney, and this exposed smoke pipe is EIGHT INCHES below a large wooden beam in the ceiling of the Basement. I consider this highly dangerous, and pointed out the fire risk to the Principal. I suggested then that some asbestos covered with tar should be placed on the lower sides of the wooden beam. If the chimney caught fire and the smoke pipe turned red there would be great danger of fire here. I should like this matter taken up with the Principal. I did mention it to Mr. Indian Agent Frost on my return to Port Alberni. Mr. Frost was not with me during this inspection tour.
Statement of health and Diet sheet for one week.

During the past year our pupils have maintained their reputation as strong healthy children. The factors that have made this possible are as follows:

1. Ample supply of good food well prepared, every child is encouraged to eat until satisfied.
2. The first indication of indisposition is noted and the child placed in the care of the Nurse at once for treatment.
3. The children from families with a poor health record are given special care and food.
4. Long hours of sleep, the Juniors have 11 hours and the Seniors 9½ to 10 hours.
5. Recreation when weather permits, For bad wet weather we need an enclosed recreation hall.
6. Keeping the pupils interested in study work or play.

Financial Statement:

The attached Financial Statement for the period January 1, 1932 to December 31, 1932 was prepared for me while I was at the school. The books appear to me to be well kept. The general business administration is excellent. This school costs the W.M.S. of the United Church a considerable sum yearly in excess of the Per Capita Grant made by the Department.

General:

There is no doubt whatever that this is one of the best administered Indian Residential Schools in British Columbia. The children are very happy, a condition which I do not find prevailing in all our schools, and they are in the best of health. There is little if any corporal punishment. The work done in the schoolrooms is superior to that in similar schoolrooms in other Indian Residential Schools, and far superior to that of the Provincial Day Schools as the passing of the entire Eighth Grade in the Provincial Entrance Examination in June proves.

I have every reason to consider the Rev. Mr. Jones a highly efficient and successful principal, and I hope that he will remain here for a number of years. I know that he has lately refused a transfer to a school outside of this Province.

Dear Sir:

I have the honour to forward herewith my report on the Ahousaht Indian Residential School, West Coast Agency, which I inspected on March 23, & 24, 1936.

During my inspection I was accompanied by Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge. It was possible to make a very thorough inspection of the school as we spent two nights there, before leaving for Christie Indian Residential School on the morning of the 25th of March.

I held the usual Fire Drill and found that the children could only use the ordinary stairways from the dormitories, as they had not been trained to come down the wooden fire escapes. I made a thorough inspection of these fire escapes and my remarks are contained in the attached report. The expense of the usual iron escapes would be high and I feel that the wooden escapes here might easily be made safe and convenient to use. I believe that the Indian Agent might well be asked to make a report on this subject.

The most important item in my report is that to do with the extension of the Half Day System here, and the more extensive training in Vocational work, Manual Training, and Marine Engine Repairing, which will be possible with the extra time available. I certainly hope that the Officials of the Schools' Branch will agree with me that the appointment of a Manual Training Instructor here who could instruct in Marine Engine Work and take the old Vice Principal would be well worth the expenditure of the usual grant in aid of this from the B.C. Special Vote. I understand that the local Indians are very anxious for the extension of the Vocational Training along the lines I have suggested in my report, and that the Indian Agent is prepared to make a report on this matter in the near future.

It was a great pleasure to meet the new Principal, Mr. Caldwell, and to find him so well adapted for the special form of educational work that he is now called upon to undertake.

Your obedient servant,

Gerald H. Perry
District Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Report on Ahousaht Indian Residential School:

Vocational Training:

There is no Manual Training Instructor at this school at the present time. As far as the Boys' work is concerned the Principal reports that they have since he took charge of the school in September done the following:

Repairs to building. Renewing shingles.
Painting entire outside of main school building, two colours, two coats.
Making Christmas toys for junior relatives in the Village, wagons, kiddie-cars, etc.
Clearing out ditching draining farm land, and deepening of ditch through rock. Work done with engine and winch.
Clearing and stumping of land at rear of school suitable for vegetable growing. Stumps pulled with engine and winch.
Planting of nursery of 100 loganberry plants, 100 blackcurrants, 50 gooseberry, 25 cherry and plum, and the permanent planting of 120 rhubarb roots.
Carving of Indian work, totems, eagles, etc.

The above are the Principal's own words.
I saw some of the work done by the Girls.
They are taught in turn the work of the house, cooking, bread making, etc. In addition they mend, patch, darn, crochet, knit, etc.
Some very fine bead work has been done by a number of the girls.
This bead work is much ahead of any done in our other Indian schools.

While at the school I was approached by three of the chief Indians who explained to me that they wished for some sort of training for their boys in the maintenance and repair of marine engines.
The Principal and the Indian Agent were also present at this meeting with the Indian Chiefs.
I explained to the Indians that the Department was anxious to have the boys learn those things which would be of use to them after they left school, and that while I did not know just how far the Department might be willing to go, I should make a recommendation to cover their request. This of course satisfied the Indian Chiefs.

I have talked the matter over with the Principal and the Indian Agent, who will no doubt report himself on this matter. I wish to recommend to the Department that the usual grant of some $450.00 per annum be given to this school to enable the Principal to employ a well trained Instructor who could teach the boys to take down and repair the ordinary gas engines, and if possible the newer types of engines now used in the larger fishing boats. This man should also be able to instruct in the more practical wood work, the making of those articles which will be required as the farming operations are enlarged here, and the construction of the simple furniture, tables, chairs, etc., used in Indian homes. I am convinced that the expenditure of say $450.00 from the B.C. Special Vote for this Vocational Work would be of the greatest possible advantage here.

I have also to recommend that the Half Day System be extended here to allow for more outdoor exercise for the Girls and Boys. This will give better opportunity for Vocational Training. I have gone into the matter with very great care, and find that the following changes can easily be made in the Classroom Work, and I would recommend that they be so made as from the opening of school after the summer vacation.

Junior Room An ALL DAY CLASS consisting of Grades 1, 2, and 3 only.
Senior Room Half Day System: Grades 6, 7, and 4 should be taken together as either a Morning or Afternoon Class, while Grades 6 & 5 should form the other class for Afternoon or Morning. The classes so formed would rotate month by month from the Morning to the Afternoon. I understand that this suggestion has the approval of the Principal and the Indian Agent. It will do much for the school, and I would ask the Department to sanction it as soon as possible.
Report on Ahousaht Indian Residential School

Page 5.

Fire Protection:

There are three Soda Type extinguishers. In my last report I recommended that these be recharged. This was done on October 12, 1935. There are also five small Pyrene extinguishers. Inside the building there are two hydrants with the usual hose. The water supply is from a tank at one end of the building. This tank is about on the level of the roof of the main building. It is twelve feet in diameter and some ten feet deep. There is not of course sufficient pressure in the pipes to send water over the roof of the school.

The water supply is from a surface well, which is some twelve feet deep to rock. The water is always coloured, probably from a small pine leakage or vegetable matter, there being a cedar swamp near the school. This is being drained now. The well being ten feet by twelve feet and as above mentioned going to rock with about eight feet of water at the most abundant season, gives sufficient water for all domestic purposes. The tank can be filled by pumping twice a day in summer. This pumping is done by a 6 H.P. Fairbanks engine attached to the pump. The well did go dry for a time last summer but conditions were very unusual.

I went into the question of Fire Escapes and Fire Drills with great care. I noticed that my recommendation for a rope with an iron ring to fit under the leg of a bed has not been acted on in the new dormitory building. It is true that a second stairway has been constructed in that building, and the old wood shed removed.

To put it very bluntly, I AM NOT SATISFIED THAT PROPER FIRE DRILLS HAVE BEEN HELD AT THIS SCHOOL SINCE MY LAST INSPECTION. Fire Drills have been held down the stairs, but I do not believe that the old wooden fire escapes have been used for a long time. There are two of these wooden fire escapes, one at each end of the main school building. Neither reaches to the ground. The steps on the Girls' Fire Escape are so narrow that it is most dangerous for a child to come down. To make my inspection complete I managed to climb up this escape, but had difficulty in coming down and had in fact to face the escape and use it as a ladder. As the escape does not reach within some eight feet to the ground I could not get down till a boy got a step ladder and helped me. Such a condition should I think be put away with for the sake of the children, even if the Department does not own the building. The exit from the dormitories to the escapes is by way of windows, which are covered with light wire screens. These can be knocked out by means of the axes kept near the windows. I think these wire screens might well be removed, and the windows just fastened with string and wax seal.

I would recommend that the fire escape on the Boys' side of the school be continued by steps to the ground, a very simple thing for the Manual Training Class to do if they had the material. On the Girls' side the last flight of steps at least should be renewed and placed in a better position to give a more gradual slope and thus permit much wider steps. This escape should also be continued to the ground. The windows on the Girls' side should also have the wire screens taken off and string and wax used as a seal.

I would ask the Department to provide the Principal with a copy of the regulations for Fire Drills, which the last Principal does not appear to have handed to Mr. Caldwell. I would also urge that when the Fire Escapes have been lengthened as suggested above and the one on the Girls' side changed, regular drills be organized down the new escapes.

A wooden escape might well be constructed to a window in the new dormitory building. Iron escapes are not in my opinion necessary here. They are just as dangerous as wooden escapes though they look safer. If there is any fire near an escape, iron or wood children will not come down it.
Dormitories: The question of wire screens over the windows leading to the Fire Escapes has been taken up above.

The general condition of the dormitories is very good. There are plenty of extra covers available should they be required. There is no overcrowding. The Principal is renewing some of the work out mattresses.

Dining Rooms: The floors of the Dining Room and Kitchen are being renewed. I spent several days at this school and therefore had a very good opportunity to see the food supplied to the children cooked and served. The Dining Room is perfectly clean and the meals are well served.
Water Supply: This is from a surface well. The quality of the water is satisfactory, though the colour is a distinct yellow. The water has been analysed lately and found to be fit to drink. The water is pumped into a tank located over the fire escape at the end of the main school building. The pressure in the fire mains is of course very low as the tank is only on a level with the roof of the main building.

Sanitary Conditions:

While these are not satisfactory in certain directions it is certainly not the fault of the Principal or members of the Staff. The whole of the school is perfectly clean. Old floors however make it hard to keep in this condition and in several rooms the Principal is relaying the floors, the new material being now at the school. The work will be done as soon as the children are away on vacation.

There are only two wash basins and one wash tub downstairs for all the boys. There is no toilet upstairs for the use of the Boys at night. There are in fact only two toilets for the Boys downstairs. The toilet accommodation on the Girls' side of the school is more satisfactory, there being a bath, two wash basins, and a toilet upstairs, and one wash basin and two toilets downstairs. The children are given at least one warm and supervised bath per week. I have no doubt that the present Principal will do all in his power to add to the above mentioned sanitary conveniences as soon as possible. In the meantime he is reflooring some of the wash places and basement rooms.

The kitchens, dining rooms, etc., are kept quite clean.

General:

I considered this school to be in a very satisfactory condition under the previous Principal, though as far as I can learn things were not quite so good towards the end of his time here. Mr. Caldwell has taken hold in a very efficient manner, and it is obvious that in a short time the school will be one of the very best in British Columbia even if it is not as large as some. I am glad to see that the Principal and Indian Agent are working in complete harmony for the good of the school. At least one new teacher will be required for the next school year, and if the Department will sanction it, a Manual Training Instructor who might also act as Vice Principal.

The available farm land, though I do not report on this matter as a rule, might well be put under cultivation now that it has been to a larger extent drained. I would recommend that the Agricultural Agent for British Columbia be asked to visit the school to help the Principal with his farming problems. If some cows could be kept here, and I believe they might be, the fresh milk would be a great help to the children. Vegetables of some sort could I think be grown with success. The Principal needs the advice of an expert in farming as to how he may best use the available land.

The children are well clothed, and appear to be very happy. I consider the general standing of the school to be "Very Good", and I wish to congratulate the Principal on the start he has made here.

Report on Inspection of Ahousaht Indian Residential School. February 26, 1927.

In main building a large gong has been installed, with key attached to each floor, and in basement. Gong is very loud, and plainly heard all over the building. Gong is also being installed in outside dormitory, where a few pupils are lodged.

Escapes are placed at either end of building, and have been extended to reach from upper floor to the ground. These escapes are in good order, and were found satisfactory. A third escape is being built at centre of building, giving access to both ends of building.

It is recommended that ropes be placed at windows of this building, secured inside, to augment the existing means of escape, viz the outside stairways. This has been referred to the Principal for his action.

Escape Windows.

Dormitory windows giving access to escapes are kept on inside latch, easily opened, and windows have been fitted to prevent difficulty in opening.

Electric Wiring.

All electric wiring has been overhauled, and is insulated. Current is generated by small engine in outside building, and power is turned off after the school children retire.

Storage of Gasoline.

Gasoline for power engine is stored in drums, and kept outside of building, with exception of feed supply for engine, and is considered safe.

Heating.

Main building is heated from coal furnace and steam boiler in basement. Furnace room is clean and free from rubbish. Pipes was thought to be too close to overhead wooden beams, and these have now been covered with asbestos.
Report on Inspection of Ahousaht Indian Residential School, February 26, 1927.

Hearing (cont.)

One small heater is kept in sitting room. Walls and floor about it are protected with galvanized iron.

Kitchen Stove and Chimney.

A lawes steamship stove is provided for the kitchen, with a separate chimney, apparently in good order. No fire is left in this stove overnight.

Fire Pails and Axes

Fire pails and axes are kept in each dormitory, and extinguishers are kept on the landings at head of stairs. Extinguishers are in good order, and pails are filled with water.

Fire Drill.

Fire drills are regularly carried out, and at this inspection the building was evacuated in less than 3 minutes. This, however, under ideal conditions.

Fire Hose.

100 ft. of 2" canvas hose, attached to hydrant, is kept at either end of building; but is considered useless except for use in basement or ground floor, as there is no water pressure.

Store Room.

Store rooms are kept clean and free of litter. Paint and oil was found stored in small room under main building, and the Principal is being advised to have this class of material stored away from building.

Workshop.

Workshop was found clean and clear of shavings and inflammable material. This room is kept locked when not occupied.
Supply of water for fire fighting purposes is derived from a well, pumped to a storage tank suspended on a wooden trestle, over a wooden fire escape, about 3000 gallons capacity.

Pressure is by gravity from this tank, and was found insufficient to throw a stream of water to the second story. It is totally inadequate to be of any use in a fire.

Discipline.

Discipline is excellent, and children and staff are well posted as to their various stations, in case of fire.

Watchman.

The nightwatchman is a very conscientious man, and very thorough and capable in the execution of his duties.

Buildings.

As reported before, the main building can only be described as a fire trap and menace. I cannot but feel very apprehensive about the building, as I am fully convinced that nothing could save it in case of fire.

For this reason, I have advised the Principal to devote all his efforts to the saving of life, and the prevention of fire, by constant care and regular drills and inspections.

Respectfully submitted,

Indian Agent.

Sanitary Conditions:

The Principal and supervisors do all that they can, I believe, to keep the place clean. It is a very old building and can never again be strictly clean. I am satisfied that the whole of the school is cleaner than was the case when I last visited here in April 1937.

In several reports I have explained the lack of sufficient toilet and washroom accommodation.

There are only two wash basins and one wash tub downstairs for the thirty-eight boys. There is no toilet upstairs for the use of the boys at night. There are in fact only two downstairs toilets for the boys and these are in a dark partitioned off part of the basement.

On the girls' side the accommodation is a little better. Here there are a bath, two wash basins, and a toilet upstairs, and one wash basin and two toilets on the ground floor.

The children are clean, though I understand that in common with many Indian children at the West Coast schools they are rather troubled with fleas. These exist in large numbers in the Indian villages and are a trouble to members of the staff as well as to the children. The children have at least one warm supervised bath a week. Two boys no longer share a bath together as mentioned in my last report.

The general sanitary condition of the school might be improved as I said in my last report. This has been partly achieved but I wish to recommend the following changes even if the school buildings are only to be used for one more year.

A single toilet should be placed in the boys' dormitory in the same way that this has been done on the girls' side of the school. This toilet can easily be connected to the present black iron plumbing, and water pipe also attached.

The present two toilets in the boys' basement should be taken right out of the school. The smell from these very old type toilets is bad. The actual toilets and tanks are of no further use. No new toilet bowls should be placed in the basement on the boys' side.

A range of at least four new toilets should be constructed outside the school buildings and at the rear of the present schoolrooms for the use of the boys. These toilets would be placed over pits dug sufficiently deep. There would be no danger of the school well being contaminated as there is a deep ditch with water draining to the sea between the proposed site of the new toilets and the school.

This matter has been mentioned to the Indian Agent and I have asked the Principal to talk to the Agent about it as the matter is urgent.

The septic tanks overflowed since my last inspection. They were then emptied by buckets, but the fluid in the drain pipes backing up spread under the school. Lime was used freely I am told. Part of the trouble is the usual draining of soap and water from the laundry and kitchens into the septic tanks. The bacteria are thus killed and the tanks do not function. I doubt that much can be done except to lay a new drain for the laundry water which could be taken away to the low lying ground at the back of the school.
General:

The children are well clothed, and appear happy. The tone in the school is not as good as was the case on the occasion of my last inspection. This is due to two facts:-

(a) Children have come here from Alberni Indian Residential School, where every member of the Staff carried a strap, I am now informed. These children have never learned how to work without punishments and have not helped the Ahousaht School.

(b) The present Girls' Supervisor is from the Alberni Residential School Staff and though her ideas of constant punishment have been considerably curtailed by the Principal, her influence on staff and girls is distinctly poor in my opinion. She will be permitted to resign at the end of June and will I hope never be again employed in an Indian school.

The general administration of the school is no better than was the case last year. The Principal knows perfectly well the things that should be done, and should not be done in a school like this. I consider Mr. Caldwell a very fine Principal. He is allowing his nerves to get the better of him, and resorts on occasion, on his own statement, to the use of the drug called in popular language Luminal. I told him this was a poor practice, but he uses it he says on Sundays to help him to get through the many duties of that day.

The heating of the school is by means of hot water.

I wish to recommend that the boiler expert, Mr Arnall, be sent to examine the boiler at this school, and to advise on what might be done to protect the laundry machinery or rather the children using it from accident. Only a very short time ago one boy had his arm smashed up in the extractor and has in consequence lost the arm.

I suggested the erection of simple wooden guards which could be done by the Manual Training Class or the older boys in the case that there is no actual Manual Training Class. I told the Principal that I should recommend that the Boiler Inspector be sent to the school and that he would then no doubt examine the other machinery at the school and advise.

The wash rooms and kitchen, and other parts of the school, with exceptions noted above, were in reasonably clean condition.

I believe that I have covered in general the more important items noted during the inspection.

An approved oil burner is being used in the kitchen range, and vitrified ware is being used on the children's dining tables in place of old enamelled plates and mugs.

Duncan, B.C.
March 20, 1938.

Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Gerald H. Barry,

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Ahousaht Indian Residential School, West Coast Agency, which I inspected on April 5th, though I was a guest of the school for several days.

Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge was with me during the larger part of the inspection.

Much of the work done during my time at Ahousaht was in connection with my School Survey of the West Coast Agency. The report on this will have now been read, and I would ask you to consider the general rather poor condition of things at Ahousaht as but one feature of the general school situation on the coast.

I do not recommend any great expenditure on the present Ahousaht School. The building is not the property of the Indian Affairs Branch, but is owned by the Women's Missionary Society of the United Church of Canada.

There is quite sufficient lumber now at the school to allow for the erection in the village of Ahousaht of a good one room Day School. This lumber was provided for the new laundry and gymnasium building, but I would recommend that all further building operations at the Ahousaht Residential School be delayed till a decision has been reached as to where a Residential School is to be located on the Coast.

I believe that Ucluelet is the proper place for the Consolidated School, and that Ahousaht can be taken care of by a good one room Day School.

The present Principal's Residence here would serve as a home for the local Missionary and/or a boarding place for the teacher of the proposed Day School.

The present school building here will probably serve for another couple of years without much further outlay. It is not well designed as a school and there is distinct risk in case of fire. In many places there are openings where fire could rush up to the dormitories from the ground floor. In fact the sooner that the present Ahousaht School building is given up as a Residential School the better.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Vocational Training:

The Vocational Instruction of the Girls is that usual in the Indian Residential Schools in this Province. They learn to cook, and carry out the various cleaning operations in the house. They sew, mend, darn, patch, crochet, knit, etc. In the way of Arts and Crafts some very nice bead work is done by the older girls. There do not appear to be any special classes for the Girls in the Vocational Training. They simply learn by doing the various operations. One or two of the older girls help in the Principal's Residence and thus gain a knowledge of more advanced house work, cooking, etc.

I should like to see far more definite instruction given in Arts and Crafts which would enable the Indian women to make a little money by work done in their own homes. Much of the mat work and weaving around articles done on the West Coast is very well carried out and in advance of the same sort of thing done in other parts of British Columbia.

The Half Day System has been extended here as recommended in my former report of March 1936 Page 4. Although Mr. R. F. Schuetze has been appointed as Manual Training Instructor, and the school receives the usual grant of some $480.00 per annum towards salary, little if any regular Manual Training has been done.

It will be remembered that the Indian parents approached me and asked that their boys be taught the maintenance and repair of marine engines. This is mentioned on Page 4 of my last report. Nothing has so far been done in this line of activity.

The Principal tells me that they have been much occupied in the following projects in which the boys helped. I shall give the Principal's own words:

"Work done by the boys during the year:
Carpentry and building construction in building of a residence at the school, a porch in front of the school building, additions to fire escape, floor laying in school building, cement mixing. Gardening in planting and care of rhubarb and small fruits. General in clearing of land and pulling stumps by machinery. Various engine repairs and construction of stump pulling machinery. Occasional fishing by older boys."

I doubt that the work done in pulling stumps has been worth while. The new Principal's Residence was no doubt needed if the school is to be carried on here. The additions to the Fire Escapes were necessary.

The fact of the matter is that the Vocational Training here is not anything more than just the ordinary everyday work of the school, and far below the standard that I expected when I recommended the extension of the Half Day System. In a small school with a small staff it is most difficult to arrange for the type of Manual Training and other Vocational Training which will be of use to the pupils on graduation. I still consider that there is room for a great advance in this sort of work at this school.

Fire Protection: This was covered in detail in my last report. Briefly I may say that the ropes recommended in the new dormitory building have been placed there. Rings have not been fitted. The ropes are tied to the beds. The screens over the windows through which exit is made from the dormitories to the fire escapes have been removed, and the windows are only fixed with small hooks which any child could open in a second.

The escapes have been continued to the ground as I recommended.

The Principal tells me that he has been provided with a copy of the regulations for Fire Drills. I am satisfied that Drills are carried out, the one I saw during my visit was "Satisfactory".
Fire Protection: Continued.

The following are the exact words of the Principal with regard to Fire Appliances as handed in a statement to me.

"Three fire gongs, one on second and third floor of main building, one in outside dormitory. Two automatic switches, one on main and one on second floor of main building. Two switches, one in basement furnace room, one in outside dormitory building. Any and all of these switches and automatic alarms will operate all gongs.

Two outside wooden fire escapes, one on each side of the building, opening out of all dormitories. Steps kept sanded. Windows affording egress to fire escapes sufficiently large for exit, approached in smaller children's dormitories by short steps from inside; all exit windows easily opened, two on hinges. Axes kept at each window. Three fire pails, kept full, in each dormitory. Two exits by stairs from outside dormitory, in which are also ropes affording exit from all windows.

Night watchman patrolling building, inside and out, at night. Fire drills taken. Time for emptying school and checking children outside under daylight drill conditions, 1 minute.

All members of staff instructed in fire emergency duties. Seven fire extinguishers distributed throughout building and in lighting power house. Gasoline for engines kept well away from buildings.

No fires kept in any premises throughout the night."

I am now satisfied that Fire Drills are being held in this school.

Dormitories: The general condition of the dormitories does not appear to me to be as good as on former visits. The rooms require more airing, and windows should be kept open even at night.

When I visited one of the Boys' Dormitories the windows in the day time were all closed; there was a definitied smell in the room. I turned down ONE bed and found that the sheets and mattress had been wet by the boy under the bed beside on. This was of course pointed out to the Principal who tells me that the boy in question is one of those from Alberni Residential School, who does not as yet altogether know the rules of the school on this matter. I think the dormitories might be cleaner and the beds better made up.

There are plenty of covers for the children. Some of the mattresses have been renewed since my last visit.

There were no signs of overcrowding.

Dining Rooms: The floors of the Dining Room and Kitchen have been renewed since my last visit.

As I spent several days at the school, I had a good opportunity to observe the type of meals served to the children.

The Weekly Menu is the same as that copied into my last report, and it is not being repeated here for that reason. The Principal tells me that he is supplying rather more fish now.

The Kitchen and Dining Room are clean and the meal served in a satisfactory manner. The food is in my opinion of sufficient quantity, good quality, and fair variety.
Inspector's Report on Ahousaht School:

Water Supply: This is as previously reported from a surface well. The quality of the water is satisfactory, though the colour is a distinct yellow.

Pumped from the well the water is stored in a small tank located over the Girls' Fire Escape at the end of the school building. The pressure in the hose pipes is very low, as the tank is on a level with the top of the building.

There is no possibility of successful attack on a fire which had any start. The proper thing to do here is to clear the building in case of fire and let the school burn. There is not sufficient water to fight fire in any case.

Sanitary Conditions:

While I believe that the Principal and Staff do all they can to keep the place clean, the general impression received from a thorough examination of the whole school is one of lack of a high standard of cleanliness.

It is true that in such an old building as this the cleaning of floors etc. is difficult. I still believe that more could be done, and the children trained in dusting and polishing, at least to a greater extent than is being done at the moment. The dormitories need greater attention.

I explained in my last report the lack of sufficient toilet and washroom accommodation.

There are only two wash basins and one wash tub downstairs for all the boys. There is no toilet upstairs for the use of the boys at night. There are in fact only two downstairs toilets for the boys.

On the Girls' side the toilet accommodation is a little better. Here there are a bath, two wash basins, and a toilet upstairs, and one wash basin and two toilets on the ground floor.

The children are clean. They receive at least one warm supervised bath per week. The Principal informs me that two boys have to share the bath together.

The kitchens and other parts of the school are clean. On the whole the school is not tidy.

The general sanitary condition of the school might I think be greatly improved even if the building is so old that its replacement within a few years in either Ahousaht or other coast village is a matter of necessity.

General:

The children are well clothed, and appear happy. There is a good tone in the school. The whole place is administered as a sort of large family.

The classroom work is one of the best features of the school. The lack of definite Manual Training has been noted, and I am sorry that more instruction in marine engine work has not been attempted. Too much time has been given to clearing land which I much doubt will ever be used.

Far more supervised play is necessary.

The old Basket Ball court, made of a large wooden playground, has been allowed to fall into such a state of disrepair that it is impossible to use it. The new playroom or gymnasium will be held up till the Indian Affairs Branch decides just where a new Residential School will be placed.

I doubt that the general administration is as good as it was on the occasion of my last inspection, and I would ask that the decision as to the location of any new school be made as soon as possible.

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Ahousaht Indian Residential School, West Coast Agency, which I inspected on March 14th, though I was at the school from March 13th to the morning of the 15th.

During my visit I had plenty of time to note the conditions of the school, and was glad to find that there had been some improvement in the sanitary state of the buildings since my previous report.

Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge was not with me during any part of the inspection as he was delayed by the great storm we have had on the west coast this last week. He will however see the school on his present inspection trip up the coast, and I spoke to him of one or two matters when we met at Tofino the most important of which was the provision of outside toilet accommodation for the boys. I think that the school will be able to arrange this without expense or reference to the Department. Mr. Caldwell was informed by me that if he wished to use any part of the available lumber at the school he would have to get the sanction of the Department as this lumber was provided for a laundry, etc., at present held up till the Indian Affairs Branch decide on the location of a new Residential School on the West Coast.

Mrs Caldwell has been ill and had I am told an operation when in Victoria a few months ago. She is not taking any part in the management of the school now. She looked to me rather ill.

I explained to Mr. Caldwell that what he called the Indian Agent's promise that a new Residential School would be built this year should never have been given as the Indian Agent has no knowledge of where or when the Department may decide to build a school. I told him that I did not know just what would be done, but that in any case he had better make arrangements to continue the Ahousaht Residential School for at least another year from September 1938. I explained that it would take time to build a new Residential School in any case and that I was not certain that the Department would have the funds necessary this year. His own letter from the Woman's Missionary Society indicates that Mr. Hoey considered that no funds were available in the 1938-39 estimates and that the use of the Ahousaht School must be continued for the present.

I do not think that there is anything else of a confidential nature to which your attention should be drawn at the present time.

Yours very truly,

In general the children have been promoted to their present Grades on the opening of the Spring Term February 1st last.
The afternoon class is much brighter than the Morning group of pupils.
The Arithmetic is well up to standard. I have suggested a better grouping of Grades for this subject. Not sufficient attention has been given to Art.
I spent some time in talking to children and teacher with regard to this. The whole subject of the work to be sent to Vancouver for the forthcoming Arts and Crafts Exhibition was gone into with care after Evens Prayers when the Staff and older pupils were all together.
I think rather advanced texts are being used in History in Grades 7 and 8. This is to prepare the pupils for the High School Entrance Test. I taught an outline lesson on British History to link this up with World and Canadian History, and suggested that the teacher would do well to just fill in the detail in the outline thus given.
Spelling is good.
Geography is perhaps just satisfactory. More work is necessary on the various parts of the British Empire.

Though there has not been much change since the last inspection in the type of work done I do think that there has been some progress.

Still more oral teaching is necessary. This is of course just where young teachers find the work so difficult. They rely far too much on texts which they have not themselves read in many cases. May I here again suggest that the Department while giving all the Work Books asked for cut down the supply of actual text books to a minimum. One of each of the new texts in History and Geography and Science is all that is necessary. I much dislike to see the dozens of beautiful texts in some cases the teacher does not know anything like enough of the subjects to make it possible for the children to make use of the books so freely given by the Department. Work Books are of course in a different class and these are as a rule not very expensive and might well be distributed freely to give all the pupils a chance to improve their English.
Report on Ahousaht Indian Residential School: Page 3.

Remarks relative to examination of pupils continued:

Junior Room Division 2 Teacher Miss K. Sceats 38 desks.

All Day Class: Grades 3, 2, and 1. 38 pupils in all.

The children in these Grades were promoted to the various classes and Sub Grades in September.

In general the Reading is quite good. Grade 1C know some 60 Sight Words and are about halfway through Two Little Indians. With an experienced teacher this would now be finished. Grade 1B are at the end of Friends, and should now read the Highroads Primer from the Board and do other reading work in any texts available. Grades 1A, 2, and 3 are reading the Highroads Reader and Grade 3 works the exercises in the Reading Exercise Work Book. Grades 3 and 2 are doing very good work in Arithmetic. Grade 3 knows Short Multiplication and Short Division to times 8, while Grade 2 can add and subtract when there is carrying and borrowing. The various Sub Grades of Grade 1 are far too slow in the Combinations and Separations. They must work quick drills daily and this has of course been explained to the teacher.

The Writing is very satisfactory. Art Work has improved since my last inspection.

The teacher has some very good work on the Boards. She has been given many suggestions.

It must be understood that this young teacher has as yet very little idea of the real methods which bring success in the classroom. Many old fashioned ideas of control and punishment will have to be eliminated, and she will need to understand the psychology of education better before she can be classified as a successful teacher.

Some distinct progress has been made since my last inspection however, and the general standing of the Grades is satisfactory.

Looking on the work of the two Divisions as a whole I may say that the duration given in this school is at much the same level as that of last year. Individual pupils have made progress, and Mr. Mathews has improved a little in his oral teaching. Much remains to be done still.

Suggestions of all sorts have been made to improve the work in the various Grades. I have taught lessons myself and obtained very good response from the pupils.

The children coming on from the late Alberni Indian Residential School have upset the work here, just as they have at the Ucluelet Indian Day School.

The Alberni Indian Residential School was so badly managed that its effects are now being felt in the other schools to which pupils have been transferred.

With kind treatment and good teaching technique Mr. Mathews and Miss Sceats may again bring these Divisions to the standard achieved before the arrival of the Alberni children.
Vocational Training:

The whole of my remarks under this heading on Page 4 of my report of April 14th 1937 might with truth be copied here.

I am attaching as Page 5 of this report the statement of Manual and Vocational Training prepared for me at Ahousaht.

I am inclined to think that the girls get a good training in the usual work of a house. They learn to cook, sew, mend, darn, crochet, knit, and bake. A few of the older children help in the Principal's House and probably gain more from this than from the ordinary instruction in the school kitchens etc.

More instruction would be of advantage in Indian Arts and Crafts. My evening talk to staff and senior pupils will I believe lead to the employment of a Mrs. Nellie Jacobson (Indian) who could well instruct in basket making and weaving and bead work. The school will exhibit in Vancouver in the forthcoming Arts and Crafts Exhibition which has here already given incentive to greater effort in those arts which might bring in a little income to children on graduation.

The Mr. R.F. Schuetze mentioned in my last report as having been appointed a Manual Training Instructor is no longer here. It appears that any well trained man can easily get more than $480.00 a year in the new gold mines starting near here.

Though the Principal make quite a lot of the work done in Practical Engineering as stated on Page 5. I am not satisfied that in fact very much real training has been given. The work he speaks of is just that usual around a Residential School. It has been carried out under the supervision of his own son in part at least.

May I suggest that the grant of $480.00 made for Manual Training be withdrawn till a fairly well qualified man is appointed to the staff for this work. I am very much dissatisfied with the present Manual Training and Engineering, and find that the tools are not being in my opinion properly cared for. I could only find some of these, as they appear to be distributed in the boat, the Manual Training Shop, and other places.

Fire Protection:

This has been covered in detail in my previous reports on the school. Windows leading to fire escapes are fixed with string and seals, and small hooks which can be opened in a moment.

The Fire Drill carried out at my request was very satisfactory.

No fires are kept in any of the buildings through the night. This has made conditions rather hard on the staff and children in the cold weather.

A night watchman is employed for the six months November to April inclusive.

The Principal's report on the Fire Protection at the school is given as Page 6 of this report.

The fire hazard at this school is much greater than that in most of the other Indian Residential Schools in British Columbia.

Ahousaht Residential School. March 1938.

FIRE PREVENTION.

HEATING. Hot water heating system from furnace in basement.
Oil-burning range in Kitchen.
Wood heaters in staff sitting-room, two class-rooms, one outside dormitory, and in laundry.

ESCAPES. 1. Girls side. One three-stair zig-zag wooden escape built in frame work under water storage tank. Opening through window to escape from junior girls' dormitory on third floor, and senior girls' dormitory on second floor.
2. Boys side. One three-stair zig-zag wooden escape with opening through window from junior girls' dormitory on third floor, and senior boys' dormitory on second floor.
3. Rear of main building. One three-stair zig-zag wooden escape, erected in 1937, with opening from window of staff bed-room on third floor, affording additional escape from third floor dormitories, and opening from window of nurse's bed-room and hospital balconies, affording additional escape from senior boys and senior girls dormitories on second floor.

Outside junior boys' dormitory over workshop. Stairs leading to ground outside at front and back of building. Ropes attached at each window. Night watchman's quarters at rear of this dormitory.

FIRE FIGHTING EQUIPMENT.

Extinguishers. 4 Pyrene, 3 Guardene, all recharged in January 1938.
2 Fire axes.
Three water filled fire buckets on wall brackets near doorways in each dormitory, 15 in all. Two large buckets on landings.
Two-100 ft. lengths 2" fabric hose with nozzles (in only fair condition) attached to pipes leading from water tank, one at each side ground floor of main building, and capable of being attached to pump machinery in laundry.
Three large alarm bells, one each on first and second storey of main building and one in outside junior dormitory, all operating simultaneously from two alarm boxes, one on main floor and one on second floor, and from two switches, one in furnace room of school and one in watchman's quarters in outside junior dormitory.

WATER SUPPLY. Pumped from shallow well at rear of laundry, via pump machinery in laundry to 4800 gallon storage tank on level with peak of roof of school building. Pressure from tank through fire hose scarcely sufficient to throw jet to second storey of school building.

Fire Drills. Weekly fire drills during term, using fire escapes from dormitories. All pupils can be evacuated from dormitories to assembly platform adjoining classrooms in slightly less than one minute.
Fire escapes are kept sanded. Senior pupils are stationed at windows opening on escapes to assist pupils. Senior boys are stationed at hose and pump engines.
All windows to escapes are kept on hook and eye fasteners and are easy to open. A member of the staff is in charge of each dormitory. The watchman is on duty from 7 p.m. until 7 a.m., making half-hourly patrols.

Owing to recognised excessive fire hazard due to poor construction and old cedar building, furnace fires have only been kept when absolutely necessary, and seldom all night.
Dormitories:

The general condition of the dormitories is much better than that noted on the occasion of my last visit.

The beds were better cared for than has been the case in the past. I understand that one of the lady members of the staff now has charge of the dormitories.

Several new mattresses have been purchased since my last visit. The children have plenty of covers. On each bed I found a mattress, these vary in condition, a pillow, pillow slip and pair of flannel sheets, two quilts and a blanket.

There were no signs of overcrowding.

Dining Rooms:

I spent almost two days at the school from the 13th to the 15th of March, and had an opportunity to see several meals served to the children.

I have included the Diet Sheet prepared for me at the school as Page 8 of this report.

The kitchen and dining room are clean though the building is so old that tableware is properly served. I think that fresh white linoleum or heavy oil cloth might be placed on the tables this summer, and would suggest that the Indian Agent take this into consideration as I have not mentioned it to the Principal.

The food is good and of sufficient variety. The children have plenty to eat.

Water Supply:

This is from a surface well. The quality of the water is satisfactory I believe though the colour is a distinct yellow.

I understand that when the septic tank overflowed and sewage backed up under the school some might possibly have drained into the well through the surface soil. The water being tested for bacteria I understand.

Pumped from the well, which is located well to the rear of and below the level of the school the water is stored in a small tank over the Girls' Fire Escape. The pressure in the fire hose is of course very low as the tank is level with the top of the school building.

There is no possibility of fighting a fire here if it once took hold of the old building.

The septic tanks are well down towards the sea in front of the school and on the opposite side to the well. Between the tanks and the well there is a ridge of rock on which the actual school is built. I do not think that the well water has been contaminated in any dangerous manner.

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Ahousaht Indian Day School, United Church, West Coast Agency, which I inspected on April 4th.

Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge was with me for the greater part of this inspection.

This school is being conducted in the two old classrooms formerly part of the Ahousaht Indian Residential School. The school in its present location is on United Church property. The buildings are of little value and would not be worth moving, though possibly some of the windows might be made use of in a new day school should the Department decide to build one in the Ahousaht village as I have recommended. Blackboards in the Primary Room are not of much use for a new school while those in the Senior Room might be used in conjunction with new boards in the proposed new school. Desks could of course be used if they were mounted on the usual strips of wood.

The work done this last year in the Senior Division has been very poor in my opinion. Mr. Bain has not proved a success with Indian children, whatever he might be able to do with other pupils.

The work done by Miss Mackie in the Primary Room has been splendid. The children have made excellent progress, and we should be fortunate to retain the services of Miss Mackie in some Indian school.

The teachers were again warned that the work of the present school would come to an end on June 30th, the close of the present Academic Year. They had been previously informed of this of course.

Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge and I again inspected possible sites for an Indian day school in the Ahousaht village, and I may say that we are in complete agreement that the best possible site is one just to the North of the rock outcrop near the centre of the village but located between two large open spaces on the sea front. He will write to you again about this site. It is mentioned in my previous letters on this subject.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

INSPECTOR'S REPORT ON AHOUSAHT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

United Church of Canada, West Coast Agency

(a) Vocational Training:

On Page 3 of this report will be found a detailed statement prepared for me at the school covering the work of the Boys' Manual Training and the Girls' Vocation Instruction since the last inspection.

The Manual Training has been practical in the sense that a considerable amount of repair and construction work has been completed around the school. No technical manual training, as this is understood in Provincial schools, has been attempted. In fact there has not, as far as I can learn, been a qualified Manual Training Instructor here since this matter was last reported on by me in March 1928.

Engineering has received some attention in that the Principal's son has given instruction on several old engines, and in the working of the school launch.

The training of the girls appears to me to be far better than that of the boys. They are taught to cook, sew, mend, darn, crochet, knit and bake. The older girls in turn help in the Principal's house.

In the fourth paragraph of Page 4 of my report on this school dated March 20th 1928 I mentioned that I had spoken on the subject of Arts and Crafts to the staff and older pupils. The practical result has been that the Indian mentioned in that paragraph, Mrs Belle Jacobson, was employed for some months to teach the girls to work etc. The bead work belts shown to me at the school and made since my last inspection were of the very highest quality. One in particular is the best bead work belt I have seen in B.C. It will be exhibited in the Canada Pacific Exhibition this year in Vancouver.

(b) Fire Protection:

On Page 4 of this report will be found the complete statement furnished to me by the Principal with regard to Fire Protection. The Fire Drill carried out for me at the school was quite satisfactory.

There is a definite fire hazard at this school. A night watchman is employed during the winter months. I noticed that the asbestos protection between the smoke pipe of the furnace and the wooden beams of the basement ceiling had been damaged in some way. I asked that this protection be repaired. No cost is involved, and I mention it here so that the Indian Agent who will read this report may satisfy himself on his next visit to the school that there is in fact satisfactory protection between this smoke pipe and the wooden ceiling of the basement. The air space I refer to is less than a foot at the point referred to above.

(c) Dining Room:

On Page 5 will be found a Diet Sheet prepared for me at the school. Meals were visited on several occasions. They were well served. The food is of good quality and variety, and the children have plenty to eat. Fresh white oil cloth has been placed on the dining tables.

Report on Ahousaht Indian Residential School:

MANUAL & DOMESTIC INSTRUCTION.

AHOUSAHT RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL, 1939.

Boys:
Manual training has embraced building construction, repairs to school building and improvements of school grounds, also, in classes the practical operation and familiarity with various gas engines, including marine engines. Particular work carried out during the current term includes:
1. Lining of part of school building, viz- the front hall, staff dining-room, staff sitting-room and five staff bed-rooms; walls and ceilings, with insulating and fire-proof felt paper, and kalsomining same.
2. Painting all lower floor of main building, and junior dormitory, and enamelling bedsteads.
3. Construction of addition to kitchen, and outside toilets.
4. Re-flooring of renovated laundry building, and gymnasium.
5. Completing lining of third floor hall.
6. Cementing floor of toilets.
7. Construction of canoe and fire-wood landing.
8. General repairs to play-court and school roof, etc.
9. Erection of Volley-ball and Badminton apparatus in gym.

Boat-building:- Falling facilities and material in school, some older pupils assisted in building a 40 ft boat in Indian Village.

Engineering:
1. A second-hand 8 H.P. Fairbanks-Morse gas marine engine was purchased, repaired and set up, and successively overhauled by boys until fully acquainted with this type. Then this engine was traded for a 5 H.P. Vulcan gas marine engine of different type, on which the boys are now receiving instruction.
2. Instruction in operating of a Fairbanks-Morse 6 H.P. gas stationary engine in laundry, a 2 H.P. gas engine used daily for pumping water, and a 110 Volt D.C. lighting engine.
3. Repairing, renovation and gearing down of a winch used to haul fire-wood and freight from the beach, and also to clear land by stump-pulling, powered by a 3 H.P. gas engine.
4. Engine operation and navigation of school launch used in landing of all school freight.
5. Operation of laundry machinery.

General:- Cupboards, benches, sick-room trays etc have been made in the workshop.
Ground has been filled in in front of school to set out lawns and gardens, and shell paved walks have been laid.
Spare time has been devoted to Indian handicrafts, eagles, totems, etc.

Girls:
1. Laundering, both by machine and hand. Ironing by hand.
2. Cookery in kitchen, preparation of meals and baking of bread.
3. General housekeeping in residence.
4. Sewing, in classes. Since September 1938, new material has been made up into the following:- 78 boys' shirts, 46 girls' nightgowns, 43 sheets, 26 dresses, 8 mattress covers, 43 pairs bloomers, 66 aprons, 5 pairs curtains, 25 pillow cases, 50 towels, 1 slips, 41 boys' nightshirts, 10 sweaters, 15 pairs ankle-socks.

Handicraft:- Basket and bead-work has been taught to all grades. In beadwork, both in design and work, the girls are especially proficient. Ten prizes were gained in competition at an exhibition in Vancouver, May, 1938. Fancy work is also done in spare time.

General:- All grades are taught the knitting of sweaters and socks, and darning and patching.
Instruction in the care of children for older girls.
BUILDINGS are of cedar frame construction.

MAIN BUILDING:- heated by hot water from wood-burning furnace and boiler in basement.

Basement:- furnace room, 2 play rooms, store room and closets.

1st Floor:- kitchen, 2 dining rooms, sewing room, 2 waiting rooms, storeroom, dispensary, staff sitting room, 1 staff bedroom, staff bath-room, boys bath and washroom.

2nd Floor:- Senior boys dormitory with lavatory and bath. Senior girls dormitory with lavatory and bath. 2 staff bedrooms, 2 single-bed sick rooms.

3rd Floor:- 2 junior girls dormitories, 2 staff bedrooms.

OUTSIDE BUILDINGS:- Workshop with junior boys dormitory and watchman's quarters above, heated with box stoves. Classrooms, 2 in one building, heated with box stoves. Laundry, with box stove. Lighting plant building. Woodshed. Pumphouse, pumping water from shallow well. Residence, hot air heated.

FIRE ESCAPES:- Main building:- Three wooden zig-zag escapes from 2nd and 3rd floors issuing from dormitories, one each on north, south and west sides. Exits to these escapes are closed only by inside hooks and eyes and sealed with sealing-wax to detect unauthorized opening. Fire axes,(2), are provided at main escape windows. Outside Junior Dormitory:- Outside escape stair from rear of dormitory. Entrance stair in front. Escape ropes attached to each window.

WATER PAILS:- Three water pails are attached to wall-racks in each of the five dormitories, making fifteen pails in all, also large water pails on each landing. These are all kept filled.

EXTINGUISHERS:- "Guardene", 3... 1 in first floor hall, main building 1 in second " " " " "Pyrene", 4... 1 in Kitchen, 1 on second floor 1 in outside classroom. 1 in lighting plant building. All extinguishers are tested and renewed annually.

FIRE ALARMS:- Three large gongs, one in hall of 1st floor, one in hall of 2nd floor of main building. One in outside dormitory. Four switches, 2 enclosed, 2 open.

DRILLS:- Conducted weekly or more frequently, weather permitting, all children leaving from fire escapes. Under expected drill conditions, buildings are entirely emptied from dormitories in one minute.

NIGHT WATCHMAN:- Employed from November 1st to April 30th.

Owing to abnormal fire hazard of old frame building fires in furnace, stoves or range are never kept at night. The furnace and boiler were officially inspected during the year and passed. Gasoline fuel for engines is stored away from buildings.

WATER SUPPLY:- From shallow well pumped to 5000 gall. tank at top and outside of main building. Two lengths, each 100 ft, of 2" fire hose are attached, one in furnace room, one in girls playroom. Pressure from tank is insufficient to reach third floor from the ground.

(d) Dormitories:

The general condition of the dormitories is good. Beds were properly cared for and there were sufficient covers. Sheets were clean.

There were no signs of overcrowding in any of the dormitories.

(e) Water Supply:

The water is obtained from a surface well. This well is located to the rear of the school and at a lower level than the school, though care has been taken to protect it from sewage contamination.

The colour of the water is a light yellow but it has been tested again and again and found good for domestic use.

Water is pumped from this well to a small tank located over the girls' fire escape. This tank is about the level of the roof of the school. No great pressure exists in the fire mains and it would not be possible to fight a fire at this school should it have taken any sort of hold on the old buildings.

(f) General Conditions:

The children are well clothed and appear to be quite happy.

The toilets and wash places are clean. The staff in general appears to have been better selected than was the case some years ago. Mrs Caldwell is now much improved in health and her influence is for the good of the school.

The Principal put forward a number of plans by which the Indians would be helped in fishing if his statements may be believed. I should suggest to the Department that great care be exercised in considering Mr Caldwell's plans. The fact is that last year he informed me that he was making use of the drug called in popular language "Luminol". At the time I warned him against the use of such drugs, but I am not satisfied that he took my advice.

There has not perhaps been any very great change in the administration of the school since my last visit. The Principal again and again mentioned to me his wide experience with Indians in the past in other parts of Canada.

The Indian Agent keeps a very close eye on this school, and I am very glad that this is so. At times I doubt that conditions between inspections are up to the level found by me on my yearly visits. I have been informed that the children have a weekly warm bath supervised by one of the members of the staff, but the Indian Agent could know better from his examination of the children when he visits the school if this is so. The general standing of the school is "Fair".
