REPORT OF INSPECTOR P.H. CAIRNS ON THE APPOUSAY BOARDING SCHOOL.

FARMING—

Immediately behind where the school buildings are situated there was a lagoon. Its greatest depth was three feet in the winter. A channel was cut and this water all drained into the sea. This 15 acre area is now used by the school for agricultural purposes.

The soil is leached out and lacking in some of the elements necessary to produce vegetables and grain. Grass does not do well. Therefore, the agricultural effort has not been a success.

It is a fine level area of land. Underdrainage would doubtless help it. I advised the Principal to box up some of the soil and send it to the Department of Agriculture for analysis.

I am quite certain this land can be made productive with proper treatment.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM REV. JOSEPH JONES, PRINCIPAL,
INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL, AHOUAHT, B. C., Jan. 6, 1931.

The construction of a plank road to connect
the school with Matilda Creek and to the road to the dock
where the steamers unload. Since my first communication
with the Mission Board on this subject, the Provincial
Government have begun work on a road from Gibsons Dock to
Duncans at the head of Matilda Creek. (See the map of the
district showing proposed road and the different points
mentioned). Upon completion of our road, we shall have a
direct connection with Matilda Creek where we can always
get our freight without danger or loss, and we shall also
be connected with the provincial road which when completed
will enable us to load a truck at the steamer and unload
directly into our store house. I want to impress upon
you the difficulties of the present way of landing our
freight on the open beach which is exposed to the rolling
surf of the Pacific. The Provincial Police attempted to
land here in an empty yawl. The seas turned them over and
our boys had to go to their help. On the 13th of Dec. it
was too rough to have the steamer stop here so our freight
was taken around to Gibson's dock, on the 17th the seas
having gone down considerably Mr. Gibson offered to bring
around my freight in their big boat the "Anchorite". (We
have no engine for our boat so I have to hire boats for
all the work). The boat was driven aground on our beach.
I hired three other boats to attempt salvage but it was
impossible to pull her off. The waves pounded her to
pieces before the next high tide. This boat was valued
at $5,000.00. They had insurance on her up until three
months ago, so it is a total loss to our neighbour
except the parts we salvaged from the wreck the next
day. Since then they have made three attempts to load the engine on a barge but the surf is too strong. Every Government and Church official who has visited here agree that a road to the calm waters of the Creek is necessary.

The proposed road will do this and in addition will eventually land us at the dock.

There is one other advantage in this road. We have here about 11 acres of level land (the bed of a lake drained by ditches) samples of this soil have been sent to the Agricultural College and they tell us we need to put fertilizer into the soil and say that kelp is the best. Every year tons of kelp is deposited on Powel Beach. This beach is less than 200 yards from the proposed road at one point. Here we propose to build a branch road out to the beach. Here we can haul the kelp to the farm, at present the land is too impoverished to grow anything, but with ample fertilizer we can grow enough feed to keep cows as well as provide vegetables for the school. At present all these have to be purchased in Victoria or Vancouver.

This road will also provide an excellent walk for the children. At present we have only a narrow plank walk from school to village.

It is proposed to build the road where it is close to ground of cedar, where it is above ground of fir and spruce. The enclosed sketch shows method of construction. You will see that the car or truck will be running on four inch plank. The centre is filled in with two inch plank. The logs at the side are safety buffers. Part of the road is through heavy timber. This will supply us with fuel for some years to come. The school land adjoins Mr. Duncan's land. He will we pleased to grant "Right of way" over his property.

The length of road will be a little less than 2000 yards including the branch to Powel Beach the cost I have carefully calculated to be no more than $6500.00.

I hope you will give this item your best consideration.

I have the honour to refer to your letter of April 9, 1926, re farm land at Ahousat Indian Residential School and to report that I inspected the land in question and feel confident that much can be done in the matter of raising vegetables and small fruits. There is also a very well constructed barn in which cows can be kept, but would like the opinion of the Agricultural Agent on this matter, as I have some doubt regarding amount and quality of available feed.

It is respectfully recommended that in view of the nature of the soil and the recent drainage that for the present year only experimental work be carried out with a view to more extensive planting if successful.

Your obedient servant,

P. B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

Mr. Solway,
Boy Scouts Association,
Vancouver, British Columbia

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing the census returns and have completed it as far as possible. You will notice that at present we are functioning without a Group Committee. We have had no camps and also, which may seem strange, no disbursements.

As this is an Indian Residential School and the people are here at all times and as there is nobody in the village who would be suitable on a Group Committee, Mr. Jones and I decided that it was not worth while bothering about such a group, yet. If it is desirable to have one in order to conform with the regulations, we can make one with the members of the staff. Things are entirely different up here from conditions in town and we have to "wink the eye" at a number of things, yet it is the Scout Law and Promise that have done a lot to make the situation as well as it is.

We are also handicapped in that we have no place which we can call our own. We use the dining room for our meetings; for the weather forbids any outside work and the room is certainly not conducive to good Scouting.

A number of the boys at the village, ages between twenty and twenty five, wish to become Rovers. I have never had anything to do with Rover Scouts myself but I am sure that none of them, at present, could live up to the Rover standard. I have given them the books "Rover Scouts, What They Are" and am hoping that they will wish to take it up. It will be very difficult for them in the village and I am afraid many points will have to be overlooked but if a fellow is honestly doing his best, why stop him.

My plan is to have them on a different night to Scouts, but I am very handicapped when I attempt anything. First they have only the scholastic mentality of a teen-aged boy yet their sexual knowledge is worthy of Solomon. Secondly, it is impossible to get away to camp and their social activities are far from proper, while thirdly it is necessary to attend church in a body and even then there is not much devotion evident.
Then again, I am the only person who could take the position of Rover Leader and I am only twenty-one, a stranger in this district and still slightly acquainted with these boys, or really young men, who wish to become Rovers. Added to that list comes a far greater technical fault. I have not received nor even applied for a Scoutmaster's warrant so that according to the letter of the law we are in a pretty sad mess.

But a Scout always whistles and smiles so I go smiling along with the knowledge that the boys themselves don't know what a hole they are in and keep whistling to buoy up my spirits if things ever appear to fall.

My Cubs are my greatest joy. I have a wonderful time with them, eleven all told, three of whom can only talk a little English, but for want of more definite information I have filled in the census to read "eleven Cubs". If I am out of order please let me know but meanwhile we are having great fun.

As you surmised, Mr. Dent has left and is now at Columbia College, New Westminster, while I have taken his place at the school. Mr. Dent very kindly left all his Scout books here so I will not require the books I ordered before I left Victoria.

If you could give me some "fatherly advice" about the way I should carry on the work here I should be only too pleased for it is rather difficult to come out from Varsity, from a highly artificial and pseudo-sophisticated society into a raw native atmosphere, where the sexual life seems to be the one goal and aim of most of the adults.

Looking over what I have written it appears that the "decks are cleared" for some real first class action and before long I hope that I shall be able to give a much better account of myself and the Troop. "Tuum Est" is my college motto and I guess that it is up to me so here goes.

Yours for good Scouting

R. Ward

P.S. What is our official name? The notice board, the charter and our record book all have different designations.

Agricultural lands of the Ahousaht School were at the request of the Principal, Mr. A. E. Caldwell, anxious to do a little farming in connection with the School. The School has approximately 20 acres of land which is capable of growing sufficient vegetables for the School and pasturage for four or five head of stock, if properly worked. This land has been ditched and fenced and some 5 acres of it has been under cultivation at some time. Why this land was abandoned I do not know, for I was told that good crops were grown on it several years ago. Mr. Caldwell thinks that it was on account of lack of interest in farming, and possibly, because it was not properly drained. Since Mr. Caldwell took over the School, he has cleaned out and deepened the ditches around the land, and at the time of my visit the land was well drained and the ditches were in good shape. Mr. Caldwell informed me that there was a meadow nearby where sufficient wild hay could be cut for all the stock that the farm could pasture. Before any attempt is made towards keeping stock, I would suggest that the land be thoroughly worked for a few years in the way of growing root crops and vegetables and thoroughly fertilized with kelp before seeding down to tame grasses. I would also suggest that the School Principal have a sample of the soil analyzed for it is possible that as the land has not been kept thoroughly drained for the past few years it may be sour and inclined to be acid and might require a dressing of lime.

As the farming land that the School owns is limited to approximately 20 acres, the area which may be used for grazing is consequently small and would not possibly raise more than four or five head of stock. If it is the intention of the School to keep dairy cows, it might be advisable to do the farming with a small tractor, thus saving the pasture for cows.

So far as farming at Ahousaht for the purpose of teaching agriculture in the School is concerned, I beg to say that I fear this would be only a waste of time, as the West Coast Indians situated as they are naturally have to depend on fishing for a livelihood and will never do any farming of any account. If the Ahousaht School wishes to go to the expense of buying farm machinery and equipment, I see no reason why they should not be able to grow sufficient vegetables for the School and keep a limited number of dairy cows as well.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Caldwell,
(Signed)
Indian Agricultural Agent for B. C.

I ASKED THE NEW YEAR.

"I asked the New Year for some motto sweet. Some word of cheer by which to guide my feet; I asked and paused. It answered soft and low: 'God's will to know.'

"'Will knowledge then suffice, New Year," I cried, 'But e'er the question into silence died, The answer came: "Nay, this remember, too—God's will to do."

Once more I asked: "Is there still more to tell?" And once again the answer softly fell: "Yes, this one thing, all things above—God's will is love."

SUBJECT FOR PRAYER.

That the Holy Spirit may deeply impress upon the hearts of all ministers and members of the church a sense of their obligation in the evangelization of the world; that the hearts of the heathen may be prepared for the reception of the truth; that a rich blessing may rest upon all efforts to deepen missionary interest, and that the Church may awake to more earnest prayer and increased liberality for the extension of Christ's Kingdom.

"Bring ye all the tithes into the storehouse, that there may be meat in mine house, and prove me now herewith, saith the Lord of hosts, if I will not open the windows of heaven, and pour you out a blessing, that there shall not be room enough to receive it."—Mal. 3:10.

"And God is able to make all grace abound toward you; that ye, always having all sufficiency in all things, may abound to every good work:"—2 Cor. 9:8.
GO FORWARD.

The season of gifts and kind wishes is again at hand, and to the readers of the "Tidings" and members of our Woman's Foreign Missionary Society we send our cordial greetings and message of love for the New Year.

The year 1900 marks upon us with a peculiar significance, as it marks the close of one century and heralds the advent of another. It comes as a link between the experiences of the past and the greater possibilities of the future, and is a fitting viewpoint from which to make preparation for a true grasp of the new opportunities. The closing century is a notable one in the world's history for great advances in science, commerce, life's industries, and interests. Rapid strides have been made in science, literature, education, and in man's power to utilize to practical purposes the great forces of nature; but even greater than the progress in these has been the development and success of missionary efforts. May the energies now in motion for the evangelization of the world be given increased power as the years advance, and may God's children everywhere be inspired with holy ambitions and earnest effort to speedily win the world for Christ!

As we look back over the closing year regrets crowd in upon us because of opportunities unimproved or gone forever by, but to linger on the regrets is vain unless it serves to spur us on to better use of the New Year's opportunities and to a brave acceptance of its responsibilities. We cannot, if we would, change the records of the past, they are written for evermore, but we may so profit by our former experiences, successes or failures, as to make them stepping-stones to truer service. Forgetting, then, "those things which are behind," and reaching forth unto those things which are before, let us press toward the mark for the prize of the high calling of God in Christ Jesus. Sacred trusts have been placed in our charge, and it is required of us that we be faithful in responding to our obligations. The blessings of the Gospel have been freely bestowed on us, and it is expected that they shall be sent on to others, and while we bring cheer and joy to our own lives, are we doing this? Are we seeking in loving sympathy to bring the lost to Christ? Are we self-denyingly seeking to win souls? If not, we are neglecting our mission, and as the Lord's Master says: "Not to be ministered unto, but to minister." The call to Christian women to-day to do service for Christ has in it no uncertain sound, and opportunities to hold out the helping hand to burdened ones, to touch with sympathy hearts of the greatest need are offered all over everywhere. To many of us these pressing demands for help come as a temptation to undue activity. More is undertaken than the strength permits to overtake, and best results are not obtained. Responsibilities are assumed without due consideration, and our days are filled with what we believe to be legitimate Christian work—so filled that we weary and worn, cannot take time to renew our strength by waiting upon Him who gives the grace to true service, and who undeservedly grants His favor. We must search ourselves to know what motive prompts us to engage in these activities, to be sure that what we do is done from love to Christ, and as an outcome of His great love to us. It is only when His love permeates and penetrates that we will have power and ability to bring blessing to others. May we in this New Year yield our wills so fully to our Lord that He will through us do great things in the building up of His Kingdom! May we have the fulness of compassion and the freedom from the cares that trouble the hearts of those for whom we work, and be constrained to believing, importunate prayer on their behalf. Power in prayer is the privilege of God's children, and power makes responsibilities not only for what we are trying to do, but for what God has promised and prepared us. Missionaries are needed at present to strengthen our staff in the foreign field, more workers are needed in our Society, especially such as are fitted to lead in the work of our Mission Bands. There are many among our members who are Presbyterian Church well fitted, physically and intellectually, to do service as missionaries. There are many women of culture and influence who profess the name of Christ, but have no interest or share in His great work of missions. Why is it that where there are so many who are in a position in which calling should be drawn that there is still the unanswered cry for more workers at home and abroad? The command is, "Pray ye, therefore, the Lord of the harvest that He will send forth labourers into His harvest." Can it be that He could offer because His servants have failed to use the power at their command to provide for its requirements? If we could realize in some measure as our Saviour did the needs of the multitudes "as sheep having no shepherd," we would pour out our hearts in ardent desire for labourers to glean the fields of our Lord's vineyard while the harvest Moon is in it. New Year rise to the height of our privilege and be a medium of rich blessing to the world. Let us no longer trifle in the Master's work. The King's business requires haste and energetic action. Let us not only cry unto the Lord for guidance and help, but hearken to His Word, as given to His servant Moses in the distant past, "Wherefore criest thou unto Me?" Speak unto the children of Israel, that they go forward."

ITEMS OF INTEREST

With the Closing Year of the 19th Century hearts have been moved to prayer for a great awakening in the spiritual life of the Church during the century that is to follow. Our pastors are praying for it; from our Board there have gone up earnest petitions that the members of all our Auxiliaries and Boards may feel it. "Povved the Spirit's request, and then the Christian element of our church may feel a personal obligation in our motto, 'The World for Christ.' Personal responsibility cannot be transferred to a church or a society; each one of us has an individual relationship to God and to the coming of His Kingdom.

"If all the lamps that are lighted,
Should steadily blaze in a line,
Over all the wide earth and the ocean,
What a girdle of glory would shine!"

A few Words of Cheer were given by Mrs. Board by Mrs. McKeown President of the Huron Presbyterial, while visiting in Toronto last month. Her words were kindly and encouraging as the Board on that day were deliberating on the question of resting our missionaries when on furlough. Glenboro' is one of our brightest Propaganda. It lies away out in the prairie district west of the city of Winnipeg. It is Provincial in its reach, but the nine Auxiliaries comprising it are entirely dependent on their own activities. The thought of seeing a live missionary is quite unheard of. "But," added Mrs. McKeown, "we are content and glad to read the letters from some mission is kept near to its heart, and the information we are able to circulate concerning the mission fields. Not that we would not gladly hear a real live missionary, but we are too far from a centre to expect one and therefore have been educated in self-support." We felt the force of her words, and commended them along. To Auxiliaries over large centres where the opportunities are varied and great, these prairie Auxiliaries are fine examples of activity and whole-souled interest in their church and its missionary spirit.

Mrs. Wilkie and Miss Chase of Indore C.I. were present at the Board meeting. Miss Chase was highly commended by the members. Several questions were asked Miss Chase with reference to work outside the College, and for which she had taken no credit in her annual report. Through her work in the College the young men had been led to put women's sphere on a higher stand, and had opened up the way for more faithful Bible-gate women in the zenanas. After the first two years when college work had become familiar she had found time to take up outside work. With the assistance of one of the Bible-women an interesting tour had been made through
neighbouring villages, in some of which the people were urgent that schools should be opened up. She had also been asked from time to time, to assist both at the dispensary and school to the patients and at the housework and cooking classes for Scripture lessons. In many cases, it was found, Miss Chase had made herself invaluable to the mission and we trust at the end of this period of rest she may be permitted to return in renewed strength to this needy field.

Presbyterial Meetings—Miss Chase expects to be at the Annual meeting of Lindsay P.S. in Cunnington on January 18th; also at the Lanark and Renfrew P.S. in Arnprior, January 23rd and 24th. Miss Prolemy is to be at the Hamilton P.S., January 16th; Miss Duncan at Chatham P.S., December 24th.

In the Programme for the Day of Prayer we call attention to a note which has been added asking for very special reference in prayer to the sad conditions of want in India. Pray, too, that the hearts of the native Christians may be opened to do what they can for the needy and that our missionaries may be able to bear the burden of poverty. "True faith makes riches written." One foal into the coming months with trembling and were it not that we knew the burden will be one of day by day and the promise is 'as thy day so shall thy strength be,' it would overpower one. Poor India, the Lord is visiting her in wrath. Will she heed and turn to the Light?

If You Read Nothing Else in this number read Dr. Margaret McKellar's graphic and pathetic account of the famine in Central India. Think of the distress! Added to the food famine six months more must pass before they can look for rain and many of the wells are already dry. Speak of it to your friends that prayerful sympathy may be far outreaching. The need is immediate and urgent.

During the Last Famine over 800,000 souls died from starvation within a few months.

The Maharaja Scindia has given 10,000 rupees for relief work. Employment has been given to three thousand men in the building of a new roadway near the Jubilee gate. It is small, only equal to four cents, but cannot be sufficient for more than one person. A month ago the price of wheat was 11-1-2 sas for the rupee, that is if the pay baba did not take off a percentage (which is doubtful) and if the bania gave correct weight (which is more doubted) the wages earner could but a small portion of the wheat. The prices have risen considerably so you see how little one grown man can earn at road-making to support a family.

Plague Rages fiercer than ever in many districts. The way in which it persistently clings to certain cities in certain sections seems to indicate that there may be truth in a theory now being advanced, which is, that where there is much malaria the plague will not come. We hope the theory may prove true and that Central India will be free from it.

A Terrible Land Slide took place lately in Darjeeling, Calcutta's Hill Station. The side of the hill fell 3,000 feet, killing between seventy and eighty people. Two years ago this station was badly wrecked by an earthquake. Our readers will remember that Miss Grier was there at the time and received a severe nervous shock.

In News from Honan we learn that Mrs. Goforth has found it her duty to return inland from the coast. She traced her horses, more than two months after, but they still lingered. The many hopes for her recovery by their stay at Pei-Tai-Ho have not been realized. Our sympathies are very deep for the poor mother in this trial.

Mrs. Mackenzie has also returned inland and we gladly report that her health has been completely restored.

The opening of the New Chapel at Chang Te was to take place October 8th. Rev. Mr. Mackenzie was to preside in the morning, Rev. W. H. Grant in the afternoon, and Rev. Donald MacGillivray in the evening. The invitation was sent out far and wide to native Christians, and together with all the missionaries a great gathering was expected. It is the largest and finest chapel in Honan, has an iron roof, real church windows with double Gothic tops.

"Progress" Sends the Following—We are more deeply indebted than ever to the Ladies' Foreign Missionary Society for their active and most valuable co-operation with us in our work. In no former years have we received such liberal assistance from the ladies of the East. From the London Presbyterian Society, through Miss Bruce, and also the Lanark and Renfrew Societies we have received very many boxes containing lots of first-class clothing. The splendid overcoats, jackets, quilts, underclothing, warm caps, boots, night dresses, felt socks, dresses, sweaters, etc., filled the carts with feelings of the most profound gratitude. The ladies sorrowed to send us any surplus, unserviceable goods. Our present assortment of warm, hand-made mitts, socks and stockings we never saw equaled. For warmth and durability they have surpassed anything purchased by the average merchant. One of our native teachers said that while supporting his wife and five long Metro Doxology was continually in her heart. We rejoice to see so many pupils (considerably over 100), who are our own by adoption, so warmly clad and so com-

pletely prepared for the keen frost of winter. But the uppermost feeling in our hearts is gratitude to the ladies of the Woman's Foreign Missionary Society, and a determination to do our utmost on behalf of the cause to which they devote such sympathetic and helpful attention.

An Unfair Distribution. An attempt from the Presidency of Victoria to the last General Assembly urged that representation be made to the Dominion Government to secure a fair share of Government support for the work of education carried on by our Church on the West Coast. Rev. Dr. Campbell, of Victoria, supported this move, and stated that for all the splendid work done by our Church the grants amounted to only $600 annually, while the Roman Catholic Church received $1,000; the Church of England, $15,050, and the Methodist Church $800 for work in the same Territory.

PRESBYTERIAL MEETINGS.

SARNIA.—Held its twelfth annual meeting in the Presbyterian Church, Petrolia, on November 1st and 2nd, the members of Petrolia Auxiliary sparing no pains to make the meeting a success. Mrs. Urquhart, President, presided at the three sessions. The afternoon session opened at 2.30. Words of welcome and the delegates were given by Miss McNaughton, of Petrolia, responded to by Mrs. Ironside, of Thorold.

All the reports presented showed increased growth and interest during the past year. There have been six Auxiliaries and one Mission Band during the year. Sarnia Presbytery now comprises twenty-two Auxiliaries and thirteen Mission Bands. 579 copies of "Tidings" are in circulation; total amount contributed for 1899 being $1,270.00. The musical programme was offered by Mrs. J. Sturges of Brantford, and after the singing of a solo by Miss Walker, of Petrolia, Miss Duncan, of India, occupied the remaining time most profitably and pleasantly by her address on her work in the foreign field, accompanying it with an exhibition of the dress she had once made, carried with her from India, adding much to the interest awakened by her remarks.

The public meeting in the evening was well attended. Rev. A. Graham, of Petrolia, presiding. Profuse addresses were given by Rev. C. Murray, of Alexandria; Rev. R. Haddow, of Watford, and Rev. C. Daly, of Oil Springs.

At the Thursday morning meeting Mrs. Fortune, of Alvinston, read an excellent paper on "Why Are We Here?" and another from Mrs. McNaughton, of Petrolia, on "How to Interest Others in Missions," lent additional pleasure and inspiration to the meeting. Mrs.

PROGRAMME FOR DAY OF PRAYER, Jan. 12th, 1900.

I. Prayer that the Holy Spirit may be poured out upon this and all similar meetings; that the spiritual life of the Church may be deepened; that during the twentieth century Christians everywhere may be more earnest in bringing to bear the world for Christ.

II. Thanksgiving for the blessings of the Gospel; for opportunities of Christian service; for faithful workers at home and abroad; for the many tokens we have received of God's guidance and blessing; for the marvellous development and success of mission work throughout the past century.
That our missionaries may be kept in health of mind and body and preserved from all danger; that they may be richly endowed with love, wisdom and power, and encouraged and sustained in their self-denying labors. That those entering on the work may receive all needed guidance and help and be enabled to testify faithfully for Christ.

IV. That the Spirit of God may open the eyes of the heathen and Mohammedans to the Light of the Truth. That converts may witness a good testimony for Christ and be earnest in seeking to win others for him; that secret believers may be strengthened to confess Christ openly.

V. That the horrors of war, pestilence and famine may be speedily brought to an end, and be overruled of God for the promotion of truth and righteousness in the dark places of the earth.

VI. For the enlightenment and building up of the Faith, of the Indians in our own land; for all the Home Mission work of our Church; for work among the Chinese in America and for the speedy conversion of the Jews.

VII. That the young may be interested in and trained for Christian service. That our training home may be greatly blessed and prospered, and that there may be no lack of consecrated candidates prepared and chosen of God. That our society may be strengthened by a large increase in the number of devoted workers. That the Church may receive a mighty impulse through the Ecumenical Council in 1908. That rich blessing may rest upon the efforts of all Protestant Missionary Societies.

VIII. That our missionaries on furlough may be renewed in health and strength and their influence blessed to the church at home. That a blessing may rest on our missionary societies and all other efforts to deepen the interest in missions. That the Church may be more earnest in believing prayer and more liberal in giving to Christ's cause. That much grace be given in the administration of Foreign Mission work.

Very special reference is asked in prayer for the people of India, that God in his mercy may speedily bring the famine to an end.

THE WIDE WORLD FOR CHRIST.

What is the population of the Globe?

One billion, five hundred million.

How many of these are Protestant Christians?

Only about one-tenth—one hundred and fifty millions.

Which nations are most interested in Foreign Mission Work?

Great Britain and the United States, though the Germans are also zealous.

What is being done by these two Anglo-Saxon Nations?

IN CHINA.

The Baptists support 450 stations, Presbyterians 435, Congregationalists 209, Methodists 127, Episcopalians 81, and with many other smaller denominations there are about 5,000 missionaries and native helpers, or one for every seventy thousand of the people. If he worked day and night for a year he might possibly talk to each one of his parish for five minutes.

What are we doing in AFRICA?

Methodists support 916 stations, Presbyterians 555, Friends 157, Congregationalists 146, and Baptists 42, with many others in smaller numbers, but there are vast millions who have as yet never heard the name of Christ.

What is our work in India?

The Episcopalians (English) support 2,118 stations, the Baptists 1,270, the Presbyterians 1,109, the Congregationalists 1,062, the Methodists 508, Reformed Dutch 140, Lutherans 201, in all 19,695 missionaries and native helpers. Although there are only about three hundred thousand actual communicant members there are many who are secret believers but are kept back by fear of losing caste. If that barrier were removed there would be a great ingathering. Let us pray for this.

What are these two nations doing in Japan?

The Congregationalists support 207 stations, The Dutch Reformed 103, the Baptists 102, the Presbyterians 99, the Episcopalians 42—1,500 workers in all.
What is the record for SOUTH AMERICA?

The Presbyterians support 34 stations, the Methodists 11, and English Episcopalians and Congregationalists a number more.

Who are working for Mexico and Guatemala?

Only Americans—Presbyterians 201 Stations, Methodists 200, Congregationalists 60, and Moravians 15—597 workers.

What is the work in PERSIA?

American Presbyterians 12 stations, 336 workers, and English Episcopalians 5 stations and 34 workers.

What is being done for Siam and Laos?

Our own Presbyterian Church has 41 stations and 155 workers, and the Baptists 1 station and 3 workers.

Who are the workers in SYRIA?

The Presbyterians support 129 stations, Episcopalians 17, Baptists 12; in all 474 workers and about 3,350 communicants, of whom 2,247 are of our own church.

Does it not greatly confuse the natives to have all these different denominations?

There is something of this, of course, but as a rule we all work in true harmony and Christian fellowship, not occupying a place already receiving the gospel, but pushing on into the regions beyond. There are one or two exceptions among the narrower denominations—notably in Persia and Syria—but our field motto is

ALL ONE IN CHRIST.

LETTERS FROM OUR MISSIONARIES.

India.

THE FAMINE IN ITS BEGINNING.

DR. MARGARET McKELLAR.

Neemuch, Central India, October 26th, 1899.

Our part of India has been called a garden, as it seldom suffers from famine and the like of its present condition has not been known for one hundred years. The gladness is to see the joy out of the plentiful fields and in the woods there shall be no singing, the grasshopper shall there be no green thing.” Six weeks ago the famine sufferers from the surrounding districts began crowding into Central India in the hope of getting food for themselves and fodder for their cattle; but alas! it was too late to save them. For weeks there have been thousands of people passing each other in Neemuch; the one that came early and passed through the land, finding out the poverty for itself, and was turned back at Rutland, and the other that will not believe except it sees for itself, and goes forward.

The scenes that are presented to us from day to day are very pathetic: grey-bearded men and women, the strong youths and little ones on the march, with their earthly all tied up in bundles or in baskets on their heads or on the backs of their cattle, their faces much marked by the carcases of the animals which have died by the way.

The need of supplying these people with food has been very urgent. A relief work in the shape of a new road was started some weeks ago, on which a few thousand have found employment, but there are those passing to and fro, and for whom nothing has been made as yet, so we have been trying to do what we could from private funds. Up to date of writing we have given food to 0.8t on our own compound. This we could not have done, if it had not been for the help of the children in the Orphanage. They came from their recent exercises, and as they came they said, “It is the sufferer of hunger, it is beautiful and touching to see their willingness and readiness to prepare the food for the hundreds who come. It means a very great deal of hard work for them, for they must be fed, and even baby Mary has helped in the work. The grain that she cleaned yesterday she stood in triumph with the remark that she does not leave even a wee bit of gravel or earth amongst it. They have had to have a little help with the grinding, as it took too much time away from their lessons, but the kneading and baking of the chapatis they do themselves, rising at four o'clock in the morning to do the
work, and when an extra one hundred have to be prepared every morning it is no small task, thus God so long as two years ago began to make provision for the need of today.

Of the hundreds who come only from 250 to 300 are children and most of them are very much the charge. It is such a little and yet it means so much to the wee ones. While we turn to get another piece, the bread is hid by the child and if we did not look sharp, many a one would get a second piece. They hide their mother and if they do not get a stitch or cloth on in which to hide the bread, they slip it between the thigh and body. Bugiza, the little invalid of the Orphanage, has been much interested in this work. She began of her own accord to give "a cup of cold water" to a few at first just outside the Home gate. She would go down to the well and said it was not in Miss Sahli's order. This she reported to us in such a broken hearted way that it was agreed she should always hand the bread to the little ones. Her days of service on earth are almost over, as she suffers from incurable disease, but there are days when she is able to be fertile to walk around to give the bread, but she comes to help break it. Several times there was not enough for all the children and she slipped away without saying a word and brought some of the bread that had been prepared for the day's meal. Is she not exemplarily beautiful, the love of the Saviour, who has become precious to her during her stay in the Home? At first we gave the grown-ups parched corn, but now they get a mixture of peas and wheat. The grain is soaked in water for a day and mixed with water and a little salt sprinkled on it and this is given to them and they are able to eat it at once. Do I hear some of you say "what about their caste?" Only three or four out of all the thousands who have come have said "we are Brahmins," give us dry flour instead of this. Others, however, who state they belong to, say "We belong to the hungry caste." Not only do they take the food that has been prepared by the Christians, but they drink water from their hands or from the hands of other Hindoos whom they know to be of a lower caste. This gives us a glorious opportunity of giving them the Gospel. Since Miss Campbell's return from the hills, she has undertaken to give them the "Bread of Life," with the help of our Christian cook. She takes four of the girls daily, from nine o'clock until noon, helps them to sing, and in this way the girls although not able to preach the Gospel are able to sing it to the people and who dare say that it shall not be blessed?

The people come, of course, for the "loaves" just as people did in our Saviour's time, but they are able in His name to tell them of "that meat which endureth unto everlasting life."

At all times, the sore burdens fall upon the mothers. We have had several with their little babes four and five days old, come to beg a portion with the crowd. I need not draw a picture to speak upon your feelings, of what these mothers have suffered, having left their homes a month or so ago and kept up with the rest on their weary line of march, sleeping by the roadside and in the open air. All the mothers with babies in their arms carried their bread as well as some grain. A day or two ago a woman kept calling out for bread, and she had been crying saying that she had a baby under her chaddar. Some how I felt that she was telling a lie and although I had given her the bread and had passed her I went back to satisfy my doubt and if there was no baby how can we be hard on them when they are suffering so much hunger?

For some days a young man has been coming with a seven month old baby, tied up in a sort of sling suspended from his neck. The child's mother is dead and it is touching to see the father's efforts at taking care of the child. We give him a cup of milk every day that he has come and in a most ingenious fashion he makes a funnel out of a green leaf and the small end is put into the child's mouth, and through it he pours the milk. We have made vain endeavours to get him to give the child if only to take care of it during the day while he works, but he won't part with it.

One evening when returning from the city dispensary I came across a family living behind a cactus hedge. One of the young men of eighteen or twenty, had been ill with dysentery and was apparently in a very critical condition. I pleaded for some one to come with me to the bungalow for medicine, but no one seemed willing to come. Just then a man passing who knew who I was, told them not to be afraid that I was doing this work for the sake of "merit." The mother answered me in a shigram with me. The poor woman had never been in the like before, and as we drove on and on, and the darkness closed swiftly around us, she settled down in silent silence, and apparently made up her mind that whatever was going to befall her she would endure it a stone. How different was the look on her face when, after giving her food and medicine for her boy, I drove her back and left her safe and sound with her family. In a week or so I had the satisfaction of seeing the same woman come with her mother and ask me to get food with the others. Last night I went again to see how they were getting on, but there was nothing to be seen but the little pile of stones and the heap of ashes, where they had cooked their food, so they have passed on their march beyond our reach.

Once when we had some bread left over, after giving to all who were present, so in the evening I tied it up and fastened it on the handle-bar of my bicycle and started off to distribute it to the poor ones. I had not thought to go by myself; my difficulty was to get a group small enough, so that each might get a piece. At last I met some, who had
FOREIGN MISSIONARY TIDINGS.

I came in from Marwar, and they did look so weary and hopeless. I don't suppose Ellith was as surprised when the ravens brought him his bread, for God had promised to send them, as these people were when I swooped down on them on my bike, and began giving them bread from such an unlooked-for source.

A day or two after Moti's arrival, a young man, Samarthi by name, of the Hindu people, presented himself, saying that he wanted to become a Christian. We set him to cutting the grass on the compound, and began at once teaching him the way of salvation. He gives every indication of being in earnest, and we have all been favorably impressed with his conduct. I could write a long letter about the interesting conversations we have had with him, but must refrain until another time.

About three weeks ago there came, after dark, a Brahmin woman (Channu) with her baby, who met me at the gate. She had been a widow for four years; has been living with a Brahmin here who is not her husband, and, while she has been faithful to him, he has beaten and treated her shamefully. For some time one of our Bible women has been helping her, and yesterday she asked about Christ so as to be willing to leave the man. I sent her on at once to the Home in Indore, as we have no place here to protect such as she. The Home in Indore is very much overcrowded, and we must have one in Neemuch for the sufferers. One other thing—there is great supply to mention—that is Nimoo, a little girl of seven or eight, who was given by her mother, a Brahmin, to Miss Campbell yesterday, and who is to all appearance very happy with her new surroundings. I want all the readers of "Missionary Tidings" to pray especially for the conversion of these five souls whom God has so providentially brought to us during the past five weeks. Let their names—Moti, Channu and her baby, Samarthi and Nimoo—become household words, as they will if you remember them daily at the throne of grace.

Since starting my letter small gifts have come in from some of the English officers in the station, and from other places to help get food for the orphanage. While writing, she has heard a donation of two rupees came in from Amy James, the teacher in the Orphanage. She receives only rupees eight per month. Who in the home-land will follow her example and give the same amount as their month's salary or income to feed God's children in Central India?

Rebecca—but, the head of the Home, was the very first person to give a donation, and a few days ago she was over helping us to distribute the food, when she saw that we were not going to have enough, for we had only prepared for 500 and 745 had come. She turned with tears to her eye and said, "Oh, Miss Sahib, we must send for more. I have a rupee by me; I'll send to the bazaar for more grain." Permission being given, she sent, and all received something. Yesterday, when giving her money to buy the usual quantity of grain, I was surprised that she did not ask for the rupee that she had spent, and I mentioned it. Her whispered answer was, "That was from myself." I felt the God's Spirit move mightily in the Orphanage, and outside of it, too; yet none of our other Indian Christians have given anything. The children are praying that money may come in, and it is since their prayers have been ascending that all the outside gifts have come. Praise the Lord! How true it often is, "A little child shall lead them." One of the girls dreamed that the Miss Sahib had received £1,500. Let us pray that her dream may come true.

HOW WE HIRED A WELL.

FROM MISS K. CAMPBELL.

Neemuch, C.I., Nov. 2.

In the home land a cup of cold water is so easily obtained at any wayside well that one does not understand what the lack of it means, nor how difficult it sometimes is to get in Eastern countries.

When the officer commanding the fort wrote about two weeks ago politely intimating that it would be impossible to allow us to get water from the fort well for the Marwaris, we cast about to find some way of continuing to give "the cup of cold water," which is so precious to these unfortunate people who come out to our door.

Twice a policeman had stopped and spoken to Dr. MacKellar about a very good well at Jammutia, a village some three or four miles out of Neemuch, but at the time she had passed it by without thought. Now she recalled his words, and we went that very evening to see if we could make a bargain for the water. We drove to the jail, but found, after a great deal of trouble, as no one seemed to know much about him, that he had gone to his village. If then we would have water for our thirsty ones we must go out there. We returned to town, hired a tonga, and set off under the stars to hang up a man whose name we did not know, and about whom we only knew that he was a policeman and owned a well. When we reached the village we asked for the Jammutia owner of the well. "There are three wells," was the answer. "Well, where is the owner of the best well?" we returned. "In Jiran," was the reply. Now Jiran is twelve miles off our hearts sank. "When did he go?" "To-day." "And return?" "We do not know." So our efforts had been for nothing. "Hold!" cried the driver; "I'll go and ask." So we took our seats, and he ran off into the darkness, leaving us outside the gate, just close to the well, the waters from which we
were so anxious to bargain for. In a few minutes he returned, and with him the very man we were enquiring about, and who, we thought, had gone to Jiran. We must go down to see what a fine well it is, and how good the water. So carrying a dishpan, we went down two flights of steps to the well's edge. We declined testing it to test its sanctity, but we had before observed that in such wells it is no uncommon thing for a man to bathe, wash his clothes, then carry away a vesselful for drinking without seeming to notice it as an unusual proceeding. The pigmies who were sleeping disturbing in their homes on the side of the well with our light and our bargaining, fluttered noisily about against the walls, so we left them to their dreams and returned to the top, where we consulted the nearest at one another (two or three days' journey) and bullocks to draw the water, and seven annas (thirteen cents) for the man, oxen and cart to bring it into our bungalow, to provide the tanks. One tank we got from the Orphanage, another was rented from the bazaar. The Jamadar insisted upon paying for the "pity" he received of good works, which we commended by providing water for the thirsty which "pity" would stand us in good stead in the next world by providing a way in at heaven's gate. He will not believe that the "way" has been opened, and that the remedy will be the blessed Saviour's commendation, "I was thirsty, and ye gave me drink."

Still the hundreds flock to our compound to be fed. Since the relief work was closed ten days ago we have had as many as in one day. We hope new work will be started soon which will take some off our hands. Among those who come are some who perhaps are not yet suffering a great deal, but many more are truly in distress, especially among the children. We sometimes see them tie up their food to take it away. On inquiry, we find that they have been told that they are not to eat it, or they may bring it to their parents. Needless to say we insist upon their eating it on the spot.

How famine kills human instincts! A week ago to-day Soma, the Chamar teacher, found two bodies, of children, and seven months respectively, near the Chamar school. Some people close by said that the parents were just moving off, so he gave chase down the road. At first they denied knowing anything of them, but finally confessed that, as they could not provide for them, they would let the children, they had left them to die. He told them to return and he would take them next morning to a lady who would care for the children. He gave them some food, and they promised to stay. At eleven that night he strolled across to see how they were faring, but there were all gone. The same thing another way out on the common behind the school, and found the two children in a ditch. The jackals and crows had already begun their hateful work on the little bodies. Whether the parents had deliberately thrown them away or had deserted them, and they had been carried off by jackals, of course we could not determine.

Dr. MacKellar mentioned little Nimo in her last letter. She was very happy with us, but the mother, finding we would not undertake to feed her, too, took the child away. She was without hearts we stripped the clothes from the poor little girl, and sent her away just as she came, minus the dirt, while we continued in prayer that God would send her again if it be His good will.

A few days later a man came to the door and said, "I have six daughters. I cannot provide for them unless you take this child she will die." And I said in heart, "Surely, and I fear she will die sooner anyway." The poor, little head was the biggest part of her. The limbs were just like dry, brown sticks. She was bathed, dressed, fed, and put to sleep with a clean, warm, well-nourished baby. For days she continued to refuse refused food, and was very miserable. By request of the matron she was called Champa, which is a beautiful, white, wax-like flower.

A day or two later, among the hundreds that were sitting waiting to receive their dole of food, came an old man with a tiny scrap of a child screaming in front of him. He called me, and said, "I am dying. Save my child; her mother is dead, and there is no one to care for her." Calling the matron, I took her and take the baby and give her some milk. She stretched out her arms and said, "Come." The poor little thing without the slightest hesitation lifted her hands eagerly to be taken up, as if she thought she'd found her mother. Happily she has found as tender hearts and ready hands to care for her. The orphan girls are now much interested in the work, and whenever they see a baby being handed over they crowd to the gate, and dozens of hands are stretched out to receive the little wail. A name had to be chosen for this little one. I much liked the names Christians have of giving babies, such as their children, such as Tabitha, Rebecca, Ruth, Victoria-bai, Evangeline-bai. Many of their own names are very pretty. So as this was a good opportunity of teaching a lesson we discussed names fully, and decided that Chameli, a white flower, would be best.

On Monday a little Bihl girl of three years was given over. She cried loudly at sight of me. I, therefore, called one of the girls (Premi), to whom the children all cling, and said, "If you are willing, take her into the Home." When I returned the girls had her washed, dressed and named. Sundari (beautiful) was the name they had aptly chosen, for she's a pretty little thing.
The Bright and the Dark Side.

FROM DR. MARION OLIVER.

Mission Hospital, Indore, Nov. 2, 1899.

This is house-cleaning time among the Hindus, and because of that we have had for some days only about half the number of women at the dispensaries. Once they get their houses set in order, and their bathing and peoga over, they will begin again to think of their bodily ailments, and we will have more of the old chronic cases, and find that the nights have become cold. Poor rheumatic patients. Poor old bodies, no wonder they often are so ready to say: "It would be good for me to die." I have just come upstairs from a long and tiresome interview with some very friendly purists, who always hang about the hospital here. They are Borahs (a sect of Mohammedans), and the husband has brought his old grandmother, his wife, his sister and two children and I had patiently to listen to an account of all their varied ailments. The grandmother is blind from cataract, but she feels that I ought to have a very hopeless case for operation, did not press it. The wife, a pretty young woman, is very lame from a form of muscular rheumatism peculiar to young women in this country, who become more or less stiff mere children. For such they can hardly me, but during the last two or three years I have had much success in treating them, so I was able to encourage the husband about his wife. The sister and children are suffering from malaria, so they also should be made to hope that the Dr. Mac Sahib may succeed in doing them good.

It is always exceedingly difficult to get a woman or her friends to believe I am telling them the truth, when I say: "I cannot do anything for you," they generally think I want to get something out of them, and begin to try to make me feel poor. I learned long since to take even little sums of money offered by poor people, because to decline is to make them think you want them to give more. So I take even an anna or an egg when offered, though I may slip it into the hand of one of the children afterwards.

Yesterday I went to one of the cleanest and best houses I have seen in India. The house was built after the usual plan—a quadrangle enclosing a fine large courtyard—wide, two-storied verandahs ran round the four sides, and in the centre of the compound was a good well. Near the well was a tall tube plant growing beside it, and also several pretty plants in pots. In a room off one of the lower verandahs I saw several women preparing food, and on an upper verandah, sitting on bright new deckes (cane rugs) was a group of eight or nine women, all looking very contented and chatting away among themselves while some of them sewed, and others played with their babies. They made a pretty picture, and I thought it is from seeing scenes like this that people write of the beautiful simplicity of Hindoo home life. I had been in an inner room, where a poor suffering child wife lay, and looked upon the picture with opened eyes, and said, "Alas! the lights and the shadows resting upon it. The women who belong to the better classes and live in the huts (zenanas) are, as a rule, not only contented to live within the four walls which bound their world, but are given to putting on very superior airs, and heart aches for them, because they are so satisfied to be as they are.

Owing to scarcity of water, we have had to let our garden go unwatered except in one corner, where we have had still the rose bushes and other plants we were anxious to preserve transplanted. We still have several feet of water in the well, but, with no prospect of rain before June, we are in great danger of a water famine as well as a food famine. The Marwaris, driven out of their homes by reason of lack of water, have come streaming hundreds into Central India, and though they have nothing like so many of them here as in the Neemuch district, yet one cannot go through the streets without seeing crowds of them. A relief camp has been opened just beyond the city. The men earn five cents daily, the women three or four cents. Just enough to keep body and soul together. For the men it is not too bad but for the poor women, with little children pulling at their mothers' skirts, and for the helpless infants it is a pitiable sight to look upon.

CONDITIONS WE MUST FACE.

FROM MISS O'HARA, DIHAR.

Dhar, Oct. 16th.

We here in Central India are face to face with a condition never before experienced in this area—a big famine. True we are not yet at the worst but it is bad enough and the prospect of what it will be when the cold weather sets in makes one really alarmed. We receive your prayers and sympathy as never before, and in order to relieve suffering we need practical help. Many of the wells are quite dry, and those that have water are in cases of many a suicide. Last Tuesday a woman came in this city had no food and the wife and mother was pleading with her husband to bring them food, but he told her he could not get food, so she sat till he went out took her youngest child in her arms and the next youngest walked by her side to the well; the mother then said: "We three will jump into the water and drown together." China.

THE HONAN EXCHANGE.

FROM A NATIVE TEACHER.

Not many years ago I was blind, but thanks to the foreign doctor who restored my sight. When I first picked up a book, however, I found that I was blind again. I could not read. The characters looked strange and distorted, and very much alike to me; but by hard and faithful study, I was at last able to read, when to my dismay I was told that I was still as one blind, for my heart's eye had yet to be opened. I found in The Book that this was so, and that I was living in darkness. But by God's grace the Great Physician also opened my heart's eye, so that now I can see, and am able to read my title clear to the mansions above.

CHANG TE FU.

To the west of us about fifteen miles there is a silver mine, which hitherto seems to have escaped the attention of the syndicates. Chinese scholars tell us that even with crude native methods, it yielded fair amounts of the white metal. It has been an interesting coincidence that the present closing of the mine, affirming that a mighty python was seen to bar the way to the Treasure Cave with his folds, leaving however, a few chinks, through which the awe-stricken, but disappointed beholders saw the cave all white with the precious ore.

The attraction of the compound is Dr. Menzie's new pump and closed-in-well. Dr. says they drink cold spring water now without

beholding it. What a luxury! To the natives, its chief charm (or drawback) seems to be that it is impossible to commit suicide by jumping into it.

Rev. A. Hoddie, on his way down from Shansi, reports that the condition of the people of that province, on account of the opium habit, is most deplorable, rendering it almost impossible to get work of any kind done. From seven to nine tenths of children, and from four to five tenths of the heads of the family, Boys of thirteen have the craving, and it is known to be a fact, that in certain cases, infants at the breast require to have opium smoke puffed in their faces, in order to pass the craving and enable them to nurse.

While this people are trying to live out a miserable existence, in the midst of the greatest poverty and opium, all the while they are unconsciously treading under their feet untold wealth, for it is definitely stated that running through Shansi Province Hoddie is a vein of coal of the first quality, eight feet feet thick, and over three hundred yards long. Prof. Drake states that the supply is practically inexhaustible, and although the native methods of mining are very slow yet in some of the coal yards near Hwai Ch'ing may be seen heaps of coal worth 300,000 taels.

THE MISSION IN ALBERTA, B.C.

FROM MRS. CAMERON.

NOV. 12.

We are having exceptional weather now. B.C. weather is generally so I think—it has rained almost continually since about the first of October, and not a Scotch mist or drizzle either. The real downpour nearly every day and night. The settlers say there has not been so much rain at this time of the year since eleven years ago. Still we have very little mud and the water soon runs away.

Harry and another have their new house now finished, and three others have started to build in the Shehshu village. Several new sets of furniture have arrived; Norah's father and his wife went both scaling, and each brought home a bedstead, dresser, commode and stand, all very nice indeed and very suitable. Their house looks something like a fine old shop. Another little Shehshu girl has been put in the school about seven weeks, and five Howchucklesht children applied for admission about a month ago; one was too scruffy but the other three boys and a girl are with us, and they are very interesting children. All the school and they are well enough except two Opichuck are attending the day school. These two have been promised me several times but their promise often means very little.
Hattie's father and grandfather are to "potlach" about $400 next week, and five trifles are being invited. We hope some of the visitors may "potlach" children to the mission; we have seventeen now, and there are twenty-six attending the day school.

Mr. Motion has had a very busy week, painting in the boys' dormitory and dressing rooms, the playground and two lower halls, and painted the floors and walls of first two, and mended and whitewashed the plaster, and he has fixed up the front of the old house for a play-room for the boys. He sold the young horse and colt to one of our ex-pupils, son of Chief Swatset, and he went to Nanaimo last week and bought a covered carriage.

TO OTTAWA PRESBYTERIAL.

FROM MR. MOTION.

We feel deeply grateful to the ladies of Ottawa Presbyterial Society for the nice supply of clothing sent to our Mission. We have opened all the bales, and were highly pleased with the nice clothes. Mrs. Motion desires me to express her grateful thanks to the ladies for the way she quoted them to her. The parcel from the Orphans' Home Mission Band, Ottawa, was simply perfect. They completely outfitted one boy and one girl; in a nice letter they tell me how gladly accomplished it. It is a lesson to show us what we could do for the cause of Christ if we would use the opportunities that lie at our hands. We were in great need of some of the things that were sent, and the nice quantity of flannellette and cloth that was sent will come in very handy.

Our work is progressing slowly. All our Indians are home from the sealing on Behring sea, except two, whom I am afraid, we will not see again. Sometimes the woman goes with her husband sealing, and it was so in this case. It meant that in a storm their boat was capsized and the poor man and his wife were drowned. Before leaving here he had built a splendid frame house at the Opitchesault village (the best there), and with his sealing money intended to finish and furnish it. The canoe was afterwards found upside down. The house will now be the property of one of our ex-pupils, Dan Watts by name. All our children are enjoying good health at present.

TO TORONTO PRESBYTERIAL SOCIETY.

FROM MISS ARBOR.

Uchucket, B.C., Nov. 14, 1899.

The bale of clothing and Christmas things for our school children and the old people arrived today from Toronto Presbyterial, and I have just finished unpacking and arranging the things. Everything is in good order and perfectly suited to our needs. I am especially thankful for the boots for the old women. They appreciate considerably, and highly that I can readily anticipate their pleasure and gratitude, and in their behalf I thank the ladies who have supplied those gifts for their kindness. The gift of blankets for Miss Armstrong is very nice, and though very much, I am sorry that almost all our people are away from Uchucket just now, but I think the greater number of them will return before Christmas. School has been closed for the last month, and the prospect is good for the people to return with their children for another month is to me very dear. However, I am turning this "waiting time" to advantage by studying the native language. I feel that I shall be very much more useful in the work by being able to speak the Indian language. The few people who have remained on the island have been very faithful in attending the Sunday service. Last Sunday, of the thirteen here, nine were at the service. Of the other three, one old man has been bedridden for the last two and a half years one was sick, and the young man, poor fellow, stayed at home doing winter work in his house. The Indians say that sickness prevented him, for when we passed his house on our return he laid away his hammer and saw. May he soon see that it is God who is taking account of their thoughts and to whom he must answer, not the missionary. The Indian men returned in good time from the Behring sea. They experienced a very rough season. The weather was bad almost continuously, with sudden high winds and very high sea. One canoe, containing David, one of our boys, was lost from the sea coast, but was picked up by another canoe which has since returned to Uchucket. Another canoe was destroyed and both occupants, a man and his wife, were lost. It was very sad to see the grief of the old parents when they got the news of their daughter's death. They were very present in their sorrow that hurts so. If they could only know the "Resurrection" and the Life it brings, this despair would give place to a holy joy! Thank God for His great gift!

The last month has been a very happy one, though we have had only an occasional glimpse of sunshine. My father has been visiting me twice out of going home to see him. He has enjoyed the trip very much, and I feel quite strengthened for work again. He leaves today. After that I shall be alone until Mrs. Swartout comes, which, I think, will be about the middle of December.

OUR NEW MISSION AT LONG PLAIN and SWAN LAKE.

FROM MR. R. MCKAY.

Swan Lake, Nov. 22, 1899.

I was very sorry indeed not to have met you on your way home.
I was pleased to hear of the flourishing condition in which you found the different missions during your visits, especially the Mistawasis Mission, in which I take a deep interest.

With regard to my mission at Long Plain is fifty-five miles from Swan Lake, the way I have to travel in summer time. Having to visit a small band of Indians at Indian Ford, about five miles east of the ferry over the Assiniboine river, increases the distance between Long Plain and Indian Ford twenty miles. In winter time the distance will be lessened, as I will not have to go around by the ferry. Following the wishes of the committee, I have visited Long Plain and Indian Ford twice every month, remaining at each place from one to three days.

At Long Plain I have had only one meeting, and have tried again and again to get them together for service, but without success, although I often go right in on them while they are holding some heathen festival, and succeed in getting a hearing for a few minutes. The course which I now follow is house-to-house visiting, which, I believe, will, with God's help, develop into large and attentive gatherings.

The situation is somewhat the same at Indian Ford. The Indians at this place are a branch of the Swan Lake band, and are few in number. I sometimes find only two or three families on this small reserve.

The Swan Lake band are the most promising, and I am able to give more of my time there than when residing at Okanese. I hold service on this Reserve twice and sometimes once Sabbath in the month. I also visit them during the week, taking care not to impose too much. The average attendance at service is about ten—very small, indeed, but very encouraging when we have the privilege of God's presence where His people are gathered together in His name. There is a great deal of sickness among the Indians, and I fear this winter is going to be one of privation. I have been trying so far to give my personal attention to the sick, dressing their sores, etc. The majority are suffering from consumption, fever, rheumatism, and various diseases. Dr. Macklin is the medical attendant for the Swan Lake Reserve. He says there is not much use treating them where they have not the proper nourishment, so necessary for the building up of the tissues. The question arises what is to be done?

The band sick seem to be nearly all almost altogether, and I am sure will suffer for the want of clothing as well as food this winter.

I am now living in Swan Lake village, about five miles from the reserve, in a fairly comfortable room.

There is one poor soul here on his death-bed. I visited him yesterday. It is wonderful how patiently he suffers—not a word or sound from him except the dreary breathing. His face brightens when I enter his hut and take a seat by his bed. He seems to drink in every word as I read to him a portion of Genesis. This is the first case of serious sickness among the reds of the Indians would allow me to speak to or even approach the sick. It is a great relief to me to accomplish this much, although it is far from being satisfactory. I believe that this soul will be saved. Although he cannot speak, I believe that God will reveal to us whether he has been brought to a knowledge of the Truth as it is in Jesus or not. I know it is not necessary for me to request your earnest co-operation in the "Throne of Grace."

TO BROCKVILLE PRESBYTERIAL.

FROM MR. R. C. MACKLIN.

Okanese Mission, Nov. 18, 1899.

I am, indeed, very glad to tell you that I am much better. Recovery has been very slow, and it will be some days yet before I am able to resume my duties. I hope and think that by Monday, 27th inst., I will be able to resume school again.

During my illness, Mr. Roger, at my request, assembled in church on Sabbath to worship God. Mr. Roger called on me before service for any message I had. It is very encouraging to us to see our people assembling themselves to worship God without a missionary.

Also, we are very thankful to you that during my illness our people have shown deep anxiety about me, and I am sure they are anxious to see me well again, judging by the way those receive me that I have met the few short times I have been here.

Enclosed please find receipt for the clothes received from the Brockville Presbytery Society. We received an excellent supply of good clothing, for which we thank the Brockville Presbyterial. We are always very much pleased to know and think that we are remembered by the different Presbyterials who are waking up the people to the need. We have had many beautiful and useful gifts from individual members, the way of household nicknacks, which we highly appreciate, but the kindness of the Brockville Presbyterial has far exceeded this.

TO TORONTO PRESBYTERIAL

FROM MR. W. S. MOORE

Mistawasis, Sask., Nov. 20, 1890.

The bale of clothing from the Toronto Presbyterial Society came to hand last week, and has been distributed by the managers. There were several Indians here, my men have received the shipments, and were extremely well pleased with the gifts; more so, perhaps, from the fact that others were not receiving. I most thank the kindness of Mrs. Moore, myself and children for "some things for the children," sent in the bale of clothing; We thoroughly appreciate this most useful gift as a practical token of your thoughtful kindness.

TO TORONTO PRESBYTERIAL

Round Lake, Nov. 24, 1890.

We were much pleased in receiving this supply of goods for Round Lake, as we would have been in such need without it. I trust now we shall be able to make the most of each poor helper who comes, adding during the winter. The clothing is good, and much of the things sent will assist us in our school. The made-up garments will save Mrs. McKay many an hour with the sewing machine. The dishes, knives and forks, etc., are all useful. May the blessing of the God of Jacob abide upon all those who give us such assistance in our work.

All the children attending school are well except Grace, who has never been strong. Angela, Augustus and Napoleon have been working out this summer but I shall allow them to have another winter at school. After that they can be well able to make a living for themselves. There are four or five little ones who are waiting until the river and lake are frozen over.

Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, 2nd January, 1900

The Secretary:

Re application for grant for the Presbyterian Home at Alberni.

In 1895 the Department contributed $1500 to aid in the erection of a new building for the Girls' Home at Alberni. This grant was given on the understanding that it would not be called upon to make any further contribution towards the building.

No application was made for a per capita grant until November 1896, when the Rev. R.F. Mackay asked that the usual boarding school grant be allowed them for 35 children. Mr. Mackay was informed that no funds were available from which a grant in addition to the amount contributed in payment of the salary of a teacher at the day school at that place, could be made. He was informed, however, that his application would be considered when the next year's estimates were being framed. No amount has been provided and no further application has been received until now.

The Department receives no returns from the Home although the last day school return shows that about 16 or 20 are in attendance, and it is presumed that this number includes the boarders as both classes of pupils are referred to by the Agent in his report.
Since September last the school has been in charge of Mr and Mrs Morton, who were formerly on the staff of the Regina Industrial school and who seem to be anxious to improve the standing of this school (which was first established for girls only) and is now taking in boys, application having been made for a set of carpenter's tools.

The Rev. Mr Mackay is apparently under the impression that the Presbyterians are being discriminated against in British Columbia in regard to the distribution of the Government grant for schools, which is not the case, as they have only lately started mission work in that Province and have only two day schools in operation in addition to this Home.

The total Indian population of British Columbia is shown by the last census to be 24,973, made up of 12,000 Roman Catholics; 4,257 Anglicans; 2,836 Methodists; 269 Presbyterians; other Christian beliefs 302; and 2,267 pagans; and bands not visited 2,500 whose religion is unknown.

The present application is made for a grant for 30 pupils at $70 and although there is accommodation for 65 children, they have never had any list like that number, and it is not usual for the Department to make a grant in first instance for all the pupils that could be accommodated. Sixty dollars is the boarding school rate at present allowed in British Columbia and if any grant were made to this school it should be at the same rate.

The Secretary:

Re application for increased grant to Alberni Boarding School.

This school is conducted under the auspices of the Presbyterian Church and for a number of years was carried on without any assistance from the Department which contributed in 1895 $1500.00 to aid in the erection of a new building on the understanding that it would not be called upon to make any further contributions towards the building. No application was made for a per capita grant until November 1926 when Rev. Mr Mackay Secretary of the Foreign Mission Committee asked that the usual boarding school grant be allowed up to 35 children. As no funds were available nothing was done in this direction until the Supplementary estimates for the current year were being prepared, when provision was made for 25 pupils, and that number have been paid for since the last July last. The last return (30th September) showed that there were 41 pupils on the roll and the Principal in his annual report claims to have an average attendance of 29. For some years previous to receiving Government aid the school had been carrying over 30.
30 pupils and it is a question whether the school ought not to be content to wait a while before asking for an increase.

The census of the West Coast Agency shows that the Presbyterians claim about 320 members out of a total population of about 2,500, while the four bands from which this school is drawing its pupils have a total Presbyterian population of about 180, which would give only about 40 pupils of school age. The buildings are large enough to accommodate 45 pupils in addition to the staff, but I think that it is question whether it would be wise to bring up all the children in a boarding school where they would be unfitted to follow the avocations which they will be called upon to pursue in after life, fishing and sealing being the principle means of livelihood within their reach.

Mr. Motion, the Principal of this school, and his wife, who is acting matron, are both old employees of the Regina Industrial school, and it is Mr. Motion's very laudable ambition to have this school recognized as an Industrial school, which if acceded to would entail an industrial school grant of $130 per capita thus doubling the cost of the institution to the Department, without any corresponding benefit to the Indians.
I understand there are 35 pupils at the Alberni Boarding School in British Columbia, but that the Church gets a grant for only 25. I think it might be arranged for next year to give them a grant for 30 pupils. I do not think it will make any difference in the estimates,—possibly the cutting off of the grant to the Comox School would about balance this.
