Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose my Quarterly Statement for Quarter ending Sept. 30th, 1900.

The Foreign Mission Committee of the Presbyterian Church having informed me that the Indian Department had kindly granted a grant of $72. per capita per annum, starting on July 1st, 1900, for twenty-five pupils, I have entered the same in my report. I feel grateful to the Indian Department for thus helping us in our work.

During this Quarter the Annual six weeks school holidays were given, starting on July 10th, and school beginning again on Aug. 27th. The boys and girls of the Home worked in their different departments one half day, and the other half they were free to enjoy themselves.

The health of the children has been very good. Andrew 31 who left on sick-leave, is not improving as I had hoped, I feel that an operation in hospital is the only remedy; his glands are badly swollen from ear to ear. I regret this very much as Andrew is a nice lad, doing well in school, and when down at his home at Newmicklesham while speaking to him, his regret was that he was not strong enough to return with me.

Our school work is getting along nicely, the children taking good interest in their studies.

I regret that Willie Roberts had to go home to assist his mother, it was necessary as the poor woman was utterly unable to help herself also having two young children under four years of age depending on her. I am pleased to say that the mother is now able to walk around, but is not strong enough to do any work yet.

We had a splendid crop of fruit in our garden this summer, and our potato crop promises well. We are busy at present securing our winter's supply of wood (fire), and building a wagon road whereby it will be easier for us to take anything to or from the garden.

We were pleased also to have you visit our Home on Aug. 1st, and trust that everything was satisfactory to you.
Mr. Agent Guilled also visited us on Sept. 27th. on his monthly visit.

I have made a requisition for forty iron spring beds (single) for our Home. I sincerely hope they will be granted to us. The beds that are in use are all wooden beds and double, necessitating two boys in each bed, they are not now in good repair, and they are certainly not the best kind of a bed in an Institution like this where it is preferable for children to have single beds. I enclose cut of bed asked for in requisition, as for asking for forty beds I feel certain that our attendance will reach that figure before next spring. OTTAWA, 19th April, 1904:

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With regard to the complaint of Mr Fred Thornburg that two of his children were taken back to the Alberni boarding school contrary to his wishes, I beg to say that if Mr Thornburg's statements are correct, Mr Motion, the Principal of the school, was not justified in removing the children without their father's consent. Thornburg is a white man who was married to an Indian and as he is a trader, living off the reserve, his children should be considered as whites, not half-breeds and not eligible for admission to an industrial or boarding school under the regulations. In this case, however, the father had given his consent in writing to have them placed in the Alberni school where they remained for two years. The school never drew any grant for these children as they were in excess of the number authorized, and under the existing arrangements I know of no reason why the school could not take them in so long as the Department was not called upon to pay for them and their residence did not interfere with the proper maintenance and education of the Indian children.

The father having changed his mind about their remaining there on religious grounds, had a right to their control and is entitled to their discharge. The father does not claim to be a Roman Catholic although he was married by a priest and his children were baptized by one, but without entering...
into the religious side of the question, he is entitled to the education and control of his children and the choice of their place of residence. As a white man he could legally claim their custody but as legal proceedings would be expensive and inconvenient for him, he asks the intervention of the Department to secure their discharge.

Of course we have heard only one side of the case and the Principal of the school may have explanations to offer but unless they are sufficient to overcome the father's statements the Department would be justified in ordering the children's release, and I would suggest that Mr. Sup. Vowell be advised of the statements made and instructed to obtain a report on the case. Authority might be given him to decide this matter on its merits.

Dear Sir:

Yours of 11th August, respecting Mr. Thornberg's complaint as to the detention of his children in the Alberni School, came to hand during my absence to the Lakes. I received an explanatory letter from Mr. Motion, a copy of which I inclose. I also received from him a sheaf of correspondence that passed between them during negotiations for reception of children into the school. If you so desire, I shall be glad to send you all the correspondence I have received.

The following is a copy of the letter dated from Mr

Motion on the 27th June 1904:

"I received your letter of the 14th instant by last mail re Mr Thornberg and his two children.

I inclose correspondence, which, after you peruse, you will better understand the statement I now make. I have not inclosed all the correspondence, but enough, so that you may understand the situation. The Indian Department granted leave of residence for the children in the school by letter Nov. 29th, 1901.

The foundation of the whole trouble is that Mr Russell did not deal with Mr Thornberg, and he became embittered against him. Mr Thornberg states that Mr Russell promised him his trade if he sent Hilda and Andy to Alberni. Mr Russell, I am certain, made no such promise. Mr Russell kept and cared for the five children during the mother's illness, beside nursing the mother all at his own expense, and Mr Thornberg, I believe, would have been willing at the time, for all the children to come to Alberni, but I asked that only the two eldest be sent.

Mr Thornberg states he never read the admission papers, but it was at his suggestion the words, "Indian Dept," were struck out. See Mr Russell's letter of August 9th 1901.

Mr Thornberg had perfect confidence in Mr Russell at that time, and did not wish the word "parent" inserted, but Mr Russell thought it best that it should. When one of the members of the Alberni staff visited Ahousaht shortly afterwards, Mr Thornberg said "That whatever Mr Russell did regarding the children, would be all right."

On Mr Thornberg refusing to return Hilda and Andy last year at the expiration of their leave of absence, and especially as he refused to return then suggesting that immoral relations had existed between Hilda and one of the school boys during my absence at Regina. Knowing this to be utterly false I went to Ahousaht, and the following morning went over to Mr Thornberg's in company of Mr Russell to seek an explanation of the statements made, also to get the children if possible.

The tide was high, and we landed practically at his door. Mr Thornberg came out just as we were landing, saw us, and immediately returned into the house. The door of the house was open and I walked in, introducing myself, and stating my reasons for coming. Hilda and Andy were not to be seen. He said Hilda did not want to see me, and that she would not speak to me. I told him I thought she would if I could see her. I asked him were the children were, and he said Andy had taken to the bush, and that Hilda was in there, pointing to a recess.

Mr Thornberg told Mr Russell and I that Rev. P.Maurus, Principal of the R.C. Boarding school, Clayoquot had been there two days before, and that he (Mr Thornberg) had promised that Hilda should go to the Roman Catholic school as soon as she received her discharge."
from Alberni. I turned to the recess and asked Hilda to come out. She came out and sat down on a trunk beside me. I was speaking to her having her hand in mine, when he seized hold of it, saying, "That's mine, not yours." With that he immediately gave Hilda a turn, saying something to her, and she fled out the front door.

Mr Thornberg following her, yelling, "Take to the bush, Hilda, take to the bush!" I went after Hilda and caught her. She was panting. She said, "I am afraid of my father. He will kill me, he will kill me!" This she repeated several times, and seemed to be in great fear of him. I told her not to fear, that it would be all right. I brought Hilda back, and told Mr Thornberg that it was no use talking further, that I had decided to take Hilda back with me. I tried to find Andy in the bush, but could not. Mr Thornberg asked Hilda if she would like to go back to Alberni, and she said at once, "Yes". Mr Thornberg wished me to leave her till next day promising he would bring her over to Mr Russell's, but I could not trust him. Hilda came over to Mr Russell's with us, and her father came and visited her there before leaving for Alberni. Mr Russell was an eye witness of all that happened between Mr Thornberg and myself.

As to its legal aspect, I asked a prominent lawyer here as to my course, and he said it was all right, and that I could send for Andy at any time. This I did, sending a constable, but unfortunately the expense in connection was $25.00.

Now that I have the custody of the children, Mr Thornberg wishes the Department to intervene on his behalf to save him expense, something he never considered either in the maintenance, care, or travel of his children. I do not think that Mr Thornberg is legally entitled to the control, choice of place of residence, or custody of his children until they are discharged from this school. The Presbyterian Church has borne the full expense of their education, and it would be sad indeed if we had so little control that the father could withdraw them at any time, and transfer them to a R.C. School, especially after the slanderous reasons put forward by Mr Thornberg.

If he wishes to withdraw his children, and should there be some legal way whereby he can obtain the custody of his children before the regular time of discharge; he should be granted the privilege by the Court that before obtaining their discharge he should pay for their maintenance while resident.

In my letter to the Department, I miswrote my letter, it should have read; "We do not intend to recommend the discharge etc." It was written hurriedly.

I am sorry that you have been troubled over this. It was my intention to place the matter before Mr Thornton Bell as soon as he returned from the East, for his legal opinion. I shall be glad if you will return the correspondence as soon as you have finished with it.

I may say in closing, that I do not think Mr Thornberg is a fit and proper person to have the care and further training of
his children who are here. He is an old man of sixty-three years of age, has lived over thirty years amongst the Indians, and is not any better than one now himself. The Captain of the "Queen City" mentioned to me that it was a blessing they were here, as the father seems to be growing worse mentally all the time.

Trusting the Committee will carefully consider this matter, and hoping they will not sacrifice the interests of the School for the sake of expedience,

With kindest regards,

Yours very sincerely,

(Sgd) Jas R. Motion

Dear Sir;-

Your note received re Mr Thornberg, and my own feeling has been in the direction which you indicate; that is, to discharge the children in order to allay agitation that must be hurtful to the work.

I have written to Mr Motion acquainting him with your judgment, and suggesting that he might negotiate with Mr Thornberg on the basis of a refund of maintenance to a small amount. I suggest this not because of the money value, but in the hope that it will prevent any others from thinking that they can by creating an agitation pursue a similar course with success. The question of discipline is the principle one involved, and possibly some such demand would prevent harm in that direction.

The Committee will meet on the 20th instant, and pronounce upon it, but I have in the meantime taken the responsibility of making this suggestion. I hope and feel confident that a solution will be reached without any injury to the work.

Yours sincerely,

OTTAWA, 6th February, 1905

The Deputy Superintendent General

With reference to the petition from the Ahousaht Indians and the accompanying correspondence regarding the retention of Hilda Thornberg at the Alberni boarding school by Mr. Motion, the Principal, I beg to say that the Principal has no right to retain the girl at the school. On the 4th Oct. last Rev. Dr. Mackay wrote the Department stating that the Foreign Mission Committee had endorsed this Department's recommendation advising Mr. Motion to surrender Thornberg's children. He also stated that he had received a letter from Mr. Motion in which he acquiesces in this decision. The boy was returned but the girl is held as collateral security for $100.00, which Mr. Motion claims as compensation for her board.

Mr. Motion has clearly no right to retain the girl and I think that Rev. Dr. Mackay should be asked to instruct him to discharge her at once. The letters from Thornberg and his son seem to reflect on the management of the school, and I think it would be well if Mr. Inspector Green were sent to this school at the earliest possible moment.

SIR—

I have the honor to report that I learn, casually and non-officially, that Mr. J.R. Norton has resigned as Principal of the Alberni Boarding school and that his successor has already been appointed.

Some years ago (in March 1900 I believe) the Dept. issued certain rules in connection with the establishment of these schools, one of which was to the effect that no member of the school staff should be changed or employed without the sanction of the Dept.

It would be an excellent thing to enforce this rule. So far as this Agency is concerned it is a dead letter. The various churches appoint principals and teachers without any reference to the Dept., and after the men are actually on the ground I report the fact to the Dept., which sends a formal approval.

I would suggest that in each case the name of the party proposed to be appointed should be submitted to the Dept., together with a statement showing his educational qualifications and experience and no appointment made until the sanction of the Dept. had been obtained. As it is done today the man or woman is actually on the field and the Dept. is really not consulted at all, merely notified and it would extremely difficult for the Dept. to object to a man after he had brought his family, perhaps a couple of thousand miles and was actually installed. But if the consent had been obtained first, the Dept. could veto an impossible appointment without trouble and the very fact of its having to be done would make the various churches more careful of who they choose.

As regards day school teachers I would suggest that there be appointments that teachers must hold a teaching certificate or its equivalent as a guarantee of their own educational qualifications.

As to the principals of Industrial & Boarding schools, I would suggest that some college training should be an essential, not entirely for the book learning thereby acquired but because a man who has attended college for several years is more likely at least to have rubbed shoulders with the world and gained some experience of dealing with men and to have acquired tact, self-control and common sense—all qualities much needed in dealing with the Indian parents. All principals should at least possess the equivalent of a first-class teacher's certificate and to have had some previous experience among Indians.

If what I hear is correct the gentleman who has been appointed as Mr. Norton's successor is a B.A., and has been for a number of years in similar work so that there would be no trouble over this appointment and for that very reason I consider the present moment a favourable one for the Dept. to announce that its rule must in future be adhered to. If one or two of the applicants of whom I have heard, had had sufficient "pull" to secure the office, the school and the Dept. would have been saddled with a dead weight which would have caused no end of trouble for many years to come.

So much of the success of these schools depends on the men at the head of them that it seems only just that the Dept., who contributes such a large portion of the cost, should be able to exercise an actual instead of merely a nominal supervision over their selection.

On Sept 23, 1905, Mr. Russell and his motion came right here to our house and took my sister Hilda off by force. I was in hiding under the house and heard all that was said. I heard my sister say "don't" and then I heard her screaming and running right past me out of the house and up the high and rocky cliffs. I also heard my father running and hallooing out "help! help!" and calling on the Indians that live across the water on the curve but none came. All the men were off sealing after a time. I heard them leave taking my sister with them so I came out of my hiding. Father showed me a very high and steep cliff where my motion gave him a heavy push and if Father had not grabbed a little underbrush just at his hand he would surely have tumbled to the bottom and that would have killed him; it is a wonder that my sister saved herself from having a tumble down this rocky cliff when that big long-legged man Mr. Motion was in full chase. He heard her screaming the whole time. I was taken away from home by an order from Inspector Russell. Dear Mr. Scott:

At our Executive meeting yesterday, we have appointed Mr. H. B. Currie to Alberni, to succeed Mr. Hendry. Mr. Currie is from Walkerton. He was brought up in Owen Sound, his educational course covering the ground necessary for a teacher's certificate, but having entered the Post Office service, he did not try for a certificate. He seems a very likeable young man and is highly commended by Mr. Wilson, the minister of Walkerton where he has been in service for a considerable number of years. He has been active in Young People's and Sabbath School work, and in every way seems to be the kind of man we are after.

You will be glad to hear that reports from Alberni and from Ahousaht are very satisfactory as to the new appointments. Miss Norrice is proving not only an efficient teacher but a good disciplinarian. I regret to report that Mr. and Mrs. W. A. Hendry, principal and matron, of the Alberni Boarding School have resigned. Mr. Hendry was in charge of this school about 6 months and had he stayed I am sure he would have worked a great improvement. A very able man, of high education, long experience in school management, and possessing in a marked degree the tact and judgment so essential to success in handling the Indians. I am pleased to know that the Department recognised his abilities and offered him a position soon after he severed his connection with the Church. Their successors have arrived, Mr. and Mrs. H. B. Currie. They appear to be very nice people and well intentioned, but they have absolutely no experience in this work, have no knowledge of school management, or of nursing, or of handling Indians; they do not appear to have even been fully informed of the conditions under which they will have to work. I repeat that, personally, I think they are people of fine character, but it is not fair to them, it is not fair to the school, it is not fair to the Department for the Church to send out people so entirely inexperienced in the work. However any assistance I can render will be heartily given and in time Mr. Currie may overcome the handicap under which he enters on his position.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Scott;

I wrote you yesterday submitting the name of Miss Grace Cox for the school at Alberni and giving you the substance of testimonials from Mr. Currie, Mr. Neil and Dr. Carruthers. I have received this morning a letter from Mr. Currie in which is the following paragraph:

"Miss Cox, whom I temporarily engaged is not a qualified teacher. She is rather a clever girl and fairly good in the class room but useless in the Home. Besides her influence with the children is not specially desirable. She has been raised in too close proximity to them and has imbibed very much of their nature. She would make a fair teacher for a day school but not for a Boarding school. I will get along in some way until a new teacher comes."

This is rather embarrassing insomuch as the testimonials were favorable of Mr. Neil and Dr. Carruthers who recommended her appointment. I notice that Mr. Currie's own testimonial is non-committal. It is as follows:

"This is to certify that Miss Grace Cox has been teaching in this School since 14th November 1910 and appears to be a capable teacher. I have no hesitation in recommending her to any school looking for a good teacher."

That seems to be definite enough and yet I can imagine that he could shield himself under the indefiniteness of not having specially recommended her appointment to their own school. I suppose it would be better, wouldn't it not, to delay confirmation until there is further correspondence? If we could get one in the West it would save the great expense of sending from Ontario. For that reason I was gratified when her name appeared.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Hon. Sirs,

Your letter of 11 July No. 116620/1 re Half Breed Children to hand,
while I have no alternative but submit to your ruling—which to my
mind is an injustice—and I doubt not, in the very near future will
cause much dissatisfaction among the Indians, and will seriously affect
our schools on the west coast of B.C.
To my mind here is the injustice—a
pure Indian man marries a half breed woman—their child is ¼ Indian, and the child is eligible
as a pupil of a Boarding School because its
father was an Indian. Now a pure
Indian woman marries a Half Breed man
their child also is ¼ Indian but is barred
(having the same proportion of Indian blood in its veins)
simply because the father is half breed.
To be fair, as I see it, both children
should be admitted or both should be barred.
Again, your new regulations are not clear and should be revised. Your regulations are "half breed children can not be admitted without special authority and then as non grant earners." My interpretation of this would be that a child with 50% or more of white blood would be barred while a child with less than 50% of white blood would be classed as "Indian" and eligible as a pupil of a Boarding School. If the Department require only "Pure Indian" children admitted as grant earners, I think it should be so stated in the regulations.

For my own personal information, I will be pleased if you will state just what I may accept as "grant earning pupils." Also in view of the points I have drawn your attention to in this letter, will you kindly reconsider my application of the instant? And if you still cannot comply with my application, will you authorize my keeping this boy as a non-grant earner?

This boy is the brightest I have come in contact with since I came to O.B., and would much like to have him as a pupil.

Your obedient servant,

H.B. Currie

December 3rd, 1913

Indian Agent's report for month of Nov. 1913

Sir,

There was considerable excitement last Sunday (Nov. 30) evening at the Alberni Boarding School, and Seshat Reserve which is quite close to the school. Fire broke out in one of the store rooms on the third floor of the school, and was first noticed by one of the Indians on the Reserve, the pupils and staff being at Sunday School, in the dining room, the other side of the building. It was very soon brought under control by the older pupils with the help of the Indians from the Reserve. Mr. Principal Currie informed after, that all the fire-fighting apparatus worked most satisfactorily. As soon as the alarm was given in town (nearly three miles distant) the Volunteer Fire Brigade turned out and I proceeded as quickly as possible by automobile. In looking over the scene of the fire afterward with Mr. Principal Currie, I estimated the damages to be roughly speaking $200, not including clothing for the pupils, which is supplied by the Mission Societies. It is thought that a spark from a nearby chimney dropped into a bundle of clothes, which were on a high shelf, thus causing the fire.

Your obedient servant,

Chas. A. Cox.

In reply I beg to inform you that when a pupil is discharged and leaves the school at the beginning of the summer holidays, the school is not entitled to receive a grant for such holidays and also, when a new pupil enters the school immediately after the summer holidays, the school is not entitled to a grant for holidays in such case.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

The Presbyterian boarding schools at Ahousaht and Alberni having both been destroyed by fire early this summer, the question of what should be done to provide for continuing the education of the pupils of these schools has been brought to the attention of the Department by the Secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the Presbyterian Church on behalf of the W.M.S., who has submitted the following propositions:

1st. That the boarding school at Ahousaht be not rebuilt, but that the church be used as a day school, in charge of the resident missionary, for whom they will build a residence, with accommodation for a field matron, preferably a graduate nurse, and that the school should be opened in the autumn.

2nd. That at Alberni the government should purchase the portion of the lot on which the buildings stood, containing 16 acres, for $1600.00, or 10 acres for $1000.00. All the buildings connected with the school were not burned; those remaining intact are the barn, woodshed, chicken house, etc., valued at $3,000.00, which would have
have to be paid for in addition to the price of the land.

Having been previously told that funds were not available for the suggested amalgamation of these schools, the W. M. S. offer to loan the Department $20,000.00 with which to erect a new boarding school to accommodate 100 pupils, to be secured by a mortgage for $24,000.00, which includes the loan and the cost of ten acres of land and the buildings. The mortgage to be at 5% and to be repaid at the end of five years. The government is to own and maintain all the buildings and the W. M. S. to retain the stock and implements. The principal of the school is to be responsible for the care of the children for a year, or until the school is rebuilt, and the W. M. S. to provide, without delay, bedding and clothing for the children.

The current year's estimates provide for the maintenance of 35 pupils at Ahousaht and 50 at Alberni, 85 in all. The returns from these schools show that there was an average attendance at Ahousaht of 29 and 49.75 at Alberni. Both these schools were doing efficient work and it would be a pity to have it interrupted. If these propositions meet with the Department's approval, it would be to the advantage of the Indian children that the proposed amalgamation should be carried out.
The following recommendations are also submitted in regard to Ucluelet:

1st. Appoint a missionary to Ucluelet to minister to the white and Indian populations, his territory to extend from Kildonan to Bamfield.

2nd. Provide the missionary with a launch.

3rd. Have the house at Ucluelet serve as a manse for the missionary and use the school for church.

4th. Discontinue day school at Ucluelet. Transfer pupils to Alberni.

It would take about three times the amount the W.M.S. offer to loan the Department to erect a suitable building to accommodate 100 pupils and, if it is decided to rebuild, it would be well to secure the 16 acres for a school site. The W.M.S. own the adjoining 146 acres which they would retain for agricultural purposes to help maintain the school.

Mr. Inspector Cairns, in his report on the Ucluelet Day School, gives the number of children of school age as 24, with an average attendance of 16. If this school were closed, there should be no objection to allowing the Presbyterian Church to use the building for church purposes.

Dear Sir:

Since writing you May 29th, we have conferred with our representatives in British Columbia in regard to the site of the proposed Indian Boarding School on the Pacific coast.

Dr. Geo. Wilson, our District Superintendent in British Columbia, writes:

"Your letter received, regarding removal of Indian School from Alberni to Ucluelet. Now that a boarding school has been built at Ahousaht, this would place the two schools twenty miles apart, which is ridiculous. I certainly would not acquiesce in the removal from Alberni. It would be interesting to know the names of the petitioners. I think when these names are revealed, you will find them belonging to a class that has never helped the Indian."

Dr. Wilson states that if he were having an objection to Alberni at all, it would not be on the ground that the Indians contaminated the whites, but that the whites contaminated the Indians.

Dr. Clay, of Victoria, our Home Mission Convener for British Columbia, replied by wire and advised "proceeding at Alberni." In a letter I have from him since, he says:

"All the local ministers strongly support the stand taken in my wire to you."

I am enclosing copy of a letter from Mr. Currie, Principal of the Alberni School. In the first place, you will see that the city council, at the last meeting, decided to provide us with water and electric power at reasonable rates. This, I think, represents the attitude of the city council. They would not be willing to cheerfully grant these concessions if they were opposed to the erection of the building.
In the autumn of 1918, you sent us copy of a letter written you by A. J. Beck, City Clerk, and dated October 30th, 1918. At that time, the town of Alberni pleaded strongly for the erection of a new building. I judge the town is still anxious to have the school at Alberni.

In regard to the site, I think Mr. Currie has advanced many good reasons for retaining the school at Alberni. While it might make little difference to the Government where the school is built, it will make a very great difference to the Church, as we have to maintain the work afterwards. With our farm, stock, garden, fruit, etc., we can maintain the work at Alberni at a much less expense than we could at a point like Ucluelet.

The General Board of the Women's Missionary Society are unanimous in urging that the building be erected at Alberni.

I brought the matter before our Board a few days ago, at our meeting in Hamilton, and they instructed me to notify the Department that we want the building at Alberni. It seems to us that there are some interested parties behind the petition that was sent to you. I am sure the Indian Department will not be a party to sending the Indians back into the wilderness, either to advance the interests or satisfy the whim of anyone.

How would it be to have a representative of the Department sent to look over the ground? From what I can learn from private sources, I do not think that the matter should be decided by your Indian Agent. It is possible that his is the only opposition.

I am enclosing also copy of a letter that has been sent us by Mr. Neill, who states that he was Indian Agent in the district for ten years; also letter from H. A. Bain, representing the session of Alberni Presbyterian Church.

Dear Mr. Edmison:

Your letters of May 22nd and 29th, to hand and contents noted. In reply to the enquiry re water and electric light, I approached the city council at the last meeting and am pleased to report that they are very pleased to meet the wants of our new school as to both light and water at reasonable rates.

As to the letter of the 23rd, re the protest re rebuilding at Alberni, I can only say it will be a calamity if the Department allows itself to be swayed to building at Ucluelet instead. As to the statements in that letter, they are untrue:

1. As to the statement there are very few Indians at Alberni. There are more Indians at Alberni than in any other tribe on the Barclay Sound. This is a statement I can give figures to prove if necessary.

2. As to the statement that the town people desire the Indian Reserves at Alberni opened up for settlement - There is no desire on the town people's part for such. There may be individuals who might hope to profit by such a move. But the town has more area than there is any demand for. At the present moment, there are over 3000 parcels of land up for sale on account of delinquent taxes.

At the next meeting of the city council, I will approach the council, and I am sure they will send you a letter approving the rebuilding on the present site, which is not within the corporation, but about two miles from its centre.

The following facts, if considered, will amply justify the Department in rebuilding at Alberni. The present high cost of living necessitates large quantities of food to be produced by the school to supplement the maintenance grant. This is being done at Alberni and will gradually improve - whereas at Ucluelet there is no suitable area procurable. Here we grow vegetables, have a large stock which furnishes us with milk, butter, beef, pork, eggs, and have a good supply of apples, pears, plums, raspberries, strawberries, gooseberries, currants. It would take simply years and a mint of money to duplicate at Ucluelet. The farm aspect alone should decide the Department.

The transportation at Ucluelet will always be an adverse consideration. There are only three boats
a month from Ucluelet to Victoria. We have the same boat service plus the train service at Alberni. The up-keep of a good sized launch would have to be provided for at Ucluelet.

There is no doctor or hospital nearer than 55 miles from Ucluelet, while at Alberni they are always available night or day. This fact often means the sacrifice of life at the present time at Ucluelet.

The fuel proposition is also an important one. On our Alberni property there is an unlimited supply which will supply the school's needs for all time. At Ucluelet, coal would have to be bought as the timber there is practically all hemlock and cedar.

Our farm at Alberni is well stocked. We have a team of horses, a motor car, 16 head of stock, three of which are registered dairy shorthorns, 14 hogs, 150 chickens, with wagon, democrat, buggy, two ploughs, two harrows, mower, hay-rake, seeders, and all necessary farm tools including a stump puller; telephone with city water and electric light available.

To my mind Alberni is an ideal location. Even the drainage is all one would desire. I believe it will be a serious mistake to even think of changing the location of our school.

Yours truly,

(Signed) H. B. Currie.

Dear Dr. Clay:

Mr. Currie came in to see me this morning re the matter of the location of the Indian School.

I am surprised that there has been such action taken by anyone in this community. I may say such a protest is unwarranted and does not represent the opinion in any way of the community here.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Re. Alberni Boarding School.

The Alberni Boarding School building was totally destroyed by fire on the 2nd of June, 1917. Nearly all of the contents of the building were saved and the following outbuildings were uninjured, woodshed, barn, chicken house, etc. In the previous month the Ahousaht Boarding School was burnt down. Both these schools were owned by the Presbyterian Church and built on their land.

In July, 1917, the Rev. Mr. Edmison, Secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the Presbyterian Church, submitted a proposition for the rebuilding of the Alberni Boarding School. He suggested that the Government should put up a building large enough to accommodate one hundred pupils and that they should buy the site on which the old school was built containing sixteen acres at $100.00 an acre and also that the Government should pay $3,000 for the outbuildings.

The Women's Missionary Society offered to loan the Government $20,000.00 towards the erection of the building, in case funds were not available.

In the meantime they proposed to put up temporary buildings and carry on the school.

The Department was not prepared to accept this offer, nor undertake the rebuilding them.

When they asked for a building for 100 pupils at Alberni, it was their intention to abandon the boarding school at Ahousaht and conduct a day school there. After giving the day school a trial it was found that it was not a success.
success and the Board of Home Missions decided to rebuild the boarding school at this point. This building was under construction when Mr. Inspector Cairns visited Ahousaht in July of this year and he stated that it would be ready for occupation shortly.

With the erection of the Ahousaht Boarding School it would not be necessary to provide for the original number contemplated at Alberni and a building to accommodate about fifty or sixty pupils and staff should meet the requirements there.

If boarders are to be taken at Alberni a new building is urgently needed, as the temporary buildings now in use are said to have totally insufficient accommodation and to be practically devoid of sanitary arrangements. The City Clerk of Alberni forwarded a resolution from the City Council, dated October 29th of this year, in which they gave it as their opinion that grave risk to the whole community in the district is at all time being taken in allowing the present makeshift arrangement to exist.

If the Department is disposed to rebuild provision will have to be made in the Estimates for the purchase of the site and outbuildings and for a suitable building to accommodate sixty pupils and staff and, as the cost of material and labour is so high at present, $60,000.00 or $70,000.00 would be required.

The Indians of the West Coast Agency earn their livelihood chiefly by fishing and sealing off shore, and also by working about the canneries. Many migrate annually to the United States to assist with the hop-picking and others go to the Chilliwack District on the mainland for the same employment. The reserves in this agency are small and scattered and, as their families accompany the Indians on these migrations, day schools in this locality are impracticable.

There are about one hundred Indian children of school age in this agency who are recognized as Presbyterians and a boarding school at Alberni and one at Ahousaht would furnish educational facilities for about all the children of that faith.

Sir:

At a meeting of the Indians of the four tribes in this vicinity by a standing vote of those present, I was instructed to respectfully pray the Government in their behalf for the immediate removal of Mr. Curry as principal of the Alberni Industrial School.

After hearing the evidence and cross-examining ex-pupils, the chiefs, and leading men, I am convinced that it is in the interest of Christianity, morality and good characters of the Indians in general, that Mr. Curry be immediately removed.

The outstanding complaint which in itself alone is sufficient cause for his immediate removal, is that several girls during Mr. Curry's supervision of the said school, have become mothers originating from having sexual intercourse while attending said school.

The consequence is that illegitimate children are brought forth into this world, with its subsequent accompanying ill results, and disgrace brought on the parents who rely on the Government to prevent anything of the kind.

The facts are that when the condition of the girl becomes noticeable, she is discharged from the school, and her parents suffer the consequences. In some cases the boy has married the girl.

The Indians bring forth the argument that a school is no institution for the purpose of increasing the population.

Mr. Curry, from reliable information, conducts a stock raising business and he sells same every week to the public, and I venture to say that it is quite probable that there is misdemeanor among the pupils while he is busy engaged in the care of his stock and fowl.

Another reason for such occurrences, is that the children are compelled to remain in school until they reach the age of 18 years. If they were let out at the age of 15 or 16 years, such events would be perhaps less rampant.

It is further reported that Mr. Curry unmercifully whips the boys on their backs, which is objected to as well as Mr. Curry fighting and kicking the boys for the purpose of correction. It is further reported that Mr. Curry gets extremely mad at the slightest provocation, and whips or hits the boys with his fists, or chokes them.

The Indians say they have complained to Indian Agent Cox, and to Mr. Curry, with no result, and they will not rest in asking the Department for his removal until he is no longer connected with the school. The Indians if necessary will make complaints against Mr. Curry by oath.

I think it is my duty as a citizen of Canada and good Government, to report the above to you, that you may take steps deserving of the case.

I respectfully submit the recommendation that Mr. Curry be discharged forthwith.

Respectfully,

Andrew Paull,
North Vancouver, B. C., Corresponding Secretary, Allied Tribes of B. C.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your inquiry re trouble in this school, resulting from boy pupils attempting to, or having intercourse with girl pupils of this school, I may say that in the summer of 1920, Margaret Jackson, a girl of about 15 years, a girl who had passed her High School Entrance Examination, had intercourse with a pupil, Alfred Fred, and got in the family way. Also Annie Gallic, a girl of about 14, got in the family way at the same time by meeting Alfred Rasalma, a boy pupil who had also passed his High School Entrance Examination. As you are aware this matter was looked into at the time by yourself, reported to the Department at Ottawa, and four pupils were discharged. At that time it was shown that every reasonable precaution was taken by the Staff of this school. These are the only two girls who have ever gotten into trouble, in the family way, in this school, since I came here twelve and a half years ago. There was another girl, Beasie Shewish that was discharged in June 1916 for being pregnant, but she acknowledged that she got that way while at her home on the reserve. We never knew her to have anything to do with a boy while she was in the school.

Since we moved into the present new school in December 1920, two attempts by boy pupils have been made to get into the girl's dormitory. In March 1921, Norman James (Hugh) and Stevens Jackson broke an inch and a half wood ventilator railing bar loose and got on the laundry roof, crossed to the balcony roof at the rear of the building, but they were heard, and when they were hit to look about, they returned to their dormitory. For this I gave them a severe strapping, with their pants off, they then promised me they would never do so again. Stevens Jackson has been a splendid boy since, and I believe he is really trying to do right, but Norman James (Hugh) has given me constant trouble. On the 12 June, 1922, he and Edward Tatocotch again made the attempt and were caught right in the girls' dormitory about two o'clock in the morning. Norman had been in bed with Cecilis Dennis and Edward with Emma Fred. Neither of the girls are in the family way. As you will remember I phoned you at the time, and you came up to look into the matter, and when I showed you and Policeman Wood the method they used to gain entrance to the girls' room, it was hard for either of you to conceive that it was possible for one to travel such a course, for they had to break one and a half inch boards bars to get into the little boys' dormitory, then to climb in out of the screen window, travel about thirty feet on the outside front wall, about 25 feet from the ground; hang onto wire sills, then again bearing wire from screen windows getting into the girl's wash room, and again break like and half wooden bars to gain entrance to the girl's dormitory. It is for such behaviour that they wish to hold me responsible.

I contend every precaution was taken, but if there is fault anywhere it is in the construction of the building. I do say it is my firm belief that since the first day in this school, I have taken greater precaution to prevent such deplorable things happening, than either Government or Church Officials can reasonably expect.

I am writing you to make application for the transfer of the Alberni Boarding School into the Alberni Industrial School. I am taking this action on the ground that we are actually an Industrial School in everything but name and grant. And I herewith apply that the change take place with the beginning of the fiscal year (1 April 1925). At a recent meeting of the Presbytery of Victoria, this matter came up for discussion and I was instructed to take the matter up with you.

Your Department has provided good buildings for our School and I can assure you we are making the very best use of same. We specialize in farming and Stockraising also dairying. These all work in well as a part of the training and maintenance of the school. At present the new barn you erected for us is full of choice stock. We have 33 head of stock, Dairy Shorthorns, and 3 work horses. 9 of the above are for beef and will be killed for school use as needed at intervals of about ten days or two weeks according to size. We are constantly improving our herd, weeding out the inferior, replacing them with Registered Shorthorns of Record of Performance quality. At present I have on order a young bull out of a cow that produced over 9000 lbs. of milk last year testing 4.4 Butter fat. Also I am getting a young heifer from the same party, out of a cow that gave 10086 lbs milk in 365 days. This also gives us abundant milk which is I believe one of the very first considerations where a lot of growing children are being cared for. I have an excellent farmer and he takes much care in instructing the boys. They are receiving a practical training that many of them will make their living by. More and more as the fishing industry is being exploited, the Indian is turning to other occupations the principal of which is land clearing and farming. I have made provision to have our local shoemaker come to the school certain days each week to give instruction to the boys. This new training will begin as soon as the leather supplies and necessary equipment arrive. As soon as I have your assurance that you will sanction our school being classified as an Industrial School I will look about for a permanent man that can instruct in both shoe repairing and Carpentry the latter trade would be very useful to our Indians.

I notice that the schools in our immediate vicinity are mostly Industrial schools. First the Christie School on the West Coast has always been, at least for many years, an Industrial School now this school has never done the Industrial work carried on in the Alberni School. I maintain that our School has a 50% stronger claim to being classed as an Industrial School than the Christie School. Next I notice that the Kuper Island and Sechelt Schools are now both classed as Industrial Schools. The latter apparently...

THE PUBLIC BE SERVED

Interesting Aspects of Canadian Indians and Their Customs

VANCOUVER, B. C., July 28.—(C.Y. Service Inc.)—The mission school for Indians. That is to say, all children from the ages of 7 to 18 must attend the government mission schools. Those schools are conducted by the government in conjunction with the Presbyterian church. The government provides one hundred dollars per child per year, the church furnishes the educators, the local Indians supply the children employ.

Near Alberton, old town, there is one of these missions. It stands on a high hill overlooking the valley and the sea. Around the village of Sheshiah the Indian tribe is located. The village is chiefly of log huts in which no white man would ever dare to live. Some hundreds Indians reside, except while off on hunting and fishing expeditions.

The mission is maintained by the H. B. Curries, charmed by the beauty of the Indian service a great number of years. They have white women nurses and two nurses. More than ninety children were cared for this year. The mission itself is very well constructed and as comfortable as any private residence in the city. It is divided into two parts—one for the boys and one for the girls. Everything that is taught in public schools is taught here, including cooking, sewing, painting, dairying, wood-carving, lumbering, etc. The finished products from these schools is said to be exceptionally fine.

Canadians are encouraged to marry into the white or yellow races. All Indians who are engaged in business are declared illegitimate and the Indians involved suffers from his fellows. Yet, all Indians are encouraged to marry, and they graduate from school.

The Indian race up here, as in other parts of the country is diminishing fast. It is said that within twenty-five years will not be more than a thousand or so on the entire Vancouver Island. The Queen Charlotte islands, some miles north of here, contains 90,000 Indians. Twenty years ago, today there are barely 5000 there.

Many of the Indians here are very fine. Some are said to be more than 100 and one would not doubt it, were we to see them by chance while driving through the woods. Most of the older Indians are almost blind and are totally deaf.

At one of the Sprout lakes, on the side of a high rock, there are all sorts of Indian carvings. These represent many things, including a monstrous fish. For many years, so the legends say, Indians came and appeared only once in a while taking back below the water with him his toll of Indians who had not behaved themselves. There is an inevitable carving of the hero who slew the fish and was made chief of the tribe.

The junior classroom is crowded, there being about sixty pupils. Mr. Pitts recommends that a third teacher be engaged. This class to meet on the ground floor of the old classroom, which would accommodate about fifty pupils.

However, it must be kept in mind that the half-day system should be used. Indian pupils will not do good work and maintain their health and strength if they are kept indoors too much. Dear Mr. Neill:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, with reference to the scale of per capita grants at Indian residential schools in your constituency. At the present time the rates are as follows:

- Alberni - $160 for 90 pupils,
- Ahousaht - $165 for 40 pupils,
- Christie - $175 for 80 pupils.

Ahousaht receives a larger grant than Alberni, because the building is church-owned and the transportation costs are higher. Christie receives a higher rate for the same reasons, and further, because it has been classed as an industrial school.

I may say that, in the past few years, there have been adjustments in the amount of grant paid to Indian residential schools. It was felt that the old classification was no longer fair to the smaller schools, particularly those situated distant from markets. These adjustments have resulted in the $20 increase for Alberni, $25 for Ahousaht and $5 for Christie.

I believe it advisable to answer the last paragraph of your letter by a short resume of the rules governing the payment of per capita grant to Indian residential schools. Our Estimates and the Appropriation provide a per capita grant for a certain pupilage at each school. If the average attendance for any school is greater than the pupilage allowed because the school authorities have recruited to overstrength, the extra pupils are carried by the management without grant, until such time as the Department secures an increased appropriation. If extra pupils are present because the Department has requested the school to admit urgent cases, then super-numerary grant is allowed and payment is made on the basis of the actual average attendance. However, in no case do we allow or ask a school to admit more pupils than can be safely accommodated. The air space in dormitories and classrooms determines the limit of safety. The addition of compulsory attendance clauses in the Indian Act did not in any way affect the rules governing payments of grants. While the Department cannot adjust attendance, we are guided by the amount of accommodation available.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

At the outset, I wish to write a short resume of the rules governing the payment of per capita grant to Indian residential schools. Our Estimates and the Appropriation provide a per capita grant for a certain pupilage at each school. If the average attendance for any quarter is greater than the pupilage allowed because the school authorities have recruited to overstrength, the extra pupils are carried by the management without grant, until such time as the Department secures an increased appropriation. While the Department can compel attendance, we are guided by the amount of accommodation available. From time to time, the Department approves of the admission of applicants to Indian residential schools. In other words, their eligibility is determined; but, of course, their actual entry to the institution is contingent upon accommodation being available.

There is no provision made whereby any authority can excuse them from attending school because of lack of accommodation, nor for school authorities to decline to accept pupils for that reason.

Dear Sir:

Yours of Sept. 26th, No. 159-1-11, to hand re progress of manual training in Alberni Indian Residential School.

On the last of May '29, I wrote Commissioner Ditchburn through Agent Frost, asking what grant or assistance would be given by the Dept. to secure a properly qualified Manual training instructor.

Commissioner Ditchburn replied on June 1st, that he "would recommend a grant of $400 per annum for this work" but that I must not take this for granted until further advised. Since then I have heard no further instructions about it.

However, as it was necessary to secure a teacher for the year I advertised for a male teacher for the senior classroom, who could teach manual training. I secured Mr. Eli Robinson who has a B.S.A. and had taught manual training at Guelph, Ont. and Stonewall, Man.

Commissioner Ditchburn objected to the classes being held in the evening. As the pupils in the senior room are in for only the half day it meant that if the teacher of that room gave time during classroom hours to manual training, that it was going to break up the classroom work for the girls as well as the boys.

July 1st, I put in a requisition for some further necessary equipment for manual training and have had no word of it since.

Another difficulty has arisen that the Department sanctions the pupils leaving the school at 16 yrs. of age. I had persuaded the older boys to come back this year and three of them to take the entrance exams next June and all to take manual training. They had just got started at this work when a good run of salmon etc. convinced the parents that they needed them and the position of the Dept. as interpreted by the Indian Agent was that we could not keep them if they wanted to go. Consequently, four of the boys took advantage of it and I had to consent to their going. Those over 16 years who remain know that if the school does not suit them they can go. We have now on the roll only 13 boys over 12 years of age out of 52, and only 5 of these are over 14 years. Indian children at these ages are not developed like white children of the same age.

As a result I find myself with a farm and stock, a large steam heating plant burning wood, a large baking outfit and a large laundry equipment, and sewing instruction room making our clothing and with children going out at 16 years none of them able to do very much to help with this work. Besides the members of staff are tied up teaching and caring for 100 small children.

For reasons above mentioned, I have not had time nor heart to undertake the Manual training. The expense of having an instructor just for this work is beyond our revenue and out of all proportion to the result that could be accomplished with these small children.

I am reporting on the above matters to the Dept. and the Church offices and asking that some understanding be reached between the Dept. and the Church as to the management of this school.

Yours truly,

F. E. Pitts

General:
The headings of this report have been arranged to follow for the most part those of my report on this school made after my inspection in June, 1931. It is necessary to read the reports together to get a true view of conditions here.

I am glad to say that there has been a very great improvement in the cleanliness of the school and the work in the schoolrooms has improved a little. The two teachers engaged by the Principal last September were recommended from this office.

After inspecting their work, I told the Principal that I thought the teachers were doing very good work. He resented this and told me that he did not consider that the Department had any right to say whether he should or should not keep on the teachers for another year. I explained that all I had done was to inform him of my opinion of his teachers, which was very much my business, as if they had not been satisfactory changes would have had to be made.

I consider that Mr. Pitts' administration of the school is very weak. It will be seen again and again through this report that the general supervision of the school is below the average. I have warned the Reverend gentleman that had it not been that the school was much cleaner this year, I should have recommended that he be asked to resign. He may make up his mind to properly look after his school, now that he understands that while I or any other official of the Department is perfectly prepared to help in any way possible poor administration which endangers the lives of the Indian children will not be tolerated. I much desire however that the Principal be permitted to continue here till I have an opportunity of again inspecting this school this Fall. I do consider that he should receive any warning that the Department considers necessary in order that conditions may be greatly improved.

Recommendation:

I wish to draw the attention of the Department to the fact that the Manual Training Grant seems to have been spent in a very poor manner. No worthwhile Manual Training has been done in this school so far this year. I also wish to point out that the salaries paid as under seem to me to be excessive:

Dear Sir:

I have before me your letters 159-1-5 July 8, 1931, and 159-1-1 July 18, 1932, both relating to Inspector Barry's report on Alberni Indian Residential School. In both these letters you seem to have gathered from the Inspector's report that we run a dirty school and have a slovenly way of doing things.

My reason for asking in letter of June 24th for a copy of Inspector Barry's report was due to the following remarks he made in my office here. On April 26, 1932, after inspecting the classrooms, residence, outbuildings and farm, apparently well satisfied with everything, he came with me into the office to get some statement of staff salaries, finances, etc. I remarked that I expected he would be remaining two days for the inspection, when he burst out in the most vindictive manner with the following remarks. "I came here intending to ask for your retirement from the principalship of this school. It has improved a little since my last visit. You have the dirtiest school in B.C. If the Roman Catholic sisters visited your school they would be shocked at the condition of it. You were not nice to me when I came for inspection. You have not a nice manner anyway. You quarrel with your staff. I have gone to the trouble to find out how you get along and have a stack of correspondence so high, (indicating about 2 inches). You tried to get me out of my job. It was too stupid of you to say anything against an officer of the Department. You can do what you like. I am strong enough now with the Dept. You can't put me out." You were not invited to attend the meeting to arrange for the inter Indian school sports. You are not interested in sports." Then referring to staff and salaries as he went out on the steps said in a loud voice that could be heard by the older Indian girls on the playground, Mr. Clark, B.C. boiler inspector and Mr. Nightingale, Indian Agent's assistant, who were in a car waiting for him, "Three of your family are getting Three Thousand Dollars salary here. You will have to carry on the school properly whether you get these salaries or not." I called him back into the office to prevent being heard by children and explained that my salary and Mrs. Pitts' salary was fixed by the Women's Mission Board in Toronto.

All of the foregoing remarks were made by Inspector Barry in my office in less than five minutes. I probably should add by way of explanation that I have had no personal acquaintance or connection whatsoever with Inspector Barry outside of his inspection of the school. His attitude toward me has arisen out of his first report on the school which was sent through your Department to the church offices in Toronto and was sent on to me for explanation and reply. I replied to the church offices and I presume my reply was sent back through your offices to Inspector Barry.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6431, File 877-1, part 2)
Mr. Barry went directly from here to the Indian Agent's office and made the same railing attack upon me there to the Agent in the presence of his assistant, Mr. Lightningale, that the school was dirty and that I was paying Three Thousand dollars in salary to my own family. If you want to know what reception his remarks got there ask Indian Agent Frost.

It is not easy to submit quietly to criticism of being dirty or selfishly dishonest in the matter of salaries.

In reply re school being dirty. The morning after Inspector Barry's remarks, I had Indian Agent Frost make a thorough inspection of the school, that he might officially answer any enquiry from your Department. I also had Miss Brodie, who has been senior teacher in Cecelia Jeffirey and Ahousant schools for the last 20 years go all over the school and I had Rev. Dr. S.S. Osterhout of Vancouver, Superintendent of Missions for the United Church go over all the residences and building. Any of these will answer questions directly to the Department concerning the cleanliness of the school.

Rev. Principal & Mrs. Raley of Cequaleetza Indian School visited us and remarked as they went through the whole building, "I don't see how you can keep an Indian School so clean." Rev. Dr. Osterhout from the pulpit in Alberni, referred to the school as a "beautiful home so beautifully kept by Mr. & Mrs. Pitts." Mr. Travers and Mr. Shepherd, inspectors of the B.C. government, after going through the dormitories and whole residence said to each other "everything is as clean as a new pin." All the visitors who go through the school speak in the same way of the cleanliness of it. The children too are so clean in their work that we have no hesitancy in having them help with preparing food and serving it for our table as well as their own.

As to management. We have no trouble with discipline of the children. Each member of staff is responsible for the children in their charge and I keep a close oversight of all the departments. We are right against an Indian village, yet we have no trouble with the Indians. The 115 children I consider a very fine lot of workers for their ages in all branches of household and farm work. Our relation to children and parents is most cordial.

As for technical manual training, i.e. with the carpenter tools, I am not at all satisfied with what we have accomplished, but it has been through no lack of interest or effort on my part. I hope we are in a way now to do better.

To answer his remark about my quarrelling with my staff, I wish to say that we all live in the building and have our meals together. So far as I am aware there has been no word of quarrel by myself or family with any other member of staff. It is true I have often found it necessary to point out their duties and errors and have dismissed a number because I was not satisfied with them. No one has left because dissatisfied with my treatment or management. Three or four whom I have dismissed probably have furnished Inspector Barry with the "stack of correspondence" he speaks of.

I did not know that I had been slighted in being left out of the Inter-Indian School sports till told of it by Inspector Barry. When he spoke of it as he did I had reason to think that he knew why. At any
I was not prepared to take the time or money to take a number of the children so far away.

To say that I am not interested in sports is another thing. Our basketball teams compete with the white boys in High School public schools and town. In the last two years have held the Junior League cup against all of these. Our boys have football and baseball teams and compete credibly with white boys in all competitions at celebrations. I engaged one of the best basketball players in the country to coach them, supply them with equipment, arrange the games, am a member of the town Athletic committee, etc., etc.

Re classroom work. Out of 200 applicants I engaged the two teachers recommended by Inspector Barry largely on his recommendation. They were inexperienced but I think did good work.

If Inspector Barry's criticism of my management has to do with the fact of my salary and that of my wife and daughter, I have only to say that we were all college trained for this work and have had considerable successful experience in it. If our salaries are too high it is the church and not the Department that is responsible for paying them. Twice this year since we knew of the 10% cut in the per capita grant we have offered to take a reduction in our salaries and the Women's Dominion Board have declined.

Inspector Barry overstepped not only his duties but his business when he attacked me in this way and when he discussed these things within the hearing of the school children are outsiders, he overstepped all propriety. And when he left me with the remark that we would be able to work together now and then went straight to the Indian Agent's office and in the same vindictive mood attacked me again behind my back he forfeited all claim to my respect or confidence.

Mrs. Pitts and I have worked for over thirty years in the church, ten and a half of which we have lived in residence with Indian children and worked in the school. We have asked no personal favors from either the Church or Department but have hoped to win from the Church and Department esteem and confidence in our work. Anyone who destroys that robs us of what we have held most dear. This is why I have been driven to state these unpleasant facts.

Your obedient servant,

H. E. Pitts

WEST COAST AGENCY INSPECTION REPORT NO.5.

6. SCHOOLS:

I visited the Alberni Residential School. There were 122 children in school at the time of my visit. I visited the class rooms of Grades 5, 6 and 8, and they appeared to be working well, under efficient teachers. It struck me, however, that some of those in Grade 8, were too old to be at school.

The manual training in this school seems very good, though it would be a great help, and of great use to the Indians if some training in boat building was given them, as after all, most of them will have to earn their livings as fishermen when they grow up, and they should be able to build and repair boats and engines.

I found everything in the dormitories and other parts of the school clean and tidy.

I also visited the kitchen which was in good order, and I found that the children were to have for supper, vegetable soup, bread and butter and jam, and that there was plenty of milk for everybody at all times.

Yours very truly,

(Geo. S. Pragnell)
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:

We are anxious to secure the fullest possible information that can be supplied us, in respect to the re-building of the Alberni Residential School.

We feel that, before a definite decision is reached, a complete survey of the territory adjacent to the Alberni School site and the Ahousaht Residential School should be undertaken by Inspector Barry, in cooperation with the Indian Agent. We should have before us an up to date census of the school population and a rough sketch or map of the district, indicating the distances between the Indian homes and the school. Information should also be supplied in respect to the permanency of the Indian population and the approximate number of pupils whose parents are likely to move from place to place during the school year.

While no definite decision has been reached by the Department, there is a strong feeling here that there should be a consolidation of the Ahousaht and Alberni Residential Schools and that this can best be achieved by building an improved day school on the Alberni site. We have in mind a day school with approximately four or five rooms, with a basement, so constructed that it could be utilized profitably for vocational instruction (elementary domestic science, carpentry work, boat building, etc.) To this main building could be added dormitory accommodation for approximately 50 or 60 pupils. This proposal, if adopted, would mean that the majority of the pupils would attend school during the day and return to their homes at the close of each school day. Dear Sir,

Arising out of your letter of Feb. 26th, I take the liberty of writing you on the question of policy for the rebuilding of Alberni Indian Residential School.

I have before me a letter from Mr. A. W. Neil, M.P. for Alberni and also a letter from the United Church offices in Toronto, both of which say that the suggestion of your Department is to replace the Alberni Residential school with a day school also the Ahousaht Residential school with a day school and to build a residential school at Ucluelet.

I have discussed these suggestions with the Indian parents, past Indian agents, Boards of Trade and residents of these communities. I have also discussed the suggestion with the Presbytery of Victoria, in session, which includes all the United Church on Vancouver Island, and also the Conference of British Columbia in session, which includes all the United Church in British Columbia. All are unanimously agreed that the residential school should be built at Alberni on the old site; that the Ucluelet residential school would be more expensive to build; would be less convenient for both children and staff; would take 20 years to develop grounds and site anywhere equal to the present site; would require the Department to own their water supply, which is questionable whether it is possible at all. It would also require sufficient fire protection and hospital accommodation. Any repairs to electric plant, plumbing, carpenter work, etc. would not be easily available and more expensive. Part time teachers in the manual training in carpenter work, boat building, diesel engineering and electric work are always available in these towns and would not be available at Ucluelet.

Two things are fundamental in training the Indian children. The first is a moral stamina that will make them dependable; the second is association with the people with whom they are to work and live when they get out of school. Without these all the book work will amount to nothing.

The residential schools have accomplished most by bringing the children from different reserves, different bands, different tribes together from the age of 7 to 18, so that now the relationship of these bands are friendly toward each other and have developed common ideals.
After 15½ years as principal of an Indian Residential school, during all of which time I and my family lived in the school with the children, (5½ years on the prairie, 10 years here) I am strongly convinced that by the return to the day schools on the reserves, the Department is throwing away a great deal of the effort and expense that has been put forth by the residential schools during the 25 years of their existence. Especially is this true of the schools on the west coast of Vancouver Island.

In an inventory to Indian Agent Ashbridge I have conservatively estimated the value of the site, building, water and light connections, etc. at $21,500.00, yet worth a small fraction of that for any other purpose than a school.

I am sure that if you personally looked over the ground you would agree with me that the residential school at Ucluelet instead of Alberni is ridiculous.

I am not writing this from personal reasons. I have already resigned and my resignation has been accepted both by the Br. Columbia conference and the Toronto Board. I am still looking after the farm and stock and Department property until the matter is decided as to whether or not it is to be used as a residential school.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

I take this opportunity of writing you direct about three pupils from this school who have been attending high school in Port Alberni and who resided in the residential school here until it was burned. From February till June they resided at their homes and attended school regularly and did exceedingly well at their studies.

Eddie Klutei and Willie Tatoosh have been in high school three years. They resided at the school and we received the usual grant for them. Your department paid the high school fees in addition to the grant—viz. $5.00 each per month.

I enclose a letter from the principal of the high school stating his opinion of these two boys and their ability as students. I heartily endorse all that he has said. These boys are all-round students. They are popular with the other students—180 in the school. They are leaders in sports and are as well advanced in music as nearly any of the pupils in the school. The whole high school staff are always enthusiastic about their deportment and conduct.

Eddie Klutei has led his class in nearly all the examinations since going into high school and Willie Tatoosh has been about fifth in a class of from 45 to 60. They have completed Grade XI and part of Grade XII or senior matriculation. They are anxious to continue in school this year but will not be able to pay the fees and provide books, clothing and board at home.

It would seem a shame that after spending so much on these boys' education that they should be thrown out after having done so well and having worked so faithfully all these years.

The third boy, Charlie Klutei, is younger-aged 14—and has been in high school only one year. He is more clever than either of the others but I am not going to urge his case lest it prove detrimental to the other two.

I hope you may see your way clear to give assistance to these boys as has been done in the past. I write you direct because Agent Ashbridge is not very favorable to higher education for the Indians. I always wrote directly to Mr. Sutherland about them.

I still believe in the Indians and that Alberni School was doing good work with them up till the fire—and that our school occupied an enviable place among Indian schools.

I have confidence in you and your ability to manage the situation re the rebuilding the residential school.

I must confess that, whoever was to blame, I think the way the department dropped us and cut off all grants and assistance the day the school burned, leaving us to pay the debts, provide for the staff, and clothing for a number of the children, look after the property etc., was, to say the least, utterly unfair, and would not have been done by any commercial organization in Canada.

Yours Respectfully,

F. E. Pitts
Port Alberni, B.C.
Sept. 7, 1937.

Dear Mr. Pitts:

I am informed that there seems to be some possibility of the three Indian boys not being able to continue at school.

In my opinion, if such should happen, it would be nothing short of a tragedy. I have been teaching school here for ten years now, and have seen various types of students in the district. Nevertheless I can unhesitatingly state that both Eddie and Willie are by far the most brilliant all-round pupils I have encountered. Should they continue I feel morally certain that either will have an excellent chance for the provincial scholarship, and aside from personal wishes in the matter, it would be a shame if these two boys, who are probably the first Indians ever to have the opportunity of leading the province, should be deprived of the chance.

I feel as certain as anyone can be of anything in this life that one of them, if not both, will at least win a bursary if allowed to continue to University.

My own opinions may seem rather strong, but I feel sure that if you consult any member of my staff you will find that my views are shared by every teacher here. Nothing that I could say in praise of either of these boys would, in my opinion, be adequate. I hope and trust that you will use every means within your power to have them enabled to complete High School.

I am very truly yours,

Eric J. Dunn

DEPUTY MINISTER,

I have, for acknowledgment, Mr. Pratt's memorandum of June 7th and also letter received by him from Mr. A. W. Neill, M.P., attached thereto.

Mr. Neill, in this letter, states that the departmental per capita grant to the Alberni Residential School was stopped immediately following the receipt of a report of the destruction of the school by fire. This statement is correct, and the action taken was in strict conformity with the Treasury Board and departmental regulations governing the payment of per capita grants. I know of no authority by which these per capita grants could be continued, other than by the introduction of a special estimate based on compassionate considerations and regularly voted by Parliament.

The action taken by the Department at Alberni has been discussed on at least two occasions with Dr. Corhrane and Dr. Dorey, representatives of the United Church. At no time has either of these representatives expressed the opinion that the action taken was in any sense unfair or irregular. The representatives of the Church were aware, of course, that the Department was called upon to make provision for a large number of the pupils who had been until then in attendance at Alberni. Eight of these were sent to the United Church residential school at Ahousaht and 17 to the day school at Ucluelet.

I understand that Mr. Neill subsequently expressed himself as favorable to the suggested amalgamation of the Ahousaht and Alberni pupilage into one school.

The question of where the new school should be built was exhaustively gone into and much time was devoted to an examination from many angles of the suitability or otherwise of the locations suggested. After prolonged consideration of all the circumstances involved, I concluded that the school should be built at Alberni and I have so recommended.
