Dear Sir:

At your request I have given some considerable thought to the question of the establishment of a new Indian Residential School in the West Coast Agency, and because of differences of opinion both in Departmental and Church circles, regarding the location of the proposed school, careful investigations have been made of the numerous sites suggested as suitable, particular attention being given to Ucluelet, Sechelt, Pachena Bay and Alberni.

I think it would be of value to look at the need for a new Indian Residential School apart from its actual location and to examine the general aspect of the Indian educational situation on the West Coast.

The present Residential School at Ahousaht can only be used as such for a very limited time, as it is in need of extensive repairs. The Ahousaht School building has been condemned on account of deterioration, lack of adequate water supply, lack of sanitary arrangements and excessive fire hazard.

The average pupilage at the Alberni Residential School was 135, and Ahousaht 50. Inspector Barry reports that there are at Ahousaht in the neighbourhood of thirty children for whom Residential School care ought to be provided, and at points along the coast line of Barclay Sound some twenty children who might well be accommodated in a residential school on the grounds of loss of one or both parents or whose home conditions are for some reason unsatisfactory. It would appear therefore that in this particular section that the total number of children for whom residential school accommodation must be provided is not in excess of 60.

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Superintendent of Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

There
There remains that large group of children at various points along the coast who have fairly good homes but who must be provided with Residential School accommodation in the absence of available Indian Day Schools.

The combined average pupilage of Ahousaht and Alberni was 185, and excluding from this 25 pupils lately attending Alberni Residential School now diverted to Coqualeetza, and about 15 receiving Residential School training who should attend the Indian Day School at Ucluelet, there would be available 145 pupils from Alberni, Sarita, Ahousaht, Clo-oose, Port Renfrew and other West Coast Reserves for Residential school attendance, entirely insufficient to justify the operation and maintenance of two protestant Indian Residential Schools for that section of Vancouver Island. The circumstances are such that there is every justification for the amalgamation of the residential school pupilage of Ahousaht and Alberni in one school. In passing it probably would be as well to mention that Ahousaht is a protestant Indian village surrounded by Roman Catholic Indian communities.

It is readily admitted that the Residential School continues to be an important factor in fitting the Indians for greater independence in both industrial and domestic spheres, but as Indian home conditions improve, as they are improving, and Indian parents more fully recognize and accept responsibility for the upbringing of their children in their own homes, it is reasonable to expect that the day school system will to an ever increasing extent, supersede the Residential School system as a medium of Indian Education. It is particularly desirable that the graduates of Indian Residential Schools be given more opportunity of accepting responsibility for the upbringing of their children and not get into the way of depending unnecessarily on governmental care and support of them.

Children of Indian Day Schools are not out of touch with their homes and parents to the same extent as the children of the Residential Schools and take home with them from day to day something or what they have learned, and unlike the Residential School pupil, they are in a much better position to learn something of the skills of their parents, Hunting, Trapping, Fishing, etc. While the Residential School continues to be necessary for the special cases, orphans, pupils from poor homes, etc., the Day School is much closer to the homes of the Indians.
The children remain within the family circle. The well trained teacher, particularly a married one, either man or woman, who lives on or near the Indian village and daily comes in contact with the Indian people, is of the very greatest help to the children and their parents.

Married men as teachers in our Day Schools whose wives are either trained nurses, or who can act as practical nurses, especially in the larger villages, are what we require.

Desirable as I consider the extension of the Day School system to be, I am not satisfied that the general condition of homes and occupation on the Reserves, of the protestant Indians of the West Coast, is such as to make the day school system feasible at this time.

After much careful thought I have concluded that it would be safer and good policy to build a new Protestant Residential School in the West Coast Agency. The building should be of good quality brick, and the general type required would be that of the Kuper Island Residential School with the wings extended to the rear. The school should be large enough to take one hundred and fifty pupils, about seventy-five in the Boys' side and the same number on the Girls' side. The wash-rooms should open off the dormitories and not be in the basement as at Lytton and Alert Bay. There should be four modern classrooms with two Vocational Rooms and a large hall to accommodate the entire pupilage, which could be used for lectures, entertainments, etc., in addition.

The drainage system should be by six or eight inch pipes, as four inch pipes have been found to clog up and frequently require cleaning out and the cause of much inconvenience and expense.

There must be an engine workshop and manual training shop and space to build boats.

The heating should be by hot water operated by automatic oil burner or automatic coal stoker.

At least four fire escapes reaching to the ground should be provided.

The ....
The foregoing together with the existing arrangements in the more modern of our Residential Schools should guide the general planning of the proposed new school.

Coastal points such as Ucluelet, Sechelt and Pachena Bay have been suggested as more suitable for the new school than Alberni but after examining all the information I could obtain, I am satisfied that the preponderance of argument is in favor of Alberni.

I respectfully submit the following recommendations to best meet the educational requirements of the Protestant Indian pupilage of the West Coast Agency:

(1) That a new Residential School to accommodate 150 pupils be built on the Departmentally owned property at Alberni and that in such construction the needs of the actual Coast Indian be kept in mind and provision made for greatly extended vocational training along lines which might be of use to the pupils on graduation.

(2) That Ahousaht Residential School be abandoned as such, and such of its pupils as should attend a Residential school, be absorbed by the new Alberni Residential School.

(3) That a new one room Indian Day School to accommodate 20 to 30 pupils be built at Ahousaht for those pupils now attending the Residential School who could, because of satisfactory home conditions, attend a day school.

The report on the School survey of the West Coast Agency by Capt. G. H. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia, in accordance with Departmental instructions dated March 9th, 1937, file 159-1-5, will be forwarded under separate cover at an early date.

Dear Mr. Pitts:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 5th instant and to state by way of comment that I am today communicating with the Indian Agent at Alberni, in the hope that arrangements can be made immediately to have the two boys on whose behalf you have written proceed with their high school studies.

In view of the fact that the high school has been open and in operation for a period of 6 weeks, it might be well to advise Charlie Klutesi to remain out of school for this year, on the understanding that his case can be reviewed at the opening of the academic year 1938-39.

I note, in the last paragraph of your letter, your reference to the destruction of the Alberni Residential School by fire and your comments thereon. I may state by way of explanation that the destruction of the Alberni School, the payment of government grants, the care of the children and a number of other matters were very carefully reviewed by the officials of the Department, immediately following the fire.

The law and regulation governing the administration of residential schools do not permit the payment of per capita or other grants to any schools other than those actually in operation. It is my understanding that this law has been in force ever since residential schools were established. Any financial assistance, therefore, necessary to compensate the staff, could only be allowed by a special appropriation voted by Parliament on compassionate grounds. Unfortunately, the fire at Alberni was

not an isolated case. Two residential schools have been destroyed by fire since I entered the Department in December last.

I find it difficult to understand your reference to clothing for the children. Not only did we make provision for the purchase of clothing necessary for the children, but we also secured from the Indian Agent and the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia reports on the best ways and means of providing day school accommodation for at least a number of the pupils. On reviewing the case at this date I cannot think of anything we could have done other than what we did do without the special authority of Parliament.

It has occurred to me that the question of governmental assistance to residential schools where buildings are destroyed by fire is one that might very well be discussed with the Government by the representatives of the churches responsible for the operation of residential schools. I have learned from experience, however, that a great many matters such as this are seldom given any attention until fire takes place or some other disaster occurs, and, at that time it is usually discovered that the law governing such institutions is not sufficiently flexible to meet the demands created by the emergency. The result is that about all the officials are in a position to do is to express sympathy. I am not at the moment blaming anyone particularly for this condition. I am simply expressing the thoughts that have occurred to me since the receipt of your communication.

Yours very sincerely,

The Hitinah Band are located near Clo-cose 34 miles south of Ucluelet.

The distance to Port Alberni by water is about 64 miles from Clo-cose. Some of the children from this Reserve go to Coqualeetza, and I would recommend that when establishing the new Residential School accommodate these pupils. The conditions at Coqualeetza are so different to those on the West Coast that the farming etc. learned at Coqualeetza will be of no use here.

It is in my opinion a very great mistake to take the Indian children out of their own environment and train them in a mode of life which they will certainly never follow. There must be some, even remote, connection between the life in the Indian Residential School and the future life on the Indian Reserve, if the children are to make any use of the training given.

There are about 37 children of school age on the Reserves near Clo-cose, with some 24 under school age. Had this place been easier to get to, and it been possible to keep all the children here, a Day School might have been established. In addition to some of the pupils being taken to Coqualeetza, no doubt for reasons satisfactory to the Indian Affairs Branch, others in the past were taught at the local Provincial Day School, I am informed.

General Remarks:

1. The Indians who remain throughout the year in their own villages are for the most part the more destitute members of the population.

2. The children of the above Indians could attend the day school located in the village, but for other reasons, home conditions, etc., are more often permitted to attend the Indian Residential Schools.

3. The Indians with facilities to fish, boats and other equipment, are those best able to support their children under the usual day school system. These Indians are however away from their own villages for some part of each school year while engaged in the usual seasonal occupational migrations. Numbers are absent for a considerable part of the year.

4. While all the better class Indians are not away from their villages for the whole of the school year, number are so absent from September to October while engaged in hop picking, from November to March attending to trap lines, and in May and June berry picking. From June to August few are in the villages. There is a general move to the fishing grounds early in June, and Indian Day Schools along the coast of B.C. are often closed about the middle of that month for want of pupils.

5. At Ahousaht the whole of the Indians are only in the village from November to February, if then.

6. In the West Coast Agency it may be taken for granted that at least seventy five per cent of the Indian parents do move from their own villages during some part of each school year.

7. Should children from the same village be received as resident pupils and as day pupils in a combined Residential and Day School located in or near a village, there would be constant complaint from the parents, in that some of the children of the local Band were receiving more clothes and food than others.

8. It is highly doubtful that the type of combined Residential and Day School mentioned in the letter from the Indian Affairs Branch under date of March 8th and No. 1591-5 would prove a success in any part of British Columbia where the population is so constantly on the move.

9. Indians in British Columbia are certain to object when another family has been given something which they have not themselves received at the same time. Day school children attending any sort of combined Day and Residential School would most certainly have to be given a substantial noon meal at the school. I am aware that this is not being done in North Vancouver, but it would certainly be best here on the West Coast.
General Remarks Continued:

10. Day pupils attending a combined Residential and Day School would need regular supervised baths in the school, and suitable school clothes. There would need to be as little difference as possible in the treatment of the day and residential pupils. A simple school uniform, as used in the B.C. private schools should be provided for day and residential pupils.

11. A Residential School takes children away from objectionable home conditions which are fairly common on the West Coast. The home conditions at Ucluelet are in advance of those in other villages. The Day School there is a success, and few if any of the Ucluelet children should be permitted to attend an ordinary Indian Residential School, as many have been attending the Alberni Indian Residential School in the past.

12. There are no lands in Indian villages on the West Coast suitable for farming and few gardens are even possible. The training of boys at an Indian Residential School in farming is a complete waste of effort. An Indian Residential School on the West Coast should eliminate farming. A large garden should be cultivated largely to provide fresh vegetables.

13. The children at present residing in Residential Schools for Indians in the villages quite generally say they have been educated. The opposition of parents is not the actual reason why they have been at school. It is due to negative methods of learning at school, and is not due to the lack of interest shown by the care of the parents.

14. Of the children attending school about half are of school age. A total of 100 pupils will attend the new school while the building is completed. It should be located near the central point along the coast.

15. There are sufficient children in the village of Ahousant to justify the establishment of a new Day School as part of the while project.
General Remarks Continued.

16. The Indian parents at Port Renfrew, Sarita (Banfield) and Clooose shown on the attached map would certainly object to send their children to a Residential School at Ahousaht owing to tribal animosity.

17. The Indian Residential School at Ahousaht is in very bad repair as far as the main building is concerned. The class rooms are very small and the older one is so constructed that the water floods over the floor in times of heavy rain. About one quarter of the floor space was a great pool of water while I was inspecting there. No building with the exception of the new residence is worth retention at Ahousaht, and the general site is a particularly poor one for a Residential School.

Recommendations:

It is recommended that a new Indian Day School of one room on the general plan of the Campbell River Indian Day School but somewhat larger be built at Ahousaht Indian Village. The school should be able to accommodate up to 35 pupils. It should be located on the high piece of rocky land in front of the Indian Village at Ahousaht. This site is on the sea, and has large village greens on each side, a path at the rear or village side, and the sea in front; and is an excellent site. It is of course on Indian Reserve, but it is likely that the Indians would like to have a new Day School here in their village.

No teacher accommodation should be provided in this proposed one-room school. The teacher should be a girl for preference, and live with the Missionary, possibly in the new residence built by the Department on the Woman's Missionary property just over a half mile from the Ahousaht village, and adjoining the present Ahousaht Indian Residential School. There is sufficient new lumber at the Ahousaht Residential School to provide a fine Day School in the village and the present classrooms (two) at the Residential School would provide desks and Blackboards, etc. These class rooms are too poor to be worth preserving. The main Ahousaht School Building is in such a poor state of repair that it will not last much longer than the time before or to which must elapse before a new Residential School can be constructed. The present Ahousaht Residential School site is hopeless for such a school from every point of view.

An improved Day School of four or five rooms with a basement and other accommodation as suggested in the letter from the Secretary of the Indian Affairs Branch dated March 9, 1937 is in my opinion quite impracticable either at Alberni, Ahousaht, or elsewhere on the British Columbia coast.

The whole of the above is submitted with respect and in the hope that my recommendations will be of assistance to the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch at Ottawa.

31st January, 1938.
Gerald H. Barry
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
Vancouver, B.C.

General Remarks:

1. The Indians who remain throughout the year in their own villages are for the most part the more destitute members of the population.

2. The children of the above Indians could attend the day school located in the village, but for other reasons, home conditions, etc., are more often permitted to attend the Indian Residential Schools.

3. The Indians with facilities to fish, boats and other equipment, are those best able to support their children under the usual day school system. These Indians are however away from their own villages for some part of each school year while engaged in the usual seasonal occupational migrations. Numbers are absent for a considerable part of the year.

4. While all the better class Indians are not away from their villages for the whole of the school year, number are so absent from September to October while engaged in hop picking, from November to March attending to trap lines, and in May and June berry picking. From June to August few are in the villages. There is a general move to the fishing grounds early in June, and Indian Day Schools along the coast of B.C. are often closed about the middle of that month for want of pupils.

5. At Ahousaht the whole of the Indians are only in the village from November to February, if then.

6. In the West Coast Agency it may be taken for granted that at least seventy five per cent of the Indian parents do move from their own villages during some part of each school year.

7. Should children from the same village be received as resident pupils and as day pupils in a combined Residential and Day School located in or near a village, there would be constant complaint from the parents, in that some of the children of the local Band were receiving more clothes and food than others.

8. It is highly doubtful that the type of combined Residential and Day School mentioned in the letter from the Indian Affairs Branch under date of March 9th and No. 159-1-5 would prove a success in any part of British Columbia where the population is so constantly on the move.

9. Indians in British Columbia are certain to object when another family has been given something which they have not themselves received at the same time. Day school children attending any sort of combined Day and Residential School would most certainly have to be given a substantial Noon meal at the school. I am aware that this is not being done in North Vancouver, but it would certainly be best here on the West Coast.
General Remarks Continued:

10. Day pupils attending a combined Residential and Day School would need regular supervised baths in the school, and suitable school clothes. There would need to be as little difference as possible in the treatment of the day and residential pupils. A simple school uniform, as used in the B.C. private schools should be provided for day and residential pupils.

11. A Residential School takes children away from objectionable home conditions which are fairly common on the West Coast. The home conditions at Ucluelet are in advance of those in other villages. The Day School there is a success, and few if any of the Ucluelet children should be permitted to attend an ordinary Indian Residential School, as many have been attending the Alberni Indian Residential School in the past.

12. There are no lands in Indian villages on the West Coast suitable for farming and few gardens are even possible. The training of boys at an Indian Residential School in farming is a complete waste of effort. Any new Indian Residential School on the West Coast should eliminate farming entirely. A large garden should be cultivated largely to provide fresh vegetables.

13. The children at present returning from Residential Schools find conditions in the villages quite different to those they have been accustomed to in school. The opposition of the older Indians, not the small parents of whom many have been at Residential School, tends to negative many of the high ideals learned at school. The failure here is not due to the school system as much as to the lack of a follow up system in the care of the young graduates.

14. Of the children at present attending Ahousaht Indian Residential School a total of 10 Boys and 12 Girls might well attend a Day School in the village while the remaining 16 Boys and 16 Girls should be in Residential School at some central point along the West Coast.

15. There are sufficient children in the village of ahousaht to make the establishment of a new Day School there a worthwhile project.
General Remarks Continued.

16. The Indian parents at Port Renfrew, Sarita (Banfield) and Clooose shown on the attached map would certainly object to send their children to a Residential School at Ahousaht owing to tribal animosity.

17. The Indian Residential School at Ahousaht is in very bad repair as far as the main building is concerned. The class rooms are very small and the older one is so constructed that the water floods over the floor in times of heavy rain. About one quarter of the floor space was a great pool of water while I was visiting there. No building with the exception of the new residence is worth retention at Ahousaht, and the general site is a particularly poor one for a Residential School.

Recommendations:

It is recommended that a new Indian Day School of one room on the general plan of the Campbell River Indian Day School but somewhat larger be built at Ahousaht Indian Village. This School should be able to accommodate up to 35 pupils. It should be located on the high piece of rocky land in front of the Indian Village at Ahousaht. This site is on the sea, and has large village greens on each side, a path at the rear or village side, and the sea in front, and is an excellent site. It is of course on Indian Reserve, but it is likely that the Indians would like to have a new Day School here in their village.

No teacher accommodation should be provided in this proposed one room school. The teacher should be a girl for preference, and live with the Missionary, possibly in the new residence built by the Department on the Woman's Missionary property just over a half mile from the Ahousaht village, and adjoining the present Ahousaht Indian Residential School. There is sufficient new lumber at the Ahousaht Residential School to provide a fine Day School in the village and the present classrooms (two) at the Residential School would provide desks and Blackboards, etc. These class rooms are too poor to be worth preserving. The main Ahousaht School Building is in such a poor state of repair that it will not last much longer than five or six years or so which must elapse before a new Residential School can be constructed. The present Ahousaht Residential School site is hopeless for such a school from every point of view.

An improved Day School of four or five rooms with a basement and other accommodation as suggested in the letter from the Secretary of the Indian Affairs Branch dated March 9, 1937 is in my opinion quite impracticable either at Alberni, Ahousaht, or elsewhere on the British Columbia coast.

The whole of the above is submitted with respect and in the hope that my recommendations will be of assistance to the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch in Ottawa.

31st January, 1938.
Gerald H. Barry

Memorandum:

The DEPUTY MINISTER,

Re: Rebuilding of Alberni Residential School

In response to the request contained in Mr. Pratt's memorandum of January 31st, I am submitting herewith, for your consideration, certain comments on a report dated January 21, 1938, relating to the rebuilding of the Alberni Residential School, submitted to the Department by Mr. D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for British Columbia.

Commissioner MacKay's report was submitted in response to instructions sent forward to him in departmental letter dated March 9, 1937.

The Alberni School, at the time of its destruction by fire (February 21, 1937) had a pupil enrolment of 115 and a per capita grant of $180.00 per annum was paid. Twenty-two of the pupils formerly enrolled at the residential school are now attending a day school at Alberni. This day school is conducted in one of the buildings that escaped destruction by fire. Seventeen are receiving instruction at the Ucluelet Day School and eight were placed in the residential school at Ahousaht. It is possible that, in addition to these, a number of the pupils enrolled at the beginning of the present academic year at Cocusaletza are pupils who were formerly enrolled at Alberni. It will thus be seen that provision has already been made...
been made for a large number of the pupils.

May I point out that five residential schools have been destroyed by fire in recent years:

Cross Lake, Manitoba - February 25, 1930,
Qu'Appelle, Sask. - November 12, 1932,
MacKay, Manitoba - March 13, 1932,
Grouard, Alberta - January 13, 1937,
Alberni B.C. - February 21, 1937.

The Lebret School has been rebuilt by the Government and the Grouard School by the Catholic Church authorities.

No provision has been made in the 1938-39 estimates for the building of residential schools. If it is decided that funds will be available in the 1939-40 estimates, my recommendation is that provision be made for the rebuilding of the Alberni Residential School. Consideration can be given in the meantime to the suitability of one or two Indian day schools or an improved Indian day school, to provide accommodation in northern Manitoba for pupils formerly enrolled at the MacKay school. I have already sent forward specific recommendations with respect to the rebuilding of the school at Cross Lake.

Commissioner MacKay's recommendation, that the Ahousaht Residential School, with an enrolment at this date of 64, should be abandoned and a residential school with accommodation for 150 pupils built at Alberni, is based on a survey made by Inspector Barry, in which the statement is made that there are 150 Indian pupils on the west coast of Vancouver Island for whom education cannot be provided in Indian day schools. The Ahousaht School, from the standpoint of sanitation and fire hazard, should be abandoned at the earliest possible date. Inspector MacKay's recommendation, therefore, appears to be sound, in view of all the circumstances.

A fully modern school of fireproof construction
with accommodation for 150 pupils would cost approximately $150,000. I concur in Commissioner MacKay's recommendation when he states that this school should be equipped with all the facilities necessary for vocational instruction.

Director.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

This Branch is in receipt of a letter from Reverend George Dorey, D.D., Associate Secretary, Board of Home Missions, United Church of Canada, requesting that the per capita rate at the Alberni Residential School be increased from $170.00 to $180.00 per annum. I understand that Dr. Dorey also spoke to Mr. Jackson regarding this matter.

There has been no radical change in the basic per capita rate at Indian residential schools since 1931. At that time certain basic rates were established at all residential schools and the rate at the Alberni School was set at $170.00 per capita, while the rate at the Christie School, which is also on Vancouver Island but is more inaccessible, was placed at $180.00. Dr. Dorey has pointed out to me that while, geographically, Christie appears more inaccessible, as a matter of fact it costs the United Church practically the same rate to ship their supplies to Alberni. Taking everything into consideration, I would appreciate receiving the Minister's approval to increase the per capita rate at Alberni from $170.00 to $180.00 per annum, effective January 1, 1945.

At this time it might be interesting for you to have a review of the per capita structure at Indian residential schools. An Order-in-Council passed on October 22, 1892, authorized the per capita grant method of financing what is now known as "Indian Residential Schools". At that time per capita grants
varied from $60.00 to $145.00 and the average grant for the succeeding twenty years was $84.00.

In response to a request from the Churches for larger grants for residential schools, the Department in 1911 prepared a schedule by geographic divisions and types of buildings and a formal agreement was made between the Department and the management of the residential schools. This agreement was in effect from April 1, 1911, to April 1, 1916. The average grant during that period was $115.00.

In 1919 a bonus or flat increase of $10.00 on the basic rate was allowed all residential schools and in 1921 an additional $10.00, or a total bonus of $20.00, made the average rate for all residential schools in Canada $135.00. In 1924 this bonus was incorporated in the regular scale of grants. In January, 1926, there was another upward revision and an effort was made to deal more fairly with the small school, also the school remote from markets and the school where farming and other facilities were inadequate. This particular revision was continued for five years, and by 1931 the average per capita grant paid to Indian residential schools in Canada amounted to $172.00. Owing to economic conditions existing following the year 1930, the per capita rate was reduced by 10%, or, in other words, the average per capita grant in Canada for 1932-33 was approximately $155.00. A further 5% deduction was made during the years 1933-34 and 1934-35, bringing the average to $147.00.

In 1935-36 and subsequent years the 15% deduction was restored, bringing the average per capita rate back to the same as existed in 1931-32, namely approximately $172.00. As a result of representations made by the Churches co-operating with the Department in the operation of residential schools, a special payment of $10.00 per capita, over and above the regular per capita rate, was made for the calendar year 1942 and a similar amount for 1943. For the year 1944 this special allowance was increased to $15.00.

Acting Director.
Ottawa, March 26, 1945.

Re: Alberni Indian Residential School

I beg to submit the following report on my investigation of conditions at the Alberni Indian Residential School.

You will recall that in July last you requested me to endeavour to look into conditions at this school as soon as I could make the necessary arrangements. It is regretted that it has not been possible to get this information before you earlier owing to heavy demands on my time and the absence of Inspector Coleman from the office. I arranged for Dr. Hugh Morrison, Provincial Inspector of Schools for the Courtenay-Alberni area, to accompany me but he was unable to do so owing to provincial matters that required his attention. Dr. Morrison did, however, arrange to inspect the school shortly following my visit and his report is enclosed herewith.

Mr. Ashbridge accompanied me during my visits to the school and was very helpful in getting out information regarding the pupils, arranging meetings and providing transportation.

The Indians of the Sheshaht and Opetchesht Bands, having learned of my presence in Alberni, requested a meeting to discuss school matters. This was arranged by Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge in cooperation with Mr. Caldwell, who kindly allowed the use of the Residential School assembly hall for the purpose. Reference will be made to this meeting later on in this report.

The greater part of three days was spent at the school during which matters relating to the operation and administration of the institution were thoroughly discussed with Mr. Caldwell and a careful inspection made of every room in the building.

Perhaps I should say at the outset that I went to Alberni feeling none too hopeful of finding conditions at the school satisfactory. Indeed, I fully expected to find little change from what I had known them to be during Mr. Scott's administration. It was most encouraging, therefore, to find evidence of considerable improvement in conditions generally. There is no doubt whatever that Mr. Caldwell has made a very commendable effort to bring the school in all its departments up to the standard expected by the Department. This is verified.
by Dr. Morrison who made his investigation in cooperation with but entirely independent of that carried out by me.

Organization of staff

Including the Principal there are twenty on the staff. The duties of each member and the salary received with board and lodging provided are as follows:

General Conditions

The school throughout was clean, indeed cleaner than I had found it on any previous visit since its opening some years ago. The boys and girls playrooms, where one could reasonably expect some untidiness and litter on the floors, were in good shape. The same condition was found in the dormitories, wash rooms, dining room, kitchen and related rooms and the class-rooms. In fact everywhere throughout the school there was evidence of properly organized effort to effectively deal with the matter of keeping the school in a clean and proper condition. It was always a most disheartening and discouraging experience for me on visits to this institution to invariably find most of the rooms...
used by the children in a dirty and untidy state and, despite earnest efforts on our part to have the principal improve matters, to see the same condition continue year after year.

The old day school building, now in use as a classroom, and the manual training shop were visited. Some painting was being done in the former to brighten the classroom which was much in need of this improvement. The Manual Training Instructor was in the process of organizing his work on the basis of Departmental requirements, and from the orderly appearance of the workshop and the program of practical instruction set out gave promise of making a worthwhile contribution in the division of the school. The facilities at present available for manual training are not satisfactory but should do until more adequate accommodation can be provided. When this happens, the existing building could be used exclusively for boat building.

There were 228 children in residence at the time of my visit. The per capita grant is allowed for 225. I doubt if the school could properly accommodate a larger number of pupils although the Principal suggested that it could. The dormitories did not appear crowded but I am satisfied that this condition would develop with a larger enrolment. Some ten children were sleeping on mattresses on the floor but this has been rectified as a result of the supply of new beds which were in order at the time. More new mattresses and bedding are needed.

The children were much better clothed than I found them on previous visits and much more responsive. They appeared happy and contented, due, no doubt, to better and more constant supervision and control, organized sports and keener interest on the part of the staff in their general well being.

Meals and Dining Room

The organization for cooking and serving meals was quite satisfactory. The behaviour of the children at the tables was commendable. There was evidence of much better supervision and control in this respect than I found on previous occasions. An abundance of food of excellent quality is supplied and increasing attention given to the matter of nutrition in the preparation of menus.

Health Services

Apart from a small number of children in the infirmary for various minor ailments, the health of the children, at the time of my visit, was good. Miss McKenzie, who holds the position of school nurse, is not properly qualified professionally nor otherwise for the post and should be replaced as soon as a suitable registered nurse can be secured. Dr. C. Pitts of Port Alberni is the doctor required, but it is doubtful if it is possible for him, in view of the heavy demands on his time owing to a shortage of doctors in the community, to give the service that an institution this size should have. This situation should be remedied immediately normal conditions return.
Water Supply

The water supply is secured from the municipal system of the city of Alberni. The quality is good and no doubt the supply is adequate for the normal needs of the school. Pressure has been reported quite low at times, too low to be of effective use in time of fire. It is understood that the city has under consideration the necessary improvements to meet this situation. The cost of water to the school has risen sharply since the first of the year as a result of the new rates established by the city. Should these rates be maintained it may be advisable to further explore the possibilities of securing a supply for both the Residential School and the local Reserve from Heath Creek or some other source.

It will be seen from this that in these two reserves there are 19 children of school age not attending any school.

It has been suggested from time to time that a day school should be provided to meet the needs of the children of the local reserves. It will be recalled that the attitude of
the Sheshaht Indians to the Residential School during a considerable part of Mr. Scott's administration was openly hostile. This situation has been somewhat composed since Mr. Caldwell took over, but is still far from satisfactory. The following solutions to meet the problem of the education of the children of the local reserves were put forward and carefully considered.

1. Have children attend the Residential School.
2. Have children attend the Residential School as day pupils and receive mid-day meal at the school.
3. Provide a day school on the Opetchesah Reserve or at a point approximately midway between the two reserves, that is, Sheshaht and Opetchesah.

With reference to solution (1), our experience would not justify a continuation of this arrangement. It has not been successful. Solution (2) would involve mixing up the Residential School and Day School pupils, which is not desirable inasmuch as it would most certainly cause discontent amongst the former owing to the wide freedom enjoyed by Day School pupils in comparison with the restrictive character of Residential School life. Dr. Morrison, Mr. Ashbridge and the writer are agreed that solution (3) appears the best under the circumstances.

The Indians suggested that the old Church building on the Opetchesah Reserve could be repaired to meet our needs until such time as a new school could be built. I examined the building referred to by the Indians and concluded that it was too far gone to warrant the extensive repairs that would be necessary to put it in shape. The building has been unused for many years and appears to be on the verge of collapse. However, I instructed Mr. Ashbridge to secure a report from a competent builder on the condition of the building. The Agent's report in this connection has now come to hand and is to the effect that the building is beyond repair and should be torn down. Mr. Ashbridge is being asked to ascertain if there is any suitable accommodation in the locality that could be secured on a temporary basis for use as a classroom.

Joint Meeting of the Sheshaht and Opetchesah Bands

As already stated the Indians of these Bands requested a meeting with the Commissioner to discuss school matters. The meeting was presided over by Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge and was orderly throughout. The particular matters which the Indians wished to discuss had to do with the following:

(a) Visiting hours at the school.
(b) Allowing children out of school to visit in Alberni and Port Alberni with their parents.
(c) Use of the wash rooms on the girls' side.

I found the regulations covering (a) and (b) quite reasonable and in line with those in force in other Residential Schools. The Indians were informed that these rules were designed to protect the health and general well-being of the pupils and, although some exception might be made because of unusual circumstances, any general relaxation of them could not be permitted. With respect to (c), it was disclosed that the use permitted of these wash rooms was altogether too limited and, in some cases, had resulted in the children having to go elsewhere to relieve themselves. I instructed the Principal to remove the existing restriction and permit the use of these facilities.
consistent with the needs of the children. It transpired that Mr. Caldwell was not familiar with the restrictions placed on the use of these wash rooms which had been imposed by the girls' matron, Mrs. Mackenzie, apparently without consulting him.

The question of establishing a day school to meet the needs of the local reserves was discussed at considerable length and resulted in the meeting unanimously declaring in favor of a day school being established on the Opetchesht Reserve or some suitable alternative site between the town of Alberni and the Residential School. There were twenty Indians eligible to vote present at the meeting, 16 from the Sheshaht Band and 4 from the Opetchesht Band.

Additional Accommodation Required

It will be observed from Dr. Morrison's report that he recommends the construction of a classroom wing with a minimum of seven classrooms to permit of full school days for Grades I to IV inclusive. If the school is to be operated on a full school day basis, and I think there is general agreement that it should, instead of the half day system as at present, no doubt seven classrooms would be necessary. In addition to classroom requirements, gymnasium and manual training accommodation should be provided. It might be possible to house all three in one building but this is a matter for the Department's architects to consider. I should be glad to further discuss this and other matters relating to this school during my forthcoming visit to the Department.

INSPECTOR'S REPORT

Alberni Residential Indian School.

Date of visit: Jan. 2, 3, 4, 5, 1945.

Alberni, B.C.

1. GENERAL CONDITIONS

Information received from competent sources in and around this school indicate that there is a distinct improvement in the school's operation since the change in principalship last summer. The principal holds the respect and loyalty of his staff, and the children appear happy - a prime requisite if their individual characters are to be properly developed.

The most important point which impressed itself upon the mind of the inspector was the necessity of additional financial investment in this plant in order to make the present excellent building and equipment more effective in regards to returns for investment already made. In other words more investment must be made, if only to protect what is already invested. Much of the following report will substantiate this statement.

(1) Present buildings.

In regards to sleeping, eating and general living conditions, the building provided is excellent. It is a three storied fire-proof attractive double winged building.

Provisions for class-work are totally inadequate. Apparently three or four years ago this wing, newly completed, containing the class-rooms, was burned. Nothing has been done since to replace it with the result
that the present temporarily improvised class-rooms are overcrowded, and the children above Grade I are receiving only half-time education. Forty of the forty-seven children in Grade I are crowded into a room 18' x 36', intended originally as a sewing room. There is no room for the other seven children, so they are, of necessity, classed as kindergarten and put under the charge of a senior pupil - which is, of course, entirely unsatisfactory to all parties concerned.

Grades 4 and 5 are taught in the auditorium (one-half time to each class), and Grades 2 and 3 are taught in an adjacent frame school structure. This is fairly satisfactory, although cloak-room space and a large stove should be provided. Grades 6, 7, 8 are held in a room which is about the same size as the Grade I room.

It is quite evident that the building of a wing containing the rooms necessary for educational purposes is imperatively and immediately necessary. In order to give an adequate and modern school program, permitting full school days for Grades I to IV inclusive, at least seven teachers, allotted as follows, will be required. (This estimate is based on the present school enrollment, which four teachers are endeavouring to handle).

| Grade   | Teachers |
|---------|----------|
| Grade I A | 1 teacher |
| Grade I B | 1 teacher |
| Grade II  | 1 teacher |
| Grade III | 1 teacher |
| Grade IV  | 1 teacher |
| Grades V, VI | 1 teacher |
| Grades VII, VIII | 1 teacher |

Seven class-rooms, then, as a minimum are required.
There is an immediate necessity of some teachers' desks for some of the present staff.

(2) Recreational facilities.

Playing space is rather limited, but plans are being made for extension. There is no gymnasium. This could very well be provided in the basement of the new class-room wing.

(3) Cultural facilities.

Library materials are meagre. The present principal and staff are to be complimented on what they have done since September to do away with the vacuum. In the new wing, space for a good library should be supplied. There is a lack of good supplementary reading materials.

No use is made of school radio programmes. Films are shown every Saturday, and a National Film Board operator visits the school once a month.

(4) Vocational education facilities.

The industrial educational shop is not very satisfactory for a school this size. As a result the programme appears to be inadequate.

There is a large barn, and some ground under cultivation. The grounds appear unsuitable for farm produce, as it is high and rocky. The loam on the floor of the river valley lies below the school. If some of this could be secured, the school could be brought close to self-sustenance, and vocational - agricultural programmes could be greatly enhanced.

(5) Health services.

The services of medical practitioners from Port Alberni are used. An infirmary with an unqualified
nurse in charge is maintained. Effective X-ray work is being done. However, the work could be more effective if a qualified nurse were in charge.

(6) Organization of Staff.

Including the principal there are twenty on the staff. In regard to nature of duties it may be divided into three parts, viz:

(a) Professional and secretarial

(b) Supervisory.

(c) Maintenance.

As already indicated in this report the professional part of the staff is understaffed. Instructional qualifications of members in the supervisory part are inadequate, if some real vocational training is to be attempted. It is realized, however, that this is a difficult problem to solve during present abnormal wartime conditions. There should be an assistant principal, who should either be the professional head of school instruction, or the chief supervisor, preferably the latter if properly qualified. The senior room teacher should be given full responsibility for operating the school. He or she should be thoroughly qualified and conversant with modern teaching techniques. In order to obtain such a person a better salary than is at present paid the senior room teacher will have to be offered.

(7) Financial Grants.

There should be a thorough investigation into the question of the adequacy of the present per-pupil grant to this school. It appears quite low. Why is
there a maximum number of 225 set for grant purposes? Yet the school is handling around 280 children.

(8) Education of children on adjoining reserve.

In regard to this question there appears to be only three solutions as follows:

(a) Have the children from the adjoining reserve attend the residential school as day pupils.

(b) Have the residential school children attend under supervision a specially built day school for children from the reserve.

(c) Keep the residential and day schools distinctly apart.

Solutions (a) and (b) would decidedly hamper the work of the residential school with its pupils. They are impractical. Solution (c) therefore, appears the best, especially as the day school should be built across the Somass River. On this side of the river, the Indian people are not itinerant, have steady employment in the mills in the Alberni District and as a consequence, maintain better homes than the itinerant Indians who live in the contiguous vicinity of the residential school.

2. VOCATIONAL TRAINING.

The school's vocational training programme is very weak. This is due to several reasons, which include lack of properly qualified instructors, inadequacy of buildings and equipment, and a certain inertia which seems to have prevailed in the school's administration.
until the appointment of the new principal. Because of the above reasons, the present programme is really more of a plant maintenance one than a training one.

At the present time not much can be done about securing highly qualified vocational instructors, who have the ability of planning and using the pupils' time to the best advantage in both a vocational and plant maintenance sense. The third reason, i.e., administrative inertia, is now a thing of the past. The present local administration has some very good and practical plans. They should get the fullest Departmental support, consistent with practicality. This will lead to the rectification of the second reason, i.e., lack of proper building and equipment. If possible the farm should be moved to the lower river flats; a general shop, as well as a woodworking shop, should be installed, so that various household maintenance arts, such as electrical repairing and sewing, may be taught. Boat building, and trades appertaining to the fishing industry should be taught. House construction and allied building trades should be taught. At the present time there appears to be little vocational training for the girls, except large scale cooking (quite unnatural for most), some sewing, mending and laundering. A graduate nurse could teach some home nursing.

Indeed in the residential schools there is a splendid opportunity for the giving of worthwhile vocational training, if the supervisory staff is qualified, and if there is adequate equipment. Under the circumstances the present supervisory staff is doing very well.
but more money must be spent on the supervisory staff and on equipment in order to secure better and more intelligent results.

3. FIRE PROTECTION.

This is a fully fire-proof building. All fire exits are lighted red on each floor. Fire extinguishers are placed outside the dormitories. There are fire gongs on each floor. There are no fire escapes on the exteriors.

4. DORMITORIES.

All dormitories are clean, tidy and well ventilated. There are all told ten; five boys and five girls. Each accommodate from twenty-two to twenty-five children. One set of lavatories and bathroom serves two dormitories. In the bathroom there are two baths, and four showers, and in the washroom, six toilets and twelve wash basins. This toilet and washing accommodation is of excellent quality, but only fairly adequate, especially as the children must arise and go to bed all at the same time.

5. MEALS AND DINING ROOM.

Dining rooms and kitchens are all very sanitary and clean. The dining room for the children is slightly crowded. In order to alleviate this situation, the principal's suggestion that the present staff dining room be given over to the senior pupils is a good one. This is based, of course, upon the proviso that accommodation elsewhere be found for the staff.

The cooking and serving of meals are well organized. The behaviour of the children at the tables is very
commendable, and correct table and eating habits are being successfully inculcated.

The food served is of excellent quality, and abundant. A study of daily menus for the past year indicated that the nutritional content is very high for an institution of this time. Sincere attempts are being made - and successfully in the summer - to meet Canada's nutritional requirements; In these days of high prices for greens it is pleasing to note that this institution does, I believe, better than the average Canadian family in meeting nutritional standards.

6. WATER SUPPLY.

Water supply is fully modern, and, I presume, is certified by public health authorities.

H. M. Morrison,
Inspector of Schools.

However, during the year, applications arising from necessitous circumstances are received from both Indian Agents and parents. I will quote from a few now before me:

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I wish to thank you for your two letters dated April 25th advising me that the Department had given consideration to the matters of increasing the maximum pupilage and also the acquiring of farm lands. In regard to the former, I may say that I had not thought our dormitory space was fully occupied as there seems so much room for the pupils. Perhaps that is because the dormitories are so high and airy. I presume there would be no objection raised to the few that we have over the present complement.

I received an urgent request recently from Mr. Ball, of Vancouver, in respect to three children who are apparently stranded at a Steveston cannery. Their mother must go to the Coqualeetza San. at once. I wrote him to send them over. There is only a short time now before the summer vacation and I presume the children in question will be kept here during the summer. I have written to all the Indian Agents re the absences of this term now on the register. If any number of these return next term I will not have room for any new pupils.

I may mention that, at Norway House, where the Medical Officer wished to enter some pupils in necessitous cases whose entry brought our pupilage over the maximum, special arrangements were made with the Medical Services branch to help to cover the expense of the care of these pupils without thereby increasing the grant-earning pupil quota. Would some such arrangement here be possible, where necessitous cases are admitted during the term, after the school complement is reached?

As to the matter of farm lands, I think there has been some misunderstanding. I had not thought to have the Department invest funds in farm land at this time. It is true that we do need more land. The present farm lands can never be made to pay. Considerable expense in survey has been made by the Department of Transport on the Somass Dairy Farm adjoining us, which has probably the best farm land on Vancouver Island. The survey is for the purpose of establishing a commercial airport there. Part of this airport would be on land owned by the large lumber mill operators, Blosdel, Stewart and Welsh. I am told that the Government engineers have recommended this site. It is unlikely that the landing strip...
would be sold separate from the rest of the farm therefore there is a probability that the Department of Transport would become possessed of the whole farm. In this event, I had thought, the school could lease the remaining farm from the Government, or in some such way acquire the use of it.

I may say that the owner of the Dairy Farm, Mr. Christie, has sold his equipment, that is, the ice cream making machinery, the pasteurizing plant and the dairy routes, to a local co-operative Company. He is a wealthy man and wishes to retire. He wanted the school to take over his 50 odd head of dairy cattle and the farm on half shares, but the proposition was too large for me to entertain; and, also, it is not my wish to operate any farm for commercial purposes in connection with the school. However, I did undertake to seed about twenty acres of the land for Mr. Christie for a half share of the crop. This is now being done without any additional expense to the school in labour, seed, or equipment. The results this fall should at least show no loss on our farm operations (as compared with a 50% loss last year) and may, in addition to providing the school with a full supply of farm produce, which has not been done hitherto, show a profit on operational costs.

The only other alternative to the undertaking of larger farming operation of the nature mentioned above was to stop all farming operations in connection with the school in order to wipe out the operating deficit. This would mean that we could not even grow root crops, for the land must have barn fertilizer, which necessitates the keeping of cattle.

I hope that this will explain my letter to Mr. Allan from whom I thought I might be able to obtain information as to what the intentions of the Department of Transport was in regard to the Somass Farm. This farm could be such an asset to the school that I hope the Department will not lose sight of the possibility of acquiring it for the school in some way in the future.

Yours very truly,

Principal.

I may add that farm operation is not valueless from a vocational training point of view. A number of our pupils come from the Fraser Valley and the Hazelton district, where the Indian people engage in farming.

SHE PAINTS HER TRIBE'S LEGENDS

Indian Girl Acclaimed As Artist of Exceptional Talent

Judith Physick Morgan, a pretty 17-year-old Indian girl who up to seven months ago never held a paint brush in her hands, today is being acclaimed by B.C. professional artists as a painter of exceptional talent.

The Indian girl was the first member here to win the $150 scholarship offered by the B.C. Indian Arts and Crafts Society at an exhibition held in the West Coast capital recently. The exhibition was open to all Indian school children in British Columbia.

Five feet tall, with an attractive bronzed complexion, Judith is quiet and reserved. She has poise and a perfectly natural ease with strangers, but is reluctant to talk about herself.

She belongs to the proud Tsimshian tribe who inhabit the Skeena river on the B.C. mainland, about sixteen miles south of Prince Rupert. She has three sisters and eight brothers. Two of her brothers, Kelly and Raymond, fought in the war, the latter having been killed. Her brother Raymond, she says, was a skilled wood carver until he was seriously injured in the arm when his tank blew up.

Judith was brought up in accordance with the ancient traditions of her people, a famous fighting tribe. She was initiated into the secret tribal societies and was taught native tribal ritual and dances at a very early age.

But her parents found the education facilities were inadequate on the Skeena Indian reserve and sent her to Albert four years ago to continue her studies. She has just completed her ninth year in school.

When an art class was formed at the school last December under George Sinclair, a well known Victoria painter, Judith from the outset showed exceptional talent. Within six months she had outstripped her classmates, and was producing paintings fit for an art gallery. Even before her work came into public notice, people were offering her up to $100 for her works. She has refused the offers on the advice of her instructors.

Judith says she got a surprise when informed she had won the scholarship. She never hoped to be able to hold her own against scores of competitors from all parts of the province. Now greatly encouraged, she wants to continue with her work and to paint Indian scenes and the legends of her people.

Since Judith has come into public notice, she has met some of the best professional painters in British Columbia. Her paintings, along with others are on exhibition in Vancouver.

Her teacher, George Sinclair, considered hard to please, described his pupil as "a girl exceptionally talented and who has shown great promise."

He admits, however, at first he was afraid that his pupil's success might go to her head.

"But I had no reason to be afraid," he says, "she is a level-headed girl and will go far with her work."

Arthur Pickering, one of the best known ethnologists in the province, and who has one of the largest private Indian collections in Canada, said she was a discovery.

"West Coast Indians are artistically gifted," he commented. "She undoubtedly the forerunner of many others who are to follow."

A soft spoken girl with an attractive browned complexion is being recognized today by prominent artists and art critics as a first-class artist. She is 17-year-old Judith Phyllis Morgan, a native girl, who has spent eight months and had never held a paint brush in her hands.

The Indian girl, who attends school in Prince Rupert, was the first member of her race to win the $150 scholarship offered by the British Columbia Welfare Society at an exhibition held here last week. The prize was open to all Indian school children in British Columbia.

She belongs to the proud Tsimshian tribe of the Skeena River, 16 miles south of Prince Rupert. She has three sisters and eight brothers. Two of her brothers served in the army. One died in the war, the latter was seriously wounded in Sicily.

MEMORANDUM

To: Indian Commissioner
from: School Inspector

As requested by you I investigated the operation of the half-day system at the Alberni residential School on the occasion of my visit during the latter part of the week of April 16th to 19th.

As you are aware, shortly after the new school was erected at Alberni the class-room block burned down which gave rise to a number of problems, one of which was the accommodation of pupils in class-rooms. For some time now the Principal has accommodated these pupils by erecting temporary partitions in the auditorium and by using some small rooms which were designed for other purposes. Even with this arrangement it was impossible to provide for the pupils on a full time basis. However, the new class-room block is now nearly completed and there is no doubt that it will be in operation for the new term beginning in September.

While the beginners are not in the class-room they are permitted to play either in the playrooms or out on the grounds, weather permitting. This play period is supervised by one of the members of the staff and it appears to be the best possible arrangement for these pupils during that time.

In connection with the new class-room block, I may say at this time that it is unfortunate that the building contains only four class-rooms and I would suggest that one of the rooms in the basement be fitted out and equipped for use as a class-room. This will make it possible for the Principal to accommodate the majority of his 230 pupils on a full time basis, although the classes even then would be quite large. I have already discussed this suggestion with the Principal and he agrees that this could be suitably arranged.

You may be interested in the attached picture which I took on the occasion of my visit. This shows the present stage of completion of the new class-room block.

Dear Dr. Dorey,

I am enclosing a letter I have received from the Manager of the Bank of Montreal which carries our account. Mr. Wylie spoke to me about the increasing overdraft. He is not, of course, worried about the account, but only about the irregularity of permitting a $7000.00 plus overdraft where the authorization is only for $4000.00. You will remember that this matter came up before when I first took over. The prospects then, however, were that the overdraft could be reduced. This was done, down to the approximate amount of $3000.00 at one time. The situation now has changed, however, and I see no prospect of anything but ever increasing expenditure if the present price and wage trend continues.

The overdraft for January is $6221.00, with a total adverse Cash Book balance of $7425.00. January accounts and salaries are still to be paid (on February 15th, when the remittance advance of $4000.00 is received). This will approximate $6000.00. The arrears of revenue due to the school amount to $1500.00, leaving an overall deficit of some $11,000.00, bringing us back to where we were three and one-half years ago.

First, there is the absolute necessity of increased Government revenue. Procrastination should no longer be tolerated. Also, the Government should either assume definite responsibility for the deficit to date, either by payment of the deficit or satisfying the carrying banks that it is a Government responsibility. In the meantime it is necessary that the Principal should have authorization to incur an overdraft to the amount of his expenditure under the present and prospective operating cost..... to what amount I cannot estimate, but I would say the authorization should be for $10,000.00. I still suggest that the expenditure over revenue should be carried as a deficit and Bank overdraft. Subsidization by the Church in the reduction of deficit or the augmentation of current revenue would simply encourage the Government to continue its policy of evading its Indian education responsibilities.

Further, may I suggest that the deferring of proper action on the part of the Government and the Church in dealing promptly and decisively with the matter of school finance tends to debase the functional value of the school personnel. I have already lost one of the best Boys' Supervisors in the educational system, a man who has made this work a vocation, because of lack of opportunity and security afforded in employment by the school. There is no inducement given to the teachers to continue employment in a residential school. They are sacrificing salary, experience scale increases and superannuation by teaching in a residential school. It might be noted here that teachers in all the Alberni Public Schools have this week been awarded an
I have been fortunate in obtaining a very good slate of teachers this term, but I cannot hope to engage them for another year. We must be able to offer teachers inducements at least the equal of the Public Schools, otherwise we must put up with the left-overs (if there are any) to the detriment of our standard of teaching.

Also there is the functional value of the Principal to consider. No Principal could be expected to continue to give efficient attention to all the many duties that make for the efficient operation of an institution such as Alberni School, and carry, at the same time, the constant burden of ever increasing debt, about which one can do nothing and of which there is no end in sight.

Surely the Churches ought to be able to impress the urgency of the emergency on the Government, so that immediate action can be taken. It is absolutely useless for the Government or the Church to counsel retrenchment or economy. This has been practiced to the limit beyond which we cannot go. It is false economy, and functional suicide, to attempt further economy in food. The late Principal of the Alert Bay School foolishly tried this experiment at the beginning of this term, resulting in his resignation, and a loss in prestige of that school with the Indian people from which it will take them a long time to recover. Salaries must be held down, at the cost of operating with a mediocre staff. The present supply situation in clothing, boots and shoes, soaps, and in practically every necessary line, is such that we cannot bargain or question either price or quality.

I will note some comparative costs as of January 1947 and January 1948:

Dry Goods cannot be compared, as we are now replenishing supplies not obtainable a year ago. However, the Dry Goods account for January of this year is $1104.56, and the Boots and Shoes account $575.16. It can also be noted that stocker coal, which cost us $12.20 per ton a year ago ($9.45 per ton two years ago) is now $19.50 per ton. May I say also that in the matter of food and fuel our consumption quantity has not been increased.

Will you please attend to the matter of the Bank letter as soon as possible? Further than that, I would at least like to be assured that the condition of the finances of this school, and the deficit, is approved by the United Church as far as the efforts of the Principal is concerned... or, of course, should a contrary viewpoint be taken, I would like to be advised.
