Principal.
The first weeks of school saw forty little folks pass into the Grade one room. Some felt very shy and some had a very strange feeling in their throats. Soon however everyone was so busy getting to know his new friends there was no time for feeling lonely.

We were delighted, a few days after school began, to have a book of our own to color, talk about and best of all to read. We are looking forward too, to the other books we will have this year.

During our Social Studies period we have spent much time learning about home life. To help in this study we have planned and made a house with the help of a few seniors. We have made some furniture and some we hope to have people in it.

Mother Goose is an old friend now for we have been learning all about her and watching her big family appear along the black board and on the windows.

Christmas shopping and the concert has come and gone. Now we are looking forward to Xmas day and all the happy things that go with it.

Nutrition teacher— "Did you have anything at recess today, Levi—candy, oranges or apples?" Levi—(thinking desperately)"Two Waters".

JUNIOR NEWS

The members of the Junior room wish to report a very successful term.

At the beginning there were forty-two pupils. Since then some of our members have departed to the new class room, one to the Sanatorium at Nanaimo; so at present we number only thirty-five. The boys seem to be in the majority—twenty to fifteen.

We believe that all pupils feel that they have made good progress and have found their work interesting.

Our Art periods have been greatly enjoyed and some very good work has been turned out.

Among the project work attempted were posters on cleanliness and posters on Indians and Eskimos. In the future we plan to make posters on Tuberculosis.

The results of our October tests were generally good.

Several have appreciated visits from their parents and friends from home.

We have all been very grateful for the lovely fall. It has helped to shorten the term a lot.

The first snow came on November 13th and brought with it the usual snowball.

We are all looking forward to Christmas and we extend to all a Very Merry Christmas and a Happy and prosperous New Year.

PRACTICAL ARTS NEWS

Our room opened September 28th with Miss Zahner as teacher.

A lot of our work is hand work and so far in our leather work periods we have completed several useful articles including some suitcases, change purses and wallets.

Every Thursday the girls spend the day in the sewing room.

We are made up of Grades one, two, three, four and five. And we go to school all day.

Said the man smiling to the waitress, "Look here girl, my pipe feet are cold." Said the girl to the man "That's up to you, if your feet are cold put on your shoe."
SENIOR NEWS

The Senior class this term is made up of grades Six, Seven and Eight.

Since the beginning of the term everyone has been working hard and the results of the October tests showed the results of this work. In grade six Barry Keith came first with Murray Livingston second and Bert Underwood third. There are twenty-three pupils in grade six this term too.

In grade seven Doris Underwood came first with Violet Campbell second and Stanley Charles third. Twenty-eight pupils make up grade seven.

In grade eight David Jacobsen and Percy Monk came first and second with Roma Ridley coming third. There are eight pupils in grade eight.

The Christmas concert has come and gone again and everyone had a busy time practising for their part.

Grade six and seven are taking practical art this year and both grades have been working on a Christmas decoration. This parade is held every Friday and is looked forward to by all.

Holidays have started and now everyone can relax for two weeks and enjoy Xmas with all its fun and frolic.

The Seniors extend to all a Very Merry Xmas and a Happy New Year.

HIGH SCHOOL NEWS

There are seven students attending high school in Alberni from here. Two are in grade nine, three in grade ten and two in grade eleven. They are kept quite busy and home work seems to be the byword. They are holding their own too, and looking forward to the day when they will graduate.

SOCIAL LIFE

The Hallowe'en parties have come and gone and everyone claims that they had a good time. The Assembly hall was gaily decorated in black and orange by Miss Kennedy's group of C.B.I.T. girls, a fine job was done.

Friday night has been set aside for dances for forms one and two with Mr. Peake as host, they have themselves a good time come Friday night.

Saturday is show day and several interesting films have been shown. Most of the films have been educational and everyone is looking forward to seeing some longer features.

We have had several visitors to this school including a group of grade three pupils from the Alberni school. They were very interested in our school and its pupils and regretted that their visit was so short.

With Xmas almost here many visitors are expected, however we will write about these next time.

SPORTS

Basketball has been the main sport so far this term. Because of the wet field and constant rain the boys have not been able to play as much basketball as they would have liked. They did play the local High school team on a very slippery field and lost the game. They are looking forward to return the match when the field is drier.

We have a junior boys basketball team who call themselves the Western Eagles. They have been playing in the junior league district and are at present in second place. Play-offs start in January and the boys hope to make a good showing. On a recent trip to Duncan the boys played the Indian boys team there and lost by two points the final score being 36-34. By the way their colors are blue and gold.

The girls have been practicing basketball too but have played no outside games yet.

The boys have been practicing boxing also in preparation for a tournament.

C.G.I.T.

Our groups this term are organized much like they were last term. There are five groups and regular meetings are held Wednesday nights. Craft work occupies most of the evening.
This year there are approximately twenty-five boys in the group. Dan has taken over Bob Wilson's position as chief ranger. Meetings are held every Tuesday night and handy crafts are the major projects.

A junior group has been organized called the Trail Rangers and they meet Tuesday nights.

CHRISTMAS CONCERT

The concert this year was held on Friday December 17th in the Auditorium at 7:30. The programme lasted until 9:30 and everyone enjoyed it. A good many of the parents and friends were there and the hall was full.

WHAT IS WRONG WITH THESE PICTURES?

by Bruce Johnson; Grade V

In our October Tests, Amelia Drake, Peggy August and Simon Williams tied for highest standing in Grade five. Howard Cecil, William Cecil and Geddes Wilson were the outstanding pupils in the Grade four class.

During the Fall several of the pupils had visitors.

Because of the heavy snows and lately the heavy snow the boys have not been able to practice football and basketball, but they are hoping to do so in the new year.

From the Principal

This is being written on Xmas Eve. Preparations are all made for a BIG DAY tomorrow. Santa will fill the stockings for the little folks during the night; the staff will serve the Christmas dinner at noon; Santa Claus will come in person at 3 o'clock in the afternoon. Then the big Christmas cake will be cut for supper. All together, pupils and staff look forward to our usual Merry Xmas (to distribute the mountain of presents that he has been sending in for the past few weeks).

This Christmas a number of pupils have been permitted to go home at the request of their parents. This is an experiment that will be continued each Christmas if the children are returned to school promptly and in good condition. Unfortunately the homes of most of the pupils are too far away to permit them to go home. The parents or such can be assured that their children will have a good Christmas.

I am glad to report a successful term thus far. Our teaching staff has been increased by two making possible the more individual care especially of backward pupils. Our school is filled to capacity, of course, and the health of the children has been excellent. We had a visit from Dr. Fett, chief of the Nutrition Division of the Department of National Health and Welfare, Ottawa, and his Associates, and we feel complimented in receiving the following recent report from him: "You may be interested to know that the dietary records so far show your school children to be better fed than most similar groups in Canada, whether Indians or not, and that their medical records are also good."
I am sure the parents will be glad to know this.

Space will not permit me to write at any great length, but I would like to mention the "Fashion Show" that was put on in the great Store of Woodard's in Port Alberni. Two of our High School girls, Judith Morgan and June Wilson, took part in this show, modelling clothes from "Slacks" to evening dresses. The girls selected the clothes they modelled themselves. I wish you could all have seen them. They received many compliments and have had such a thrill in wearing what has been put on.

I may also say that the Basketball game with the Duncan Indian boy's team, mentioned elsewhere in the letter, is the first game of organized basketball to be played among Indian teams on Vancouver Island. This is good stuff and we have more of it.

In conclusion, my wishes to you and your family very Happy and joyous Christmas out to all the parents everywhere. May we all remember that Christmas is celebrated because: "Unto you is born this day in the City of David a Saviour which is Christ the Lord."

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT the Alberni Residential School is presently being paid an annual per capita grant for each Indian pupil receiving tuition, food, clothing and other personal services;

THAT the management of this and other schools are having great difficulty in securing the services of properly qualified teachers;

THAT teachers in Indian day schools and in provincial schools enjoy the benefits of definite salary schedules and pension plans.

THAT the denominations operating Indian residential schools cannot provide similar benefits;

THAT the calibre of teachers in such residential schools has therefore been deteriorating greatly;

THAT Indian parents have been complaining about the poor type of education received in such residential schools;

THAT such residential schools will be required for many years yet to provide educational facilities for certain types of Indian pupils.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that an experiment be conducted at the Alberni Residential School to determine whether it is feasible for residential school teachers to be paid at the same rates as day school teachers and to enjoy the other benefits enjoyed by these day school teachers.

THAT effective 1 September, 1949, the classroom teachers at the Alberni Residential School be classified and paid for the period of one year as if they were teachers of an Indian Day School.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Dear Mr. Davey,

I have been able to satisfy my teachers in the matter of salary, to carry them over the Christmas vacation, but I have advanced them altogether $2400.00, which is mortgaging my bank credit near the maximum. In a letter from Dr. Dorey recently received he states:

Would it not be possible for the "contract" to institute the payment of the teaching salaries at once, leaving the legal technicalities and the financial adjustment until later? This is the time of the year of our greatest operational expense, with cost of fuel and utilities at their yearly peak.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

ALBERNI INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Please find attached a submission to Council concerning the payment of the teachers at the Alberni Residential School. This matter has already been discussed with Mr. Jackson and the submission indicates an experiment in the payment of teachers at Indian residential schools.

As you are aware, this is being done at three schools: the Mohawk Institute, the Shubenacadie Residential School and now, as indicated, the Alberni Residential School.

As both the Mohawk Institute and the Shubenacadie Residential School are government institutions, it was not necessary to make a submission to Council. The Alberni Residential School is, however, operated by the United Church of Canada, which denomination has concurred in the payment of these teachers.

The present per capita rate at this residential school is $274.00 per pupil per year. An increase to $288.00 was authorized by the Minister but this has never been paid, due to the fact that this matter had been discussed with Mr. Jackson and it was decided to delay the increase until a decision had been made in connection with the teachers' salaries.

When authority is obtained by Order-in-Council for the payment of these teachers, it is our intention to obtain details of the qualifications and salaries of these teachers, when a further submission will be made concerning such changes, if any, in the per capita rate.

Mr. Maize, our Senior Teacher, has given me your letter to him of the 10th Inst., and your explanation that you are not aware of the type of publication that is on the material list issued by the Department clears up the question that has been in my mind as to why such publications were recommended for our pupils.

As you see, the publications are of a very high order, on excellent paper and of a fine excellence of presentation, but it is purely propaganda and it's seeming reasonableness makes it most undesirable material, in my mind, for the inculcation of the student mind, particularly the Indian, gaining first impressions of political and economic ways of life.

Reading the material, it is hardly to be wondered that our High School and University youth, striving towards an ideal, and conscious that our own democratic way falls far short of the ideal, finds it attractive, particularly under the impression that it is disseminated with the approval of our Government. Such material is only safe reading for the advanced student of political economy, fully acquainted with counterbalancing material.

Would it be possible for our Government to combat this propaganda of the U.S.S.R. by compiling equally attractive publications explaining and eulogizing the democratic way of life? The effectiveness of such would be out of all proportion to the expense, and would be much more productive of educative result than banning the undesirable publications.

However, as far as our own students are concerned, I think it would be desirable to remove these publications from the list of study material.

I will await your comment.

Sincerely yours,

Re: Teachers Salary Olan.

Dear Col. Neary,

In reply to your letter of June 24th enquiring as to the success of the experiment in the paying of Residential School teachers' salaries by the Department, I do not know how far the plan had been premeditated in other schools in which the experiment has been conducted, but in our own case we will be better able to make a report at the end of the coming term, as, not being fully assured last September nor indeed until the Order in Council was passed establishing the policy in December, that the increased salary scale would actually become operative, we were not in a position to be as selective in our teaching appointments as we now are for the coming term.

While all our teachers were fully qualified, a condition which I have been able to maintain without exception during my principalship of Alberni, their teaching capabilities, for the most part, left much to be desired. Our senior teacher, a veteran who has been here for the past three years, lacked the experience and capability to take charge of a grade 8 class, nearly all of which, under our present developed system, will graduate to the 9th grade in the Public High School. Further, it was expected that this teacher would function as class room principal, for which his inexperience unfitted him, leaving the general class-room supervision to myself, and I had neither the time nor the academic teaching training to handle this work as efficiently as required. This teacher is now taking summer school and hopes to gain further experience in the Public Schools.

Then we filled our teaching staff with three elderly teachers who were verging on, or past, the age limit of 65. One had been teaching for some years at the File Hills Indian School and came well recommended but did not measure up, by any means, to our required standard. Another had passed the period of possibly former efficiency. The third was possibly the best teacher on the staff and is being retained next term.

Of the three male teachers (one being the senior teacher already referred to) one was efficient and is being retained, and the other inefficient. We had further employed a teacher who, while unqualified, had operated a kindergarten in the Old Country, and who was given, in addition to her main function of singing and music instructor (she was nominally on the supervisory staff) a pre-primary class of some 20 pupils. She did a splendid job with these pupils and I plan to keep her on under the same circumstances, although she cannot qualify for a civil service appointment.
Only two of our teachers from last term, therefore, have been considered sufficiently efficient to retain. Perhaps I should say three, as a Primary teacher, Miss Bone, who had been here three years and has been progressively efficient, resigned to leave the field of instruction, largely because, being of an intensely evangelical turn of mind, was perfectly satisfied with the low salary she was formerly receiving, but considered there was not sufficient sacrifice entailed in working for the larger salary. There is nothing much one can do in a case like that. Mr. Davey would have liked to appoint her to a day school but the same circumstances apply there.

I go into this detail to indicate, as I said, that the experiment has not had a fair trial. Some teachers have already been engaged for next term. Mr. Davey has furnished me with their qualifications and indications are that we will have a more efficient teaching staff under the new, and now established conditions.

However, I can report that we have had a very successful academic year. It is less than two years since I have been able to establish the full day class-room instruction, doing away entirely with the half-day instruction in all grades as formerly. This has had a most marked effect in the work of the pupils, even more than might be expected. The progress is apparent in all grades, but particularly in the Primary and Intermediate, and it is already affecting the age at which pupils are prepared to enter the Grade 9 in the Public High School. In another year or two, it is apparent that the age for Grade 9 advance will be 14 to 15, instead of 16 to 17 as formerly. I am confident that, with efficient teaching such as we can now expect, this average age of Grade 9 advance will be further reduced.

If I may take up your time, I would like to further discuss this High School question with you. This term we had 16 pupils in the High School, 8 in Grade 9, 4 in 10, 2 in 11 and 2 in 12. Seven pupils were taking the University Entrance Course and nine the Commercial or General Course. Two pupils graduated from Grade 12, one is accepted for nursing training at the Vancouver General Hospital and one is attending Normal in Victoria, with a view to the teaching of Art (with Morgan). One pupil failed in Grade 11 and two in Grade 9. It is recommended that one of the Grade 9 failures take the Grade 10 general Course next term. The other two failures are not returning. All others passed their grades, with one Grade 12 pupil being recommended in all subjects. Our pupils are handicapped in English and Mathematics particularly... although little below the average High School pupil. This is accounted for by the lack of elementary grade grounding due to the half-day classroom system formerly employed.

I might add, in passing, that we have had many compliments from the High School teachers on the general conduct and good manners of our Indian pupils. I am told they are models for others in the High School. Actually, contrary to my own former apprehensions, we have had not the slightest behavioral trouble with our High School pupils in the school, probably due to the fact that, while being permitted to engage in all High School activities and social functions, within the Residential school they are subjected to the same routine exactly as other pupils. Their social contacts have been successful beyond my expectations. Friends have been made, and visitation by invitation at friends' homes and by friends here at the school has been permitted and encouraged. There has not been a vestige of discrimination and the innate fear of discrimination has practically been eliminated from the psychology of our Indian pupils. One of our girls was President of the Hi-Y group in
Grade 12 and was the representative at the annual convention of the Groups in Vancouver. This process of assimilation has been greatly furthered in our school generally by participation in league sports, softball, football, etc., with all the Sunday Schools of the city, and with teams from industrial plants and other organizations. Although our teams were, on the average, better than opponents, often of older ages, the good spirit displayed, and the real friendships formed, have been most encouraging. It has been my policy to eliminate the word "Indian" as a discriminatory term in the school, as it tends to establish a sense of inferiority that has a retarding influence on general progress, and in this I think we have been quite successful.

I may say here also, that I have just received a request to attend the opening of the Exhibition of Indian Arts and Crafts in Victoria on Monday next, taking two of our pupils, who have entered art exhibits, with me. I understand that Dolly Morgan, sister of the now famous Judith Morgan, has been awarded this year's scholarship, with some other award to the other top pupil. Our Art class this year has been extra-curricular and has been supervised by Judith Morgan in evening sessions.

To continue with the High School problem. First, I may say, that the parents, almost without exception, are desirous, with the pupils, of High School continuance. We are fortunate, at Alberni, in having a High School where our pupils are welcomed and where a somewhat intensive interest is taken in them. It was apparent, at the High School convocation a few weeks ago, where over 40 pupils graduated, that the two graduating pupils from this school were easily the most popular, judged by the applause of the audience.

As it appears at the present writing, 12 of our pupils will be continuing at High School in grades 10, 11, and 12 next term. In addition there will be 14 pupils entering grade 9..... the grade 8 graduates of this term. I have had two further applications for High School pupils who have passed grade 8 in day schools. This will make a total High School pupilage of 28 attending the Public High School next term. If the present trend continues (and I see no reason why it should not only continue but be accelerated) there is indication that, conservatively, there will be an advancement to High School of some 15 pupils per year...... not including any entrants from day schools who may be sent here for High School entrance. An average of 15 yearly (which, as I say, is a conservative estimate) covering the four years of High School, will give us a High School resident pupilage of 60 at this school, and this within the next three years.

The actual situation now is that we have a full pupilage of 24. Not more than 12 to 15 pupils will be discharged, or may not return, for the beginning of next term in September. Applications for admission, as indicated by requests from the various Indian Superintendents, are in the neighbourhood of 150. High School pupils for next term will take up dormitory space for 26...... 2 are attending the High School from their local homes. That is the problem both present and future. If a policy of admissions is left with me as Principal, I am at least able to know what accommodations are available for the few I can take at the expense of the prospective primary applicants or at the expense of the High School continuants. Personally, I feel that we are doing the greatest good in providing for the High School pupils, not only in continuing their education looking towards their establishment in useful and independent occupations, but also, and perhaps the most important, in having these pupils under our supervision and guidance during the middle teen age when they most need care. My experience generally has been that these pupils develop a remarkable solidarity of character in their latter teens under sympathetic guidance.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6431, File 877-1, part 4)
Thus, our immediate problem is that of space and policy. With the remarkable increased interest, on the part of both parents and pupils, in matters of education, I feel that we will be missing a great opportunity if we were either to curtail or neglect to expand the educational facilities. It is a problem that must rest on the Government.

I am fully in accord with the policy of placing Indian pupils in public, or (as far as the elementary grades are concerned) in the Indian Day schools. I have eliminated every pupil in this school that can be so accommodated and will continue to do so as opportunity affords, but the necessity of the residential school, both as a means of education for the underprivileged and as an opportunity for higher education continually increases.

I regret the length of this letter but the opportunity for discussion occasioned by your request for information provided an unusual opportunity.

In conclusion, I would give as my opinion, after a number of years of competition in teacher engagement not only with the Public schools but, of late years, with our own Department in the matter of salaries, of necessity having to put up with teachers who were the rejects from the Public schools, or teachers from other Provinces desiring to insinuate themselves into the B.C. Public School system by means of summer school credits while engaged in Indian work, that our new system can produce nothing but unqualified success.

I need scarcely add that the relief of the financial burden which this new system has occasioned and which has permitted me to see financial daylight for the first time in my experience at Alberni, is appreciated more than I can say.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal.

I must add that I appreciate greatly the whole hearted support, encouragement and understanding that I have continually received from Commissioner Arnell, Inspector Davey and the other officials of the Department.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading “Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter”.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the “Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter” by the “Total number of days in quarter”.

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the “Average attendance of pupils during quarter” by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.
